27.11: "My brother Esau is a hairy man," Jacob reminded her. "And I am not.
27.12: If my father touches me and realizes I am trying to trick him, he will put a curse on me instead of giving me a blessing."
27.13: Rebekah insisted, "Let his curse fall on me! Just do what I say and bring me the meat."
27.14: So Jacob brought the meat to his mother, and she cooked the tasty food that his father liked.
27.15: Then she took Esau's best clothes and put them on Jacob.
27.16: She also covered the smooth part of his hands and neck with goatskins
27.17: and gave him some bread and the tasty food she had cooked.
27.18: Jacob went to his father and said, "Father, here I am." "Which one of my sons are you?" his father asked.
27.19: Jacob replied, "I am Esau, your first-born, and I have done what you told me. Please sit up and eat the meat I have brought. Then you can give me your blessing."
27.20: Isaac asked, "My son, how did you find an animal so quickly?" "The LORD your God was kind to me," Jacob answered.
27.21: "My son," Isaac said, "come closer, where I can touch you and find out if you really are Esau."
27.22: Jacob went closer. His father touched him and said, "You sound like Jacob, but your hands feel hairy like Esau's."
27.23: And so Isaac blessed Jacob, thinking he was Esau.
27.24: Isaac asked, "Are you really my son Esau?" "Yes, I am," Jacob answered.
27.25: So Isaac told him, "Serve me the wild meat, and I can give you my blessing." Jacob gave him some meat, and he ate it. He also gave him some wine, and he drank it.
27.26: Then Isaac said, "Son, come over here and kiss me."
27.27: While Jacob was kissing him, Isaac caught the smell of his clothes and said: "The smell of my son is like a field the LORD has blessed.
27.28: God will bless you, my son, with dew from heaven and with fertile fields, rich with grain and grapes.
27.29: Nations will be your servants and bow down to you. You will rule over your brothers, and they will kneel at your feet. Anyone who curses you will be cursed; anyone who blesses you will be blessed."
27.30: Right after Isaac had given Jacob his blessing and Jacob had gone, Esau came back from hunting.
27.31: He cooked the tasty food, brought it to his father, and said, "Father, please sit up and eat the meat I have brought you, so you can give me your blessing."
27.32: "Who are you?" Isaac asked. "I am Esau, your first-born son."
27.33: Isaac started trembling and said, "Then who brought me some wild meat right before you came in? I ate it and gave him a blessing that cannot be taken back."
27.34: Esau cried loudly and begged, "Father, give me a blessing too!"
27.35: Isaac answered, "Your brother tricked me and stole your blessing."
27.36: Esau replied, "My brother deserves the name Jacob, because he has already cheated me twice. The first time he cheated me out of my rights as the first-born son, and now he has cheated me out of my blessing." Then Esau asked his father, "Don't you still have any blessing left for me?"
27.37: "My son," Isaac answered, "I have made Jacob the ruler over you and your brothers, and all of you will be his servants. I have also promised him all the grain and grapes that he needs. There's nothing left that I can do for you."
27.38: "Father," Esau asked, "don't you have more than one blessing? You can surely give me a blessing too!" Then Esau started crying again.
27.39: So his father said: "Your home will be far from that fertile land, where dew comes down from the heavens.
27.40: You will live by the power of your sword and be your brother's slave. But when you decide to be free, you will break loose."
27.41: Esau hated his brother Jacob because he had stolen the blessing that was supposed to be his. So he said to himself, "Just as soon as my father dies, I'll kill Jacob."
27.42: When Rebekah found out what Esau planned to do, she sent for Jacob and told him, "Son, your brother Esau is just waiting for the time when he can kill you.
27.43: Now listen carefully and do what I say. Go to the home of my brother Laban in Haran
27.44: and stay with him for a while. When Esau stops being angry
27.45: and forgets what you have done to him, I'll send for you to come home. Why should I lose both of my sons on the same day?"
27.46: Rebekah later told Isaac, "Those Hittite wives of Esau are making my life miserable! If Jacob marries a Hittite woman, I'd be better off dead."

28.1: Isaac called in Jacob, then gave him a blessing, and said: Don't marry any of those Canaanite women.
28.2: Go at once to your mother's father Bethuel in northern Syria and choose a wife from one of the daughters of Laban, your mother's brother.
28.3: I pray that God All-Powerful will bless you with many descendants and let you become a great nation.
28.4: May he bless you with the land he gave Abraham, so that you will take over this land where we now live as foreigners.
28.5: Isaac then sent Jacob to stay with Rebekah's brother Laban, the son of Bethuel the Aramean. Esau Marries the Daughter of Ishmael
28.6: Esau found out that his father Isaac had blessed Jacob and had warned him not to marry any of the Canaanite women. He also learned that Jacob had been sent to find a wife in northern Syria
28.7: and that he had obeyed his father and mother.
28.8: Esau already had several wives, but he realized at last how much his father hated the Canaanite women.
28.9: So he married Ishmael's daughter Mahalath, who was the sister of Nebaioth and the granddaughter of Abraham. Jacob's Dream at Bethel
28.10: Jacob left the town of Beersheba and started out for Haran.
28.11: At sunset he stopped for the night and went to sleep, resting his head on a large rock.
28.12: In a dream he saw a ladder that reached from earth to heaven, and God's angels were going up and down on it.
28.13: The LORD was standing beside the ladder and said: I am the LORD God who was worshiped by Abraham and Isaac. I will give to you and your family the land on which you are now sleeping.
28.14: Your descendants will spread over the earth in all directions and will become as numerous as the specks of dust. Your family will be a blessing to all people.
28.15: Wherever you go, I will watch over you, then later I will bring you back to this land. I won't leave you--I will do all I have promised.
28.16: Jacob woke up suddenly and thought, "The LORD is in this place, and I didn't even know it."
28.17: Then Jacob became frightened and said, "This is a fearsome place! It must be the house of God and the ladder to heaven."
28.18: When Jacob got up early the next morning, he took the rock that he had used for a pillow and stood it up for a place of worship. Then he poured olive oil on the rock to dedicate it to God,
28.19: and he named the place Bethel. Before that it had been named Luz.
28.20: Jacob solemnly promised God, "If you go with me and watch over me as I travel, and if you give me food and clothes
28.21: and bring me safely home again, you will be my God.
28.22: This rock will be your house, and I will give back to you a tenth of everything you give me."

29.1: As Jacob continued on his way to the east,
29.2: he looked out in a field and saw a well where shepherds took their sheep for water. Three flocks of sheep were lying around the well, which was covered with a large rock.
29.3: Shepherds would roll the rock away when all their sheep had gathered there. Then after the sheep had been watered, the shepherds would roll the rock back over the mouth of the well.
29.4: Jacob asked the shepherds, "Where are you from?" "We're from Haran," they answered.
29.5: Then he asked, "Do you know Nahor's grandson Laban?" "Yes we do," they replied.
29.6: "How is he?" Jacob asked. "He's fine," they answered. "And here comes his daughter Rachel with the sheep."
29.7: Jacob told them, "Look, the sun is still high up in the sky, and it's too early to bring in the rest of the flocks. Water your sheep and take them back to the pasture."
29.8: But they replied, "We can't do that until they all get here, and the rock has been rolled away from the well."
29.9: While Jacob was still talking with the men, his cousin Rachel came up with her father's sheep.
29.10: When Jacob saw her and his uncle's sheep, he rolled the rock away and watered the sheep.
29.11: He then kissed Rachel and started crying because he was so happy.
29.12: He told her that he was the son of her aunt Rebekah, and she ran and told her father about him.
29.13: As soon as Laban heard the news, he ran out to meet Jacob. He hugged and kissed him and brought him to his home, where Jacob told him everything that had happened.
29.14: Laban said, "You are my nephew, and you are like one of my own family." After Jacob had been there for a month, Jacob Marries Leah and Rachel
29.15: Laban said to him, "You shouldn't have to work without pay, just because you are a relative of mine. What do you want me to give you?"
29.16: Laban had two daughters. Leah was older than Rachel, but her eyes didn't sparkle, while Rachel was beautiful and had a good figure.
29.18: Since Jacob was in love with Rachel, he answered, "If you will let me marry Rachel, I'll work seven years for you."
29.19: Laban replied, "It's better for me to let you marry Rachel than for someone else to have her. So stay and work for me."
29.20: Jacob worked seven years for Laban, but the time seemed like only a few days, because he loved Rachel so much.
29.21: Jacob said to Laban, "The time is up, and I want to marry Rachel now!"
29.22: So Laban gave a big feast and invited all their neighbors.
29.23: But that evening he brought Leah to Jacob, who married her and spent the night with her.
29.24: Laban also gave Zilpah to Leah as her servant woman.
29.25: The next morning Jacob found out that he had married Leah, and he asked Laban, "Why did you do this to me? Didn't I work to get Rachel? Why did you trick me?"
29.26: Laban replied, "In our country the older daughter must get married first.
29.27: After you spend this week with Leah, you may also marry Rachel. But you will have to work for me another seven years."
29.28: At the end of the week of celebration, Laban let Jacob marry Rachel, and he gave her his servant woman Bilhah. Jacob loved Rachel more than he did Leah, but he had to work another seven years for Laban.
29.31: The LORD knew that Jacob loved Rachel more than he did Leah, and so he gave children to Leah, but not to Rachel.
29.32: Leah gave birth to a son and named him Reuben, because she said, "The LORD has taken away my sorrow. Now my husband will love me more than he does Rachel."
29.33: She had a second son and named him Simeon, because she said, "The LORD has heard that my husband doesn't love me."
29.34: When Leah's third son was born, she said, "Now my husband will hold me close." So this son was named Levi.
29.35: She had one more son and named him Judah, because she said, "I'll praise the LORD!"

30.1: Rachel was very jealous of Leah for having children, and she said to Jacob, "I'll die if you don't give me some children!"
30.2: But Jacob became upset with Rachel and answered, "Don't blame me! I'm not God."
30.3: "Here, take my servant Bilhah," Rachel told him. "Have children by her, and I'll let them be born on my knees to show that they are mine."
30.4: Then Rachel let Jacob marry Bilhah,
30.6: Rachel named him Dan, because she said, "God has answered my prayers. He has judged me and given me a son."
30.7: When Bilhah and Jacob had a second son,
30.8: Rachel said, "I've struggled hard with my sister, and I've won!" So she named the boy Naphtali.
30.9: When Leah realized she could not have any more children, she let Jacob marry her servant Zilpah,
30.11: "I'm really lucky," Leah said, and she named the boy Gad.
30.13: Leah exclaimed, "I'm happy now, and all the women will say how happy I am." So she named him Asher. Love Flowers
30.14: During the time of the wheat harvest, Reuben found some love flowers and took them to his mother Leah. Rachel asked Leah for some of them,
30.15: but Leah said, "It's bad enough that you stole my husband! Now you want my son's love flowers too.""All right," Rachel answered. "Let me have the flowers, and you can sleep with Jacob tonight."
30.16: That evening when Jacob came in from the fields, Leah told him, "You're sleeping with me tonight. I hired you with my son's love flowers." They slept together that night,
30.17: and God answered Leah's prayers by giving her a fifth son.
30.18: Leah shouted, "God has rewarded me for letting Jacob marry my servant," and she named the boy Issachar.
30.20: she exclaimed, "God has given me a wonderful gift, and my husband will praise me for giving him six sons." So she named the boy Zebulun.
30.21: Later, Leah had a daughter and named her Dinah.
30.22: Finally, God remembered Rachel--he answered her prayer by giving her a son. "God has taken away my disgrace," she said.
30.24: "I'll name the boy Joseph, and I'll pray that the LORD will give me another son." Jacob and Laban
30.25: After Joseph was born, Jacob said to Laban, "Release me from our agreement and let me return to my own country.
30.26: You know how hard I've worked for you, so let me take my wives and children and leave."
30.27: But Laban told him, "If you really are my friend, stay on, and I'll pay whatever you ask. I'm sure the LORD has blessed me because of you."
30.29: Jacob answered: You've seen how hard I've worked for you, and you know how your flocks and herds have grown under my care.
30.30: You didn't have much before I came, but the LORD has blessed everything I have ever done for you. Now it's time for me to start looking out for my own family.
30.31: "How much do you want me to pay you?" Laban asked. Then Jacob told him: I don't want you to pay me anything. Just do one thing, and I'll take care of your sheep and goats.
30.32: Let me go through your flocks and herds and take the sheep and goats that are either spotted or speckled and the black lambs. That's all you need to give me.
30.33: In the future you can easily find out if I've been honest. Just look and see if my animals are either spotted or speckled, or if the lambs are black. If they aren't, they've been stolen from you.
30.34: "I agree to that," was Laban's response.
30.35: Before the end of the day, Laban had separated his spotted and speckled animals and the black lambs from the others and had put his sons in charge of them.
30.36: Then Laban made Jacob keep the rest of the sheep and goats at a distance of three days' journey.
30.37: Jacob cut branches from some poplar trees and from some almond and evergreen trees. He peeled off part of the bark and made the branches look spotted and speckled.
30.38: Then he put the branches where the sheep and goats would see them while they were drinking from the water trough. The goats mated there
30.39: in front of the branches, and their young were spotted and speckled.
30.40: Some of the sheep that Jacob was keeping for Laban were already spotted. And when the others were ready to mate, he made sure that they faced in the direction of the spotted and black ones. In this way, Jacob built up a flock of sheep for himself and did not put them with the other sheep.
30.41: When the stronger sheep were mating near the drinking place, Jacob made sure that the spotted branches were there.
30.42: But he would not put out the branches when the weaker animals were mating. So Jacob got all of the healthy animals, and Laban got what was left.
30.43: Jacob soon became rich and successful. He owned many sheep, goats, camels, and donkeys, as well as a lot of slaves.

31.1: Jacob heard that Laban's sons were complaining, "Jacob is now a rich man, and he got everything he owns from our father."
31.2: Jacob also noticed that Laban was not as friendly as he had been before.
31.3: One day the LORD said, "Jacob, go back to your relatives in the land of your ancestors, and I will bless you."
31.4: Jacob sent for Rachel and Leah to meet him in the field where he kept his sheep,
31.5: and he told them: Your father isn't as friendly with me as he used to be, but the God my ancestors worshiped has been on my side.
31.6: You know that I have worked hard for your father
31.7: and that he keeps cheating me by changing my wages time after time. But God has protected me.
31.8: When your father said the speckled sheep would be my wages, all of them were speckled. And when he said the spotted ones would be mine, all of them were spotted.
31.9: That's how God has taken sheep and goats from your father and given them to me.
31.10: Once, when the flocks were mating, I dreamed that all the rams were either spotted or speckled.
31.11: Then God's angel called me by name. I answered,
31.12: and he said, "Notice that all the rams are either spotted or speckled. I know everything Laban is doing to you,
31.13: and I am the God you worshiped at Bethel, when you poured olive oil on a rock and made a promise to me. Leave here right away and return to the land where you were born."
31.14: Rachel and Leah said to Jacob: There's nothing left for us to inherit from our father.
31.15: He treats us like foreigners and has even cheated us out of the bride price that should have been ours.
31.16: Now do whatever God tells you to do. Even the property God took from our father and gave to you really belongs to us and our children.
31.17: Then Jacob, his wives, and his children got on camels and left
31.18: for the home of his father Isaac in Canaan. Jacob took all of the flocks, herds, and other property that he had gotten in northern Syria.
31.19: Before Rachel left, she stole the household idols while Laban was out shearing his sheep.
31.20: Jacob tricked Laban the Aramean by not saying that he intended to leave.
31.21: When Jacob crossed the Euphrates River and headed for the hill country of Gilead, he took with him everything he owned. Laban Catches Up with Jacob
31.22: Three days later Laban found out that Jacob had gone.
31.23: So he took some of his relatives along and chased after Jacob for seven days, before catching up with him in the hill country of Gilead.
31.24: But God appeared to Laban in a dream that night and warned, "Don't say a word to Jacob. Don't make a threat or a promise."
31.25: Jacob had set up camp in the hill country of Gilead, when Laban and his relatives came and set up camp in another part of the hill country. Laban went to Jacob
31.26: and said: Look what you've done! You've tricked me and run off with my daughters like a kidnapper.
31.27: Why did you sneak away without telling me? I would have given you a going-away party with singing and with music on tambourines and harps.
31.28: You didn't even give me a chance to kiss my own grandchildren and daughters good-by. That was really foolish.
31.29: I could easily hurt you, but the God your father worshiped has warned me not to make any threats or promises.
31.30: I can understand why you were eager to return to your father, but why did you have to steal my idols?
31.31: Jacob answered, "I left secretly because I was afraid you would take your daughters from me by force.
31.32: If you find that any one of us has taken your idols, I'll have that person killed. Let your relatives be witnesses. Show me what belongs to you, and you can take it back." Jacob did not realize that Rachel had stolen the household idols.
31.33: Laban searched the tents of Jacob, Leah, and the two servant women, but did not find the idols. Then he started for Rachel's tent.
31.34: She had already hidden them in the cushion she used as a saddle and was sitting on it. Laban searched everywhere and did not find them.
31.35: Rachel said, "Father, please don't be angry with me for not getting up; I am having my period." Laban kept on searching, but still did not find the idols.
31.36: Jacob became very angry and said to Laban: What have I done wrong? Have I committed some crime? Is that why you hunted me down?
31.37: After searching through everything I have, did you find anything of yours? If so, put it here, where your relatives and mine can see it. Then we can decide what to do.
31.38: In all the twenty years that I've worked for you, not one of your sheep or goats has had a miscarriage, and I've never eaten even one of your rams.
31.39: If a wild animal killed one of your sheep or goats, I paid for it myself. In fact, you demanded the full price, whether the animal was killed during the day or at night.
31.40: I sweated every day, and I couldn't sleep at night because of the cold.
31.41: I had to work fourteen of these twenty long years to earn your two daughters and another six years to buy your sheep and goats. During that time you kept changing my wages.
31.42: If the fearsome God worshiped by Abraham and my father Isaac had not been on my side, you would have sent me away without a thing. But God saw my hard work, and he knew the trouble I was in, so he helped me. Then last night he told you how wrong you were. Jacob and Laban Make an Agreement
31.43: Laban said to Jacob, "Leah and Rachel are my daughters, and their children belong to me. All these sheep you are taking are really mine too. In fact, everything you have belongs to me. But there is nothing I can do to keep my daughters and their children.
31.44: So I am ready to make an agreement with you, and we will pile up some large rocks here to remind us of the agreement."
31.45: After Jacob had set up a large rock,
31.46: he told his men to get some more rocks and pile them up next to it. Then Jacob and Laban ate a meal together beside the rocks.
31.47: Laban named the pile of rocks Jegar Sahadutha. But Jacob named it Galeed.
31.48: Laban said to Jacob, "This pile of rocks will remind us of our agreement." That's why the place was named Galeed.
31.49: Laban also said, "This pile of rocks means that the LORD will watch us both while we are apart from each other." So the place was also named Mizpah.
31.50: Then Laban said: If you mistreat my daughters or marry other women, I may not know about it, but remember, God is watching us!
31.51: Both this pile of rocks and this large rock have been set up between us as a reminder. I must never go beyond them to attack you, and you must never go beyond them to attack me.
31.53: My father Nahor, your grandfather Abraham, and their ancestors all worshiped the same God, and he will make sure that we each keep the agreement. Then Jacob made a promise in the name of the fearsome God his father Isaac had worshiped.
31.54: Jacob killed an animal and offered it as a sacrifice there on the mountain, and he invited his men to eat with him. After the meal they spent the night on the mountain.
31.55: Early the next morning, Laban kissed his daughters and his grandchildren good-by, then he left to go back home.

32.1: As Jacob was on his way back home, some of God's angels came and met him.
32.2: When Jacob saw them, he said, "This is God's camp." So he named the place Mahanaim.
32.3: Jacob sent messengers on ahead to Esau, who lived in the land of Seir, also known as Edom.
32.4: Jacob told them to say to Esau, "Master, I am your servant! I have lived with Laban all this time,
32.5: and now I own cattle, donkeys, and sheep, as well as many slaves. Master, I am sending these messengers in the hope that you will be kind to me."
32.6: When the messengers returned, they told Jacob, "We went to your brother Esau, and now he is heading this way with four hundred men."
32.7: Jacob was so frightened that he divided his people, sheep, cattle, and camels into two groups.
32.8: He thought, "If Esau attacks one group, perhaps the other can escape."
32.9: Then Jacob prayed: You, LORD, are the God who was worshiped by my grandfather Abraham and by my father Isaac. You told me to return home to my family, and you promised to be with me and make me successful.
32.10: I don't deserve all the good things you have done for me, your servant. When I first crossed the Jordan, I had only my walking stick, but now I have two large groups of people and animals.
32.11: Please rescue me from my brother. I am afraid he will come and attack not only me, but my wives and children as well.
32.12: But you have promised that I would be a success and that someday it will be as hard to count my descendants as it is to count the stars in the sky.
32.13: After Jacob had spent the night there, he chose some animals as gifts for Esau:
32.14: two hundred female goats and twenty males, two hundred female sheep and twenty males, thirty female camels with their young, forty cows and ten bulls, and twenty female donkeys and ten males.
32.16: Jacob put servants in charge of each herd and told them, "Go ahead of me and keep a space between each herd."
32.17: Then he said to the servant in charge of the first herd, "When Esau meets you, he will ask whose servant you are. He will want to know where you are going and who owns those animals in front of you.
32.18: So tell him, 'They belong to your servant Jacob, who is coming this way. He is sending them as a gift to his master Esau.'"
32.19: Jacob also told the men in charge of the second and third herds and those who followed to say the same thing when they met Esau.
32.20: And Jacob told them to be sure to say that he was right behind them. Jacob hoped the gifts would make Esau friendly, so Esau would be glad to see him when they met.
32.21: Jacob's men took the gifts on ahead of him, but he spent the night in camp. Jacob's Name Is Changed to Israel
32.22: Jacob got up in the middle of the night and took his wives, his eleven children, and everything he owned across to the other side of the Jabbok River for safety.
32.24: Afterwards, Jacob went back and spent the rest of the night alone. A man came and fought with Jacob until just before daybreak.
32.25: When the man saw that he could not win, he struck Jacob on the hip and threw it out of joint.
32.26: They kept on wrestling until the man said, "Let go of me! It's almost daylight." "You can't go until you bless me," Jacob replied.
32.27: Then the man asked, "What is your name?" "Jacob," he answered.
32.28: The man said, "Your name will no longer be Jacob. You have wrestled with God and with men, and you have won. That's why your name will be Israel."
32.29: Jacob said, "Now tell me your name." "Don't you know who I am?" he asked. And he blessed Jacob.
32.30: Jacob said, "I have seen God face to face, and I am still alive." So he named the place Peniel.
32.31: The sun was coming up as Jacob was leaving Peniel. He was limping because he had been struck on the hip,
32.32: and the muscle on his hip joint had been injured. That's why even today the people of Israel don't eat the hip muscle of any animal.

33.1: Later that day Jacob met Esau coming with his four hundred men. So Jacob had his children walk with their mothers.
33.2: The two servant women, Zilpah and Bilhah, together with their children went first, followed by Leah and her children, then by Rachel and Joseph.
33.3: Jacob himself walked in front of them all, bowing to the ground seven times as he came near his brother.
33.4: But Esau ran toward Jacob and hugged and kissed him. Then the two brothers started crying.
33.5: When Esau noticed the women and children he asked, "Whose children are these?" Jacob answered, "These are the ones the LORD has been kind enough to give to me, your servant."
33.6: Then the two servant women and their children came and bowed down to Esau.
33.7: Next, Leah and her children came and bowed down; finally, Joseph and Rachel also came and bowed down.
33.8: Esau asked Jacob, "What did you mean by these herds I met along the road?" "Master," Jacob answered, "I sent them so that you would be friendly to me."
33.9: "But, brother, I already have plenty," Esau replied. "Keep them for yourself."
33.10: "No!" Jacob said. "Please accept these gifts as a sign of your friendship for me. When you welcomed me and I saw your face, it was like seeing the face of God.
33.11: Please accept these gifts I brought to you. God has been good to me, and I have everything I need." Jacob kept insisting until Esau accepted the gifts.
33.12: "Let's get ready to travel," Esau said. "I'll go along with you."
33.13: But Jacob answered, "Master, you know traveling is hard on children, and I have to look after the sheep and goats that are nursing their young. If my animals travel too much in one day, they will all die.
33.14: Why don't you go on ahead and let me travel along slowly with the children, the herds, and the flocks. We can meet again in the country of Edom."
33.15: Esau replied, "Let me leave some of my men with you." "You don't have to do that," Jacob answered. "I am happy, simply knowing that you are friendly to me."
33.17: But Jacob went to Succoth, where he built a house for himself and set up shelters for his animals. That's why the place is called Succoth. Jacob Arrives at Shechem
33.18: After leaving northern Syria, Jacob arrived safely at Shechem in Canaan and set up camp outside the city.
33.19: The land where he camped was owned by the descendants of Hamor, the father of Shechem. So Jacob paid them one hundred pieces of silver for the property,
33.20: then he set up his tents and built an altar there to honor the God of Israel.

34.1: Dinah, the daughter of Jacob and Leah, went to visit some of the women who lived there.
34.2: She was seen by Hamor's son Shechem, the leader of the Hivites, and he grabbed her and raped her.
34.3: But Shechem was attracted to Dinah, so he told her how much he loved her.
34.4: He even asked his father to get her for his wife.
34.5: Meanwhile, Jacob heard what had happened. But his sons were out in the fields with the cattle, so he did not do anything at the time.
34.7: just as Jacob's sons were coming in from work. When they learned that their sister had been raped, they became furiously angry. Nothing is more disgraceful than rape, and it should not be tolerated in Israel.
34.8: Hamor said to Jacob and his sons: My son Shechem really loves Dinah. Please let him marry her.
34.9: Why don't you start letting your families marry into our families and ours marry into yours?
34.10: You can share this land with us. Move freely about until you find the property you want; then buy it and settle down here.
34.11: Shechem added, "Do this favor for me, and I'll give whatever you want.
34.12: Ask anything, no matter how expensive. I'll do anything, just let me marry Dinah."
34.13: Jacob's sons wanted to get even with Shechem and his father because of what had happened to their sister.
34.14: So they tricked them by saying: You're not circumcised! It would be a disgrace for us to let you marry Dinah now.
34.15: But we will let you marry her, if you and the other men in your tribe get circumcised.
34.16: Then your families can marry into ours, and ours can marry into yours, and we can live together like one nation.
34.17: But if you don't agree to get circumcised, we'll take Dinah and leave this place.
34.18: Hamor and Shechem liked what was said.
34.19: Shechem was the most respected person in his family, and he was so in love with Dinah that he hurried off to get everything done.
34.20: The two men met with the other leaders of their city and told them:
34.21: These people really are friendly. Why not let them move freely about until they find the property they want? There's enough land here for them and for us. Then our families can marry into theirs, and theirs can marry into ours.
34.22: We have to do only one thing before they will agree to stay here and become one nation with us. Our men will have to be circumcised like their men.
34.23: Just think! We'll get their property, as well as their flocks and herds. All we have to do is to agree, and they will live here with us.
34.24: Every grown man followed this advice and got circumcised. Dinah's Brothers Take Revenge
34.25: Three days later the men who had been circumcised were still weak from pain. So Simeon and Levi, two of Dinah's brothers, attacked with their swords and killed every man in town,
34.26: including Hamor and Shechem. Then they took Dinah and left.
34.27: Jacob's other sons came and took everything they wanted. All this was done because of the horrible thing that had happened to their sister.
34.28: They took sheep, goats, donkeys, and everything else that was in the town or the fields.
34.29: After taking everything of value from the houses, they dragged away the wives and children of their victims.
34.30: Jacob said to Simeon and Levi, "Look what you've done! Now I'm in real trouble with the Canaanites and Perizzites who live around here. There aren't many of us, and if they attack, they'll kill everyone in my household."
34.31: They answered, "Was it right to let our own sister be treated that way?"

35.1: God told Jacob, "Return to Bethel, where I appeared to you when you were running from your brother Esau. Make your home there and build an altar for me."
35.2: Jacob said to his family and to everyone else who was traveling with him: Get rid of your foreign gods! Then make yourselves acceptable to worship God and put on clean clothes.
35.3: Afterwards, we'll go to Bethel. I will build an altar there for God, who answered my prayers when I was in trouble and who has always been at my side.
35.4: So everyone gave Jacob their idols and their earrings, and he buried them under the oak tree near Shechem.
35.5: While Jacob and his family were traveling through Canaan, God terrified the people in the towns so much that no one dared bother them.
35.6: Finally, they reached Bethel, also known as Luz.
35.7: Jacob built an altar there and called it "God of Bethel," because that was the place where God had appeared to him when he was running from Esau.
35.8: While they were there, Rebekah's personal servant Deborah died. They buried her under an oak tree and called it "Weeping Oak." God Blesses Jacob at Bethel
35.9: After Jacob came back to the land of Canaan, God appeared to him again. This time he gave Jacob a new name and blessed him by saying: I am God All-Powerful, and from now on your name will be Israel instead of Jacob. You will have many children. Your descendants will become nations, and some of the men in your family will even be kings.
35.12: I will give you the land that I promised Abraham and Isaac, and it will belong to your family forever.
35.14: Jacob set up a large rock, so that he would remember what had happened there. Then he poured wine and olive oil on the rock to show that it was dedicated to God,
35.15: and he named the place Bethel. Benjamin Is Born
35.16: Jacob and his family had left Bethel and were still a long way from Ephrath, when the time came for Rachel's baby to be born.
35.17: She was having a rough time, but the woman who was helping her said, "Don't worry! It's a boy."
35.18: Rachel was at the point of death, and right before dying, she said, "I'll name him Benoni." But Jacob called him Benjamin.
35.19: Rachel was buried beside the road to Ephrath, which is also called Bethlehem.
35.20: Jacob set up a tombstone over her grave, and it is still there.
35.21: Jacob, also known as Israel, traveled to the south of Eder Tower, where he set up camp.
35.22: During their time there, Jacob's oldest son Reuben slept with Bilhah, who was one of Jacob's other wives. And Jacob found out about it. Jacob's Twelve Sons
35.23: Jacob had twelve sons while living in northern Syria. His first-born Reuben was the son of Leah, who later gave birth to Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, and Zebulun. Leah's servant Zilpah had two sons: Gad and Asher. Jacob and his wife Rachel had Joseph and Benjamin. Rachel's servant woman Bilhah had two more sons: Dan and Naphtali. Isaac Dies
35.27: Jacob went to his father Isaac at Hebron, also called Mamre or Kiriath-Arba, where Isaac's father Abraham had lived as a foreigner.
35.28: Isaac died at the ripe old age of one hundred eighty, then his sons Esau and Jacob buried him.

36.1: Esau, also known as Edom, had many descendants.
36.2: He married three Canaanite women: The first was Adah, the daughter of Elon the Hittite; the second was Oholibamah, the daughter of Anah and the granddaughter of Zibeon the Hivite;
36.3: the third was Basemath, who was Ishmael's daughter and Nebaioth's sister.
36.4: Esau and his three wives had five sons while in Canaan. Adah's son was Eliphaz; Basemath's son was Reuel; Oholibamah's three sons were Jeush, Jalam, and Korah.
36.6: Esau took his children and wives, his relatives and servants, his animals and possessions he had gotten while in Canaan, and moved far from Jacob.
36.7: He did this because the land was too crowded and could not support him and his brother with their flocks and herds.
36.8: That's why Esau made his home in the hill country of Seir.
36.9: Esau lived in the hill country of Seir and was the ancestor of the Edomites. Esau had three wives: Adah, Basemath, and Oholibamah. Here is a list of his descendants: Esau and Adah had a son named Eliphaz, whose sons were Teman, Omar, Zepho, Gatam, and Kenaz. Timna was the other wife of Esau's son Eliphaz, and she had a son named Amalek. Esau and Basemath had a son named Reuel, whose sons were Nahath, Zerah, Shammah, and Mizzah. Esau and Oholibamah had three sons: Jeush, Jalam, and Korah. Chiefs and Leaders in Edom
36.15: Esau and Adah's oldest son was Eliphaz, and the clans that descended from him were Teman, Omar, Zepho, Kenaz,
36.16: Korah, Gatam, and Amalek. These and Esau's other descendants lived in the land of Edom.
36.17: The clans that descended from Esau and Basemath's son Reuel were Nahath, Zerah, Shammah, and Mizzah.
36.18: The clans that descended from Esau and Oholibamah the daughter of Anah were Jeush, Jalam, and Korah.
36.19: All of these clans descended from Esau, who was known as Edom.
36.20: Seir was from the Horite tribe that had lived in Edom before the time of Esau. The clans that had descended from him were Lotan, Shobal, Zibeon, Anah,
36.22: Lotan's sons were Hori and Heman; his sister was Timna.
36.23: Shobal's sons were Alvan, Manahath, Ebal, Shepho, and Onam.
36.24: Zibeon's sons were Aiah and Anah--the same Anah who found an oasis in the desert while taking the donkeys of his father out to pasture.
36.25: Anah's children were Dishon and Oholibamah.
36.26: Dishon's sons were Hemdan, Eshban, Ithran, and Cheran.
36.27: Ezer's sons were Bilhan, Zaavan, and Akan.
36.28: Dishan's sons were Uz and Aran.
36.29: The clans of the Horites were Lotan, Shobal, Zibeon, Anah,
36.30: Dishon, Ezer, and Dishan, and they lived in the land of Seir.
36.31: Before there were kings in Israel, the following kings ruled Edom one after another: Bela son of Beor from Dinhabah; Jobab son of Zerah from Bozrah; Husham from the land of Teman; Hadad son of Bedad from Avith (Bedad had defeated the Midianites in Moab); Samlah from Masrekah; Shaul from the city of Rehoboth on the Euphrates River; Baalhanan son of Achbor; Hadar from the city of Pau (his wife Mehetabel was the daughter of Matred and the granddaughter of Mezahab).
36.40: The clans that descended from Esau took their names from their families and the places where they lived. They are Timna, Alvah, Jetheth,
36.43: Magdiel, and Iram. These clans descended from Esau, who was known as Edom, the father of the Edomites. They took their names from the places where they settled.

37.1: Jacob lived in the land of Canaan, where his father Isaac had lived,
37.2: and this is the story of his family. When Jacob's son Joseph was seventeen years old, he took care of the sheep with his brothers, the sons of Bilhah and Zilpah. But he was always telling his father all sorts of bad things about his brothers.
37.3: Jacob loved Joseph more than he did any of his other sons, because Joseph was born after Jacob was very old. Jacob had given Joseph a fancy coat
37.4: to show that he was his favorite son, and so Joseph's brothers hated him and would not be friendly to him.
37.5: One day, Joseph told his brothers what he had dreamed, and they hated him even more.
37.6: Joseph said, "Let me tell you about my dream.
37.7: We were out in the field, tying up bundles of wheat. Suddenly my bundle stood up, and your bundles gathered around and bowed down to it."
37.8: His brothers asked, "Do you really think you are going to be king and rule over us?" Now they hated Joseph more than ever because of what he had said about his dream.
37.9: Joseph later had another dream, and he told his brothers, "Listen to what else I dreamed. The sun, the moon, and eleven stars bowed down to me."
37.10: When he told his father about this dream, his father became angry and said, "What's that supposed to mean? Are your mother and I and your brothers all going to come and bow down in front of you?"
37.11: Joseph's brothers were jealous of him, but his father kept wondering about the dream. Joseph Is Sold and Taken to Egypt
37.12: One day when Joseph's brothers had taken the sheep to a pasture near Shechem,
37.13: his father Jacob said to him, "I want you to go to your brothers. They are with the sheep near Shechem." "Yes, sir," Joseph answered.
37.14: His father said, "Go and find out how your brothers and the sheep are doing. Then come back and let me know." So he sent him from Hebron Valley. Joseph was near Shechem
37.15: and wandering through the fields, when a man asked, "What are you looking for?"
37.16: Joseph answered, "I'm looking for my brothers who are watching the sheep. Can you tell me where they are?"
37.17: "They're not here anymore," the man replied. "I overheard them say they were going to Dothan." Joseph left and found his brothers in Dothan.
37.18: But before he got there, they saw him coming and made plans to kill him.
37.19: They said to one another, "Look, here comes the hero of those dreams!
37.20: Let's kill him and throw him into a pit and say that some wild animal ate him. Then we'll see what happens to those dreams."
37.21: Reuben heard this and tried to protect Joseph from them. "Let's not kill him," he said.
37.22: "Don't murder him or even harm him. Just throw him into a dry well out here in the desert." Reuben planned to rescue Joseph later and take him back to his father.
37.23: When Joseph came to his brothers, they pulled off his fancy coat
37.24: and threw him into a dry well.
37.25: As Joseph's brothers sat down to eat, they looked up and saw a caravan of Ishmaelites coming from Gilead. Their camels were loaded with all kinds of spices that they were taking to Egypt.
37.26: So Judah said, "What will we gain if we kill our brother and hide his body?
37.27: Let's sell him to the Ishmaelites and not harm him. After all, he is our brother." And the others agreed.
37.28: When the Midianite merchants came by, Joseph's brothers took him out of the well, and for twenty pieces of silver they sold him to the Ishmaelites who took him to Egypt.
37.29: When Reuben returned to the well and did not find Joseph there, he tore his clothes in sorrow.
37.30: Then he went back to his brothers and said, "The boy is gone! What am I going to do?"
37.31: Joseph's brothers killed a goat and dipped Joseph's fancy coat in its blood.
37.32: After this, they took the coat to their father and said, "We found this! Look at it carefully and see if it belongs to your son."
37.33: Jacob knew it was Joseph's coat and said, "It's my son's coat! Joseph has been torn to pieces and eaten by some wild animal."
37.34: Jacob mourned for Joseph a long time, and to show his sorrow he tore his clothes and wore sackcloth.
37.35: All of Jacob's children came to comfort him, but he refused to be comforted. "No," he said, "I will go to my grave, mourning for my son." So Jacob kept on grieving.
37.36: Meanwhile, the Midianites had sold Joseph in Egypt to a man named Potiphar, who was the king's official in charge of the palace guard.

38.1: About that time Judah left his brothers in the hill country and went to live near his friend Hirah in the town of Adullam.
38.2: While there he met the daughter of Shua, a Canaanite man. Judah married her,
38.3: and they had three sons. He named the first one Er;
38.4: she named the next one Onan.
38.5: The third one was born when Judah was in Chezib, and she named him Shelah.
38.6: Later, Judah chose Tamar as a wife for Er, his oldest son.
38.7: But Er was very evil, and the LORD took his life.
38.8: So Judah told Onan, "It's your duty to marry Tamar and have a child for your brother."
38.9: Onan knew the child would not be his, and when he had sex with Tamar, he made sure that she would not get pregnant.
38.10: The LORD wasn't pleased with Onan and took his life too.
38.11: Judah did not want the same thing to happen to his son Shelah, and he told Tamar, "Go home to your father and live there as a widow until my son Shelah is grown." So Tamar went to live with her father.
38.12: Some years later Judah's wife died, and he mourned for her. He then went with his friend Hirah to the town of Timnah, where his sheep were being sheared.
38.13: Tamar found out that her father-in-law Judah was going to Timnah to shear his sheep.
38.14: She also realized that Shelah was now a grown man, but she had not been allowed to marry him. So she decided to dress in something other than her widow's clothes and to cover her face with a veil. After this, she sat outside the town of Enaim on the road to Timnah.
38.15: When Judah came along, he did not recognize her because of the veil. He thought she was a prostitute
38.16: and asked her to sleep with him. She asked, "What will you give me if I do?"
38.17: "One of my young goats," he answered. "What will you give me to keep until you send the goat?" she asked.
38.18: "What do you want?" he asked in return. "The ring on that cord around your neck," was her reply. "I also want the special walking stick you have with you." He gave them to her, they slept together, and she became pregnant.
38.19: After returning home, Tamar took off the veil and dressed in her widow's clothes again.
38.20: Judah had his friend Hirah take a goat to the woman, so he could get back the ring and walking stick, but she wasn't there.
38.21: Hirah asked the people of Enaim, "Where is the prostitute who sat along the road outside your town?" "There's never been one here," they answered.
38.22: Hirah went back and told Judah, "I couldn't find the woman, and the people of Enaim said no prostitute had ever been there."
38.23: "If you couldn't find her, we'll just let her keep the things I gave her," Judah answered. "And we'd better forget about the goat, or else we'll look like fools."
38.24: About three months later someone told Judah, "Your daughter-in-law Tamar has behaved like a prostitute, and now she's pregnant!" "Drag her out of town and burn her to death!" Judah shouted.
38.25: As Tamar was being dragged off, she sent someone to tell her father-in-law, "The man who gave me this ring, this cord, and this walking stick is the one who got me pregnant."
38.26: "Those are mine!" Judah admitted. "She's a better person than I am, because I broke my promise to let her marry my son Shelah." After this, Judah never slept with her again.
38.27: Tamar later gave birth to twins. But before either of them was born, one of them stuck a hand out of her womb. The woman who was helping tied a red thread around the baby's hand and explained, "This one came out first."
38.29: Right away his hand went back in, and the other child was born first. The woman then said, "What an opening you've made for yourself!" So they named the baby Perez.
38.30: When the brother with the red thread came out, they named him Zerah.

39.1: The Ishmaelites took Joseph to Egypt and sold him to Potiphar, the king's official in charge of the palace guard.
39.2: So Joseph lived in the home of Potiphar, his Egyptian owner. Soon Potiphar realized that the LORD was helping Joseph to be successful in whatever he did.
39.4: Potiphar liked Joseph and made him his personal assistant, putting him in charge of his house and all of his property.
39.5: Because of Joseph, the LORD began to bless Potiphar's family and fields.
39.6: Potiphar left everything up to Joseph, and with Joseph there, the only decision he had to make was what he wanted to eat. Joseph was well-built and handsome,
39.7: and Potiphar's wife soon noticed him. She asked him to make love to her,
39.8: but he refused and said, "My master isn't worried about anything in his house, because he has placed me in charge of everything he owns.
39.9: No one in my master's house is more important than I am. The only thing he hasn't given me is you, and that's because you are his wife. I won't sin against God by doing such a terrible thing as this."
39.10: She kept begging Joseph day after day, but he refused to do what she wanted or even to go near her.
39.11: One day, Joseph went to Potiphar's house to do his work, and none of the other servants were there.
39.12: Potiphar's wife grabbed hold of his coat and said, "Make love to me!" Joseph ran out of the house, leaving her hanging onto his coat.
39.14: she called in her servants and said, "Look! This Hebrew has come just to make fools of us. He tried to rape me, but I screamed for help.
39.15: And when he heard me scream, he ran out of the house, leaving his coat with me."
39.16: Potiphar's wife kept Joseph's coat until her husband came home.
39.17: Then she said, "That Hebrew slave of yours tried to rape me!
39.18: But when I screamed for help, he left his coat and ran out of the house."
39.20: and threw Joseph in the same prison where the king's prisoners were kept. While Joseph was in prison,
39.21: the LORD helped him and was good to him. He even made the jailer like Joseph so much that
39.22: he put him in charge of the other prisoners and of everything that was done in the jail.
39.23: The jailer did not worry about anything, because the LORD was with Joseph and made him successful in all that he did.

40.1: While Joseph was in prison, both the king's personal servant and his chief cook made the king angry. So he had them thrown into the same prison with Joseph.
40.4: They spent a long time in prison, and Potiphar, the official in charge of the palace guard, made Joseph their servant.
40.5: One night each of the two men had a dream, but their dreams had different meanings.
40.6: The next morning, when Joseph went to see the men, he could tell they were upset,
40.7: and he asked, "Why are you so worried today?"
40.8: "We each had a dream last night," they answered, "and there is no one to tell us what they mean." Joseph replied, "Doesn't God know the meaning of dreams? Now tell me what you dreamed."
40.9: The king's personal servant told Joseph, "In my dream I saw a vine
40.10: with three branches. As soon as it budded, it blossomed, and its grapes became ripe.
40.11: I held the king's cup and squeezed the grapes into it, then I gave the cup to the king."
40.12: Joseph said: This is the meaning of your dream. The three branches stand for three days,
40.13: and in three days the king will pardon you. He will make you his personal servant again, and you will serve him his wine, just as you used to do.
40.14: But when these good things happen, please don't forget to tell the king about me, so I can get out of this place.
40.15: I was kidnapped from the land of the Hebrews, and here in Egypt I haven't done anything to deserve being thrown in jail.
40.16: When the chief cook saw that Joseph had given a good meaning to the dream, he told Joseph, "I also had a dream. In it I was carrying three breadbaskets stacked on top of my head.
40.17: The top basket was full of all kinds of baked things for the king, but birds were eating them."
40.18: Joseph said: This is the meaning of your dream. The three baskets are three days,
40.19: and in three days the king will cut off your head. He will hang your body on a pole, and birds will come and peck at it.
40.20: Three days later, while the king was celebrating his birthday with a dinner for his officials, he sent for his personal servant and the chief cook.
40.21: He put the personal servant back in his old job
40.22: and had the cook put to death. Everything happened just as Joseph had said it would,
40.23: but the king's personal servant completely forgot about Joseph.

41.1: Two years later the king of Egypt dreamed he was standing beside the Nile River.
41.2: Suddenly, seven fat, healthy cows came up from the river and started eating grass along the bank.
41.3: Then seven ugly, skinny cows came up out of the river and
41.4: ate the fat, healthy cows. When this happened, the king woke up.
41.5: The king went back to sleep and had another dream. This time seven full heads of grain were growing on a single stalk.
41.6: Later, seven other heads of grain appeared, but they were thin and scorched by the east wind.
41.7: The thin heads of grain swallowed the seven full heads. Again the king woke up, and it had only been a dream.
41.8: The next morning the king was upset. So he called in his magicians and wise men and told them what he had dreamed. None of them could tell him what the dreams meant.
41.9: The king's personal servant said: Now I remember what I was supposed to do.
41.10: When you were angry with me and your chief cook, you threw us both in jail in the house of the captain of the guard.
41.11: One night we both had dreams, and each dream had a different meaning.
41.12: A young Hebrew, who was a servant of the captain of the guard, was there with us at the time. When we told him our dreams, he explained what each of them meant,
41.13: and everything happened just as he said it would. I got my job back, and the cook was put to death.
41.14: The king sent for Joseph, who was quickly brought out of jail. He shaved, changed his clothes, and went to the king.
41.15: The king said to him, "I had a dream, yet no one can explain what it means. I am told that you can interpret dreams."
41.16: "Your Majesty," Joseph answered, "I can't do it myself, but God can give a good meaning to your dreams."
41.17: The king told Joseph: I dreamed I was standing on the bank of the Nile River.
41.18: I saw seven fat, healthy cows come up out of the river, and they began feeding on the grass.
41.19: Next, seven skinny, bony cows came up out of the river. I have never seen such terrible looking cows anywhere in Egypt.
41.20: The skinny cows ate the fat ones.
41.21: But you couldn't tell it, because these skinny cows were just as skinny as they were before. Right away, I woke up.
41.22: I also dreamed that I saw seven heads of grain growing on one stalk. The heads were full and ripe.
41.23: Then seven other heads of grain came up. They were thin and scorched by a wind from the desert.
41.24: These heads of grain swallowed the full ones. I told my dreams to the magicians, but none of them could tell me the meaning of the dreams.
41.25: Joseph replied: Your Majesty, both of your dreams mean the same thing, and in them God has shown what he is going to do.
41.26: The seven good cows stand for seven years, and so do the seven good heads of grain.
41.27: The seven skinny, ugly cows that came up later also stand for seven years, as do the seven bad heads of grain that were scorched by the east wind. The dreams mean there will be seven years when there won't be enough grain.
41.28: It is just as I said--God has shown what he intends to do.
41.29: For seven years Egypt will have more than enough grain,
41.30: but that will be followed by seven years when there won't be enough. The good years of plenty will be forgotten, and everywhere in Egypt people will be starving.
41.31: The famine will be so bad that no one will remember that once there had been plenty.
41.32: God has given you two dreams to let you know that he has definitely decided to do this and that he will do it soon.
41.33: Your Majesty, you should find someone who is wise and will know what to do, so that you can put him in charge of all Egypt.
41.34: Then appoint some other officials to collect one-fifth of every crop harvested in Egypt during the seven years when there is plenty.
41.35: Give them the power to collect the grain during those good years and to store it in your cities.
41.36: It can be stored until it is needed during the seven years when there won't be enough grain in Egypt. This will keep the country from being destroyed because of the lack of food. Joseph Is Made Governor over Egypt
41.37: The king and his officials liked this plan.
41.38: So the king said to them, "No one could possibly handle this better than Joseph, since the Spirit of God is with him."
41.39: The king told Joseph, "God is the one who has shown you these things. No one else is as wise as you are or knows as much as you do.
41.40: I'm putting you in charge of my palace, and everybody will have to obey you. No one will be over you except me.
41.41: You are now governor of all Egypt!"
41.42: Then the king took off his royal ring and put it on Joseph's finger. He gave him fine clothes to wear and placed a gold chain around his neck.
41.43: He also let him ride in the chariot next to his own, and people shouted, "Make way for Joseph!" So Joseph was governor of Egypt.
41.44: The king told Joseph, "Although I'm king, no one in Egypt is to do anything without your permission."
41.45: He gave Joseph the Egyptian name Zaphenath Paneah. And he let him marry Asenath, the daughter of Potiphera, a priest in the city of Heliopolis. Joseph traveled all over Egypt.
41.46: Joseph was thirty when the king made him governor, and he went everywhere for the king.
41.47: For seven years there were big harvests of grain.
41.48: Joseph collected and stored up the extra grain in the cities of Egypt near the fields where it was harvested.
41.49: In fact, there was so much grain that they stopped keeping record, because it was like counting the grains of sand along the beach.
41.50: Joseph and his wife had two sons before the famine began.
41.51: Their first son was named Manasseh, which means, "God has let me forget all my troubles and my family back home."
41.52: His second son was named Ephraim, which means "God has made me a success in the land where I suffered."
41.53: Egypt's seven years of plenty came to an end,
41.54: and the seven years of famine began, just as Joseph had said. There was not enough food in other countries, but all over Egypt there was plenty.
41.55: When the famine finally struck Egypt, the people asked the king for food, but he said, "Go to Joseph and do what he tells you to do."
41.56: The famine became bad everywhere in Egypt, so Joseph opened the storehouses and sold the grain to the Egyptians.
41.57: People from all over the world came to Egypt, because the famine was severe in their countries.

42.1: When Jacob found out there was grain in Egypt, he said to his sons, "Why are you just sitting here, staring at one another?
42.2: I have heard there is grain in Egypt. Now go down and buy some, so we won't starve to death."
42.3: Ten of Joseph's brothers went to Egypt to buy grain.
42.4: But Jacob did not send Joseph's younger brother Benjamin with them; he was afraid that something might happen to him.
42.5: So Jacob's sons joined others from Canaan who were going to Egypt because of the terrible famine.
42.6: Since Joseph was governor of Egypt and in charge of selling grain, his brothers came to him and bowed with their faces to the ground.
42.7: They did not recognize Joseph, but right away he knew who they were, though he pretended not to know. Instead, he spoke harshly and asked, "Where do you come from?" "From the land of Canaan," they answered. "We've come here to buy grain."
42.9: Joseph remembered what he had dreamed about them and said, "You're spies! You've come here to find out where our country is weak."
42.10: "No sir," they replied. "We're your servants, and we have only come to buy grain.
42.11: We're honest men, and we come from the same family--we're not spies."
42.12: "That isn't so!" Joseph insisted. "You've come here to find out where our country is weak."
42.13: But they explained, "Sir, we come from a family of twelve brothers. The youngest is still with our father in Canaan, and one of our brothers is dead."
42.14: Joseph replied: It's just like I said. You're spies,
42.15: and I'm going to find out who you really are. I swear by the life of the king that you won't leave this place until your youngest brother comes here.
42.16: Choose one of you to go after your brother, while the rest of you stay here in jail. That will show whether you are telling the truth. But if you are lying, I swear by the life of the king that you are spies!
42.17: Joseph kept them all under guard for three days,
42.18: before saying to them: Since I respect God, I'll give you a chance to save your lives.
42.19: If you are honest men, one of you must stay here in jail, and the rest of you can take the grain back to your starving families.
42.20: But you must bring your youngest brother to me. Then I'll know that you are telling the truth, and you won't be put to death. Joseph's brothers agreed
42.21: and said to one another, "We're being punished because of Joseph. We saw the trouble he was in, but we refused to help him when he begged us. That's why these terrible things are happening."
42.22: Reuben spoke up, "Didn't I tell you not to harm the boy? But you wouldn't listen, and now we have to pay the price for killing him."
42.23: They did not know that Joseph could understand them, since he was speaking through an interpreter.
42.24: Joseph turned away from them and cried, but soon he turned back and spoke to them again. Then he had Simeon tied up and taken away while they watched. Joseph's Brothers Return to Canaan
42.25: Joseph gave orders for his brothers' grain sacks to be filled with grain and for their money to be put in their sacks. He also gave orders for them to be given food for their journey home. After this was done,
42.26: they each loaded the grain on their donkeys and left.
42.27: When they stopped for the night, one of them opened his sack to get some grain for his donkey, and right away he saw his moneybag.
42.28: "Here's my money!" he told his brothers. "Right here in my sack." They were trembling with fear as they stared at one another and asked themselves, "What has God done to us?"
42.29: When they returned to the land of Canaan, they told their father Jacob everything that had happened to them:
42.30: The governor of Egypt was rude and treated us like spies.
42.31: But we told him, "We're honest men, not spies.
42.32: We come from a family of twelve brothers. The youngest is still with our father in Canaan, and the other is dead."
42.33: Then the governor of Egypt told us, "I'll find out if you really are honest. Leave one of your brothers here with me, while you take the grain to your starving families.
42.34: But bring your youngest brother to me, so I can be certain that you are honest men and not spies. After that, I'll let your other brother go free, and you can stay here and trade."
42.35: When the brothers started emptying their sacks of grain, they found their moneybags in them. They were frightened, and so was their father Jacob,
42.36: who said, "You have already taken my sons Joseph and Simeon from me. And now you want to take away Benjamin! Everything is against me."
42.37: Reuben spoke up, "Father, if I don't bring Benjamin back, you can kill both of my sons. Trust me with him, and I will bring him back."
42.38: But Jacob said, "I won't let my son Benjamin go down to Egypt with the rest of you. His brother is already dead, and he is the only son I have left. I am an old man, and if anything happens to him on the way, I'll die from sorrow, and all of you will be to blame."

43.1: The famine in Canaan got worse,
43.2: until finally, Jacob's family had eaten all the grain they had bought in Egypt. So Jacob said to his sons, "Go back and buy some more grain."
43.3: Judah replied, "The governor strictly warned us that we would not be allowed to see him unless we brought our youngest brother with us. If you let us take Benjamin along, we will go and buy grain. But we won't go without him!"
43.6: Jacob asked, "Why did you cause me so much trouble by telling the governor you had another brother?"
43.7: They answered, "He asked a lot of questions about us and our family. He wanted to know if you were still alive and if we had any more brothers. All we could do was answer his questions. How could we know he would tell us to bring along our brother?"
43.8: Then Judah said to his father, "Let Benjamin go with me, and we will leave right away, so that none of us will starve to death.
43.9: I promise to bring him back safely, and if I don't, you can blame me as long as I live.
43.10: If we had not wasted all this time, we could already have been there and back twice."
43.11: Their father said: If Benjamin must go with you, take the governor a gift of some of the best things from our own country, such as perfume, honey, spices, pistachio nuts, and almonds.
43.12: Also take along twice the amount of money for the grain, because there must have been some mistake when the money was put back in your sacks.
43.13: Take Benjamin with you and leave right away.
43.14: When you go in to see the governor, I pray that God All-Powerful will be good to you and that the governor will let your other brother and Benjamin come back home with you. If I must lose my children, I suppose I must.
43.15: The brothers took the gifts, twice the amount of money, and Benjamin. Then they hurried off to Egypt. When they stood in front of Joseph,
43.16: he saw Benjamin and told the servant in charge of his house, "Take these men to my house. Slaughter an animal and cook it, so they can eat with me at noon."
43.17: The servant did as he was told and took the brothers to Joseph's house.
43.18: But on the way they got worried and started thinking, "We are being taken there because of the money that was put back in our sacks last time. He will arrest us, make us his slaves, and take our donkeys."
43.19: So when they arrived at Joseph's house, they said to the servant in charge,
43.20: "Sir, we came to Egypt once before to buy grain.
43.21: But when we stopped for the night, we each found in our grain sacks the exact amount we had paid. We have brought that money back,
43.22: together with enough money to buy more grain. We don't know who put the money in our sacks."
43.23: "It's all right," the servant replied. "Don't worry. The God you and your father worship must have put the money there, because I received your payment in full." Then he brought Simeon out to them.
43.24: The servant took them into Joseph's house and gave them water to wash their feet. He also tended their donkeys.
43.25: The brothers got their gifts ready to give to Joseph at noon, since they had heard they were going to eat there.
43.26: When Joseph came home, they gave him the gifts they had brought, and they bowed down to him.
43.27: After Joseph had asked how they were, he said, "What about your elderly father? Is he still alive?"
43.28: They answered, "Your servant our father is still alive and well." And again they bowed down to Joseph.
43.29: When Joseph looked around and saw his brother Benjamin, he said, "This must be your youngest brother, the one you told me about. God bless you, my son."
43.30: Right away he rushed off to his room and cried because of his love for Benjamin.
43.31: After washing his face and returning, he was able to control himself and said, "Serve the meal!"
43.32: Joseph was served at a table by himself, and his brothers were served at another. The Egyptians sat at yet another table, because Egyptians felt it was disgusting to eat with Hebrews.
43.33: To the surprise of Joseph's brothers, they were seated in front of him according to their ages, from the oldest to the youngest.
43.34: They were served food from Joseph's table, and Benjamin was given five times as much as each of the others. So Joseph's brothers drank with him and had a good time.

44.1: Later, Joseph told the servant in charge of his house, "Fill the men's grain sacks with as much as they can hold and put their money in the sacks. Also put my silver cup in the sack of the youngest brother." The servant did as he was told.
44.3: Early the next morning, the men were sent on their way with their donkeys.
44.4: But they had not gone far from the city when Joseph told the servant, "Go after those men! When you catch them, say, 'My master has been good to you. So why have you stolen his silver cup?
44.5: Not only does he drink from his cup, but he also uses it to learn about the future. You have done a terrible thing.'"
44.6: When the servant caught up with them, he said exactly what Joseph had told him to say.
44.7: But they replied, "Sir, why do you say such things? We would never do anything like that!
44.8: We even returned the money we found in our grain sacks when we got back to Canaan. So why would we want to steal any silver or gold from your master's house?
44.9: If you find that one of us has the cup, then kill him, and the rest of us will become your slaves."
44.10: "Good!" the man replied, "I'll do what you have said. But only the one who has the cup will become my slave. The rest of you can go free."
44.11: Each of the brothers quickly put his sack on the ground and opened it.
44.12: Joseph's servant started searching the sacks, beginning with the one that belonged to the oldest brother. When he came to Benjamin's sack, he found the cup.
44.13: This upset the brothers so much that they began tearing their clothes in sorrow. Then they loaded their donkeys and returned to the city.
44.14: When Judah and his brothers got there, Joseph was still at home. So they bowed down to Joseph,
44.15: who asked them, "What have you done? Didn't you know I could find out?"
44.16: "Sir, what can we say?" Judah replied. "How can we prove we are innocent? God has shown that we are guilty. And now all of us are your slaves, especially the one who had the cup."
44.17: Joseph told them, "I would never punish all of you. Only the one who was caught with the cup will become my slave. The rest of you are free to go home to your father." Judah Pleads for Benjamin
44.18: Judah went over to Joseph and said: Sir, you have as much power as the king himself, and I am only your slave. Please don't get angry if I speak.
44.19: You asked us if our father was still alive and if we had any more brothers.
44.20: So we told you, "Our father is a very old man. In fact, he was already old when Benjamin was born. Benjamin's brother is dead. Now Benjamin is the only one of the two brothers who is still alive, and our father loves him very much."
44.21: You ordered us to bring him here, so you could see him for yourself.
44.22: We told you that our father would die if Benjamin left him.
44.23: But you warned us that we could never see you again, unless our youngest brother came with us.
44.24: So we returned to our father and reported what you had said.
44.25: Later our father told us to come back here and buy more grain.
44.26: But we answered, "We can't go back to Egypt without our youngest brother. We will never be let in to see the governor, unless he is with us."
44.27: Sir, our father then reminded us that his favorite wife had given birth to two sons.
44.28: One of them was already missing and had not been seen for a long time. My father thinks the boy was torn to pieces by some wild animal,
44.29: and he said, "I am an old man. If you take Benjamin from me, and something happens to him, I will die of a broken heart."
44.30: That's why Benjamin must be with us when I go back to my father. He loves him so much
44.31: that he will die if Benjamin doesn't come back with me.
44.32: I promised my father that I would bring him safely home. If I don't, I told my father he could blame me the rest of my life.
44.33: Sir, I am your slave. Please let me stay here in place of Benjamin and let him return home with his brothers.
44.34: How can I face my father if Benjamin isn't with me? I couldn't bear to see my father in such sorrow.

45.1: Since Joseph could no longer control his feelings in front of his servants, he sent them out of the room. When he was alone with his brothers, he told them, "I am Joseph."
45.2: Then he cried so loudly that the Egyptians heard him and told about it in the king's palace.
45.3: Joseph asked his brothers if his father was still alive, but they were too frightened to answer.
45.4: Joseph told them to come closer to him, and when they did, he said: Yes, I am your brother Joseph, the one you sold into Egypt.
45.5: Don't worry or blame yourselves for what you did. God is the one who sent me ahead of you to save lives.
45.6: There has already been a famine for two years, and for five more years no one will plow fields or harvest grain.
45.7: But God sent me on ahead of you to keep your families alive and to save you in this wonderful way.
45.8: After all, you weren't really the ones who sent me here--it was God. He made me the highest official in the king's court and placed me over all Egypt.
45.9: Now hurry back and tell my father that his son Joseph says, "God has made me ruler of Egypt. Come here as quickly as you can.
45.10: You will live near me in the region of Goshen with your children and grandchildren, as well as with your sheep, goats, cattle, and everything else you own.
45.11: I will take care of you there during the next five years of famine. But if you don't come, you and your family and your animals will starve to death."
45.12: All of you, including my brother Benjamin, can tell by what I have said that I really am Joseph.
45.13: Tell my father about my great power here in Egypt and about everything you have seen. Hurry and bring him here.
45.14: Joseph and Benjamin hugged each other and started crying.
45.15: Joseph was still crying as he kissed each of his other brothers. After this, they started talking with Joseph.
45.16: When it was told in the palace that Joseph's brothers had come, the king and his officials were happy.
45.17: So the king said to Joseph: Tell your brothers to load their donkeys and return to Canaan.
45.18: Have them bring their father and their families here. I will give them the best land in Egypt, and they can eat and enjoy everything that grows on it.
45.19: Also tell your brothers to take some wagons from Egypt for their wives and children to ride in. And be sure to have them bring their father.
45.20: They can leave their possessions behind, because they will be given the best of everything in Egypt.
45.21: Jacob's sons agreed to do what the king had said. And Joseph gave them wagons and food for their trip home, just as the king had ordered.
45.22: Joseph gave some new clothes to each of his brothers, but to Benjamin he gave five new outfits and three hundred pieces of silver.
45.23: To his father he sent ten donkeys loaded with the best things in Egypt, and ten other donkeys loaded with grain and bread and other food for the return trip.
45.24: Then he sent his brothers off and told them, "Don't argue on the way home!"
45.25: Joseph's brothers left Egypt, and when they arrived in Canaan,
45.26: they told their father that Joseph was still alive and was the ruler of Egypt. But their father was so surprised that he could not believe them.
45.27: Then they told him everything Joseph had said. When he saw the wagons Joseph had sent, he felt much better
45.28: and said, "Now I can believe you! My son Joseph must really be alive, and I will get to see him before I die."

46.1: Jacob packed up everything he owned and left for Egypt. On the way he stopped near the town of Beersheba and offered sacrifices to the God his father Isaac had worshiped.
46.2: That night, God spoke to him and said, "Jacob! Jacob!" "Here I am," Jacob answered.
46.3: God said, "I am God, the same God your father worshiped. Don't be afraid to go to Egypt. I will give you so many descendants that one day they will become a nation.
46.4: I will go with you to Egypt, and later I will bring your descendants back here. Your son Joseph will be at your side when you die."
46.5: Jacob and his family set out from Beersheba and headed for Egypt. His sons put him in the wagon that the king had sent for him, and they put their small children and their wives in the other wagons. Jacob's whole family went to Egypt, including his sons, his grandsons, his daughters, and his granddaughters. They took along their animals and everything else they owned.
46.8: When Jacob went to Egypt, his children who were born in northern Syria also went along with their families. Jacob and his wife Leah had a total of thirty-three children, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren, but two of their grandchildren had died in Canaan. Their oldest son Reuben took his sons Hanoch, Pallu, Hezron, and Carmi. Their son Simeon took his sons Jemuel, Jamin, Ohad, Jachin, Zohar, and Shaul, whose mother was a Canaanite. Their son Levi took his sons Gershon, Kohath, and Merari. Their son Judah took his sons Shelah, Perez, and Zerah. Judah's sons Er and Onan had died in Canaan. Judah's son Perez took his sons Hezron and Hamul. Their son Issachar took his sons Tola, Puvah, Jashub, and Shimron. Their son Zebulun took his sons Sered, Elon, and Jahleel. Their daughter Dinah also went.
46.16: Jacob and Zilpah, the servant woman Laban had given his daughter Leah, had a total of sixteen children, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren. Their son Gad took his sons Ziphion, Haggi, Shuni, Ezbon, Eri, Arodi, and Areli. Their son Asher took his sons Imnah, Ishvah, Ishvi, and Beriah, who took his sons, Heber and Malchiel. Serah, the daughter of Asher, also went.
46.19: Jacob and Rachel had fourteen children and grandchildren. Their son Joseph was already in Egypt, where he had married Asenath, daughter of Potiphera, the priest of Heliopolis. Joseph and Asenath had two sons, Manasseh and Ephraim. Jacob and Rachel's son Benjamin took his sons Bela, Becher, Ashbel, Gera, Naaman, Ehi, Rosh, Muppim, Huppim, and Ard.
46.23: Jacob and Bilhah, the servant woman Laban had given his daughter Rachel, had seven children and grandchildren. Their son Dan took his son Hushim. Their son Naphtali took his sons Jahzeel, Guni, Jezer, and Shillem.
46.26: Sixty-six members of Jacob's family went to Egypt with him, not counting his daughters-in-law.
46.27: Jacob's two grandsons who were born there made it a total of seventy members of Jacob's family in Egypt.
46.28: Jacob had sent his son Judah ahead of him to ask Joseph to meet them in Goshen.
46.29: So Joseph got in his chariot and went to meet his father. When they met, Joseph hugged his father around the neck and cried for a long time.
46.30: Jacob said to Joseph, "Now that I have seen you and know you are still alive, I am ready to die."
46.31: Then Joseph said to his brothers and to everyone who had come with them: I must go and tell the king that you have arrived from Canaan.
46.32: I will tell him that you are shepherds and that you have brought your sheep, goats, cattle, and everything else you own.
46.33: The king will call you in and ask what you do for a living.
46.34: When he does, be sure to say, "We are shepherds. Our families have always raised sheep." If you tell him this, he will let you settle in the region of Goshen. Joseph wanted them to say this to the king, because the Egyptians did not like to be around anyone who raised sheep.

47.1: Joseph took five of his brothers to the king and told him, "My father and my brothers have come from Canaan. They have brought their sheep, goats, cattle, and everything else they own to the region of Goshen." Then he introduced his brothers to the king,
47.3: who asked them, "What do you do for a living?" "Sir, we are shepherds," was their answer. "Our families have always raised sheep.
