20.18: But the Edomite king answered, " No, I won't let you go through our country! And if you try, we will attack you."
20.19: Moses sent back this message: " We promise to stay on the main road, and if any of us or our livestock drink your water, we will pay for it. We just want to pass through."
20.20: But the Edomite king insisted, " You can't go through our land!" Then Edom sent out its strongest troops
20.21: to keep Israel from passing through its territory. So the Israelites had to go in another direction. Aaron Dies
20.22: After the Israelites had left Kadesh and had gone as far as Mount Hor
20.23: on the Edomite border, the LORD said,
20.24: " Aaron, this is where you will die. You and Moses disobeyed me at Meribah, and so you will not enter the land I promised the Israelites.
20.25: Moses, go with Aaron and his son Eleazar to the top of the mountain.
20.26: Then take Aaron's priestly robe from him and place it on Eleazar. Aaron will die there."
20.27: Moses obeyed, and everyone watched as he and Aaron and Eleazar walked to the top of Mount Hor.
20.28: Moses then took the priestly robe from Aaron and placed it on Eleazar. Aaron died there. When Moses and Eleazar came down,
20.29: the people knew that Aaron had died, and they mourned his death for thirty days.

21.1: The Canaanite king of Arad lived in the Southern Desert of Canaan, and when he heard that the Israelites were on their way to the village of Atharim, he attacked and took some of them hostage.
21.2: The Israelites prayed, " Our LORD, if you will help us defeat these Canaanites, we will completely destroy their towns and everything in them, to show that they belong to you."
21.3: The LORD answered their prayer and helped them wipe out the Canaanite army and completely destroy their towns. That's why one of the towns is named Hormah, which means " Destroyed Place." Moses Makes a Bronze Snake
21.4: The Israelites had to go around the territory of Edom, so when they left Mount Hor, they headed south toward the Red Sea. But along the way, the people became so impatient
21.5: that they complained against God and said to Moses, " Did you bring us out of Egypt, just to let us die in the desert? There's no water out here, and we can't stand this awful food!"
21.6: Then the LORD sent poisonous snakes that bit and killed many of them.
21.7: Some of the people went to Moses and admitted, " It was wrong of us to insult you and the LORD. Now please ask him to make these snakes go away." Moses prayed,
21.8: and the LORD answered, " Make a snake out of bronze and place it on top of a pole. Anyone who gets bitten can look at the snake and won't die."
21.9: Moses obeyed the LORD. And all of those who looked at the bronze snake lived, even though they had been bitten by the poisonous snakes. Israel's Journey to Moab
21.10: As the Israelites continued their journey to Canaan, they camped at Oboth,
21.11: then at Iye-Abarim in the desert east of Moab,
21.12: and then in the Zered Gorge.
21.13: After that, they crossed the Arnon River gorge and camped in the Moabite desert bordering Amorite territory. The Arnon was the border between the Moabites and the Amorites.
21.14: A song in The Book of the LORD's Battles mentions the town of Waheb with its creeks in the territory of Suphah. It also mentions the Arnon River,
21.15: with its valleys that lie alongside the Moabite border and extend to the town of Ar.
21.16: From the Arnon, the Israelites went to the well near the town of Beer, where the LORD had said to Moses, " Call the people together, and I will give them water to drink."
21.17: That's also the same well the Israelites sang about in this song: Let's celebrate! The well has given us water.
21.18: With their royal scepters, our leaders pointed out where to dig the well. The Israelites left the desert and camped near the town of Mattanah,
21.19: then at Nahaliel, and then at Bamoth.
21.20: Finally, they reached Moabite territory, where they camped near Mount Pisgah in a valley overlooking the desert north of the Dead Sea. Israel Defeats King Sihon the Amorite(Deuteronomy 2.26-37)
21.21: The Israelites sent this message to King Sihon of the Amorites:
21.22: Please let us pass through your territory. We promise to stay away from your fields and vineyards, and we won't drink any water from your wells. As long as we're in your land, we won't get off the main road.
21.23: But Sihon refused to let Israel travel through his land. Instead, he called together his entire army and marched into the desert to attack Israel near the town of Jahaz.
21.24: Israel defeated them and took over the Amorite territory from the Arnon River gorge in the south to the Jabbok River gorge in the north. Beyond the Jabbok was the territory of the Ammonites, who were much stronger than Israel.
21.25: The Israelites settled in the Amorite towns, including the capital city of Heshbon with its surrounding villages.
21.26: King Sihon had ruled from Heshbon, after defeating the Moabites and taking over their land north of the Arnon River gorge.
21.27: That's why the Amorites had written this poem about Heshbon: Come and rebuild Heshbon, King Sihon's capital city!
21.28: His armies marched out like fiery flames, burning down the town of Ar and destroying the hills along the Arnon River.
21.29: You Moabites are done for! Your god Chemosh deserted your people; they were captured, taken away by King Sihon the Amorite.
21.30: We completely defeated Moab. The towns of Heshbon and Dibon, of Nophah and Medeba are ruined and gone.
21.31: After the Israelites had settled in the Amorite territory,
21.32: Moses sent some men to explore the town of Jazer. Later, the Israelites captured the villages surrounding it and forced out the Amorites who lived there. Israel Defeats King Og of Bashan(Deuteronomy 3.1-11)
21.33: The Israelites headed toward the region of Bashan, where King Og ruled, and he led his entire army to Edrei to meet Israel in battle.
21.34: The LORD said to Moses, " Don't be afraid of Og. I will help you defeat him and his army, just as you did King Sihon who ruled in Heshbon. Og's territory will be yours."
21.35: So the Israelites wiped out Og, his family, and his entire army--there were no survivors. Then Israel took over the land of Bashan.

22.1: Israel moved from there to the hills of Moab, where they camped across the Jordan River from the town of Jericho. King Balak of Moab Hires Balaam To Curse Israel
22.2: When King Balak of Moab and his people heard how many Israelites there were and what they had done to the Amorites, he and the Moabites were terrified and panicked.
22.4: They said to the Midianite leaders, " That bunch of Israelites will wipe out everything in sight, like a bull eating grass in a field." So King Balak
22.5: sent a message to Balaam son of Beor who lived among his relatives in the town of Pethor near the Euphrates River. It said: I need your help. A huge group of people has come here from Egypt and settled near my territory.
22.6: They are too powerful for us to defeat, so would you come and place a curse on them? Maybe then we can run them off. I know that anyone you bless will be successful, but anyone you curse will fail.
22.7: The leaders of Moab and Midian left and took along money to pay Balaam for his work. When they got to his house, they gave him Balak's message.
22.8: " Spend the night here," Balaam replied, " and tomorrow I will tell you the LORD's answer." So the officials stayed at his house.
22.9: During the night, God asked Balaam, " Who are these people at your house?"
22.10: " They are messengers from King Balak of Moab," Balaam answered. " He sent them
22.11: to ask me to go to Moab and place a curse on the people who have come there from Egypt. They have settled everywhere around him, and he wants to run them off."
22.12: But God replied, " Don't go with Balak's messengers. I have blessed those people who have come from Egypt, so don't curse them."
22.13: The next morning, Balaam said to Balak's officials, " Go on back home. The LORD says I cannot go with you."
22.14: The officials left and told Balak that Balaam refused to come.
22.15: Then Balak sent a larger group of officials, who were even more important than the first ones.
22.16: They went to Balaam and told him that Balak had said, " Balaam, if you come to Moab,
22.17: I'll pay you very well and do whatever you ask. Just come and place a curse on these people."
22.18: Balaam answered, " Even if Balak offered me a palace full of silver or gold, I wouldn't do anything to disobey the LORD my God.
22.19: You are welcome to spend the night here, just as the others did. I will find out if the LORD has something else to say about this."
22.20: That night, God said, " Balaam, I'll let you go to Moab with Balak's messengers, but do only what I say."
22.21: So Balaam got up the next morning and saddled his donkey, then left with the Moabite officials. Balaam and His Donkey Meet an Angel
22.22: Balaam was riding his donkey to Moab, and two of his servants were with him. But God was angry that Balaam had gone, so one of the LORD's angels stood in the road to stop him.
22.23: When Balaam's donkey saw the angel standing there with a sword, it walked off the road and into an open field. Balaam had to beat the donkey to get it back on the road.
22.24: Then the angel stood between two vineyards, in a narrow path with a stone wall on each side.
22.25: When the donkey saw the angel, it walked so close to one of the walls that Balaam's foot scraped against the wall. Balaam beat the donkey again.
22.26: The angel moved once more and stood in a spot so narrow that there was no room for the donkey to go around.
22.27: So it just lay down. Balaam lost his temper, then picked up a stick and smacked the donkey.
22.28: When that happened, the LORD told the donkey to speak, and it asked Balaam, " What have I done to you that made you beat me three times?"
22.29: " You made me look stupid!" Balaam answered. " If I had a sword, I'd kill you here and now!"
22.30: " But you're my owner," replied the donkey, " and you've ridden me many times. Have I ever done anything like this before?" " No," Balaam admitted.
22.31: Just then, the LORD let Balaam see the angel standing in the road, holding a sword, and Balaam bowed down.
22.32: The angel said, " You had no right to treat your donkey like that! I was the one who blocked your way, because I don't think you should go to Moab.
22.33: If your donkey had not seen me and stopped those three times, I would have killed you and let the donkey live."
22.34: Balaam replied, " I was wrong. I didn't know you were trying to stop me. If you don't think I should go, I'll return home right now."
22.35: " It's all right for you to go," the LORD's angel answered. " But you must say only what I tell you." So Balaam went on with Balak's officials. King Balak Meets Balaam
22.36: When Balak heard that Balaam was coming, he went to meet him at the town of Ir, which is on the northern border of Moab.
22.37: Balak asked, " Why didn't you come when I invited you the first time? Did you think I wasn't going to pay you?"
22.38: " I'm here now," Balaam answered. " But I will say only what God tells me to say."
22.39: They left and went to the town of Kiriath-Huzoth,
22.40: where Balak sacrificed cattle and sheep and gave some of the meat to Balaam and the officials who were with him.
22.41: The next morning, Balak took Balaam to the town of Bamoth-Baal. From there, Balaam could see some of the Israelites.

23.1: Balaam said to Balak, " Build seven altars here, then bring seven bulls and seven rams."
23.2: After Balak had done this, they sacrificed a bull and a ram on each altar.
23.3: Then Balaam said, " Wait here beside your offerings, and I'll go somewhere to be alone. Maybe the LORD will appear to me. If he does, I will tell you everything he says." And he left.
23.4: When God appeared to him, Balaam said, " I have built seven altars and have sacrificed a bull and a ram on each one."
23.5: The LORD gave Balaam a message, then sent him back to tell Balak.
23.6: When Balaam returned, he found Balak and his officials standing beside the offerings.
23.7: Balaam said: " King Balak of Moab brought me from the hills of Syria to curse Israel and announce its doom.
23.8: But I can't go against God! He did not curse or condemn Israel.
23.9: " From the mountain peaks, I look down and see Israel, the obedient people of God.
23.10: They are living alone in peace. And though they are many, they don't bother the other nations. " I hope to obey God for as long as I live and to die in such peace."
23.11: Balak said, " What are you doing? I asked you to come and place a curse on my enemies. But you have blessed them instead!"
23.12: Balaam answered, " I can say only what the LORD tells me." Balaam's Second Message
23.13: Balak said to Balaam, " Let's go somewhere else. Maybe if you see a smaller part of the Israelites, you will be able to curse them for me."
23.14: So he took Balaam to a field on top of Mount Pisgah where lookouts were stationed. Then he built seven altars there and sacrificed a bull and a ram on each one.
23.15: " Wait here beside your offerings," Balaam said. " The LORD will appear to me over there."
23.16: The LORD appeared to Balaam and gave him another message, then he told him to go and tell Balak.
23.17: Balaam went back and saw him and his officials standing beside the offerings. Balak asked, " What did the LORD say?"
23.18: Balaam answered: " Pay close attention to my words--
23.19: God is no mere human! He doesn't tell lies or change his mind. God always keeps his promises.
23.20: " My command from God was to bless these people, and there's nothing I can do to change what he has done.
23.21: Israel's king is the LORD God. He lives there with them and intends them no harm.
23.22: With the strength of a wild ox, God led Israel out of Egypt.
23.23: No magic charms can work against them-- just look what God has done for his people.
23.24: They are like angry lions ready to attack; and they won't rest until their victim is gobbled down."
23.25: Balak shouted, " If you're not going to curse Israel, then at least don't bless them."
23.26: " I've already told you," Balaam answered. " I will say only what the LORD tells me." Balaam's Third Message
23.27: Balak said to Balaam, " Come on, let's try another place. Maybe God will let you curse Israel from there."
23.28: So he took Balaam to Mount Peor overlooking the desert north of the Dead Sea.
23.29: Balaam said, " Build seven altars here, then bring me seven bulls and seven rams."
23.30: After Balak had done what Balaam asked, he sacrificed a bull and a ram on each altar.

24.1: Balaam was sure that the LORD would tell him to bless Israel again. So he did not use any magic to find out what the LORD wanted him to do, as he had the first two times. Instead, he looked out toward the desert
24.2: and saw the tribes of Israel camped below. Just then, God's Spirit took control of him,
24.3: and Balaam said: " I am the son of Beor, and my words are true, so listen to my message!
24.4: It comes from the LORD, the God All-Powerful. I bowed down to him and saw a vision of Israel.
24.5: " People of Israel, your camp is lovely.
24.6: It's like a grove of palm trees or a garden beside a river. You are like tall aloe trees that the LORD has planted, or like cedars growing near water.
24.7: You and your descendants will prosper like an orchard beside a stream. Your king will rule with power and be a greater king than Agag the Amalekite.
24.8: With the strength of a wild ox, God led you out of Egypt. You will defeat your enemies, shooting them with arrows and crushing their bones.
24.9: Like a lion you lie down, resting after an attack. Who would dare disturb you? " Anyone who blesses you will be blessed; anyone who curses you will be cursed."
24.10: When Balak heard this, he was so furious that he pounded his fist against his hand and said, " I called you here to place a curse on my enemies, and you've blessed them three times.
24.11: Leave now and go home! I told you I would pay you well, but since the LORD didn't let you do what I asked, you won't be paid."
24.12: Balaam answered, " I told your messengers
24.13: that even if you offered me a palace full of silver or gold, I would still obey the LORD. And I explained that I would say only what he told me.
24.14: So I'm going back home, but I'm leaving you with a warning about what the Israelites will someday do to your nation." Balaam's Fourth Message
24.15: Balaam said: " I am the son of Beor, and my words are true, so listen to my message!
24.16: My knowledge comes from God Most High, the LORD All-Powerful. I bowed down to him and saw a vision of Israel.
24.17: " What I saw in my vision hasn't happened yet. But someday, a king of Israel will appear like a star. He will wipe out you Moabites and destroy those tribes who live in the desert.
24.18: Israel will conquer Edom and capture the land of that enemy nation.
24.19: The king of Israel will rule and destroy the survivors of every town there.
24.20: " And I saw this vision about the Amalekites: Their nation is now great, but it will someday disappear forever.
24.21: " And this is what I saw about the Kenites: They think they're safe, living among the rocks,
24.22: but they will be wiped out when Assyria conquers them.
24.23: " No one can survive if God plans destruction.
24.24: Ships will come from Cyprus, bringing people who will invade the lands of Assyria and Eber. But finally, Cyprus itself will be ruined."
24.25: After Balaam finished, he started home, and Balak also left.

25.1: While the Israelites were camped at Acacia, some of the men had sex with Moabite women.
25.2: These women then invited the men to ceremonies where sacrifices were offered to their gods. The men ate the meat from the sacrifices and worshiped the Moabite gods.
25.3: The LORD was angry with Israel because they had worshiped the god Baal Peor.
25.4: So he said to Moses, " Take the Israelite leaders who are responsible for this and have them killed in front of my sacred tent where everyone can see. Maybe then I will stop being angry with the Israelites."
25.5: Moses told Israel's officials, " Each of you must put to death any of your men who worshiped Baal."
25.6: Later, Moses and the people were at the sacred tent, crying, when one of the Israelite men brought a Midianite woman to meet his family.
25.7: Phinehas, the grandson of Aaron the priest, saw the couple and left the crowd. He found a spear
25.8: and followed the man into his tent, where he ran the spear through the man and into the woman's stomach. The LORD immediately stopped punishing Israel with a deadly disease,
25.9: but twenty-four thousand Israelites had already died.
25.11: " In my anger, I would have wiped out the Israelites if Phinehas had not been faithful to me.
25.12: But instead of punishing them, I forgave them. So because of the loyalty that Phinehas showed, I solemnly promise that he and his descendants will always be my priests."
25.14: The Israelite man that was killed was Zimri son of Salu, who was one of the leaders of the Simeon tribe.
25.15: And the Midianite woman killed with him was Cozbi, the daughter of a Midianite clan leader named Zur.
25.17: " The Midianites are now enemies of Israel, so attack and defeat them! They tricked the people of Israel into worshiping their god at Peor, and they are responsible for the death of Cozbi, the daughter of one of their own leaders."

26.1: After the LORD had stopped the deadly disease from killing the Israelites, he said to Moses and Eleazar son of Aaron,
26.2: " I want you to find out how many Israelites are in each family. And list every man twenty years and older who is able to serve in Israel's army."
26.3: Israel was now camped in the hills of Moab across the Jordan River from the town of Jericho. Moses and Eleazar told them
26.4: what the LORD had said about counting the men twenty years and older, just as Moses and their ancestors had done when they left Egypt.
26.5: There were 43,730 men from the tribe of Reuben, the oldest son of Jacob. These men were from the clans of Hanoch, Pallu, Hezron, and Carmi.
26.8: Pallu was the father of Eliab
26.9: and the grandfather of Nemuel, Dathan, and Abiram. These are the same Dathan and Abiram who had been chosen by the people, but who followed Korah and rebelled against Moses, Aaron, and the LORD.
26.10: That's when the LORD made the earth open up and swallow Dathan, Abiram, and Korah. At the same time, fire destroyed two hundred fifty men as a warning to the other Israelites.
26.11: But the Korahite clan wasn't destroyed.
26.12: There were 22,200 men from the tribe of Simeon; they were from the clans of Nemuel, Jamin, Jachin, Zerah, and Shaul.
26.15: There were 40,500 men from the tribe of Gad; they were from the clans of Zephon, Haggi, Shuni, Ozni, Eri, Arod, and Areli.
26.19: There were 76,500 men from the tribe of Judah; they were from the clans of Shelah, Perez, Zerah, Hezron, and Hamul. Judah's sons Er and Onan had died in Canaan.
26.23: There were 64,300 men from the tribe of Issachar; they were from the clans of Tola, Puvah, Jashub, and Shimron.
26.26: There were 60,500 men from the tribe of Zebulun; they were from the clans of Sered, Elon, and Jahleel.
26.28: There were 52,700 men from the tribe of Manasseh son of Joseph; they were from the clan of Machir, the clan of Gilead his son, and the clans of his six grandsons: Iezer, Helek, Asriel, Shechem, Shemida, and Hepher. Zelophehad son of Hepher had no sons, but he had five daughters: Mahlah, Noah, Hoglah, Milcah, and Tirzah.
26.35: There were 32,500 men from the tribe of Ephraim son of Joseph; they were from the clans of Shuthelah, Becher, Tahan, and Eran the son of Shuthelah.
26.38: There were 45,600 men from the tribe of Benjamin; they were from the clans of Bela, Ashbel, Ahiram, Shephupham, Hupham, as well as from Ard and Naaman, the two sons of Bela.
26.42: There were 64,400 men from the tribe of Dan; they were all from the clan of Shuham.
26.44: There were 53,400 men from the tribe of Asher; they were from the clans of Imnah, Ishvi, and Beriah, and from the two clans of Heber and Malchiel, the sons of Beriah. Asher's daughter was Serah.
26.48: There were 45,400 men from the tribe of Naphtali; they were from the clans of Jahzeel, Guni, Jezer, and Shillem.
26.51: The total number of Israelite men listed was 601,730.
26.53: " Divide the land of Canaan among these tribes, according to the number of people in each one,
26.54: so the larger tribes have more land than the smaller ones.
26.55: I will show you what land to give each tribe, and they will receive as much land as they need, according to the number of people in it."
26.57: The tribe of Levi included the clans of the Gershonites, Kohathites, Merarites,
26.58: as well as the clans of Libni, Hebron, Mahli, Mushi, and Korah. Kohath the Levite was the father of Amram,
26.59: the husband of Levi's daughter Jochebed, who was born in Egypt. Amram and Jochebed's three children were Aaron, Moses, and Miriam.
26.60: Aaron was the father of Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar.
26.61: But Nadab and Abihu had died when they offered fire that was unacceptable to the LORD.
26.62: In the tribe of Levi there were 23,000 men and boys at least a month old. They were not listed with the other tribes, because they would not receive any land in Canaan.
26.63: Moses and Eleazar counted the Israelites while they were camped in the hills of Moab across the Jordan River from Jericho.
26.64: None of the people that Moses and Aaron had counted in the Sinai Desert were still alive,
26.65: except Caleb son of Jephunneh and Joshua son of Nun. The LORD had said that everyone else would die there in the desert.

27.1: Zelophehad was from the Manasseh tribe, and he had five daughters, whose names were Mahlah, Noah, Hoglah, Milcah, and Tirzah.
27.2: One day his daughters went to the sacred tent, where they met with Moses, Eleazar, and some other leaders of Israel, as well as a large crowd of Israelites. The young women said:
27.3: You know that our father died in the desert. But it was for something he did wrong, not for joining with Korah in rebelling against the LORD. Our father left no sons
27.4: to carry on his family name. But why should his name die out for that reason? Give us some land like the rest of his relatives in our clan, so our father's name can live on.
27.5: Moses asked the LORD what should be done,
27.7: Zelophehad's daughters are right. They should each be given part of the land their father would have received.
27.8: Tell the Israelites that when a man dies without a son, his daughter will inherit his land.
27.9: If he has no daughter, his brothers will inherit the land.
27.10: But if he has no brothers, his father's brothers will inherit the land.
27.11: And if his father has no brothers, the land must be given to his nearest relative in the clan. This is my law, and the Israelites must obey it. Joshua Is Appointed Israel's Leader(Deuteronomy 31.1-8)
27.12: The LORD said to Moses, " One day you will go up into the Abarim Mountains, and from there you will see the land I am giving the Israelites.
27.13: After you have seen it, you will die, just like your brother Aaron,
27.14: because both of you disobeyed me at Meribah near the town of Kadesh in the Zin Desert. When the Israelites insulted me there, you didn't believe in my holy power."
27.16: " You are the LORD God, and you know what is in everyone's heart. So I ask you to appoint a leader for Israel.
27.17: Your people need someone to lead them into battle, or else they will be like sheep wandering around without a shepherd."
27.18: The LORD answered, " Joshua son of Nun can do the job. Place your hands on him to show that he is the one to take your place.
27.19: Then go with him and have him stand in front of Eleazar the priest and the Israelites. Appoint Joshua as their new leader
27.20: and tell them they must now obey him, just as they obey you.
27.21: But Joshua must depend on Eleazar to find out from me what I want him to do as he leads Israel into battle."
27.22: Moses followed the LORD's instructions and took Joshua to Eleazar and the people,
27.23: then he placed his hands on Joshua and appointed him Israel's leader.

28.2: to say to the people of Israel: Offer sacrifices to me at the appointed times of worship, so that I will smell the smoke and be pleased.
28.3: Each day offer two rams a year old as sacrifices to please me. The animals must have nothing wrong with them;
28.4: one will be sacrificed in the morning, and the other in the evening.
28.5: Along with each of them, two pounds of your finest flour mixed with a quart of olive oil must be offered as a grain sacrifice.
28.6: This sacrifice to please me was first offered on Mount Sinai.
28.7: Finally, along with each of these two sacrifices, a quart of wine must be poured on the altar as a drink offering.
28.8: The second ram will be sacrificed that evening, along with the other offerings, just like the one sacrificed that morning. The smell of the smoke from these sacrifices will please me. The Sacrifice on the SabbathThe LORD said:
28.9: On the Sabbath, in addition to the regular daily sacrifices, you must sacrifice two rams a year old to please me. These rams must have nothing wrong with them, and they will be sacrificed with a drink offering and four pounds of your finest flour mixed with olive oil. The Sacrifices on the First Day of the MonthThe LORD said:
28.11: On the first day of each month, bring to the altar two bulls, one full-grown ram, and seven rams a year old that have nothing wrong with them. Then offer these as sacrifices to please me.
28.12: Six pounds of your finest flour mixed with olive oil must be offered with each bull as a grain sacrifice. Four pounds of flour mixed with oil must be offered with the ram,
28.13: and two pounds of flour mixed with oil must be offered with each of the young rams. The smell of the smoke from these sacrifices will please me.
28.14: Offer two quarts of wine as a drink offering with each bull, one and a half quarts with the ram, and one quart with each of the young rams. Finally, you must offer a goat as a sacrifice for sin. These sacrifices are to be offered on the first day of each month, in addition to the regular daily sacrifices. The LORD said: The Sacrifices during Passover and the Festival of Thin Bread(Leviticus 23.4-8)
28.16: Celebrate Passover in honor of me on the fourteenth day of the first month of each year.
28.17: The following day will begin the Festival of Thin Bread, which will last for a week. During this time you must honor me by eating bread made without yeast.
28.18: On the first day of this festival, you must rest from your work and come together for worship.
28.19: Bring to the altar two bulls, one full-grown ram, and seven rams a year old that have nothing wrong with them. And then offer these as sacrifices to please me.
28.20: Six pounds of your finest flour mixed with olive oil must be offered with each bull as a grain sacrifice. Four pounds of flour mixed with oil must be offered with the ram,
28.21: and two pounds of flour mixed with oil must be offered with each of the young rams.
28.22: Also offer a goat as a sacrifice for the sins of the people.
28.23: All of these are to be offered in addition to the regular daily sacrifices, and the smoke from them will please me.
28.25: Then on the last day of the festival, you must once again rest from work and come together for worship. The LORD said: The Sacrifices during the Harvest Festival(Leviticus 23.15-22)
28.26: On the first day of the Harvest Festival, you must rest from your work, come together for worship, and bring a sacrifice of new grain.
28.27: Offer two young bulls, one full-grown ram, and seven rams a year old as sacrifices to please me.
28.28: Six pounds of your finest flour mixed with olive oil must be offered with each bull as a grain sacrifice. Four pounds of flour mixed with oil must be offered with the ram,
28.29: and two pounds of flour mixed with oil must be offered with each of the young rams.
28.30: Also offer a goat as a sacrifice for sin.
28.31: The animals must have nothing wrong with them and are to be sacrificed along with the regular daily sacrifices. The LORD said:

29.1: On the first day of the seventh month, you must rest from your work and come together to celebrate at the sound of the trumpets.
29.2: Bring to the altar one bull, one full-grown ram, and seven rams a year old that have nothing wrong with them. And then offer these as sacrifices to please me.
29.3: Six pounds of your finest flour mixed with olive oil must be offered with the bull as a grain sacrifice. Four pounds of flour mixed with oil must be offered with the ram,
29.4: and two pounds of flour mixed with oil must be offered with each of the young rams.
29.5: You must also offer a goat as a sacrifice for sin.
29.6: These sacrifices will be made in addition to the regular daily sacrifices and the sacrifices for the first day of the month. The smoke from these sacrifices will please me. The LORD said: The Sacrifices on the Great Day of Forgiveness(Leviticus 23.26-32)
29.7: The tenth day of the seventh month is the Great Day of Forgiveness. On that day you must rest from all work and come together for worship. Show sorrow for your sins by going without food,
29.8: and bring to the altar one young bull, one full-grown ram, and seven rams a year old that have nothing wrong with them. Then offer these as sacrifices to please me.
29.9: Six pounds of your finest flour mixed with olive oil must be offered with the bull as a grain sacrifice. Four pounds of flour mixed with oil must be offered with the ram,
29.10: and two pounds of flour mixed with oil must be offered with each of the young rams.
29.11: A goat must also be sacrificed for the sins of the people. You will offer these sacrifices in addition to the sacrifice to ask forgiveness and the regular daily sacrifices. The LORD said: The Sacrifices during the Festival of Shelters(Leviticus 23.33-44)
29.12: Beginning on the fifteenth day of the seventh month and continuing for seven days, everyone must celebrate the Festival of Shelters in honor of me.
29.13: On the first day, you must rest from your work and come together for worship. Bring to the altar thirteen bulls, two full-grown rams, and fourteen rams a year old that have nothing wrong with them. Then offer these as sacrifices to please me.
29.14: Six pounds of your finest flour mixed with olive oil must be offered with each bull as a grain sacrifice. Four pounds of flour mixed with oil must be offered with each of the rams,
29.15: and two pounds of flour mixed with oil must be offered with each of the young rams.
29.16: You must also offer a goat as a sacrifice for sin. These are to be offered in addition to the regular daily sacrifices.
29.17: For the next six days of the festival, you will sacrifice one less bull than the day before, so that on the seventh day, seven bulls will be sacrificed. The other sacrifices and offerings must remain the same for each of these days.
29.35: On the eighth day, you must once again rest from your work and come together for worship.
29.36: Bring to the altar one bull, one full-grown ram, and seven rams a year old that have nothing wrong with them. Then offer these as sacrifices to please me.
29.37: You must also offer the proper grain sacrifices and drink offerings of wine with each animal.
29.38: And offer a goat as the sacrifice to ask forgiveness for the people. These sacrifices are made in addition to the regular daily sacrifices.
29.39: You must offer all these sacrifices to me at the appointed times of worship, together with any offerings that are voluntarily given or given because of a promise.
29.40: Moses told the people of Israel everything the LORD had told him about the sacrifices.

30.1: The LORD told Moses to say to Israel's tribal leaders:
30.2: When one of you men makes a promise to the LORD, you must keep your word.
30.3: Suppose a young woman who is still living with her parents makes a promise to the LORD.
30.4: If her father hears about it and says nothing, she must keep her promise.
30.5: But if he hears about it and objects, then she no longer has to keep her promise. The LORD will forgive her, because her father did not agree with the promise.
30.6: Suppose a woman makes a promise to the LORD and then gets married. If her husband later hears about the promise but says nothing, she must do what she said, whether she meant it or not.
30.8: But if her husband hears about the promise and objects, she no longer has to keep it, and the LORD will forgive her.
30.9: Widows and divorced women must keep every promise they make to the LORD.
30.10: Suppose a married woman makes a promise to the LORD.
30.11: If her husband hears about the promise and says nothing, she must do what she said.
30.12: But if he hears about the promise and does object, she no longer has to keep it. The LORD will forgive her, because her husband would not allow her to keep the promise.
30.13: Her husband has the final say about any promises she makes to the LORD.
30.14: If her husband hears about a promise and says nothing about it for a whole day, she must do what she said--since he did not object, the promise must be kept.
30.15: But if he waits until the next day to stop her from keeping her promise, he is the one who must be punished.
30.16: These are the laws that the LORD gave Moses about husbands and wives, and about young daughters who still live at home.

31.2: " Before you die, make sure that the Midianites are punished for what they did to Israel."
31.3: Then Moses told the people, " The LORD wants to punish the Midianites. So have our men prepare for battle.
31.4: Each tribe will send a thousand men to fight."
31.5: Twelve thousand men were picked from the tribes of Israel, and after they were prepared for battle,
31.6: Moses sent them off to war. Phinehas the son of Eleazar went with them and took along some things from the sacred tent and the trumpets for sounding the battle signal.
31.7: The Israelites fought against the Midianites, just as the LORD had commanded Moses. They killed all the men,
31.8: including Balaam son of Beor and the five Midianite kings, Evi, Rekem, Zur, Hur, and Reba.
31.9: The Israelites captured every woman and child, then led away the Midianites' cattle and sheep, and took everything else that belonged to them.
31.10: They also burned down the Midianite towns and villages.
31.11: Israel's soldiers gathered together everything they had taken from the Midianites, including the captives and the animals.
31.12: Then they returned to their own camp in the hills of Moab across the Jordan River from Jericho, where Moses, Eleazar, and the other Israelite leaders met the troops outside camp.
31.14: Moses became angry with the army commanders
31.15: and said, " I can't believe you let the women live!
31.16: They are the ones who followed Balaam's advice and invited our people to worship the god Baal Peor. That's why the LORD punished us by killing so many of our people.
31.17: You must put to death every boy and all the women who have ever had sex.
31.18: But do not kill the young women who have never had sex. You may keep them for yourselves."
31.19: Then Moses said to the soldiers, " If you killed anyone or touched a dead body, you are unclean and have to stay outside the camp for seven days. On the third and seventh days, you must go through a ceremony to make yourselves and your captives clean.
31.20: Then wash your clothes and anything made from animal skin, goat's hair, or wood."
31.21: Eleazar then explained, " If you need to purify something that won't burn, such as gold, silver, bronze, iron, tin, or lead, you must first place it in a hot fire. After you take it out, sprinkle it with the water that purifies. Everything else should only be sprinkled with the water. Do all of this, just as the LORD commanded Moses.
31.24: Wash your clothes on the seventh day, and after that, you will be clean and may return to the camp." Everything Taken from the Midianites Is Divided
31.26: Make a list of everything taken from the Midianites, including the captives and the animals. Then divide them between the soldiers and the rest of the people. Eleazar the priest and the family leaders will help you.
31.28: From the half that belongs to the soldiers, set aside for the LORD one out of every five hundred people or animals and give these to Eleazar.
31.30: From the half that belongs to the people, set aside one out of every fifty and give these to the Levites in charge of the sacred tent.
31.31: Moses and Eleazar followed the LORD's instructions
31.32: and listed everything that had been taken from the Midianites. The list included 675,000 sheep and goats, 72,000 cattle, 61,000 donkeys, and 32,000 young women who had never had sex.
31.36: Each half included 337,500 sheep and goats, 36,000 cattle, 30,500 donkeys, and 16,000 young women. From the half that belonged to the soldiers, Moses counted out 675 sheep and goats, 72 cattle, 61 donkeys, and 32 women and gave them to Eleazar to be dedicated to the LORD. Then from the half that belonged to the people, Moses set aside one out of every fifty animals and women, as the LORD had said, and gave them to the Levites.
31.48: The army commanders went to Moses
31.49: and said, " Sir, we have counted our troops, and not one soldier is missing.
31.50: So we want to give the LORD all the gold jewelry we took from the Midianites. It's our gift to him for watching over us and our troops."
31.51: Moses and Eleazar accepted the jewelry from the commanders,
31.52: and its total weight was over four hundred pounds.
31.53: This did not include the things that the soldiers had kept for themselves.
31.54: So Moses and Eleazar placed the gold in the LORD's sacred tent to remind Israel of what had happened.

32.1: The tribes of Reuben and Gad owned a lot of cattle and sheep, and they saw that the regions of Jazer and Gilead had good pastureland.
32.2: So they went to Moses, Eleazar, and the other leaders of Israel and said,
32.3: " The LORD has helped us capture the land around the towns of Ataroth, Dibon, Jazer, Nimrah, Heshbon, Elealeh, Sebam, Nebo, and Beon. That's good pastureland, and since we own cattle and sheep,
32.5: would you let us stay here east of the Jordan River and have this land as our own?"
32.6: Moses answered: You mean you'd stay here while the rest of the Israelites go into battle?
32.7: If you did that, it would discourage the others from crossing over into the land the LORD promised them.
32.8: This is exactly what happened when I sent your ancestors from Kadesh-Barnea to explore the land.
32.9: They went as far as Eshcol Valley, then returned and told the people that we should not enter it.
32.11: And he said that no one who was twenty years or older when they left Egypt would enter the land he had promised to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. Not one of those people believed in the LORD's power,
32.12: except Caleb and Joshua. They remained faithful to the LORD,
32.13: but he was so angry with the others that he forced them to wander around in the desert forty years. By that time everyone who had sinned against him had died.
32.14: Now you people of Reuben and Gad are doing the same thing and making the LORD even angrier.
32.15: If you reject the LORD, he will once again abandon his people and leave them here in the desert. And you will be to blame!
32.16: The men from Reuben and Gad replied: Let us build places to keep our sheep and goats, and towns for our wives and children,
32.17: where they can stay and be safe. Then we'll prepare to fight and lead the other tribes into battle.
32.18: We will stay with them until they have settled in their own tribal lands.
32.19: The land on this side of the Jordan River will be ours, so we won't expect to receive any on the other side.
32.20: Moses said: You promised that you would be ready to fight for the LORD.
32.21: You also agreed to cross the Jordan and stay with the rest of the Israelites, until the LORD forces our enemies out of the land. If you do these things,
32.22: then after the LORD helps Israel capture the land, you can return to your own land. You will no longer have to stay with the others.
32.23: But if you don't keep your promise, you will sin against the LORD and be punished.
32.24: Go ahead and build towns for your wives and children, and places for your sheep and goats. Just be sure to do what you have promised.
32.25: The men from Reuben and Gad answered: Sir, we will do just what you have said.
32.26: Our wives and children and sheep and cattle will stay here in the towns in Gilead.
32.27: But those of us who are prepared for battle will cross the Jordan and fight for the LORD.
32.28: Then Moses said to Eleazar, Joshua, and the family leaders,
32.29: " Make sure that the tribes of Gad and Reuben prepare for battle and cross the Jordan River with you. If they do, then after the land is in your control, give them the region of Gilead as their tribal land.
32.30: But if they break their promise, they will receive land on the other side of the Jordan, like the rest of the tribes."
32.31: The tribes of Gad and Reuben replied, " We are your servants and will do whatever the LORD has commanded.
32.32: We will cross the Jordan River, ready to fight for the LORD in Canaan. But the land we will inherit as our own will be on this side of the river."
32.33: So Moses gave the tribes of Gad, Reuben, and half of Manasseh the territory and towns that King Sihon the Amorite had ruled, as well as the territory and towns that King Og of Bashan had ruled.
32.34: The tribe of Gad rebuilt the towns of Dibon, Ataroth, Aroer,
32.36: Beth-Nimrah, and Beth-Haran. They built walls around them and also built places to keep their sheep and goats.
32.37: The tribe of Reuben rebuilt Heshbon, Elealeh, Kiriathaim,
32.38: Sibmah, as well as the towns that used to be known as Nebo and Baal-Meon. They renamed all those places.
32.39: The clan of Machir from the tribe of East Manasseh went to the region of Gilead, captured its towns, and forced out the Amorites.
32.40: So Moses gave the Machirites the region of Gilead, and they settled there.
32.41: Jair from the Manasseh tribe captured villages and renamed them " Villages of Jair."
32.42: Nobah captured the town of Kenath with its villages and renamed it Nobah.

33.1: As Israel traveled from Egypt under the command of Moses and Aaron,
33.2: Moses kept a list of the places they camped, just as the LORD had instructed. Here is the record of their journey:
33.3: Israel left the Egyptian city of Rameses on the fifteenth day of the first month. This was the day after the LORD had punished Egypt's gods by killing the first-born sons in every Egyptian family. So while the Egyptians were burying the bodies, they watched the Israelites proudly leave their country.
33.5: After the Israelites left Rameses, they camped at Succoth,
33.6: and from there, they moved their camp to Etham on the edge of the desert.
33.7: Then they turned back toward Pi-Hahiroth, east of Baal-Zephon, and camped near Migdol.
33.8: They left Pi-Hahiroth, crossed the Red Sea, then walked three days into the Etham Desert and camped at Marah.
33.9: Next, they camped at Elim, where there were twelve springs of water and seventy palm trees.
33.10: They left Elim and camped near the Red Sea,
33.11: then turned east and camped along the western edge of the Sinai Desert.
33.12: From there they went to Dophkah, Alush, and Rephidim, where they had no water.
33.15: They left Rephidim and finally reached the Sinai Desert.
33.16: As Israel traveled from the Sinai Desert to Kadesh in the Zin Desert, they camped at Kibroth-Hattaavah, Hazeroth, Rithmah, Rimmon-Perez, Libnah, Rissah, Kehelathah, Mount Shepher, Haradah, Makheloth, Tahath, Terah, Mithkah, Hashmonah, Moseroth, Bene-Jaakan, Hor-Haggidgad, Jotbathah, Abronah, Ezion-Geber, and finally Kadesh.
33.37: When they left Kadesh, they came to Mount Hor, on the border of Edom.
33.38: That's where the LORD commanded Aaron the priest to go to the top of the mountain. Aaron died there on the first day of the fifth month, forty years after the Israelites left Egypt.
33.39: He was one hundred twenty-three years old at the time.
33.40: It was then that the Canaanite king of Arad, who lived in the Southern Desert of Canaan, heard that Israel was headed that way.
33.41: The Israelites left Mount Hor and headed toward Moab. Along the way, they camped at Zalmonah, Punon, Oboth, Iye-Abarim in the territory of Moab, Dibon-Gad, Almon-Diblathaim, at a place near Mount Nebo in the Abarim Mountains,
33.48: and finally in the lowlands of Moab across the Jordan River from Jericho.
33.49: Their camp stretched from Beth-Jeshimoth to Acacia. The LORD's Command To Conquer Canaan
33.50: While Israel was camped in the lowlands of Moab across the Jordan River from Jericho, the LORD told Moses
33.51: to give the people of Israel this message: When you cross the Jordan River and enter Canaan,
33.52: you must force out the people living there. Destroy their idols and tear down their altars.
33.53: Then settle in the land--I have given it to you as your own.
33.54: I will show you how to divide the land among the tribes, according to the number of clans in each one, so that the larger tribes will have more land than the smaller ones.
33.55: If you don't force out all the people there, they will be like pointed sticks in your eyes and thorns in your back. They will always be trouble for you,
33.56: and I will treat you as cruelly as I planned on treating them.

34.2: to tell the people of Israel that their land in Canaan would have the following borders:
34.3: The southern border will be the Zin Desert and the northwest part of Edom. This border will begin at the south end of the Dead Sea.
34.4: It will go west from there, but will turn southward to include Scorpion Pass, the village of Zin, and the town of Kadesh-Barnea. From there, the border will continue to Hazar-Addar and on to Azmon.
34.5: It will run along the Egyptian Gorge and end at the Mediterranean Sea.
34.6: The western border will be the Mediterranean Sea.
34.7: The northern border will begin at the Mediterranean, then continue eastward to Mount Hor.
34.8: After that, it will run to Lebo-Hamath and across to Zedad, which is the northern edge of your land.
34.9: From Zedad, the border will continue east to Ziphron and end at Hazar-Enan.
34.10: The eastern border will begin at Hazar-Enan in the north, then run south to Shepham,
34.11: and on down to Riblah on the east side of Ain. From there, it will go south to the eastern hills of Lake Galilee,
34.12: then follow the Jordan River down to the north end of the Dead Sea. The land within those four borders will belong to you.
34.13: Then Moses told the people, " You will receive the land inside these borders. It will be yours, but the LORD has commanded you to divide it among the nine and a half tribes.
34.14: The tribes of Reuben, Gad, and East Manasseh have already been given their land
34.15: across from Jericho, east of the Jordan River." The Leaders Who Will Divide the Land
34.17: " Eleazar the priest and Joshua son of Nun will divide the land for the Israelites.
34.18: One leader from each tribe will help them,
34.19: and here is the list of their names: Caleb son of Jephunneh from Judah, Shemuel son of Ammihud from Simeon, Elidad son of Chislon from Benjamin, Bukki son of Jogli from Dan, Hanniel son of Ephod from Manasseh, Kemuel son of Shiphtan from Ephraim, Elizaphan son of Parnach from Zebulun, Paltiel son of Azzan from Issachar, Ahihud son of Shelomi from Asher, and Pedahel son of Ammihud from Naphtali."
34.29: These are the men the LORD commanded to help Eleazar and Joshua divide the land for the Israelites.

35.1: While the people of Israel were still camped in the lowlands of Moab across the Jordan River from Jericho, the LORD told Moses
35.2: to say to them: When you receive your tribal lands, you must give towns and pastures to the Levi tribe.
35.3: That way, the Levites will have towns to live in and pastures for their animals.
35.4: The pasture around each of these towns must be in the shape of a square, with the town itself in the center. The pasture is to measure three thousand feet on each side, with fifteen hundred feet of land outside each of the town walls. This will be the Levites' pastureland.
35.6: Six of the towns you give them will be Safe Towns where a person who has accidentally killed someone can run for protection. But you will also give the Levites forty-two other towns,
35.7: so they will have a total of forty-eight towns with their surrounding pastures.
35.8: Since the towns for the Levites must come from Israel's own tribal lands, the larger tribes will give more towns than the smaller ones. The Safe Towns(Deuteronomy 19.1-13; Joshua 20.1-9)
35.10: to tell the people of Israel: After you have crossed the Jordan River and are settled in Canaan,
35.11: choose Safe Towns, where a person who has accidentally killed someone can run for protection.
35.12: If the victim's relatives think it was murder, they might try to take revenge. Anyone accused of murder can run to one of these Safe Towns for protection and not be killed before a trial is held.
35.13: There are to be six of these Safe Towns,
35.14: three on each side of the Jordan River.
35.15: They will be places of protection for anyone who lives in Israel and accidentally kills someone. Laws about Murder and Accidental KillingThe LORD said:
35.16: Suppose you hit someone with a piece of iron or a large stone or a dangerous wooden tool. If that person dies, then you are a murderer and must be put to death
35.19: by one of the victim's relatives. He will take revenge for his relative's death as soon as he finds you.
35.20: Or suppose you get angry and kill someone by pushing or hitting or by throwing something. You are a murderer and must be put to death by one of the victim's relatives.
35.22: But if you are not angry and accidentally kill someone in any of these ways, the townspeople must hold a trial and decide if you are guilty.
35.25: If they decide that you are innocent, you will be protected from the victim's relative and sent to stay in one of the Safe Towns until the high priest dies.
35.26: But if you ever leave the Safe Town
35.27: and are killed by the victim's relative, he cannot be punished for killing you.
35.28: You must stay inside the town until the high priest dies; only then can you go back home.
35.29: The community of Israel must always obey these laws.
35.30: Death is the penalty for murder. But no one accused of murder can be put to death unless there are at least two witnesses to the crime.
35.31: You cannot give someone money to escape the death penalty; you must pay with your own life!
35.32: And if you have been proven innocent of murder and are living in a Safe Town, you cannot pay to go back home; you must stay there until the high priest dies.
35.33: I, the LORD, live among you people of Israel, so your land must be kept pure. But when a murder takes place, blood pollutes the land, and it becomes unclean. If that happens, the murderer must be put to death, so the land will be clean again. Keep murder out of Israel!

36.1: One day the family leaders from the Gilead clan of the Manasseh tribe went to Moses and the other family leaders of Israel
36.2: and said, "Sir, the LORD has said that he will show what land each tribe will receive as their own. And the LORD has commanded you to give the daughters of our relative Zelophehad the land that he would have received.
36.3: But if they marry men from other tribes of Israel, the land they receive will become part of that tribe's inheritance and will no longer belong to us.
36.4: Even when land is returned to its original owner in the Year of Celebration, we will not get back Zelophehad's land--it will belong to the tribe into which his daughters married."
36.5: So Moses told the people that the LORD had said: These men from the Manasseh tribe are right.
36.6: I will allow Zelophehad's daughters to marry anyone, as long as those men belong to one of the clans of the Manasseh tribe.
36.7: Tribal land must not be given to another tribe--it will remain the property of the tribe that received it.
36.8: In the future, any daughter who inherits land must marry someone from her own tribe. Israel's tribal land is never to be passed from one tribe to another.
36.10: Mahlah, Tirzah, Hoglah, Milcah, and Noah the daughters of Zelophehad obeyed the LORD and married their uncles' sons
36.12: and remained part of the Manasseh tribe. So their land stayed in their father's clan.
36.13: These are the laws that the LORD gave to Moses and the Israelites while they were camped in the lowlands of Moab across the Jordan River from Jericho.

1.1: This book contains the speeches that Moses made while Israel was in the land of Moab, camped near the town of Suph in the desert east of the Jordan River. The town of Paran was in one direction from their camp, and the towns of Tophel, Laban, Hazeroth, and Dizahab were in the opposite direction. Earlier, Moses had defeated the Amorite King Sihon of Heshbon. Moses had also defeated King Og of Bashan, who used to live in Ashtaroth for part of the year and in Edrei for the rest of the year. Although it takes only eleven days to walk from Mount Sinai to Kadesh-Barnea by way of the Mount Seir Road, these speeches were not made until forty years after Israel left Egypt. The LORD's Command at Mount Sinai The LORD had given Moses his laws for the people of Israel. And on the first day of the eleventh month, Moses began explaining those laws by saying: THE FIRST SPEECH: MOSES REVIEWS THE PAST
1.6: People of Israel, when we were in our camp at Mount Sinai, the LORD our God told us: You have stayed here long enough.
1.7: Leave this place and go into the land that belongs to the Amorites and their neighbors the Canaanites. This land includes the Jordan River valley, the hill country, the western foothills, the Southern Desert, the Mediterranean seacoast, the Lebanon Mountains, and all the territory as far as the Euphrates River.
1.8: I give you this land, just as I promised your ancestors Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. Now you must go and take the land. Moses said: Leaders Were Appointed(Exodus 18.13-27)
1.9: Right after the LORD commanded us to leave Mount Sinai, I told you: Israel, being your leader is too big a job for one person.
1.10: The LORD our God has blessed us, and so now there are as many of us as there are stars in the sky.
1.11: God has even promised to bless us a thousand times more, and I pray that he will.
1.12: But I cannot take care of all your problems and settle all your arguments alone.
1.13: Each tribe must choose some experienced men who are known for their wisdom and understanding, and I will make those men the official leaders of their tribes.
1.14: You answered, " That's a good idea!"
1.15: Then I took these men, who were already wise and respected leaders, and I appointed them as your official leaders. Some of them became military officers in charge of groups of a thousand, or a hundred, or fifty, or ten,
1.16: and others became judges. I gave these judges the following instructions: When you settle legal cases, your decisions must be fair. It doesn't matter if the case is between two Israelites, or between an Israelite and a foreigner living in your community.
1.17: And it doesn't matter if one is helpless and the other is powerful. Don't be afraid of anyone! No matter who shows up in your court, God will help you make a fair decision. If any case is too hard for you, bring the people to me, and I will make the decision.
1.18: After I gave these instructions to the judges, I taught you the LORD's commands. Moses said to Israel: Men Were Sent To Explore the Hill Country(Numbers 13.1-33)
1.19: The LORD had commanded us to leave Mount Sinai and go to the hill country that belonged to the Amorites, so we started out into the huge desert. You remember how frightening it was, but soon we were at Kadesh-Barnea,
1.20: and I told you, " We have reached the hill country. It belongs to the Amorites now, but the LORD our God is giving it to us. He is the same God our ancestors worshiped, and he has told us to go in and take this land, so don't hesitate and be afraid."
1.22: Then all of you came to me and said, " Before we go into the land, let's send some men to explore it. When they come back, they can tell us about the towns we will find and what roads we should take to get there."
1.23: It seemed like a good idea, so I chose twelve men, one from each tribe.
1.24: They explored the hill country as far as Bunch Valley
1.25: and even brought back some of the fruit. They said, " The LORD our God is giving us good land." Moses said to Israel: Israel Refused To Obey the LORD(Numbers 14.1-45)
1.26: You did not want to go into the land, and you refused to obey the LORD your God.
1.27: You stayed in your tents and grumbled, " The LORD must hate us--he brought us out of Egypt, just so he could hand us over to the Amorites and get rid of us.
1.28: We are afraid, because the men who explored the land told us that the cities are large, with walls that reach to the sky. The people who live there are taller and stronger than we are, and some of them are Anakim. We have nowhere to go."
1.30: The LORD our God will lead the way. He will fight on our side, just as he did when we saw him do all those things to the Egyptians.
1.31: And you know that the LORD has taken care of us the whole time we've been in the desert, just as you might carry one of your children."
1.32: But you still would not trust the LORD,
1.33: even though he had always been with us in the desert. During the daytime, the LORD was in the cloud, leading us in the right direction and showing us where to camp. And at night, he was there in the fire.
1.34: You had made the LORD angry, and he said:
1.35: You people of this generation are evil, and I refuse to let you go into the good land that I promised your ancestors.
1.36: Caleb son of Jephunneh is the only one of your generation that I will allow to go in. He obeyed me completely, so I will give him and his descendants the land he explored.
1.37: The LORD was even angry with me because of you people, and he said, " Moses, I won't let you go into the land either.
1.38: Instead, I will let Joshua your assistant lead Israel to conquer the land. So encourage him."
1.39: Then the LORD spoke to you again: People of Israel, you said that your innocent young children would be taken prisoner in the battle for the land. But someday I will let them go into the land, and with my help they will conquer it and live there.
1.40: Now, turn around and go back into the desert by way of Red Sea Road.
1.41: Then you told me, " We disobeyed the LORD our God, but now we want to obey him. We will go into the hill country and fight, just as he told us to do." So you picked up your weapons, thinking it would be easy to take over the hill country.
1.42: But the LORD said, " Moses, warn them not to go into the hill country. I won't help them fight, and their enemies will defeat them."
1.43: I told you what the LORD had said, but you paid no attention. You disobeyed him and went into the hill country anyway. You thought you were so great!
1.44: But when the Amorites in the hill country attacked from their towns, you ran from them as you would run from a swarm of bees. The Amorites chased your troops into Seir as far as Hormah, killing them as they went.
1.45: Then you came back to the place of worship at Kadesh-Barnea and wept, but the LORD would not listen to your prayers. Israel Spent Years in the DesertMoses said to Israel:
1.46: After we had been in Kadesh for a few months, we obeyed the LORD and headed back into the desert by way of Red Sea Road.

2.1: We spent many years wandering around outside the hill country of Seir,
2.2: until the LORD said: Moses,
2.3: Israel has wandered in these hills long enough. Turn and go north.
2.4: And give the people these orders: " Be very careful, because you will soon go through the land that belongs to your relatives, the descendants of Esau. They are afraid of you,
2.5: but don't start a war with them. I have given them the hill country of Seir, so I won't give any of it to you, not even enough to set a foot on.
2.6: And as you go through their land, you will have to buy food and water from them."
2.7: The LORD has helped us and taken care of us during the past forty years that we have been in this huge desert. We've had everything we needed, and the LORD has blessed us and made us successful in whatever we have done.
2.8: We went past the territory that belonged to our relatives, the descendants of Esau. We followed Arabah Road that starts in the south at Elath and Ezion-Geber, then we turned onto the desert road that leads to Moab.
2.9: The LORD told me, " Don't try to start a war with Moab. Leave them alone, because I gave the land of Ar to them, and I will not let you have any of it." Tribes That Lived near Canaan
2.10: Before the LORD gave the Moabites their land, a large and powerful tribe lived there. They were the Emim, and they were as tall as the Anakim.
2.11: The Moabites called them Emim, though others sometimes used the name Rephaim for both the Anakim and the Emim.
2.12: The Horites used to live in Seir, but the Edomites took over that region. They killed many of the Horites and forced the rest of them to leave, just as Israel did to the people in the land that the LORD gave them. Israel Crossed the Zered GorgeMoses said to Israel:
2.13: When we came to the Zered Gorge along the southern border of Moab, the LORD told us to cross the gorge into Moab, and we did.
2.14: This was thirty-eight years after we left Kadesh-Barnea, and by that time all the men who had been in the army at Kadesh-Barnea had died, just as the LORD had said they would.
2.15: The LORD kept getting rid of them until finally none of them were left.
2.17: Then the LORD told me,
2.18: " Moses, now go past the town of Ar and cross Moab's northern border
2.19: into Ammon. But don't start a war with the Ammonites. I gave them their land, and I won't give any of it to Israel." More Nations That Lived near Canaan
2.20: Before the Ammonites conquered the land that the LORD had given them, some of the Rephaim used to live there, although the Ammonites called them Zamzummim.
2.21: The Zamzummim were a large and powerful tribe and were as tall as the Anakim. But the LORD helped the Ammonites, and they killed many of the Zamzummim and forced the rest to leave. Then the Ammonites settled there.
2.22: The LORD helped them as he had helped the Edomites, who killed many of the Horites in Seir and forced the rest to leave before settling there themselves.
2.23: A group called the Avvim used to live in villages as far south as Gaza, but the Philistines killed them and settled on their land. Israel Crossed the Arnon GorgeMoses said:
2.24: After we went through Ammon, the LORD told us: Israel, pack up your possessions, take down your tents, and cross the Arnon River gorge. The territory of the Amorite King Sihon of Heshbon lies on the other side of the river, but I now give you his land. So attack and take it!
2.25: Today I will start making all other nations afraid of you. They will tremble with fear when anyone mentions you, and they will be terrified when you show up. Moses said to Israel: The Defeat of King Sihon of Heshbon(Numbers 21.21-30)
2.26: After we had crossed the Arnon and had set up camp in the Kedemoth Desert, I sent messengers to King Sihon of Heshbon, telling him that his nation and ours could be at peace. I said:
2.27: Please let Israel go across your country. We will walk straight through, without turning off the road.
2.28: You can even sell us food and water, and we will pay with silver. We need to reach the Jordan River and cross it, because the LORD our God is giving us the land on the west side. The Edomites and Moabites have already let us cross their land. Please let us cross your land as well.
2.30: But Sihon refused to let us go across his country, because the LORD made him stubborn and eager to fight us. The LORD told me, " I am going to help you defeat Sihon and take his land, so attack him!"
2.32: We met Sihon and his army in battle at Jahaz,
2.33: and the LORD our God helped us defeat them. We killed Sihon, his sons, and everyone else in his army.
2.34: Then we captured and destroyed every town in Sihon's kingdom, killing everyone,
2.35: but keeping the livestock and everything else of value.
2.36: The LORD helped us capture every town from the Arnon River gorge north to the boundary of Gilead, including the town of Aroer on the edge of the gorge and the town in the middle of the gorge.
2.37: However, we stayed away from all the Ammonite towns, both in the hill country and near the Jabbok River, just as the LORD had commanded. Moses said to Israel:

3.1: When we turned onto the road that leads to Bashan, King Og of Bashan led out his whole army to fight us at Edrei.
3.2: But the LORD told me, " Moses, don't be afraid of King Og. I am going to help you defeat him and his army and take over his land. Destroy him and his people, just as you did with the Amorite King Sihon of Heshbon."
3.3: The LORD our God helped us destroy Og and his army and conquer his entire kingdom of Bashan, including the Argob region. His kingdom had lots of villages and sixty towns with high walls and gates that locked with bars. We completely destroyed them all, killing everyone,
3.7: but keeping the livestock and everything else of value.
3.8: Sihon and Og had ruled Amorite kingdoms east of the Jordan River. Their land stretched from the Arnon River gorge in the south to Mount Hermon in the north, and we captured it all.
3.9: Mount Hermon is called Mount Sirion by the people of Sidon, and it is called Mount Senir by the Amorites.
3.10: We captured all the towns in the highlands, all of Gilead, and all of Bashan as far as Salecah and Edrei, two of the towns that Og had ruled. Og's Coffin
3.11: King Og was the last of the Rephaim, and his coffin is in the town of Rabbah in Ammon. It is made of hard black rock and is thirteen and a half feet long and six feet wide. Moses said to Israel: The Land East of the Jordan River Is Divided(Numbers 32.1-42)
3.12: I gave some of the land and towns we captured to the tribes of Reuben and Gad. Their share started at the Arnon River gorge in the south, took in the town of Aroer on the edge of the gorge, and went far enough north to include the southern half of the Gilead region. The northern part of their land went as far east as the upper Jabbok River gorge, which formed their border with the Ammonites. I also gave them the eastern side of the Jordan River valley, from Lake Galilee south to the Dead Sea below the slopes of Mount Pisgah. I gave the northern half of Gilead and all of the Bashan region to half the tribe of Manasseh. Bashan had belonged to King Og, and the Argob region in Bashan used to be called the Land of the Rephaim. Jair from the Manasseh tribe conquered the Argob region as far west as the kingdoms of Geshur and Maacah. The Israelites even started calling Bashan by the name " Villages of Jair," and that is still its name. I gave the northern half of Gilead to the Machir clan.
3.18: At that time I told the men of Reuben, Gad, and East Manasseh: The LORD our God told me to give you this land with its towns, and that's what I have done. Now your wives and children can stay here with your large flocks of sheep and goats and your large herds of cattle. But all of you men that can serve in our army must cross the Jordan River and help the other tribes, because they are your relatives.
3.20: The LORD will let them defeat the enemy nations on the west side of the Jordan and take their land. Afterwards, you can come back here to the land I gave you.
3.21: Then I told Joshua, " You saw how the LORD our God helped us destroy King Sihon and King Og. So don't be afraid! Wherever you go, the LORD will fight on your side and help you destroy your enemies." God Refused To Let Moses Enter CanaanMoses said to Israel:
3.23: At that time I prayed and begged,
3.24: " Our LORD, it seems that you have just begun to show me your great power. No other god in the sky or on earth is able to do the mighty things that you do.
3.25: The land west of the Jordan is such good land. Please let me cross the Jordan and see the hills and the Lebanon Mountains."
3.26: But the LORD was angry with me because of you people, and he refused to listen. " That's enough!" he said. " I don't want to hear any more.
3.27: Climb to the top of Mount Pisgah and look north, south, east, and west. Take a good look, but you are not going to cross the Jordan River.
3.28: Joshua will lead Israel across the Jordan to take the land, so help him be strong and brave and tell him what he must do."
3.29: After this we stayed in the valley at Beth-Peor.

4.1: Israel, listen to these laws and teachings! If you obey them, you will live, and you will go in and take the land that the LORD is giving you. He is the God your ancestors worshiped,
4.2: and now he is your God. I am telling you everything he has commanded, so don't add anything or take anything away.
4.3: You saw how he killed everyone who worshiped the god Baal Peor.
4.4: But all of you that were faithful to the LORD your God are still alive today.
4.5: No other nation has laws that are as fair as the ones the Lord my God told me to give you. If you faithfully obey them when you enter the land, you will show other nations how wise you are. In fact, everyone that hears about your laws will say, " That great nation certainly is wise!" And what makes us greater than other nations? We have a God who is close to us and answers our prayers.
4.9: You must be very careful not to forget the things you have seen God do for you. Keep reminding yourselves, and tell your children and grandchildren as well.
4.10: Do you remember the day you stood in the LORD's presence at Mount Sinai? The LORD said, " Moses, bring the people of Israel here. I want to speak to them so they will obey me as long as they live, and so they will teach their children to obey me too."
4.11: Mount Sinai was surrounded by deep dark clouds, and fire went up to the sky. You came to the foot of the mountain,
4.12: and the LORD spoke to you from the fire. You could hear him and understand what he was saying, but you couldn't see him.
4.13: The LORD said he was making an agreement with you, and he told you that your part of the agreement is to obey the Ten Commandments. Then the LORD wrote these Commandments on two flat stones.
4.14: That's when the LORD commanded me to give you the laws and teachings you must obey in the land that you will conquer west of the Jordan River. Don't Worship IdolsMoses said to Israel:
4.15: When God spoke to you from the fire, he was invisible. So be careful
4.16: not to commit the sin of worshiping idols. Don't make idols to be worshiped, whether they are shaped like men, women,
4.17: animals, birds,
4.18: reptiles, or fish.
4.19: And when you see the sun or moon or stars, don't be tempted to bow down and worship them. The LORD put them there for all the other nations to worship.
4.20: But you are the LORD's people, because he led you through fiery trials and rescued you from Egypt.
4.21: The LORD was angry at me because of what you said, and he told me that he would not let me cross the Jordan River into the good land that he is giving you.
4.22: So I must stay here and die on this side of the Jordan, but you will cross the river and take the land.
4.23: Always remember the agreement that the LORD your God made with you, and don't make an idol in any shape or form.
4.24: The LORD will be angry if you worship other gods, and he can be like a fire destroying everything in its path.
4.25: Soon you will cross the Jordan River and settle down in the land. Then in the years to come, you will have children, and they will give you grandchildren. After many years, you might lose your sense of right and wrong and make idols, even though the LORD your God hates them. So I am giving you fair warning today, and I call the earth and the sky as witnesses. If you ever make idols, the LORD will be angry, and you won't have long to live, because the LORD will let you be wiped out.
4.27: Only a few of you will survive, and the LORD will force you to leave the land and will scatter you among the nations.
4.28: There you will have to worship gods made of wood and stone, and these are nothing but idols that can't see or hear or eat or smell.
4.29: In all of your troubles, you may finally decide that you want to worship only the LORD. And if you turn back to him and obey him completely, he will again be your God.
4.31: The LORD your God will have mercy--he won't destroy you or desert you. The LORD will remember his promise, and he will keep the agreement he made with your ancestors.
4.32: When the LORD your God brought you out of Egypt, you saw how he fought for you and showed his great power by performing terrifying miracles. You became his people, and at Mount Sinai you heard him talking to you out of fiery flames. And yet you are still alive! Has anything like this ever happened since the time God created humans? No matter where you go or who you ask, you will get the same answer. No one has ever heard of another god even trying to do such things as the LORD your God has done for you.
4.35: The LORD wants you to know he is the only true God, and he wants you to obey him. That's why he let you see his mighty miracles and his fierce fire on earth, and why you heard his voice from that fire and from the sky.
4.37: The LORD loved your ancestors and decided that you would be his people. So the LORD used his great power to bring you out of Egypt.
4.38: Now you face other nations more powerful than you are, but the LORD has already started forcing them out of their land and giving it to you.
4.39: So remember that the LORD is the only true God, whether in the sky above or on the earth below.
4.40: Today I am explaining his laws and teachings. And if you always obey them, you and your descendants will live long and be successful in the land the LORD is giving you. Safe Towns
4.41: Moses said, " People of Israel, you must set aside the following three towns east of the Jordan River as Safe Towns: Bezer in the desert highlands belonging to the Reuben tribe; Ramoth in Gilead, belonging to the Gad tribe; and Golan in Bashan, belonging to the Manasseh tribe. If you kill a neighbor without meaning to, and if you had not been angry with that person, you can run to one of these towns and find safety." Israel at Beth-Peor THE SECOND SPEECH: MOSES TELLS WHAT THE LORD DEMANDS
4.44: The Israelites had come from Egypt and were camped east of the Jordan River near Beth-Peor, when Moses gave these laws and teachings. The land around their camp had once belonged to King Sihon of Heshbon. But Moses and the Israelites defeated him
4.47: and King Og of Bashan, and took their lands. These two Amorite kings had ruled the territory east of the Jordan River
4.48: from the town of Aroer on the edge of the Arnon River gorge, north to Mount Hermon.
4.49: Their land included the eastern side of the Jordan River valley, as far south as the Dead Sea below the slopes of Mount Pisgah.

5.1: Moses called together the people of Israel and said: Today I am telling you the laws and teachings that you must follow, so listen carefully.
5.2: The LORD our God made an agreement with our nation at Mount Sinai.
5.3: That agreement wasn't only with our ancestors but with us, who are here today.
5.4: The LORD himself spoke to you out of the fire,
5.5: but you were afraid of the fire and refused to go up the mountain. So I spoke with the LORD for you, then I told you that he had said:
5.6: I am the LORD your God, the one who brought you out of Egypt where you were slaves.
5.7: Do not worship any god except me.
5.8: Do not make idols that look like anything in the sky or on earth or in the ocean under the earth.
5.9: Don't bow down and worship idols. I am the LORD your God, and I demand all your love. If you reject me and worship idols, I will punish your families for three or four generations.
5.10: But if you love me and obey my laws, I will be kind to your families for thousands of generations.
5.11: Do not misuse my name. I am the LORD your God, and I will punish anyone who misuses my name.
5.12: Show respect for the Sabbath Day--it belongs to me.
5.13: You have six days when you can do your work,
5.14: but the seventh day of the week belongs to me, your God. No one is to work on that day--not you, your children, your oxen or donkeys or any other animal, not even those foreigners who live in your towns. And don't make your slaves do any work.
5.15: This special day of rest will remind you that I reached out my mighty arm and rescued you from slavery in Egypt.
5.16: Respect your father and mother, and you will live a long and successful life in the land I am giving you.
5.17: Do not murder.
5.18: Be faithful in marriage.
5.19: Do not steal.
5.20: Do not tell lies about others.
5.21: Do not want anything that belongs to someone else. Don't want anyone's wife or husband, house, land, slaves, oxen, donkeys, or anything else.
