14.16: In fact, I knew that you would listen and save my son and me from those who want to take the land that God gave us.
14.17: I can rest easy now that you have given your decision. You know the difference between right and wrong just like an angel of God, and I pray that the LORD your God will be with you.
14.18: Then David said to the woman, "Now I'm going to ask you a question, and don't try to hide the truth!" The woman replied, "Please go ahead, Your Majesty."
14.19: David asked, "Did Joab put you up to this?" The woman answered, "Your Majesty, I swear by your life that no one can hide the truth from you. Yes, Joab did tell me what to say,
14.20: but only to show you the other side of this problem. You must be as wise as the angel of God to know everything that goes on in this country."
14.21: David turned to Joab and said, "It seems that I have already given my decision. Go and bring Absalom back."
14.22: Joab bowed very low and said, "Your Majesty, I thank you for giving your permission. It shows that you approve of me."
14.23: Joab went to Geshur to get Absalom. But when they came back to Jerusalem,
14.24: David told Joab, "I don't want to see my son Absalom. Tell him to stay away from me." So Absalom went to his own house without seeing his father. Absalom Was Handsome
14.25: No one in all Israel was as handsome and well-built as Absalom.
14.26: He got his hair cut once a year, and when the hair was weighed, it came to about five pounds.
14.27: Absalom had three sons. He also had a daughter named Tamar, who grew up to be very beautiful. Absalom Finally Sees David
14.28: Absalom lived in Jerusalem for two years without seeing his father.
14.29: He wanted Joab to talk to David for him. So one day he sent a message asking Joab to come over, but Joab refused. Absalom sent another message, but Joab still refused.
14.30: Finally, Absalom told his servants, "Joab's barley field is right next to mine. Go set it on fire!" And they did.
14.31: Joab went to Absalom's house and demanded, "Why did your servants set my field on fire?"
14.32: Absalom answered, "You didn't pay any attention when I sent for you. I want you to ask my father why he told me to come back from Geshur. I was better off there. I want to see my father now! If I'm guilty, let him kill me."
14.33: Joab went to David and told him what Absalom had said. David sent for Absalom, and Absalom came. He bowed very low, and David leaned over and kissed him.

15.1: Some time later, Absalom got himself a chariot with horses to pull it, and he had fifty men run in front.
15.2: He would get up early each morning and wait by the side of the road that led to the city gate. Anyone who had a complaint to bring to King David would have to go that way, and Absalom would ask each of them, "Where are you from?" If they said, "I'm from a tribe in the north,"
15.3: Absalom would say, "You deserve to win your case. It's too bad the king doesn't have anyone to hear complaints like yours.
15.4: I wish someone would make me the judge around here! I would be fair to everyone."
15.5: Whenever anyone would come to Absalom and start bowing down, he would reach out and hug and kiss them.
15.6: That's how he treated everyone from Israel who brought a complaint to the king. Soon everyone in Israel liked Absalom better than they liked David.
15.7: Four years later, Absalom said to David, "Please, let me go to Hebron. I have to keep a promise that I made to the LORD,
15.8: when I was living with the Arameans in Geshur. I promised that if the LORD would bring me back to live in Jerusalem, I would worship him in Hebron."
15.9: David gave his permission, and Absalom went to Hebron.
15.10: He took two hundred men from Jerusalem with him, but they had no idea what he was going to do. Absalom offered sacrifices in Hebron and sent someone to Gilo to tell David's advisor Ahithophel to come. More and more people were joining Absalom and supporting his plot. Meanwhile, Absalom had secretly sent some messengers to the northern tribes of Israel. The messengers told everyone, "When you hear the sound of the trumpets, you must shout, 'Absalom now rules as king in Hebron!'" David Has To Leave Jerusalem
15.13: A messenger came and told David, "Everyone in Israel is on Absalom's side!"
15.14: David's officials were in Jerusalem with him, and he told them, "Let's get out of here! We'll have to leave soon, or none of us will escape from Absalom. Hurry! If he moves fast, he could catch us while we're still here. Then he will kill us and everyone else in the city."
15.15: The officials said, "Your Majesty, we'll do whatever you say."
15.16: David left behind ten of his wives to take care of the palace, but the rest of his family and his officials and soldiers went with him. They stopped at the last house at the edge of the city.
15.18: Then David stood there and watched while his regular troops and his bodyguards marched past. The last group was the six hundred soldiers who had followed him from Gath. Their commander was Ittai.
15.19: David spoke to Ittai and said, "You're a foreigner from the town of Gath. You don't have to leave with us. Go back and join the new king!
15.20: You haven't been with me very long, so why should you have to follow me, when I don't even know where I'm going? Take your soldiers and go back. I pray that the Lord will be kind and faithful to you."
15.21: Ittai answered, "Your Majesty, just as surely as you and the LORD live, I will go where you go, no matter if it costs me my life."
15.22: "Then come on!" David said. So Ittai and all his men and their families walked on past David. David Sends the Sacred Chest Back to Jerusalem
15.23: The people of Jerusalem were crying and moaning as David and everyone with him passed by. He led them across Kidron Valley and along the road toward the desert.
15.24: Zadok and Abiathar the priests were there along with several men from the tribe of Levi who were carrying the sacred chest. They set the chest down, and left it there until David and his followers had gone out of the city.
15.25: Then David said: Zadok, take the sacred chest back to Jerusalem. If the LORD is pleased with me, he will bring me back and let me see it and his tent again.
15.26: But if he says he isn't pleased with me, then let him do what he knows is best.
15.27: Zadok, you are a good judge of things, so return to the city and don't cause any trouble. Take your son Ahimaaz with you. Abiathar and his son Jonathan will also go back.
15.28: I'll wait at the river crossing in the desert until I hear from you.
15.29: Zadok and Abiathar took the sacred chest back into Jerusalem and stayed there.
15.30: David went on up the slope of the Mount of Olives. He was barefoot and crying, and he covered his head to show his sorrow. Everyone with him was crying, and they covered their heads too.
15.31: Someone told David, "Ahithophel is helping Absalom plot against you!" David said, "Please, LORD, keep Ahithophel's plans from working!" David Sends Hushai Back as a Spy
15.32: When David reached the top of the Mount of Olives, he met Hushai the Archite at a place of worship. Hushai's robe was torn, and dust was on his head.
15.33: David told him: If you come with me, you might slow us down.
15.34: Go back into the city and tell Absalom, "Your Majesty, I am your servant. I will serve you now, just as I served your father in the past." Hushai, if you do that, you can help me ruin Ahithophel's plans.
15.35: Zadok and Abiathar the priests will be there with you, and you can tell them everything you hear in the palace.
15.36: Then have them send their sons Ahimaaz and Jonathan to tell me what you've heard.
15.37: David's advisor Hushai slipped back into Jerusalem, just about the same time that Absalom was coming in.

16.1: David had started down the other side of the Mount of Olives, when he was met by Ziba, the chief servant of Mephibosheth. Ziba had two donkeys that were carrying two hundred loaves of bread, a hundred handfuls of raisins, a hundred figs, and some wine.
16.2: "What's all this?" David asked. Ziba said, "The donkeys are for your family to ride. The bread and fruit are for the people to eat, and the wine is for them to drink in the desert when they are tired out."
16.3: "And where is Mephibosheth?" David asked. Ziba answered, "He stayed in Jerusalem, because he thinks the people of Israel want him to rule the kingdom of his grandfather Saul."
16.4: David then told him, "Everything that used to belong to Mephibosheth is now yours." Ziba said, "Your Majesty, I am your humble servant, and I hope you will be pleased with me." Shimei Curses David
16.5: David was near the town of Bahurim when a man came out and started cursing him. The man was Shimei the son of Gera, and he was one of Saul's distant relatives.
16.6: He threw stones at David, at his soldiers, and at everyone else, including the bodyguards who walked on each side of David.
16.7: Shimei was yelling at David, "Get out of here, you murderer! You good-for-nothing,
16.8: the LORD is paying you back for killing so many in Saul's family. You stole his kingdom, but now the LORD has given it to your son Absalom. You're a murderer, and that's why you're in such big trouble!"
16.9: Abishai said, "Your Majesty, this man is as useless as a dead dog! He shouldn't be allowed to curse you. Let me go over and chop off his head."
16.10: David replied, "What will I ever do with you and your brother Joab? If Shimei is cursing me because the LORD has told him to, then who are you to tell him to stop?"
16.11: Then David said to Abishai and all his soldiers: My own son is trying to kill me! Why shouldn't this man from the tribe of Benjamin want me dead even more? Let him curse all he wants. Maybe the LORD did tell him to curse me.
16.12: But if the LORD hears these curses and sees the trouble I'm in, maybe he will have pity on me instead.
16.13: David and the others went on down the road. Shimei went along the hillside by the road, cursing and throwing rocks and dirt at them.
16.14: When David and those with him came to the Jordan River, they were tired out. But after they rested, they felt much better. Hushai Meets Absalom
16.15: By this time, Absalom, Ahithophel, and the others had reached Jerusalem.
16.16: David's friend Hushai came to Absalom and said, "Long live the king! Long live the king!"
16.17: But Absalom asked Hushai, "Is this how you show loyalty to your friend David? Why didn't you go with him?"
16.18: Hushai answered, "The LORD and the people of Israel have chosen you to be king. I can't leave. I have to stay and serve the one they've chosen.
16.19: Besides, it seems right for me to serve you, just as I served your father." Ahithophel's Advice
16.20: Absalom turned to Ahithophel and said, "Give us your advice! What should we do?"
16.21: Ahithophel answered, "Some of your father's wives were left here to take care of the palace. You should have sex with them. Then everyone will find out that you have publicly disgraced your father. This will make you and your followers even more powerful."
16.22: Absalom had a tent set up on the flat roof of the palace, and everyone watched as he went into the tent with his father's wives.
16.23: Ahithophel gave such good advice in those days that both Absalom and David thought it came straight from God.

17.1: Ahithophel said to Absalom: Let me choose twelve thousand men and attack David tonight,
17.2: while he is tired and discouraged. He will panic, and everyone with him will run away. I won't kill anyone except David,
17.3: since he's the one you want to get rid of. Then I'll bring the whole nation back to you like a bride coming home to her husband. This way there won't be a civil war. Hushai Fools Absalom
17.4: Absalom and all the leaders of the tribes of Israel agreed that Ahithophel had a good plan.
17.5: Then Absalom said, "Bring in Hushai the Archite. Let's hear what he has to say."
17.6: Hushai came in, and Absalom told him what Ahithophel had planned. Then Absalom said, "Should we do what he says? And if we shouldn't, can you come up with anything better?"
17.7: Hushai said: This time Ahithophel's advice isn't so good.
17.8: You know that your father and his followers are real warriors. Right now they are as fierce as a mother bear whose cubs have just been killed. Besides, your father has a lot of experience in fighting wars, and he won't be spending the night with the others.
17.9: He has probably already found a hiding place in a cave or somewhere else. As soon as anyone hears that some of your soldiers have been killed, everyone will think your whole army has been destroyed.
17.10: Then even those who are as brave as a lion will lose their courage. All Israel knows what a great warrior your father is and what brave soldiers he has.
17.11: My advice is to gather all the fighting men of Israel from the town of Dan in the north down to the town of Beersheba in the south. You will have more soldiers than there are grains of sand on the seashore. Absalom, you should lead them yourself,
17.12: and we will all go to fight David wherever he is. We will fall on him just as dew falls and covers the ground. He and all his soldiers will die!
17.13: If they go into a walled town, we will put ropes around that town and drag it into the river. We won't leave even one small piece of a stone.
17.14: Absalom and the others liked Hushai's plan better than Ahithophel's plan. This was because the LORD had decided to keep Ahithophel's plan from working and to cause trouble for Absalom. Jonathan and Ahimaaz Tell David the News
17.15: Right away, Hushai went to Zadok and Abiathar. He told them what advice Ahithophel had given to Absalom and to the leaders of Israel. He also told them about the advice he had given.
17.16: Then he said, "Hurry! Send someone to warn David not to spend the night on this side of the river. He must get across the river, so he and the others won't be wiped out!"
17.17: Jonathan and Ahimaaz had been waiting at Rogel Spring because they did not want to be seen in Jerusalem. A servant girl went to the spring and gave them the message for David.
17.18: But a young man saw them and went to tell Absalom. So Jonathan and Ahimaaz left and hurried to the house of a man who lived in Bahurim. Then they climbed down into a well in the courtyard.
17.19: The man's wife put the cover on the well and poured grain on top of it, so the well could not be seen.
17.20: Absalom's soldiers came to the woman and demanded, "Where are Ahimaaz and Jonathan?" The woman answered, "They went across the stream." The soldiers went off to look for the two men. But when they did not find the men, they went back to Jerusalem.
17.21: After the soldiers had gone, Jonathan and Ahimaaz climbed out of the well. They went to David and said, "Hurry! Get ready to cross the river!" Then they told him about Ahithophel's plan.
17.22: David and the others got ready and started crossing the Jordan River. By sunrise all of them were on the other side. Ahithophel Kills Himself
17.23: When Ahithophel saw that Absalom and the leaders of Israel were not going to follow his advice, he saddled his donkey and rode back to his home in Gilo. He told his family and servants what to do. Then he hanged himself, and they buried him in his family's burial place. Absalom Puts Amasa in Charge of the Army
17.24: David went to the town of Mahanaim, and Absalom crossed the Jordan River with the army of Israel.
17.25: Absalom put Amasa in Joab's place as commander of the army. Amasa's father was Ithra from the family of Ishmael, and his mother was Abigal, the daughter of Nahash and the sister of Joab's mother Zeruiah.
17.26: The Israelites under Absalom's command set up camp in the region of Gilead. Friends Bring Supplies to David
17.27: After David came to the town of Mahanaim, Shobi the son of Nahash came from Rabbah in Ammon, Machir the son of Ammiel came from Lo-Debar, and Barzillai the Gileadite came from Rogelim.
17.28: Here is a list of what they brought: sleeping mats, blankets, bowls, pottery jars, wheat, barley, flour, roasted grain, beans, lentils, honey, yogurt, sheep, and cheese. They brought the food for David and the others because they knew that everyone would be hungry, tired, and thirsty from being out in the desert.

18.1: David divided his soldiers into groups of a hundred and groups of a thousand. Then he chose officers to be in command of each group.
18.2: He sent out one-third of his army under the command of Joab, another third under the command of Abishai the son of Zeruiah, and the rest under the command of Ittai from Gath. He told the soldiers, "I'm going into battle with you."
18.3: But the soldiers said, "No, don't go into battle with us! It won't matter to our enemies if they make us all run away, or even if they kill half of us. But you are worth ten thousand of us. It would be better for you to stay in town and send help if we need it."
18.4: David said, "All right, if you think I should." Then in a voice loud enough for everyone to hear, he said, "Joab! Abishai! Ittai! For my sake, be sure that Absalom comes back unharmed." David stood beside the town gate as his army marched past in groups of a hundred and in groups of a thousand. The war with Israel took place in Ephraim Forest. Joab Kills Absalom
18.7: Battles were being fought all over the forest, and David's soldiers were winning. Twenty thousand soldiers were killed that day, and more of them died from the dangers of the forest than from the fighting itself.
18.9: Absalom was riding his mule under a huge tree when his head caught in the branches. The mule ran off and left Absalom hanging in midair. Some of David's soldiers happened by,
18.10: and one of them went and told Joab, "I saw Absalom hanging in a tree!"
18.11: Joab said, "You saw Absalom? Why didn't you kill him? I would have given you ten pieces of silver and a special belt."
18.12: The man answered, "Even if you paid me a thousand pieces of silver here and now, I still wouldn't touch the king's son. We all heard King David tell you and Abishai and Ittai not to harm Absalom.
18.13: He always finds out what's going on. I would have been risking my life to kill Absalom, because you would have let me take the blame."
18.14: Joab said, "I'm not going to waste any more time on you!" Absalom was still alive, so Joab took three spears and stuck them through Absalom's chest.
18.15: Ten of Joab's bodyguards came over and finished him off.
18.16: Then Joab blew a trumpet to signal his troops to stop chasing Israel's soldiers.
18.17: They threw Absalom's body into a deep pit in the forest and put a big pile of rocks over it. Meanwhile, the people of Israel had all run back to their own homes.
18.18: When Absalom was alive, he had set up a stone monument for himself in King's Valley. He explained, "I don't have any sons to keep my name alive." He called it Absalom's Monument, and that is the name it still has today. Ahimaaz Wants To Tell David
18.19: Ahimaaz the son of Zadok said, "Joab, let me run and tell King David that the LORD has rescued him from his enemies."
18.20: Joab answered, "You're not the one to tell the king that his son is dead. You can take him a message some other time, but not today."
18.21: Someone from Ethiopia was standing there, and Joab told him, "Go and tell the king what you have seen." The man knelt down in front of Joab and then got up and started running.
18.22: Ahimaaz spoke to Joab again, "No matter what happens, I still want to run. And besides, the Ethiopian has already left." Joab said, "Why should you run? You won't get a reward for the news you have!"
18.23: "I'll run no matter what!" Ahimaaz insisted. "All right then, run!" Joab said. Ahimaaz took the road through the Jordan Valley and outran the Ethiopian.
18.24: Meanwhile, David was sitting between the inner and outer gates in the city wall. One of his soldiers was watching from the roof of the gate-tower. He saw a man running toward the town
18.25: and shouted down to tell David. David answered, "If he's alone, he must have some news." The runner was getting closer,
18.26: when the soldier saw someone else running. He shouted down to the gate, "Look! There's another runner!" David said, "He must have some news too."
18.27: The soldier on the roof shouted, "The first one runs just like Ahimaaz the son of Zadok." This time David said, "He's a good man. He must have some good news."
18.28: Ahimaaz called out, "We won! We won!" Then he bowed low to David and said, "Your Majesty, praise the LORD your God! He has given you victory over your enemies."
18.29: "Is my son Absalom all right?" David asked. Ahimaaz said, "When Joab sent your personal servant and me, I saw a noisy crowd. But I don't know what it was all about."
18.30: David told him, "Stand over there and wait." Ahimaaz went over and stood there.
18.31: The Ethiopian came and said, "Your Majesty, today I have good news! The LORD has rescued you from all your enemies!"
18.32: "Is my son Absalom all right?" David asked. The Ethiopian replied, "I wish that all Your Majesty's enemies and everyone who tries to harm you would end up like him!" David Cries for Absalom
18.33: David started trembling. Then he went up to the room above the city gate to cry. As he went, he kept saying, "My son Absalom! My son, my son Absalom! I wish I could have died instead of you! Absalom, my son, my son!"

19.1: Someone told Joab, "The king is crying because Absalom is dead."
19.2: David's army found out he was crying because his son had died, and their day of victory suddenly turned into a day of sadness.
19.3: The troops were sneaking into Mahanaim, just as if they had run away from a battle and were ashamed.
19.4: David held his hands over his face and kept on crying loudly, "My son, Absalom! Absalom, my son, my son!"
19.5: Joab went to the house where David was staying and told him: You've made your soldiers ashamed! Not only did they save your life, they saved your sons and daughters and wives as well.
19.6: You're more loyal to your enemies than to your friends. What you've done today has shown your officers and soldiers that they don't mean a thing to you. You would be happy if Absalom was still alive, even if the rest of us were dead.
19.7: Now get up! Go out there and thank them for what they did. If you don't, I swear by the LORD that you won't even have one man left on your side tomorrow morning. You may have had a lot of troubles in the past, but this will be the worst thing that has ever happened to you!
19.8: David got up and went to the town gate and sat down. When the people heard that he was sitting there, they came to see him. After Israel's soldiers had all returned home, Israel and Judah Want David Back
19.9: everyone in Israel started arguing. They were saying to each other, "King David rescued us from the Philistines and from our other enemies. But then we chose Absalom to be our new leader, and David had to leave the country to get away. Absalom died in battle, so why hasn't something been done to bring David back?"
19.11: When David found out what they were saying, he sent a message to Zadok and Abiathar the priests. It said: Say to the leaders of Judah, "Why are you the last tribe to think about bringing King David back home?
19.12: He is your brother, your own relative! Why haven't you done anything to bring him back?"
19.13: And tell Amasa, "You're my nephew, and with God as a witness, I swear I'll make you commander of my army instead of Joab."
19.14: Soon the tribe of Judah again became followers of David, and they sent him this message: "Come back, and bring your soldiers with you." David Starts Back for Jerusalem
19.15: David started back and had gone as far as the Jordan River when he met the people of Judah. They had gathered at Gilgal and had come to help him cross the river.
19.16: Shimei the son of Gera was there with them. He had hurried from Bahurim to meet David. Shimei was from the tribe of Benjamin, and
19.17: a thousand others from Benjamin had come with him. Ziba, the chief servant of Saul's family, also came to the Jordan River. He and his fifteen sons and twenty servants waded across to meet David.
19.18: Then they brought David's family and servants back across the river, and they did everything he wanted them to do. Shimei crossed the Jordan River and bowed down in front of David. Shimei Meets with David
19.19: He said, "Your Majesty, I beg you not to punish me! Please, forget what I did when you were leaving Jerusalem. Don't even think about it.
19.20: I know I was wrong. That's why I wanted to be the first one from the northern tribes to meet you."
19.21: But Abishai shouted, "You should be killed for cursing the LORD's chosen king!"
19.22: David said, "Abishai, what will I ever do with you and your brother Joab? Is it your job to tell me who has done wrong? I've been made king of all Israel today, and no one will be put to death!"
19.23: Then David promised Shimei that he would not be killed. Mephibosheth Meets with David
19.24: Mephibosheth, the grandson of Saul, also came to meet David. He had missed David so much that he had not taken a bath or trimmed his beard or washed his clothes the whole time David was gone.
19.25: After they had gone back to Jerusalem, Mephibosheth came to see David, who asked him, "Why didn't you go with me?"
19.26: He answered, "Your Majesty, you know I can't walk. I told my servant to saddle a donkey for me so I could go with you. But my servant left without me, and
19.27: then he lied about me. You're as wise as an angel of God, so do what you think is right.
19.28: After all, you could have killed my whole family and me. But instead, you let me eat at your own table. Your Majesty, what more could I ask?"
19.29: David answered, "You've said enough! I've decided to divide the property between you and Ziba."
19.30: Mephibosheth replied, "He can have it all! I'm just glad you've come home safely." Barzillai Returns Home
19.31: Barzillai came from Rogelim in Gilead to meet David at the Jordan River and go across with him.
19.32: Barzillai was eighty years old. He was very rich and had sent food to David in Mahanaim.
19.33: David said to him, "Cross the river and go to Jerusalem with me. I will take care of you."
19.34: Barzillai answered: Your Majesty, why should I go to Jerusalem? I don't have much longer to live.
19.35: I'm already eighty years old, and my body is almost numb. I can't taste my food or hear the sound of singing, and I would be nothing but a burden.
19.36: I'll cross the river with you, but I'll only go a little way on the other side. You don't have to be so kind to me.
19.37: Just let me return to my hometown, where I can someday be buried near my father and mother. My servant Chimham can go with you, and you can treat him as your own.
19.38: David said, "I'll take Chimham with me, and whatever you ask me to do for him, I'll do. And if there's anything else you want, I'll also do that."
19.39: David's soldiers went on across the river, while he stayed behind to tell Barzillai good-by and to wish him well. Barzillai returned home, but
19.40: Chimham crossed the river with David. All of Judah's army and half of Israel's army were there to help David cross the river. Israel and Judah Argue
19.41: The soldiers from Israel came to him and said, "Why did our relatives from Judah sneak you and your family and your soldiers across the Jordan?"
19.42: The people of Judah answered, "Why are you so angry? We are the king's relatives. He didn't give us any food, and we didn't take anything for ourselves!"
19.43: Those from Israel said, "King David belongs to us ten times more than he belongs to you. Why didn't you think we were good enough to help you? After all, we were the first ones to think of bringing him back!" The people of Judah spoke more harshly than the people of Israel.

20.1: A troublemaker from the tribe of Benjamin was there. His name was Sheba the son of Bichri, and he blew a trumpet to get everyone's attention. Then he said, "People of Israel, David the son of Jesse doesn't belong to us! Let's go home."
20.2: So they stopped following David and went off with Sheba. But the people of Judah stayed close to David all the way from the Jordan to Jerusalem. David's Ten Wives
20.3: David had left ten of his wives in Jerusalem to take care of his palace. But when he came back, he had them taken to another house, and he placed soldiers there to guard them. He gave them whatever they needed, but he never slept with any of them again. They had to live there for the rest of their lives as if they were widows. The Army Goes after Sheba
20.4: David said to Amasa, "Three days from now I want you and all of Judah's army to be here!"
20.5: Amasa started bringing the army together, but it was taking him more than three days.
20.6: So David said to Abishai, "Sheba will hurt us more than Absalom ever did. Take my best soldiers and go after him. We don't want him to take over any walled cities and get away from us." Joab Kills Amasa
20.7: Abishai left Jerusalem to try and capture Sheba. He took along Joab and his soldiers, as well as David's bodyguard and best troops.
20.8: They had gone as far as the big rock at Gibeon when Amasa caught up with them. Joab had a dagger strapped around his waist over his military uniform, but it fell out as he started toward Amasa.
20.9: Joab said, "Amasa, my cousin, how are you?" Then Joab took hold of Amasa's beard with his right hand, so that he could greet him with a kiss.
20.10: Amasa did not see the dagger in Joab's other hand. Joab stuck it in Amasa's stomach, and his insides spilled out on the ground. Joab only struck him once, but Amasa was dying. Joab and his brother Abishai went off to chase Sheba.
20.11: One of Joab's soldiers stood by Amasa and shouted, "If any of you like Joab, and if you are for David, then follow Joab!"
20.12: Amasa was still rolling in his own blood in the middle of the road. The soldier who had shouted noticed that everyone who passed by would stop, so he dragged Amasa off the road and covered him with a blanket.
20.13: After this, no one else stopped. They all walked straight past him on their way to help Joab capture Sheba. Sheba Hides Out in the Town of Abel
20.14: Sheba had gone through all of the tribes of Israel when he came to the town of Abel Beth-Maacah. All of his best soldiers met him there and followed him into the town.
20.15: Joab and his troops came and surrounded Abel, so that no one could go in or come out. They made a dirt ramp up to the town wall and then started to use a battering ram to knock the wall down. A Wise Woman Saves the Town
20.16: A wise woman shouted from the top of the wall, "Listen to me! Listen to me! I have to talk to Joab! Tell him to come here!"
20.17: When he came, the woman said, "Are you Joab?""Yes, I am," he answered. She said, "Please, listen to what I have to say." "All right," he said. "I'll listen."
20.18: She said, "Long ago people used to say, 'If you want good advice, go to the town of Abel to get it.' The answers they got here were all that was needed to settle any problem.
20.19: We are Israelites, and we want peace! You can trust us. Why are you trying to destroy a town that's like a mother in Israel? Why do you want to wipe out the LORD's people?"
20.20: Joab answered, "No, no! I'm not trying to wipe you out or destroy your town!
20.21: That's not it at all. There's a man in your town from the hill country of Ephraim. His name is Sheba, and he is the leader of a rebellion against King David. Turn him over to me, and we will leave your town alone." The woman told Joab, "We will throw his head over the wall."
20.22: She went to the people of the town and talked them into doing it. They cut off Sheba's head and threw it to Joab. Joab blew a signal on his trumpet, and the soldiers returned to their homes. Joab went back to David in Jerusalem. Another List of David's Officials (20.23 Another List of David's Officials: See also the list in 8.16,17.)
20.23: Joab was the commander of Israel's entire army. Benaiah the son of Jehoiada was in command of David's bodyguard.
20.24: Adoram was in charge of the slave-labor force. Jehoshaphat the son of Ahilud kept government records.
20.25: Sheva was the secretary. Zadok and Abiathar were the priests.
20.26: Ira from Jair was David's priest.

21.1: While David was king, there were three years in a row when the nation of Israel could not grow enough food. So David asked the LORD for help, and the LORD answered, "Saul and his family are guilty of murder, because he had the Gibeonites killed."
21.2: The Gibeonites were not Israelites; they were descendants of the Amorites. The people of Israel had promised not to kill them, but Saul had tried to kill them because he wanted Israel and Judah to control all the land. David had the Gibeonites come, and he talked with them.
21.3: He said, "What can I do to make up for what Saul did, so that you'll ask the LORD to be kind to his people again?"
21.4: The Gibeonites answered, "Silver and gold from Saul and his family are not enough. On the other hand, we don't have the right to put any Israelite to death." David said, "I'll do whatever you ask."
21.5: They replied, "Saul tried to kill all our people so that none of us would be left in the land of Israel.
21.6: Give us seven of his descendants. We will hang these men near the place where the LORD is worshiped in Gibeah, the hometown of Saul, the LORD's chosen king.""I'll give them to you," David said.
21.7: David had made a promise to Jonathan with the LORD as his witness, so he spared Jonathan's son Mephibosheth, the grandson of Saul.
21.8: But Saul and Rizpah the daughter of Aiah had two sons named Armoni and Mephibosheth. Saul's daughter Merab had five sons whose father was Adriel the son of Barzillai from Meholah. David took Rizpah's two sons and Merab's five sons and
21.9: turned them over to the Gibeonites, who hanged all seven of them on the mountain near the place where the LORD was worshiped. This happened right at the beginning of the barley harvest. Rizpah Takes Care of the Bodies
21.10: Rizpah spread out some sackcloth on a nearby rock. She wouldn't let the birds land on the bodies during the day, and she kept the wild animals away at night. She stayed there from the beginning of the harvest until it started to rain. The Burial of Saul and His Descendants
21.11: Earlier the Philistines had killed Saul and Jonathan on Mount Gilboa and had hung their bodies in the town square at Beth-Shan. The people of Jabesh in Gilead had secretly taken the bodies away, but David found out what Saul's wife Rizpah had done, and he went to the leaders of Jabesh to get the bones of Saul and his son Jonathan.
21.13: David had their bones taken to the land of Benjamin and buried in a side room in Saul's family burial place. Then he gave orders for the bones of the men who had been hanged to be buried there. It was done, and God answered prayers to bless the land. The Descendants of the Rephaim(1 Chronicles 20.4-8)
21.15: One time David got very tired when he and his soldiers were fighting the Philistines.
21.16: One of the Philistine warriors was Ishbibenob, who was a descendant of the Rephaim, and he tried to kill David. Ishbibenob was armed with a new sword, and his bronze spearhead alone weighed seven and a half pounds.
21.17: But Abishai came to the rescue and killed the Philistine. David's soldiers told him, "We can't let you risk your life in battle anymore! You give light to our nation, and we want that flame to keep burning."
21.18: There was another battle with the Philistines at Gob, where Sibbecai from Hushah killed a descendant of the Rephaim named Saph.
21.19: There was still another battle with the Philistines at Gob. A soldier named Elhanan killed Goliath from Gath, whose spear shaft was like a weaver's beam. Elhanan's father was Jari from Bethlehem.
21.20: There was another war, this time in Gath. One of the enemy soldiers was a descendant of the Rephaim. He was as big as a giant and had six fingers on each hand and six toes on each foot.
21.21: But when he made fun of Israel, David's nephew Jonathan killed him. Jonathan was the son of David's brother Shimei.
21.22: David and his soldiers killed these four men who were descendants of the Rephaim from Gath.

22.1: David sang a song to the LORD after the LORD had rescued him from his enemies, especially Saul. These are the words to David's song:
22.2: Our LORD and our God, you are my mighty rock, my fortress, my protector.
22.3: You are the rock where I am safe. You are my shield, my powerful weapon, and my place of shelter. You rescue me and keep me from being hurt.
22.4: I praise you, our LORD! I prayed to you, and you rescued me from my enemies.
22.5: Death, like ocean waves, surrounded me, and I was almost swallowed by its flooding waters.
22.6: Ropes from the world of the dead had coiled around me, and death had set a trap in my path.
22.7: I was in terrible trouble when I called out to you, but from your temple you heard me and answered my prayer.
22.8: Earth shook and shivered! The columns supporting the sky rocked back and forth. You were angry
22.9: and breathed out smoke. Scorching heat and fiery flames spewed from your mouth.
22.10: You opened the heavens like curtains, and you came down with storm clouds under your feet.
22.11: You rode on the backs of flying creatures. You appeared with the wind as wings.
22.12: Darkness was your tent! Thunderclouds filled the sky, hiding you from sight.
22.13: Fiery coals lit up the sky in front of you.
22.14: LORD Most High, your voice thundered from the heavens.
22.15: You scattered your enemies with arrows of lightning.
22.16: You roared at the sea, and its deepest channels could be seen. You snorted, and the earth shook to its foundations.
22.17: You reached down from heaven, and you lifted me from deep in the ocean.
22.18: You rescued me from enemies who were hateful and too powerful for me.
22.19: On the day disaster struck, they came and attacked, but you defended me.
22.20: When I was fenced in, you freed and rescued me because you love me.
22.21: You are good to me, LORD, because I do right, and you reward me because I am innocent.
22.22: I do what you want and never turn to do evil.
22.23: I keep your laws in mind and never turn away from your teachings.
22.24: I obey you completely and guard against sin.
22.25: You have been good to me because I do right; you have rewarded me for being innocent by your standards.
22.26: You are always loyal to your loyal people, and you are faithful to the faithful.
22.27: With all who are sincere you are sincere, but you treat the unfaithful as their deeds deserve.
22.28: You rescue the humble, but you look for ways to put down the proud.
22.29: Our LORD and God, you are my lamp. You turn darkness to light.
22.30: You help me defeat armies and capture cities.
22.31: Your way is perfect, LORD, and your word is correct. You are a shield for those who run to you for help.
22.32: You alone are God! Only you are a mighty rock.
22.33: You are my strong fortress, and you set me free.
22.34: You make my feet run as fast as those of a deer, and you help me stand on the mountains.
22.35: You teach my hands to fight and my arms to use a bow of bronze.
22.36: You alone are my shield, and by coming to help me, you have made me famous.
22.37: You clear the way for me, and now I won't stumble.
22.38: I kept chasing my enemies until I caught them and destroyed them.
22.39: I destroyed them! I stuck my sword through my enemies, and they were crushed under my feet.
22.40: You helped me win victories and forced my attackers to fall victim to me.
22.41: You made my enemies run, and I killed them.
22.42: They cried out for help, but no one saved them; they called out to you, but there was no answer.
22.43: I ground them to dust, and I squashed them like mud in the streets.
22.44: You rescued me from my stubborn people and made me the leader of foreign nations, who are now my slaves.
22.46: They have lost all courage and from their fortresses they come trembling.
22.47: You are the living LORD! I will praise you! You are a mighty rock. I will honor you for keeping me safe.
22.48: You took revenge for me, and you put nations in my power.
22.49: You protected me from violent enemies, and you made me much greater than all of them.
22.50: I will praise you, LORD, and I will honor you among the nations.
22.51: You give glorious victories to your chosen king. Your faithful love for David and for his descendants will never end.

23.1: These are the last words of David the son of Jesse. The God of Jacob chose David and made him a great king. The Mighty God of Israel loved him. When God told him to speak, David said:
23.2: The Spirit of the LORD has told me what to say.
23.3: Our Mighty Rock, the God of Jacob, told me, "A ruler who obeys God and does right
23.4: is like the sunrise on a cloudless day, or like rain that sparkles on the grass."
23.5: I have ruled this way, and God will never break his promise to me. God's promise is complete and unchanging; he will always help me and give me what I hope for.
23.6: But evil people are pulled up like thornbushes. They are not dug up by hand,
23.7: but with a sharp spear and are burned on the spot. The Three Warriors(1 Chronicles 11.10-19)
23.8: These are the names of David's warriors: Ishbosheth the son of Hachmon was the leader of the Three Warriors. In one battle, he killed eight hundred men with his spear.
23.9: The next one of the Three Warriors was Eleazar the son of Dodo the Ahohite. One time when the Philistines were at war with Israel, he and David dared the Philistines to fight them. Every one of the Israelite soldiers turned and ran,
23.10: except Eleazar. He killed Philistines until his hand was cramped, and he couldn't let go of his sword. When Eleazar finished, all the Israelite troops had to do was come back and take the enemies' weapons and armor. The LORD gave Israel a great victory that day.
23.11: Next was Shammah the son of Agee the Hararite. One time the Philistines brought their army together to destroy a crop of peas growing in a field near Lehi. The rest of Israel's soldiers ran away from the Philistines,
23.12: but Shammah stood in the middle of the field and killed the Philistines. The crops were saved, and the LORD gave Israel a great victory.
23.13: One year at harvest time, the Three Warriors went to meet David at Adullam Cave. The Philistine army had set up camp in Rephaim Valley
23.14: and had taken over Bethlehem. David was in his fortress,
23.15: and he was very thirsty. He said, "I wish I had a drink from the well by the gate at Bethlehem."
23.16: The Three Warriors sneaked into the Philistine camp and got some water from the well near Bethlehem's gate. But after they brought the water back to David, he refused to drink it. Instead, he poured it out as a sacrifice
23.17: and said to the LORD, "I can't drink this water! It's like the blood of these men who risked their lives to get it for me." The Three Warriors did these brave deeds. The Thirty Warriors(1 Chronicles 11.20-47)
23.18: Joab's brother Abishai was the leader of the Thirty Warriors, and in one battle he killed three hundred men with his spear. He was as famous as the Three Warriors
23.19: and certainly just as famous as the rest of the Thirty Warriors. He was the commander of the Thirty Warriors, but he still did not become one of the Three Warriors.
23.20: Benaiah the son of Jehoiada was a brave man from Kabzeel who did some amazing things. He killed two of Moab's best fighters, and on a snowy day he went down into a pit and killed a lion.
23.21: Another time, he killed an Egyptian, as big as a giant. The Egyptian was armed with a spear, but Benaiah only had a club. Benaiah grabbed the spear from the Egyptian and killed him with it.
23.22: Benaiah did these things. He never became one of the Three Warriors, but he was just as famous as they were and certainly just as famous as the rest of the Thirty Warriors. David made him the leader of his bodyguard.
23.24: Some of the Thirty Warriors were: Asahel the brother of Joab Elhanan the son of Dodo from Bethlehem Shammah from Harod Elika from Harod Helez the Paltite Ira the son of Ikkesh from Tekoa Abiezer from Anathoth Mebunnai the Hushathite Zalmon the Ahohite Maharai from Netophah Heleb the son of Baanah from Netophah Ittai the son of Ribai from Gibeah of the tribe of Benjamin Benaiah from Pirathon Hiddai from the streams on Mount Gaash Abialbon from Beth-Arabah Azmaveth from Bahurim Eliahba from Shaalbon Jashen Jonathan the son of Shammah the Hararite Ahiam the son of Sharar the Hararite Eliphelet the son of Ahasbai from Maacah Eliam the son of Ahithophel from Gilo Hezro from Carmel Paarai the Arbite Igal the son of Nathan from Zobah Bani the Gadite Zelek from Ammon Naharai from Beeroth, who carried the weapons of Joab the son of Zeruiah Ira the Ithrite Gareb the Ithrite Uriah the Hittite There were thirty-seven in all.

24.1: The LORD was angry at Israel again, and he made David think it would be a good idea to count the people in Israel and Judah.
24.2: So David told Joab and the army officers, "Go to every tribe in Israel, from the town of Dan in the north all the way south to Beersheba, and count everyone who can serve in the army. I want to know how many there are."
24.3: Joab answered, "I hope the LORD your God will give you a hundred times more soldiers than you already have. I hope you will live to see that day! But why do you want to do a thing like this?"
24.4: But when David refused to change his mind, Joab and the army officers went out and started counting the people.
24.5: They crossed the Jordan River and began with Aroer and the town in the middle of the river valley. From there they went toward Gad and on as far as Jazer.
24.6: They went to Gilead and to Kadesh in Syria. Then they went to Dan, Ijon, and on toward Sidon.
24.7: They came to the fortress of Tyre, then went through every town of the Hivites and the Canaanites. Finally, they went to Beersheba in the Southern Desert of Judah.
24.8: After they had gone through the whole land, they went back to Jerusalem. It had taken them nine months and twenty days.
24.9: Joab came and told David, "In Israel there are eight hundred thousand who can serve in the army, and in Judah there are five hundred thousand." The LORD Punishes David(1 Chronicles 21.7-17)
24.10: After David had everyone counted, he felt guilty and told the LORD, "What I did was stupid and terribly wrong. LORD, please forgive me."
24.11: Before David even got up the next morning, the LORD had told David's prophet Gad
24.12: to take a message to David. Gad went to David and told him: You must choose one of three ways for the LORD to punish you: Will there be seven years when the land won't grow enough food for your people? Or will your enemies chase you and make you run from them for three months? Or will there be three days of horrible disease in your land? Think about it and decide, because I have to give your answer to God, who sent me.
24.14: David was really frightened and said, "It's a terrible choice to make! But the LORD is kind, and I'd rather have him punish us than for anyone else to do it."
24.15: So that morning, the LORD sent an angel to spread a horrible disease everywhere in Israel, from Dan to Beersheba. And before it was over, seventy thousand people had died. When the angel was about to destroy Jerusalem, the LORD felt sorry for all the suffering he had caused and told the angel, "That's enough! Don't touch them." This happened at the threshing place that belonged to Araunah the Jebusite.
24.17: David saw the angel killing everyone and told the LORD, "These people are like sheep with me as their shepherd. I have sinned terribly, but they have done nothing wrong. Please, punish me and my family instead of them!" David Buys Araunah's Threshing Place(1 Chronicles 21.18--22.1)
24.18: That same day the prophet Gad came and told David, "Go to the threshing place that belongs to Araunah and build an altar there for the LORD." So David went.
24.20: Araunah looked and saw David and his soldiers coming up toward him. He went over to David, bowed down low,
24.21: and said, "Your Majesty! Why have you come to see me?" David answered, "I've come to buy your threshing place. I have to build the LORD an altar here, so this disease will stop killing the people."
24.22: Araunah said, "Take whatever you want and offer your sacrifice. Here are some oxen for the sacrifice. You can use the threshing-boards and the wooden yokes for the fire.
24.23: Take them--they're yours! I hope the LORD your God will be pleased with you."
24.24: But David answered, "No! I have to pay you what they're worth. I can't offer the LORD my God a sacrifice that I got for nothing." So David bought the threshing place and the oxen for fifty pieces of silver.
24.25: Then he built an altar for the LORD. He sacrificed animals and burned them on the altar. The LORD answered the prayers of the people, and no one else died from the terrible disease.

1.1: King David was now an old man, and he always felt cold, even under a lot of blankets.
1.2: His officials said, "Your Majesty, we will look for a young woman to take care of you. She can lie down beside you and keep you warm."
1.3: They looked everywhere in Israel until they found a very beautiful young woman named Abishag, who lived in the town of Shunem. They brought her to David, and she took care of him. But David did not have sex with her. Adonijah Tries To Become King
1.5: Adonijah was the son of David and Haggith. He was Absalom's younger brother and was very handsome. One day, Adonijah started bragging, "I'm going to make myself king!" So he got some chariots and horses, and he hired fifty men as bodyguards. David did not want to hurt his feelings, so he never asked Adonijah why he was doing these things.
1.7: Adonijah met with Joab the son of Zeruiah and Abiathar the priest and asked them if they would help him become king. Both of them agreed to help.
1.8: But Zadok the priest, Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, Nathan the prophet, Shimei, Rei, and David's bodyguards all refused.
1.9: Adonijah invited his brothers and David's officials from Judah to go with him to Crawling Rock near Rogel Spring, where he sacrificed some sheep, cattle, and fat calves.
1.10: But he did not invite Nathan, Benaiah, David's bodyguards, or his own brother Solomon.
1.11: When Nathan heard what had happened, he asked Bathsheba, Solomon's mother: Have you heard that Adonijah the son of Haggith has made himself king? But David doesn't know a thing about it.
1.12: You and your son Solomon will be killed, unless you do what I tell you.
1.13: Go say to David, "You promised me that Solomon would be the next king. So why is Adonijah now king?"
1.14: While you are still talking to David, I'll come in and tell him that everything you said is true.
1.15: Meanwhile, David was in his bedroom where Abishag was taking care of him because he was so old. Bathsheba went in
1.16: and bowed down. "What can I do for you?" David asked.
1.17: Bathsheba answered: Your Majesty, you promised me in the name of the LORD your God that my son Solomon would be the next king.
1.18: But Adonijah has already been made king, and you didn't know anything about it.
1.19: He sacrificed a lot of cattle, calves, and sheep. And he invited Abiathar the priest, Joab your army commander, and all your sons to be there, except Solomon, your loyal servant.
1.20: Your Majesty, everyone in Israel is waiting for you to announce who will be the next king.
1.21: If you don't, they will say that Solomon and I have rebelled. They will treat us like criminals and kill us as soon as you die.
1.22: Just then, Nathan the prophet arrived.
1.23: Someone told David that he was there, and Nathan came in. He bowed with his face to the ground
1.24: and said: Your Majesty, did you say that Adonijah would be king?
1.25: Earlier today, he sacrificed a lot of cattle, calves, and sheep. He invited the army commanders, Abiathar, and all your sons to be there. Right now they are eating and drinking and shouting, "Long live King Adonijah!"
1.26: But he didn't invite me or Zadok the priest or Benaiah or Solomon.
1.27: Did you say they could do this without telling the rest of us who would be the next king? Solomon Becomes King
1.28: David said, "Tell Bathsheba to come here." She came and stood in front of him.
1.29: Then he said, "The living LORD God of Israel has kept me safe. And so today, I will keep the promise I made to you in his name: Solomon will be the next king!"
1.31: Bathsheba bowed with her face to the ground and said, "Your Majesty, I pray that you will live a long time!"
1.32: Then David said, "Tell Zadok, Nathan, and Benaiah to come here." When they arrived,
1.33: he told them: Take along some of my officials and have Solomon ride my own mule to Gihon Spring.
1.34: When you get there, Zadok and Nathan will make Solomon the new king of Israel. Then after the ceremony is over, have someone blow a trumpet and tell everyone to shout, "Long live King Solomon!"
1.35: Bring him back here, and he will take my place as king. He is the one I have chosen to rule Israel and Judah.
1.36: Benaiah answered, "We will do it, Your Majesty. I pray that the LORD your God will let it happen.
1.37: The LORD has always watched over you, and I pray that he will now watch over Solomon. May the LORD help Solomon to be an even greater king than you."
1.38: Zadok, Nathan, and Benaiah left and took along the two groups of David's special bodyguards. Solomon rode on David's mule as they led him to Gihon Spring.
1.39: Zadok the priest brought some olive oil from the sacred tent and poured it on Solomon's head to show that he was now king. A trumpet was blown and everyone shouted, "Long live King Solomon!"
1.40: Then they played flutes and celebrated as they followed Solomon back to Jerusalem. They made so much noise that the ground shook.
1.41: Adonijah and his guests had almost finished eating when they heard the noise. Joab also heard the trumpet and asked, "What's all that noise about in the city?"
1.42: Just then, Jonathan son of Abiathar came running up. "Come in," Adonijah said. "An important man like you must have some good news."
1.43: Jonathan answered: No, I don't! David has just announced that Solomon will be king.
1.44: Solomon rode David's own mule to Gihon Spring, and Zadok, Nathan, Benaiah, and David's special bodyguards went with him. When they got there, Zadok and Nathan made Solomon king. Then everyone celebrated all the way back to Jerusalem. That's the noise you hear in the city.
1.47: And listen to this! David's officials told him, "We pray that your God will help Solomon to be an even greater king!" David was in his bed at the time, but he bowed
1.48: and prayed, "I praise you, LORD God of Israel. You have made my son Solomon king and have let me live to see it."
1.49: Adonijah's guests shook with fear when they heard this news, and they left as fast as they could.
1.50: Adonijah himself was afraid of what Solomon might do to him, so he ran to the sacred tent and grabbed hold of the corners of the altar for protection.
1.51: Someone told Solomon, "Adonijah is afraid of you and is holding onto the corners of the altar. He wants you to promise that you won't kill him."
1.52: Solomon answered, "If Adonijah doesn't cause any trouble, I won't hurt him. But if he does, I'll have him killed."
1.53: Then he sent someone to the altar to get Adonijah. After Adonijah came and bowed down, Solomon said, "Adonijah, go home."

2.1: Not long before David died, he told Solomon:
2.2: My son, I will soon die, as everyone must. But I want you to be strong and brave.
2.3: Do what the LORD your God commands and follow his teachings. Obey everything written in the Law of Moses. Then you will be a success, no matter what you do or where you go.
2.4: You and your descendants must always faithfully obey the LORD. If you do, he will keep the solemn promise he made to me that someone from our family will always be king of Israel.
2.5: Solomon, don't forget what Joab did to me by killing Abner son of Ner and Amasa son of Jether, the two commanders of Israel's army. He killed them as if they were his enemies in a war, but he did it when there was no war. He is guilty, and now it's up to you to punish him
2.6: in the way you think best. Whatever you do, don't let him die peacefully in his old age.
2.7: The sons of Barzillai from Gilead helped me when I was running from your brother Absalom. Be kind to them and let them eat at your table.
2.8: Be sure to do something about Shimei son of Gera from Bahurim in the territory of Benjamin. He cursed and insulted me the day I went to Mahanaim. But later, when he came to meet me at the Jordan River, I promised that I wouldn't kill him.
2.9: Now you must punish him. He's an old man, but you're wise enough to know that you must have him killed. David Dies
2.10: David was king of Israel forty years. He ruled seven years from Hebron and thirty-three years from Jerusalem. Then he died and was buried in Jerusalem.
2.12: His son Solomon became king and took control of David's kingdom. Adonijah Is Killed
2.13: One day, Adonijah went to see Bathsheba, Solomon's mother, and she asked, "Is this a friendly visit?" "Yes.
2.14: I just want to talk with you." "All right," she told him, "go ahead."
2.15: "You know that I was king for a little while," Adonijah replied. "And everyone in Israel accepted me as their ruler. But the LORD wanted my brother to be king, so now things have changed.
2.16: Would you do me a favor?" "What do you want?" Bathsheba asked.
2.17: "Please ask Solomon to let me marry Abishag. He won't say no to you."
2.18: "All right," she said. "I'll ask him."
2.19: When Bathsheba went to see Solomon, he stood up to meet her, then bowed low. He sat back down and had another throne brought in, so his mother could sit at his right side.
2.20: Bathsheba sat down and then asked, "Would you do me a small favor?" Solomon replied, "Mother, just tell me what you want, and I will do it."
2.21: "Allow your brother Adonijah to marry Abishag," she answered.
2.22: Solomon said: What? Let my older brother marry Abishag? You may as well ask me to let him rule the kingdom! And why don't you ask such favors for Abiathar and Joab?
2.23: I swear in the name of the LORD that Adonijah will die because he asked for this! If he doesn't, I pray that God will severely punish me.
2.24: The LORD made me king in my father's place and promised that the kings of Israel would come from my family. Yes, I swear by the living LORD that Adonijah will die today.
2.25: "Benaiah," Solomon shouted, "go kill Adonijah." So Adonijah died. Abiathar Is Sent Back Home
2.26: Solomon sent for Abiathar the priest and said: Abiathar, go back home to Anathoth! You ought to be killed too, but I won't do it now. When my father David was king, you were in charge of the sacred chest, and you went through a lot of hard times with my father.
2.27: But I won't let you be a priest of the LORD anymore. And so the promise that the LORD had made at Shiloh about the family of Eli came true. Joab Is Killed
2.28: Joab had not helped Absalom try to become king, but he had helped Adonijah. So when Joab learned that Adonijah had been killed, he ran to the sacred tent and grabbed hold of the corners of the altar for protection.
2.29: When Solomon heard about this, he sent someone to ask Joab, "Why did you run to the altar?" Joab sent back his answer, "I was afraid of you, and I ran to the LORD for protection." Then Solomon shouted, "Benaiah, go kill Joab!"
2.30: Benaiah went to the sacred tent and yelled, "Joab, the king orders you to come out!" "No!" Joab answered. "Kill me right here." Benaiah went back and told Solomon what Joab had said.
2.31: Solomon replied: Do what Joab said. Kill him and bury him! Then my family and I won't be responsible for what he did to Abner the commander of Israel's army and to Amasa the commander of Judah's army. He killed those innocent men without my father knowing about it. Both of them were better men than Joab. Now the LORD will make him pay for those murders.
2.33: Joab's family will always suffer because of what he did, but the LORD will always bless David's family and his kingdom with peace.
2.34: Benaiah went back and killed Joab. His body was taken away and buried near his home in the desert.
2.35: Solomon put Benaiah in Joab's place as army commander, and he put Zadok in Abiathar's place as priest. Shimei Is Killed
2.36: Solomon sent for Shimei and said, "Build a house here in Jerusalem and live in it. But whatever you do, don't leave the city!
2.37: If you ever cross Kidron Valley and leave Jerusalem, you will be killed. And it will be your own fault."
2.38: "That's fair, Your Majesty," Shimei answered. "I'll do that." So Shimei lived in Jerusalem from then on.
2.39: About three years later, two of Shimei's servants ran off to King Achish in Gath. When Shimei found out where they were,
2.40: he saddled his donkey and went after them. He found them and brought them back to Jerusalem.
2.41: Someone told Solomon that Shimei had gone to Gath and was back.
2.42: Solomon sent for him and said: Shimei, you promised in the name of the LORD that you would never leave Jerusalem. I warned you that you would die if you did. You agreed that this was fair, didn't you?
2.43: You have disobeyed me and have broken the promise you made to the LORD.
2.44: I know you remember all the cruel things you did to my father David. Now the LORD is going to punish you for what you did.
2.45: But the LORD will bless me and make my father's kingdom strong forever.
2.46: "Benaiah," Solomon shouted, "kill Shimei." So Shimei died. Solomon was now in complete control of his kingdom.

3.1: Solomon signed a treaty with the king of Egypt and married his daughter. She lived in the older part of Jerusalem until the palace, the LORD's temple, and the wall around Jerusalem were completed.
3.2: At that time, there was no temple for worshiping the LORD, and everyone offered sacrifices at the local shrines.
3.3: Solomon loved the LORD and followed his father David's instructions, but Solomon also offered sacrifices and burned incense at the shrines.
3.4: The most important shrine was in Gibeon, and Solomon had offered more than a thousand sacrifices on that altar.
3.5: One night while Solomon was in Gibeon, the LORD God appeared to him in a dream and said, "Solomon, ask for anything you want, and I will give it to you."
3.6: Solomon answered: My father David, your servant, was honest and did what you commanded. You were always loyal to him, and you gave him a son who is now king.
3.7: LORD God, I'm your servant, and you've made me king in my father's place. But I'm very young and know so little about being a leader.
3.8: And now I must rule your chosen people, even though there are too many of them to count.
3.9: Please make me wise and teach me the difference between right and wrong. Then I will know how to rule your people. If you don't, there is no way I could rule this great nation of yours.
3.10: God said: Solomon, I'm pleased that you asked for this. You could have asked to live a long time or to be rich. Or you could have asked for your enemies to be destroyed. Instead, you asked for wisdom to make right decisions.
3.12: So I'll make you wiser than anyone who has ever lived or ever will live.
3.13: I'll also give you what you didn't ask for. You'll be rich and respected as long as you live, and you'll be greater than any other king.
3.14: If you obey me and follow my commands, as your father David did, I'll let you live a long time.
3.15: Solomon woke up and realized that God had spoken to him in the dream. He went back to Jerusalem and stood in front of the sacred chest, where he offered sacrifices to please the Lord and sacrifices to ask his blessing. Then Solomon gave a feast for his officials. Solomon Makes a Difficult Decision
3.16: One day two women came to King Solomon,
3.17: and one of them said: Your Majesty, this woman and I live in the same house. Not long ago my baby was born at home,
3.18: and three days later her baby was born. Nobody else was there with us.
3.19: One night while we were all asleep, she rolled over on her baby, and he died.
3.20: Then while I was still asleep, she got up and took my son out of my bed. She put him in her bed, then she put her dead baby next to me.
3.21: In the morning when I got up to feed my son, I saw that he was dead. But when I looked at him in the light, I knew he wasn't my son.
3.22: "No!" the other woman shouted. "He was your son. My baby is alive!" "The dead baby is yours," the first woman yelled. "Mine is alive!" They argued back and forth in front of Solomon,
3.23: until finally he said, "Both of you say this live baby is yours.
3.24: Someone bring me a sword." A sword was brought, and Solomon ordered,
3.25: "Cut the baby in half! That way each of you can have part of him."
3.26: "Please don't kill my son," the baby's mother screamed. "Your Majesty, I love him very much, but give him to her. Just don't kill him." The other woman shouted, "Go ahead and cut him in half. Then neither of us will have the baby."
3.27: Solomon said, "Don't kill the baby." Then he pointed to the first woman, "She is his real mother. Give the baby to her."
3.28: Everyone in Israel was amazed when they heard how Solomon had made his decision. They realized that God had given him wisdom to judge fairly.

4.1: Here is a list of Solomon's highest officials while he was king of Israel: Azariah son of Zadok was the priest; Elihoreph and Ahijah sons of Shisha were the secretaries; Jehoshaphat son of Ahilud kept the government records; Benaiah son of Jehoiada was the army commander; Zadok and Abiathar were priests; Azariah son of Nathan was in charge of the regional officers; Zabud son of Nathan was a priest and the king's advisor; Ahishar was the prime minister; Adoniram son of Abda was in charge of the forced labor.
4.7: Solomon chose twelve regional officers, who took turns bringing food for him and his household. Each officer provided food from his region for one month of the year.
4.8: These were the twelve officers: The son of Hur was in charge of the hill country of Ephraim.
4.9: The son of Deker was in charge of the towns of Makaz, Shaalbim, Beth-Shemesh, and Elon-Beth-Hanan.
4.10: The son of Hesed was in charge of the towns of Arubboth and Socoh, and the region of Hepher.
4.11: The son of Abinadab was in charge of Naphath-Dor and was married to Solomon's daughter Taphath.
4.12: Baana son of Ahilud was in charge of the towns of Taanach and Megiddo. He was also in charge of the whole region of Beth-Shan near the town of Zarethan, south of Jezreel from Beth-Shan to Abel-Meholah to the other side of Jokmeam.
4.13: The son of Geber was in charge of the town of Ramoth in Gilead and the villages in Gilead belonging to the family of Jair, a descendant of Manasseh. He was also in charge of the region of Argob in Bashan, which had sixty walled towns with bronze bars on their gates.
4.14: Ahinadab son of Iddo was in charge of the territory of Mahanaim.
4.15: Ahimaaz was in charge of the territory of Naphtali and was married to Solomon's daughter Basemath.
4.16: Baana son of Hushai was in charge of the territory of Asher and the town of Bealoth.
4.17: Jehoshaphat son of Paruah was in charge of the territory of Issachar.
4.18: Shimei son of Ela was in charge of the territory of Benjamin.
4.19: Geber son of Uri was in charge of Gilead, where King Sihon of the Amorites and King Og of Bashan had lived. And one officer was in charge of the territory of Judah. The Size of Solomon's Kingdom
4.20: There were so many people living in Judah and Israel while Solomon was king that they seemed like grains of sand on a beach. Everyone had enough to eat and drink, and they were happy.
4.21: Solomon ruled every kingdom between the Euphrates River and the land of the Philistines down to Egypt. These kingdoms paid him taxes as long as he lived.
4.22: Every day, Solomon needed one hundred fifty bushels of fine flour, three hundred bushels of coarsely-ground flour,
4.23: ten grain-fed cattle, twenty pasture-fed cattle, one hundred sheep, as well as deer, gazelles, and geese.
4.24: Solomon ruled the whole region west of the Euphrates River, from Tiphsah to Gaza, and he was at peace with all of the countries around him.
4.25: Everyone living in Israel, from the town of Dan in the north to Beersheba in the south, was safe as long as Solomon lived. Each family sat undisturbed beneath its own grape vines and fig trees.
4.26: Solomon had forty thousand stalls of chariot horses and twelve thousand chariot soldiers.
4.27: Each of the twelve regional officers brought food to Solomon and his household for one month of the year. They provided everything he needed,
4.28: as well as barley and straw for the horses. Solomon's Wisdom
4.29: Solomon was brilliant. God had blessed him with insight and understanding.
4.30: He was wiser than anyone else in the world, including the wisest people of the east and of Egypt. He was even wiser than Ethan the Ezrahite, and Mahol's three sons, Heman, Calcol, and Darda. Solomon became famous in every country around Judah and Israel.
4.32: Solomon wrote three thousand wise sayings and composed more than one thousand songs.
4.33: He could talk about all kinds of plants, from large trees to small bushes, and he taught about animals, birds, reptiles, and fish.
4.34: Kings all over the world heard about Solomon's wisdom and sent people to listen to him teach.

5.1: King Hiram of Tyre had always been friends with Solomon's father David. When Hiram learned that Solomon was king, he sent some of his officials to meet with Solomon.
5.2: Solomon sent a message back to Hiram:
5.3: Remember how my father David wanted to build a temple where the LORD his God could be worshiped? But enemies kept attacking my father's kingdom, and he never had the chance.
5.4: Now, thanks to the LORD God, there is peace in my kingdom and no trouble or threat of war anywhere.
5.5: The LORD God promised my father that when his son became king, he would build a temple for worshiping the LORD. So I've decided to do that.
5.6: I'd like you to have your workers cut down cedar trees in Lebanon for me. I will pay them whatever you say and will even have my workers help them. We both know that your workers are more experienced than anyone else at cutting lumber.
5.7: Hiram was so happy when he heard Solomon's request that he said, "I am grateful that the LORD gave David such a wise son to be king of that great nation!"
5.8: Then he sent back his answer: I received your message and will give you all the cedar and pine logs you need.
5.9: My workers will carry them down from Lebanon to the Mediterranean Sea. They will tie the logs together and float them along the coast to wherever you want them. Then they will untie the logs, and your workers can take them from there. To pay for the logs, you can provide the grain I need for my household.
5.10: Hiram gave Solomon all the cedar and pine logs he needed.
5.11: In return, Solomon gave Hiram about one hundred twenty-five thousand bushels of wheat and about one thousand one hundred gallons of pure olive oil each year.
5.12: The LORD kept his promise and made Solomon wise. Hiram and Solomon signed a treaty and never went to war against each other. Solomon's Workers
5.13: Solomon ordered thirty thousand people from all over Israel to cut logs for the temple,
5.14: and he put Adoniram in charge of these workers. Solomon divided them into three groups of ten thousand. Each group worked one month in Lebanon and had two months off at home.
5.15: He also had eighty thousand workers to cut stone in the hill country of Israel, seventy thousand workers to carry the stones,
5.16: and over three thousand assistants to keep track of the work and to supervise the workers.
5.17: He ordered the workers to cut and shape large blocks of good stone for the foundation of the temple.
5.18: Solomon's and Hiram's men worked with men from the city of Gebal, and together they got the stones and logs ready for the temple.

6.1: Solomon's workers started building the temple during Ziv, the second month of the year. It had been four years since Solomon became king of Israel, and four hundred eighty years since the people of Israel left Egypt.
6.2: The inside of the LORD's temple was ninety feet long, thirty feet wide, and forty-five feet high.
6.3: A fifteen-foot porch went all the way across the front of the temple.
6.4: The windows were narrow on the outside but wide on the inside.
6.5: Along the sides and back of the temple, there were three levels of storage rooms. The rooms on the bottom level were seven and a half feet wide, the rooms on the middle level were nine feet wide, and those on the top level were ten and a half feet wide. There were ledges on the outside of the temple that supported the beams of the storage rooms, so that nothing was built into the temple walls.
6.7: Solomon did not want the noise of hammers and axes to be heard at the place where the temple was being built. So he had the workers shape the blocks of stone at the quarry.
6.8: The entrance to the bottom storage rooms was on the south side of the building, and stairs to the other rooms were also there.
6.9: The roof of the temple was made out of beams and cedar boards. The workers finished building the outside of the temple.
6.10: Storage rooms seven and a half feet high were all around the temple, and they were attached to the temple by cedar beams.
6.11: The LORD told Solomon:
6.12: If you obey my commands and do what I say, I will keep the promise I made to your father David. I will live among my people Israel in this temple you are building, and I will not desert them.
6.14: So Solomon's workers finished building the temple. The Inside of the Temple Is Furnished(2 Chronicles 3.8-14)
6.15: The floor of the temple was made out of pine, and the walls were lined with cedar from floor to ceiling.
6.16: The most holy place was in the back of the temple, and it was thirty feet square. Cedar boards standing from floor to ceiling separated it from the rest of the temple.
6.17: The temple's main room was sixty feet long, and it was in front of the most holy place.
6.18: The inside walls were lined with cedar to hide the stones, and the cedar was decorated with carvings of gourds and flowers.
6.19: The sacred chest was kept in the most holy place.
6.20: This room was thirty feet long, thirty feet wide, and thirty feet high, and it was lined with pure gold. There were also gold chains across the front of the most holy place. The inside of the temple, as well as the cedar altar in the most holy place, was covered with gold.
6.23: Solomon had two statues of winged creatures made from olive wood to put in the most holy place. Each creature was fifteen feet tall
6.24: and fifteen feet across. They had two wings, and the wings were seven and a half feet long.
6.27: Solomon put them next to each other in the most holy place. Their wings were spread out and reached across the room.
6.28: The creatures were also covered with gold.
6.29: The walls of the two rooms were decorated with carvings of palm trees, flowers, and winged creatures.
6.30: Even the floor was covered with gold.
6.31: The two doors to the most holy place were made out of olive wood and were decorated with carvings of palm trees, flowers, and winged creatures. The doors and the carvings were covered with gold. The door frame came to a point at the top.
6.33: The two doors to the main room of the temple were made out of pine, and each one had two sections so they could fold open. The door frame was shaped like a rectangle and was made out of olive wood.
6.35: The doors were covered with gold and were decorated with carvings of palm trees, flowers, and winged creatures.
6.36: The inner courtyard of the temple had walls made out of three layers of cut stones with one layer of cedar beams.
6.37: Work began on the temple during Ziv, the second month of the year, four years after Solomon became king of Israel.
6.38: Seven years later the workers finished building it during Bul, the eighth month of the year. It was built exactly as it had been planned.

7.1: Solomon's palace took thirteen years to build.
7.2: Forest Hall was the largest room in the palace. It was one hundred fifty feet long, seventy-five feet wide, and forty-five feet high, and was lined with cedar from Lebanon. It had four rows of cedar pillars, fifteen in a row, and they held up forty-five cedar beams. The ceiling was covered with cedar.
7.4: Three rows of windows on each side faced each other,
7.5: and there were three doors on each side near the front of the hall.
7.6: Pillar Hall was seventy-five feet long and forty-five feet wide. A covered porch supported by pillars went all the way across the front of the hall.
7.7: Solomon's throne was in Justice Hall, where he judged cases. This hall was completely lined with cedar.
7.8: The section of the palace where Solomon lived was behind Justice Hall and looked exactly like it. He had a similar place built for his wife, the daughter of the king of Egypt.
7.9: From the foundation all the way to the top, these buildings and the courtyard were made out of the best stones carefully cut to size, then smoothed on every side with saws.
7.10: The foundation stones were huge, good stones--some of them fifteen feet long and others twelve feet long.
7.11: The cedar beams and other stones that had been cut to size were on top of these foundation stones.
7.12: The walls around the palace courtyard were made out of three layers of cut stones with one layer of cedar beams, just like the front porch and the inner courtyard of the temple. Hiram Makes the Bronze Furnishings(2 Chronicles 3.15-17; 4.1-10)
7.13: Hiram was a skilled bronze worker from the city of Tyre. His father was now dead, but he also had been a bronze worker from Tyre, and his mother was from the tribe of Naphtali. King Solomon asked Hiram to come to Jerusalem and make the bronze furnishings to use for worship in the LORD's temple, and he agreed to do it.
7.15: Hiram made two bronze columns twenty-seven feet tall and about six feet across.
7.16: For the top of each column, he also made a bronze cap seven and a half feet high.
7.17: The caps were decorated with seven rows of designs that looked like chains,
7.18: with two rows of designs that looked like pomegranates.
7.19: The caps for the columns of the porch were six feet high and were shaped like lilies.
7.20: The chain designs on the caps were right above the rounded tops of the two columns, and there were two hundred pomegranates in rows around each cap.
7.21: Hiram placed the two columns on each side of the main door of the temple. The column on the south side was called Jachin, and the one on the north was called Boaz.
7.22: The lily-shaped caps were on top of the columns. This completed the work on the columns.
7.23: Hiram also made a large bowl called the Sea. It was seven and a half feet deep, about fifteen feet across, and forty-five feet around.
7.24: Two rows of bronze gourds were around the outer edge of the bowl, ten gourds to every eighteen inches.
7.25: The bowl itself sat on top of twelve bronze bulls with three bulls facing outward in each of four directions.
7.26: The sides of the bowl were four inches thick, and its rim was like a cup that curved outward like flower petals. The bowl held about eleven thousand gallons.
