9.20: Mordecai wrote down everything that had happened. Then he sent letters to the Jews everywhere in the provinces
9.21: and told them: Each year you must celebrate on both the fourteenth and the fifteenth of Adar,
9.22: the days when we Jews defeated our enemies. Remember this month as a time when our sorrow was turned to joy, and celebration took the place of crying. Celebrate by having parties and by giving to the poor and by sharing gifts of food with each other.
9.23: They followed Mordecai's instructions and set aside these two days every year as a time of celebration. The Reason for the Festival of Purim
9.24: Haman was the son of Hammedatha and a descendant of Agag. He hated the Jews so much that he planned to destroy them, but he wanted to find out the best time to do it. So he cast lots.
9.25: Esther went to King Xerxes and asked him to save her people. Then the king gave written orders for Haman and his sons to be punished in the same terrible way that Haman had in mind for the Jews. So they were hanged.
9.26: Mordecai's letter had said that the Jews must celebrate for two days because of what had happened to them. This time of celebration is called Purim, which is the Hebrew word for the lots that were cast.
9.27: Now every year the Jews set aside these two days for having parties and celebrating, just as they were told to do.
9.28: From now on, all Jewish families must remember to celebrate Purim on these two days each year.
9.29: Queen Esther, daughter of Abihail, wanted to give full authority to Mordecai's letter about the Festival of Purim, and with his help she wrote a letter about the feast.
9.30: Copies of this letter were sent to Jews in the one hundred twenty-seven provinces of King Xerxes. In the letter they said: We pray that all of you will live in peace and safety.
9.31: You and your descendants must always remember to celebrate Purim at the time and in the way that we have said. You must also follow the instructions that we have given you about mourning and going without eating.
9.32: These laws about Purim are written by the authority of Queen Esther.

10.1: King Xerxes made everyone in his kingdom pay taxes, even those in lands across the sea.
10.2: All the great and famous things that King Xerxes did are written in the record books of the kings of Media and Persia. These records also tell about the honors that the king gave to Mordecai.
10.3: Next to the king himself, Mordecai was the highest official in the kingdom. He was a popular leader of the Jews, because he helped them in many ways and would even speak to the king for them.

1.1: Many years ago, a man named Job lived in the land of Uz. He was a truly good person, who respected God and refused to do evil.
1.2: Job had seven sons and three daughters.
1.3: He owned seven thousand sheep, three thousand camels, five hundred pair of oxen, five hundred donkeys, and a large number of servants. He was the richest person in the East.
1.4: Job's sons took turns having feasts in their homes, and they always invited their three sisters to join in the eating and drinking.
1.5: After each feast, Job would send for his children and perform a ceremony, as a way of asking God to forgive them of any wrongs they may have done. He would get up early the next morning and offer a sacrifice for each of them, just in case they had sinned or silently cursed God. Angels, the LORD, and Satan
1.6: One day, when the angels had gathered around the LORD, and Satan was there with them,
1.7: the LORD asked, "Satan, where have you been?" Satan replied, "I have been going all over the earth."
1.8: Then the LORD asked, "What do you think of my servant Job? No one on earth is like him--he is a truly good person, who respects me and refuses to do evil."
1.9: "Why shouldn't he respect you?" Satan remarked.
1.10: "You are like a wall protecting not only him, but his entire family and all his property. You make him successful in whatever he does, and his flocks and herds are everywhere.
1.11: Try taking away everything he owns, and he will curse you to your face."
1.12: The LORD replied, "All right, Satan, do what you want with anything that belongs to him, but don't harm Job." Then Satan left. Job Loses Everything
1.13: Job's sons and daughters were having a feast in the home of his oldest son,
1.14: when someone rushed up to Job and said, "While your servants were plowing with your oxen, and your donkeys were nearby eating grass,
1.15: a gang of Sabeans attacked and stole the oxen and donkeys! Your other servants were killed, and I was the only one who escaped to tell you."
1.16: That servant was still speaking, when a second one came running up and saying, "God sent down a fire that killed your sheep and your servants. I am the only one who escaped to tell you."
1.17: Before that servant finished speaking, a third one raced up and said, "Three gangs of Chaldeans attacked and stole your camels! All of your other servants were killed, and I am the only one who escaped to tell you."
1.18: That servant was still speaking, when a fourth one dashed up and said, "Your children were having a feast and drinking wine at the home of your oldest son,
1.19: when suddenly a windstorm from the desert blew the house down, crushing all of your children. I am the only one who escaped to tell you."
1.20: When Job heard this, he tore his clothes and shaved his head because of his great sorrow. He knelt on the ground, then worshiped God
1.21: and said: "We bring nothing at birth; we take nothing with us at death. The LORD alone gives and takes. Praise the name of the LORD!"
1.22: In spite of everything, Job did not sin or accuse God of doing wrong.

2.1: When the angels gathered around the LORD again, Satan was there with them,
2.2: and the LORD asked, "Satan, where have you been?" Satan replied, "I have been going all over the earth."
2.3: Then the LORD asked, "What do you think of my servant Job? No one on earth is like him--he is a truly good person, who respects me and refuses to do evil. And he hasn't changed, even though you persuaded me to destroy him for no reason."
2.4: Satan answered, "There's no pain like your own. People will do anything to stay alive.
2.5: Try striking Job's own body with pain, and he will curse you to your face."
2.6: "All right!" the LORD replied. "Make Job suffer as much as you want, but just don't kill him."
2.7: Satan left and caused painful sores to break out all over Job's body--from head to toe.
2.8: Then Job sat on the ash-heap to show his sorrow. And while he was scraping his sores with a broken piece of pottery,
2.9: his wife asked, "Why do you still trust God? Why don't you curse him and die?"
2.10: Job replied, "Don't talk like a fool! If we accept blessings from God, we must accept trouble as well." In all that happened, Job never once said anything against God. Job's Three Friends
2.11: Eliphaz from Teman, Bildad from Shuah, and Zophar from Naamah were three of Job's friends, and they heard about his troubles. So they agreed to visit Job and comfort him.
2.12: When they came near enough to see Job, they could hardly recognize him. And in their great sorrow, they tore their clothes, then sprinkled dust on their heads and cried bitterly.
2.13: For seven days and nights, they sat silently on the ground beside him, because they realized what terrible pain he was in.

3.1: Finally, Job cursed the day of his birth
3.2: by saying to God:
3.3: Blot out the day of my birth and the night when my parents created a son.
3.4: Forget about that day, cover it with darkness,
3.5: and send thick, gloomy shadows to fill it with dread.
3.6: Erase that night from the calendar and conceal it with darkness.
3.7: Don't let children be created or joyful shouts be heard ever again in that night.
3.8: Let those with magic powers place a curse on that day.
3.9: Darken its morning stars and remove all hope of light,
3.10: because it let me be born into a world of trouble. Why Didn't I Die at Birth?
3.11: Why didn't I die at birth?
3.12: Why was I accepted and allowed to nurse at my mother's breast?
3.13: Now I would be at peace in the silent world below
3.14: with kings and their advisors whose palaces lie in ruins,
3.15: and with rulers once rich with silver and gold.
3.16: I wish I had been born dead and then buried, never to see the light of day.
3.17: In the world of the dead, the wicked and the weary rest without a worry.
3.18: Everyone is there--
3.19: where captives and slaves are free at last. Why Does God Let Me Live?
3.20: Why does God let me live when life is miserable and so bitter?
3.21: I keep longing for death more than I would seek a valuable treasure.
3.22: Nothing could make me happier than to be in the grave.
3.23: Why do I go on living when God has me surrounded, and I can't see the road?
3.24: Moaning and groaning are my food and drink,
3.25: and my worst fears have all come true.
3.26: I have no peace or rest-- only troubles and worries.

4.1: Eliphaz from Teman said:
4.2: Please be patient and listen to what I have to say.
4.3: Remember how your words
4.4: have guided and encouraged many in need.
4.5: But now you feel discouraged when struck by trouble.
4.6: You respect God and live right, so don't lose hope!
4.7: No truly innocent person has ever died young.
4.8: In my experience, only those who plant seeds of evil harvest trouble,
4.9: and then they are swept away by the angry breath of God.
4.10: They may roar and growl like powerful lions. But when God breaks their teeth,
4.11: they starve, and their children are scattered. A Secret Was Told to Me
4.12: A secret was told to me in a faint whisper--
4.13: I was overcome by sleep, but disturbed by dreams;
4.14: I trembled with fear,
4.15: and my hair stood on end, as a wind blew past my face.
4.16: It stopped and stood still. Then a form appeared-- a shapeless form. And from the silence, I heard a voice say,
4.17: "No humans are innocent in the eyes of God their Creator.
4.18: He finds fault with his servants and even with his angels.
4.19: Humans are formed from clay and are fragile as moths, so what chance do you have?
4.20: Born after daybreak, you die before nightfall and disappear forever.
4.21: Your tent pegs are pulled up, and you leave this life, having gained no wisdom."

5.1: Job, call out for help and see if an angel comes!
5.2: Envy and jealousy will kill a stupid fool.
5.3: I have seen fools take root. But God sends a curse, suddenly uprooting them
5.4: and leaving their children helpless in court.
5.5: Then hungry and greedy people gobble down their crops and grab up their wealth.
5.6: Our suffering isn't caused by the failure of crops;
5.7: it's all part of life, like sparks shooting skyward.
5.8: Job, if I were you, I would ask God for help.
5.9: His miracles are marvelous, more than we can count.
5.10: God sends showers on earth and waters the fields.
5.11: He protects the sorrowful and lifts up those who have been disgraced.
5.12: God swiftly traps the wicked
5.13: in their own evil schemes, and their wisdom fails.
5.14: Darkness is their only companion, hiding their path at noon.
5.15: God rescues the needy from the words of the wicked and the fist of the mighty.
5.16: The poor are filled with hope, and injustice is silenced. Consider Yourself Fortunate
5.17: Consider yourself fortunate if God All-Powerful chooses to correct you.
5.18: He may cause injury and pain, but he will bandage and heal your cuts and bruises.
5.19: God will protect you from harm, no matter how often trouble may strike.
5.20: In times of war and famine, God will keep you safe.
5.21: You will be sheltered, without fear of hurtful words or any other weapon.
5.22: You will laugh at the threat of destruction and famine. And you won't be afraid of wild animals--
5.23: they will no longer be fierce, and your rocky fields will become friendly.
5.24: Your home will be secure, and your sheep will be safe.
5.25: You will have more descendants than there are blades of grass on the face of the earth.
5.26: You will live a long life, and your body will be strong until the day you die.
5.27: Our experience has proven these things to be true, so listen and learn.

6.1: Job said:
6.2: It's impossible to weigh my misery and grief!
6.3: They outweigh the sand along the beach, and that's why I have spoken without thinking first.
6.4: The fearsome arrows of God All-Powerful have filled my soul with their poison.
6.5: Do oxen and wild donkeys cry out in distress unless they are hungry?
6.6: What is food without salt? What is more tasteless than the white of an egg?
6.7: That's how my food tastes, and my appetite is gone.
6.8: How I wish that God would answer my prayer
6.9: and do away with me.
6.10: Then I would be comforted, knowing that in all of my pain I have never disobeyed God.
6.11: Why should I patiently hope when my strength is gone?
6.12: I am not strong as stone or bronze,
6.13: and I have finally reached the end of my rope. My Friends, I Am Desperate
6.14: My friends, I am desperate, and you should help me, even if I no longer respect God All-Powerful.
6.15: But you are treacherous
6.16: as streams that swell with melting snow,
6.17: then suddenly disappear in the summer heat.
6.18: I am like a caravan, lost in the desert while searching for water.
6.19: Caravans from Tema and Sheba
6.20: thought they would find water. But they were disappointed,
6.21: just as I am with you. Only one look at my suffering, and you run away scared. What Have I Done Wrong?
6.22: Have I ever asked any of you to give me a gift
6.23: or to purchase my freedom from brutal enemies?
6.24: What have I done wrong? Show me, and I will keep quiet.
6.25: The truth is always painful, but your arguments prove nothing.
6.26: Here I am desperate, and you consider my words as worthless as wind.
6.27: Why, you would sell an orphan or your own neighbor!
6.28: Look me straight in the eye; I won't lie to you.
6.29: Stop accusing me falsely; my reputation is at stake.
6.30: I know right from wrong, and I am not telling lies.

7.1: Why is life so hard? Why do we suffer?
7.2: We are slaves in search of shade; we are laborers longing for our wages.
7.3: God has made my days drag on and my nights miserable.
7.4: I pray for night to end, but it stretches out while I toss and turn.
7.5: My parched skin is covered with worms, dirt, and sores,
7.6: and my days are running out quicker than the thread of a fast-moving needle. Don't Forget!
7.7: I beg you, God, don't forget! My life is just a breath, and trouble lies ahead.
7.8: I will vanish from sight, and no one, including you, will ever see me again.
7.9: I will disappear in the grave or vanish from sight like a passing cloud.
7.10: Never will I return home; soon I will be forgotten.
7.11: And so, I cry out to you in agony and distress.
7.12: Am I the sea or a sea monster? Is that why you imprison me?
7.13: I go to bed, hoping for rest,
7.14: but you torture me with terrible dreams.
7.15: I'd rather choke to death than live in this body.
7.16: Leave me alone and let me die; my life has no meaning.
7.17: What makes you so concerned about us humans?
7.18: Why do you test us from sunrise to sunset?
7.19: Won't you look away just long enough for me to swallow?
7.20: Why do you watch us so closely? What's it to you, if I sin? Why am I your target and such a heavy burden?
7.21: Why do you refuse to forgive? Soon you won't find me, because I'll be dead.

8.1: Bildad from Shuah said:
8.2: How long will you talk and keep saying nothing?
8.3: Does God All-Powerful stand in the way of justice?
8.4: He made your children pay for their sins.
8.5: So why don't you turn to him
8.6: and start living right? Then he will decide to rescue and restore you to your place of honor.
8.7: Your future will be brighter by far than your past. Our Ancestors Were Wise
8.8: Our ancestors were wise, so learn from them.
8.9: Our own time has been short, like a fading shadow, and we know very little.
8.10: But they will instruct you with great understanding.
8.11: Papyrus reeds grow healthy only in a swamp,
8.12: and if the water dries up, they die sooner than grass.
8.13: Such is the hopeless future of all who turn from God
8.14: and trust in something as frail as a spider's web--
8.15: they take hold and fall because it's so flimsy.
8.16: Sinful people are like plants with spreading roots and plenty of sun and water.
8.17: They wrap their roots tightly around rocks.
8.18: But once they are pulled up, they have no more place;
8.19: their life slips away, and other plants grow there.
8.20: We know God doesn't reject an innocent person or help a sinner.
8.21: And so, he will make you happy and give you something to smile about.
8.22: But your evil enemies will be put to shame and disappear forever.

9.1: Job said:
9.2: What you say is true. No human is innocent in the sight of God.
9.3: Not once in a thousand times could we win our case if we took him to court.
9.4: God is wise and powerful-- who could possibly oppose him and win?
9.5: When God becomes angry, he can move mountains before they even know it.
9.6: God can shake the earth loose from its foundations
9.7: or command the sun and stars to hold back their light.
9.8: God alone stretched out the sky, stepped on the sea,
9.9: and set the stars in place-- the Big Dipper and Orion, the Pleiades and the stars in the southern sky.
9.10: Of all the miracles God works, we cannot understand a one.
9.11: God walks right past me, without making a sound.
9.12: And if he grabs something, who can stop him or raise a question?
9.13: When God showed his anger, the servants of the sea monster fell at his feet.
9.14: How, then, could I possibly argue my case with God? Though I Am Innocent
9.15: Even though I am innocent, I can only beg for mercy.
9.16: And if God came into court when I called him, he would not hear my case.
9.17: He would strike me with a storm and increase my injuries for no reason at all.
9.18: Before I could get my breath, my miseries would multiply.
9.19: God is much stronger than I am, and who would call me into court to give me justice?
9.20: Even if I were innocent, God would prove me wrong.
9.21: I am not guilty, but I no longer care what happens to me.
9.22: What difference does it make? God destroys the innocent along with the guilty.
9.23: When a good person dies a sudden death, God sits back and laughs.
9.24: And who else but God blindfolds the judges, then lets the wicked take over the earth? My Life Is Speeding By
9.25: My life is speeding by, without a hope of happiness.
9.26: Each day passes swifter than a sailing ship or an eagle swooping down.
9.27: Sometimes I try to be cheerful and to stop complaining,
9.28: but my sufferings frighten me, because I know that God still considers me guilty.
9.29: So what's the use of trying to prove my innocence?
9.30: Even if I washed myself with the strongest soap,
9.31: God would throw me into a pit of stinking slime, leaving me disgusting to my clothes.
9.32: God isn't a mere human like me. I can't put him on trial.
9.33: Who could possibly judge between the two of us?
9.34: Can someone snatch away the stick God carries to frighten me?
9.35: Then I could speak up without fear of him, but for now, I cannot speak.

10.1: I am sick of life! And from my deep despair, I complain to you, my God.
10.2: Don't just condemn me! Point out my sin.
10.3: Why do you take such delight in destroying those you created and in smiling on sinners?
10.4: Do you look at things the way we humans do?
10.5: Is your life as short as ours?
10.6: Is that why you are so quick to find fault with me?
10.7: You know I am innocent, but who can defend me against you?
10.8: Will you now destroy someone you created?
10.9: Remember that you molded me like a piece of clay. So don't turn me back into dust once again.
10.10: As cheese is made from milk, you created my body from a tiny drop.
10.11: Then you tied my bones together with muscles and covered them with flesh and skin.
10.12: You, the source of my life, showered me with kindness and watched over me. You Have Not Explained
10.13: You have not explained all of your mysteries,
10.14: but you catch and punish me each time I sin.
10.15: Guilty or innocent, I am condemned and ashamed because of my troubles.
10.16: No matter how hard I try, you keep hunting me down like a powerful lion.
10.17: You never stop accusing me; you become furious and attack over and over again.
10.18: Why did you let me be born? I would rather have died before birth
10.19: and been carried to the grave without ever breathing.
10.20: I have only a few days left. Why don't you leave me alone? Let me find some relief,
10.21: before I travel to the land
10.22: of darkness and despair, the place of no return.

11.1: Zophar from Naamah said:
11.2: So much foolish talk cannot go unanswered.
11.3: Your words have silenced others and made them ashamed; now it is only right for you to be put to shame.
11.4: You claim to be innocent and argue that your beliefs are acceptable to God.
11.5: But I wish he would speak
11.6: and let you know that wisdom has many different sides. You would then discover that God has punished you less than you deserve.
11.7: Can you understand the mysteries surrounding God All-Powerful?
11.8: They are higher than the heavens and deeper than the grave. So what can you do when you know so little,
11.9: and these mysteries outreach the earth and the ocean?
11.10: If God puts you in prison or drags you to court, what can you do?
11.11: God has the wisdom to know when someone is worthless and sinful,
11.12: but it's easier to tame a wild donkey than to make a fool wise. Surrender Your Heart to God
11.13: Surrender your heart to God, turn to him in prayer,
11.14: and give up your sins-- even those you do in secret.
11.15: Then you won't be ashamed; you will be confident and fearless.
11.16: Your troubles will go away like water beneath a bridge,
11.17: and your darkest night will be brighter than noon.
11.18: You will rest safe and secure, filled with hope and emptied of worry.
11.19: You will sleep without fear and be greatly respected.
11.20: But those who are evil will go blind and lose their way. Their only escape is death!

12.1: Job said to his friends:
12.2: You think you are so great, with all the answers.
12.3: But I know as much as you do, and so does everyone else.
12.4: I have always lived right, and God answered my prayers; now friends make fun of me.
12.5: It's easy to condemn those who are suffering, when you have no troubles.
12.6: Robbers and other godless people live safely at home and say, "God is in our hands!" If You Want To Learn
12.7: If you want to learn, then go and ask the wild animals and the birds,
12.8: the flowers and the fish.
12.9: Any of them can tell you what the LORD has done.
12.10: Every living creature is in the hands of God.
12.11: We hear with our ears, taste with our tongues,
12.12: and gain some wisdom from those who have lived a long time.
12.13: But God is the real source of wisdom and strength.
12.14: No one can rebuild what he destroys, or release those he has imprisoned.
12.15: God can hold back the rain or send a flood,
12.16: just as he rules over liars and those they lie to.
12.17: God destroys counselors, turns judges into fools,
12.19: God removes priests and others who have great power--
12.20: he confuses wise, experienced advisors,
12.21: puts mighty kings to shame, and takes away their power.
12.23: he makes nations strong, then shatters their strength.
12.24: God strikes their rulers senseless, then leaves them to roam through barren deserts,
12.25: lost in the dark, staggering like someone drunk.

13.1: I know and understand every bit of this.
13.2: None of you are smarter than I am; there's nothing you know that I don't.
13.3: But I prefer to argue my case with God All-Powerful--
13.4: you are merely useless doctors, who treat me with lies.
13.5: The wisest thing you can do is to keep quiet
13.6: and listen to my argument.
13.7: Are you telling lies for God
13.8: and not telling the whole truth when you argue his case?
13.9: If he took you to court, could you fool him, just as you fool others?
13.10: If you were secretly unfair, he would correct you,
13.11: and his glorious splendor would make you terrified.
13.12: Your wisdom and arguments are as delicate as dust. Be Quiet While I Speak
13.13: Be quiet while I speak, then say what you will.
13.14: I will be responsible for what happens to me.
13.15: God may kill me, but still I will trust him and offer my defense.
13.16: This may be what saves me, because no guilty person would come to his court.
13.17: Listen carefully to my words!
13.18: I have prepared my case well, and I am certain to win.
13.19: If you can prove me guilty, I will give up and die. Job PraysI Ask Only Two Things
13.20: I ask only two things of you, my God, and I will no longer hide from you--
13.22: Then speak, and I will reply; or else let me speak, and you reply.
13.23: Please point out my sins, so I will know them.
13.24: Why have you turned your back and count me your enemy?
13.25: Do you really enjoy frightening a fallen leaf?
13.26: Why do you accuse me of horrible crimes and make me pay for sins I did in my youth?
13.27: You have tied my feet down and keep me surrounded;
13.28: I am rotting away like cloth eaten by worms.

14.1: Life is short and sorrowful for every living soul.
14.2: We are flowers that fade and shadows that vanish.
14.3: And so, I ask you, God, why pick on me?
14.4: There's no way a human can be completely pure.
14.5: Our time on earth is brief; the number of our days is already decided by you.
14.6: Why don't you leave us alone and let us find some happiness while we toil and labor? When a Tree Is Chopped Down
14.7: When a tree is chopped down, there is always the hope that it will sprout again.
14.8: Its roots and stump may rot,
14.9: but at the touch of water, fresh twigs shoot up.
14.10: Humans are different-- we die, and that's the end.
14.11: We are like streams and lakes after the water has gone;
14.12: we fall into the sleep of death, never to rise again, until the sky disappears.
14.13: Please hide me, God, deep in the ground-- and when you are angry no more, remember to rescue me. Will We Humans Live Again?
14.14: Will we humans live again? I would gladly suffer and wait for my time.
14.15: My Creator, you would want me; you would call out, and I would answer.
14.16: You would take care of me, but not count my sins--
14.17: you would put them in a bag, tie it tight, and toss them away.
14.18: But in the real world, mountains tumble, and rocks crumble;
14.19: streams wear away stones and wash away soil. And you destroy our hopes!
14.20: You change the way we look, then send us away, wiped out forever.
14.21: We never live to know if our children are praised or disgraced.
14.22: We feel no pain but our own, and when we mourn, it's only for ourselves.

15.1: Eliphaz from Teman said:
15.2: Job, if you had any sense,
15.3: you would stop spreading all of this hot air.
15.4: Your words are enough to make others turn from God and lead them to doubt.
15.5: And your sinful, scheming mind is the source of all you say.
15.6: I am not here as your judge; your own words are witnesses against you.
15.7: Were you the first human? Are you older than the hills?
15.8: Have you ever been present when God's council meets? Do you alone have wisdom?
15.9: Do you know and understand something we don't?
15.10: We have the benefit of wisdom older than your father.
15.11: And you have been offered comforting words from God. Isn't this enough?
15.12: Your emotions are out of control, making you look fierce;
15.13: that's why you attack God with everything you say.
15.14: No human is pure and innocent,
15.15: and neither are angels-- not in the sight of God. If God doesn't trust his angels,
15.16: what chance do humans have? We are so terribly evil that we thirst for sin. Just Listen to What I Know
15.17: Just listen to what I know, and you will learn
15.18: wisdom known by others since ancient times.
15.19: Those who gained such insights also gained the land, and they were not influenced by foreign teachings.
15.20: But suffering is in store each day for those who sin.
15.21: Even in times of success, they constantly hear the threat of doom.
15.22: Darkness, despair, and death are their destiny.
15.23: They scrounge around for food, all the while dreading the approaching darkness.
15.24: They are overcome with despair, like a terrified king about to go into battle.
15.25: This is because they rebelled against God All-Powerful
15.26: and have attacked him with their weapons.
15.27: They may be rich and fat,
15.28: but they will live in the ruins of deserted towns.
15.29: Their property and wealth will shrink and disappear.
15.30: They won't escape the darkness, and the blazing breath of God will set their future aflame.
15.31: They have put their trust in something worthless; now they will become worthless
15.32: like a date palm tree without a leaf.
15.33: Or like vineyards or orchards whose blossoms and unripe fruit drop to the ground.
15.34: Yes, the godless and the greedy will have nothing but flames feasting on their homes,
15.35: because they are the parents of trouble and vicious lies.

16.1: Job said:
16.2: I have often heard this, and it offers no comfort.
16.3: So why don't you keep quiet? What's bothering you?
16.4: If I were in your place, it would be easy to criticize or to give advice.
16.5: But I would offer hope and comfort instead.
16.6: If I speak, or if I don't, I hurt all the same. My torment continues.
16.7: God has worn me down and destroyed my family;
16.8: my shriveled up skin proves that I am his prisoner.
16.9: God is my hateful enemy, glaring at me and attacking with his sharp teeth.
16.10: Everyone is against me; they sneer and slap my face.
16.11: And God is the one who handed me over to this merciless mob. Everything Was Going Well
16.12: Everything was going well, until God grabbed my neck and shook me to pieces. God set me up as the target
16.13: for his arrows, and without showing mercy, he slashed my stomach open, spilling out my insides.
16.14: God never stops attacking,
16.15: and so, in my sorrow I dress in sackcloth and sit in the dust.
16.16: My face is red with tears, and dark shadows circle my eyes,
16.17: though I am not violent, and my prayers are sincere.
16.18: If I should die, I beg the earth not to cover my cry for justice.
16.19: Even now, God in heaven is both my witness and my protector.
16.20: My friends have rejected me, but God is the one I beg
16.21: to show that I am right, just as a friend should.
16.22: Because in only a few years, I will be dead and gone.

17.1: My hopes have died, my time is up, and the grave is ready.
17.2: All I can see are angry crowds, making fun of me.
17.3: If you, LORD, don't help, who will pay the price for my release?
17.4: My friends won't really listen, all because of you, and so you must be the one to prove them wrong.
17.5: They have condemned me, just to benefit themselves; now blind their children.
17.6: You, God, are the reason I am insulted and spit on.
17.7: I am almost blind with grief; my body is a mere shadow.
17.8: People who are truly good would feel so alarmed, that they would become angry at my worthless friends.
17.9: They would do the right thing and because they did, they would grow stronger.
17.10: But none of my friends show any sense.
17.11: My life is drawing to an end; hope has disappeared.
17.12: But all my friends can do is offer empty hopes.
17.13: I could tell the world below to prepare me a bed.
17.14: Then I could greet the grave as my father and say to the worms, "Hello, mother and sisters!"
17.15: But what kind of hope is that?
17.16: Will it keep me company in the world of the dead?

18.1: Bildad from Shuah said:
18.2: How long will you talk? Be sensible! Let us speak.
18.3: Or do you think that we are dumb animals?
18.4: You cut yourself in anger. Will that shake the earth or even move the rocks?
18.5: The lamps of sinful people soon are snuffed out,
18.7: Their powerful legs become weak, and they stumble on schemes of their own doing.
18.8: Before they know it,
18.9: they are trapped in a net,
18.11: Terror strikes and pursues from every side.
18.12: Starving, they run, only to meet disaster,
18.13: then afterwards to be eaten alive by death itself.
18.14: Those sinners are dragged from the safety of their tents to die a gruesome death.
18.15: Then their tents and possessions are burned to ashes,
18.16: and they are left like trees, dried up from the roots.
18.17: They are gone and forgotten,
18.18: thrown far from the light into a world of darkness,
18.19: without any children to carry on their name.
18.20: Everyone, from east to west, is overwhelmed with horror.
18.21: Such is the fate of sinners and their families who don't know God.

19.1: Job said:
19.2: How long will you torture me with your words?
19.3: Isn't ten times enough for you to accuse me? Aren't you ashamed?
19.4: Even if I have sinned, you haven't been harmed.
19.5: You boast of your goodness, claiming I am suffering because I am guilty.
19.6: But God is the one at fault for finding fault with me.
19.7: Though I pray to be rescued from this torment, no whisper of justice answers me.
19.8: God has me trapped with a wall of darkness
19.9: and stripped of respect.
19.10: God rips me apart, uproots my hopes,
19.11: and attacks with fierce anger, as though I were his enemy.
19.12: His entire army advances, then surrounds my tent. I Am Forgotten
19.13: God has turned relatives and friends against me,
19.14: and I am forgotten.
19.15: My guests and my servants consider me a stranger,
19.16: and when I call my servants, they pay no attention.
19.17: My breath disgusts my wife; everyone in my family turns away.
19.18: Young children can't stand me, and when I come near, they make fun.
19.19: My best friends and loved ones have turned from me.
19.20: I am skin and bones-- just barely alive.
19.21: My friends, I beg you for pity! God has made me his target.
19.22: Hasn't he already done enough? Why do you join the attack?
19.23: I wish that my words could be written down
19.25: I know that my Savior lives, and at the end he will stand on this earth.
19.26: My flesh may be destroyed, yet from this body I will see God.
19.27: Yes, I will see him for myself, and I long for that moment.
19.28: My friends, you think up ways to blame and torment me, saying I brought it on myself.
19.29: But watch out for the judgment, when God will punish you!

20.1: Zophar from Naamah said:
20.2: Your words are disturbing; now I must speak.
20.3: You have accused and insulted me, and reason requires a reply.
20.4: Since the time of creation, everyone has known
20.5: that sinful people are happy for only a while.
20.6: Though their pride and power may reach to the sky,
20.7: they will disappear like dust, and those who knew them will wonder what happened.
20.8: They will be forgotten like a dream
20.9: and vanish from the sight of family and friends.
20.10: Their children will have to repay what the parents took from the poor.
20.11: Indeed, the wicked will die and go to their graves in the prime of life. Sinners Love the Taste of Sin
20.12: Sinners love the taste of sin; they relish every bite
20.14: But their food will turn sour and poison their stomachs.
20.15: Then God will make them lose the wealth they gobbled down.
20.16: They will die from the fangs of poisonous snakes
20.17: and never enjoy rivers flowing with milk and honey.
20.18: Their hard work will result in nothing gained,
20.19: because they cheated the poor and took their homes.
20.20: Greedy people want everything and are never satisfied.
20.21: But when nothing remains for them to grab, they will be nothing.
20.22: Once they have everything, distress and despair will strike them down,
20.23: and God will make them swallow his blazing anger.
20.24: While running from iron spears, they will be killed by arrows of bronze,
20.25: whose shining tips go straight through their bodies. They will be trapped by terror,
20.26: and what they treasure most will be lost in the dark. God will send flames to destroy them in their tents with all their property.
20.27: The heavens and the earth will testify against them,
20.28: and all their possessions will be dragged off when God becomes angry.
20.29: This is what God has decided for those who are evil.

21.1: Job said:
21.2: If you want to offer comfort, then listen to me.
21.3: And when I have finished, you can start your insults all over again.
21.4: My complaint is against God; that's why I am impatient.
21.5: Just looking at me is enough to make you sick,
21.6: and the very thought of myself fills me with disgust.
21.7: Why do evil people live so long and gain such power?
21.8: Why are they allowed to see their children grow up?
21.9: They have no worries at home, and God never punishes them.
21.10: Their cattle have lots of calves without ever losing one;
21.11: their children play and dance safely by themselves.
21.12: These people sing and celebrate to the sound of tambourines, small harps, and flutes,
21.13: and they are successful, without a worry, until the day they die. Leave Us Alone!
21.14: Those who are evil say to God All-Powerful, "Leave us alone! Don't bother us with your teachings.
21.15: What do we gain from praying and worshiping you?
21.16: We succeeded all on our own." And so, I keep away from them and their evil schemes.
21.17: How often does God become angry and send disaster and darkness to punish sinners?
21.18: How often does he strike them like a windstorm that scatters straw?
21.19: You say, "God will punish those sinners' children in place of those sinners." But I say, "Let him punish those sinners themselves until they really feel it.
21.20: Let God All-Powerful force them to drink their own destruction from the cup of his anger.
21.21: Because after they are dead, they won't care what happens to their children." Who Can Tell God What To Do?
21.22: Who can tell God what to do? He judges powerful rulers.
21.25: while others die in poverty, having known only pain.
21.26: But we all end up dead, beneath a blanket of worms.
21.27: My friends, I know that you are plotting against me.
21.28: You ask, "Where is the home of that important person who does so much evil?"
21.30: that those who do wrong never suffer disaster, when God becomes angry.
21.31: No one points out their sin or punishes them.
21.32: Then at their funerals, they are highly praised;
21.33: the earth welcomes them home, while crowds mourn.
21.34: But empty, meaningless words are the comfort you offer me.

22.1: Eliphaz from Teman said:
22.2: What use are we humans to God, even the wisest of us?
22.3: If you were completely sinless, that would still mean nothing to God All-Powerful.
22.4: Is he correcting you for worshiping him?
22.5: No! It's because of your terrible sins.
22.6: To guarantee payment of a debt, you have taken clothes from the poor.
22.7: And you refused bread and water to the hungry and thirsty,
22.8: although you were rich, respected, and powerful.
22.9: You have turned away widows and have broken the arms of orphans.
22.10: That's why you were suddenly trapped by terror,
22.11: blinded by darkness, and drowned in a flood. God Lives in the Heavens
22.12: God lives in the heavens above the highest stars, where he sees everything.
22.13: Do you think the deep darkness hides you from God?
22.14: Do thick clouds cover his eyes, as he walks around heaven's dome high above the earth?
22.15: Give up those ancient ideas believed by sinners,
22.16: who were swept away without warning.
22.17: They rejected God All-Powerful, feeling he was helpless,
22.18: although he had been kind to their families. The beliefs of these sinners are truly disgusting.
22.19: When God's people see the godless swept away, they celebrate,
22.20: saying, "Our enemies are gone, and fire has destroyed their possessions." Surrender to God All-Powerful
22.21: Surrender to God All-Powerful! You will find peace and prosperity.
22.22: Listen to his teachings and take them to heart.
22.23: If you return to God and turn from sin, all will go well for you.
22.24: So get rid of your finest gold, as though it were sand.
22.25: Let God All-Powerful be your silver and gold,
22.26: and you will find happiness by worshiping him.
22.27: God will answer your prayers, and you will keep the promises you made to him.
22.28: He will do whatever you ask, and life will be bright.
22.29: When others are disgraced, God will clear their names in answer to your prayers.
22.30: Even those who are guilty will be forgiven, because you obey God.

23.2: Today I complain bitterly, because God has been cruel and made me suffer.
23.3: If I knew where to find God, I would go there
23.5: Then I would discover what he wanted to say.
23.6: Would he overwhelm me with his greatness? No! He would listen
23.7: because I am innocent, and he would say, "I now set you free!"
23.8: I cannot find God anywhere-- in front or back of me,
23.9: to my left or my right. God is always at work, though I never see him.
23.10: But he knows what I am doing, and when he tests me, I will be pure as gold.
23.11: I have never refused to follow any of his commands,
23.12: and I have always treasured his teachings.
23.13: But he alone is God, and who can oppose him? God does as he pleases,
23.14: and he will do exactly what he intends with me.
23.15: Merely the thought of God All-Powerful
23.17: God has covered me with darkness, but I refuse to be silent.

24.1: Why doesn't God set a time for court? Why don't his people know where he can be found?
24.2: Sinners remove boundary markers and take care of sheep they have stolen.
24.3: They cheat orphans and widows by taking their donkeys and oxen.
24.4: The poor are trampled and forced to hide
24.5: in the desert, where they and their children must live like wild donkeys and search for food.
24.6: If they want grain or grapes, they must go to the property of these sinners.
24.7: They sleep naked in the cold, because they have no cover,
24.8: and during a storm their only shelters are caves among the rocky cliffs.
24.9: Children whose fathers have died are taken from their mothers as payment for a debt.
24.10: Then they are forced to work naked in the grain fields because they have no clothes, and they go hungry.
24.11: They crush olives to make oil and grapes to make wine-- but still they go thirsty.
24.12: And along the city streets, the wounded and dying cry out, yet God does nothing. Some Reject the Light
24.13: Some rebel and refuse to follow the light.
24.14: Soon after sunset they murder the poor and the needy, and at night they steal.
24.15: Others wait for the dark, thinking they won't be seen if they sleep with the wife or husband of someone else.
24.16: Robbers hide during the day, then break in after dark because they reject the light.
24.17: They prefer night to day, since the terrors of the night are their friends. Sinners Are Filthy Foam
24.18: Those sinners are filthy foam on the surface of the water. And so, their fields and vineyards will fall under a curse and won't produce.
24.19: Just as the heat of summer swallows the snow, the world of the dead swallows those who sin.
24.20: Forgotten here on earth, and with their power broken, they taste sweet to worms.
24.21: Sinners take advantage of widows and other helpless women.
24.22: But God's mighty strength destroys those in power. Even if they seem successful, they are doomed to fail.
24.23: God may let them feel secure, but they are never out of his sight.
24.24: Great for a while; gone forever! Sinners are mowed down like weeds, then they wither and die.
24.25: If I haven't spoken the truth, then prove me wrong.

25.2: God is the one to fear, because God is in control and rules the heavens.
25.3: Who can count his army of stars? Isn't God the source of light?
25.4: How can anyone be innocent in the sight of God?
25.5: To him, not even the light of the moon and stars can ever be pure.
25.6: So how can we humans, when we are merely worms?

26.2: You have really been helpful to someone weak and weary.
26.3: You have given great advice and wonderful wisdom to someone truly in need.
26.4: How can anyone possibly speak with such understanding?
26.5: Remember the terrible trembling of those in the world of the dead below the mighty ocean.
26.6: Nothing in that land of death and destruction is hidden from God,
26.7: who hung the northern sky and suspended the earth on empty space.
26.8: God stores water in clouds, but they don't burst,
26.9: and he wraps them around the face of the moon.
26.10: On the surface of the ocean, God has drawn a boundary line between light and darkness.
26.11: And columns supporting the sky tremble at his command.
26.12: By his power and wisdom, God conquered the force of the mighty ocean.
26.13: The heavens became bright when he breathed, and the escaping sea monster died at the hands of God.
26.14: These things are merely a whisper of God's power at work. How little we would understand if this whisper ever turned into thunder!

27.2: I am desperate because God All-Powerful refuses to do what is right. As surely as God lives,
27.3: and while he gives me breath,
27.4: I will tell only the truth.
27.5: Until the day I die, I will refuse to do wrong by saying you are right,
27.6: because each day my conscience agrees that I am innocent.
27.7: I pray that my enemies will suffer no less than the wicked.
27.8: Such people are hopeless, and God All-Powerful will cut them down,
27.9: without listening when they beg for mercy.
27.10: And that is what God should do, because they don't like him or ever pray.
27.11: Now I will explain in detail what God All-Powerful does.
27.12: All of you have seen these things for yourselves. So you have no excuse. How God Treats the Wicked
27.13: Here is how God All-Powerful treats those who are wicked and brutal.
27.14: They may have many children, but most of them will go hungry or suffer a violent death.
27.15: Others will die of disease, and their widows won't be able to weep.
27.16: The wicked may collect riches and clothes in abundance as easily as clay.
27.17: But God's people will wear clothes taken from them and divide up their riches.
27.18: No homes built by the wicked will outlast a cocoon or a shack.
27.19: Those sinners may go to bed rich, but they will wake up poor.
27.20: Terror will strike at night like a flood or a storm.
27.21: Then a scorching wind will sweep them away

1.1: God blesses those people who refuse evil advice and won't follow sinners or join in sneering at God.
1.2: Instead, the Law of the LORD makes them happy, and they think about it day and night.
1.3: They are like trees growing beside a stream, trees that produce fruit in season and always have leaves. Those people succeed in everything they do.
1.4: That isn't true of those who are evil, because they are like straw blown by the wind.
1.5: Sinners won't have an excuse on the day of judgment, and they won't have a place with the people of God.
1.6: The LORD protects everyone who follows him, but the wicked follow a road that leads to ruin.

2.1: Why do the nations plot, and why do their people make useless plans?
2.2: The kings of this earth have all joined together to turn against the LORD and his chosen one.
2.3: They say, "Let's cut the ropes and set ourselves free!"
2.4: In heaven the LORD laughs as he sits on his throne, making fun of the nations.
2.5: The LORD becomes furious and threatens them. His anger terrifies them as he says,
2.6: "I've put my king on Zion, my sacred hill."
2.7: I will tell the promise that the LORD made to me: "You are my son, because today I have become your father.
2.8: Ask me for the nations, and every nation on earth will belong to you.
2.9: You will smash them with an iron rod and shatter them like dishes of clay."
2.10: Be smart, all you rulers, and pay close attention.
2.11: Serve and honor the LORD; be glad and tremble.
2.12: Show respect to his son because if you don't, the LORD might become furious and suddenly destroy you. But he blesses and protects everyone who runs to him.

3.1: I have a lot of enemies, LORD. Many fight against
3.2: me and say, "God won't rescue you!"
3.3: But you are my shield, and you give me victory and great honor.
3.4: I pray to you, and you answer from your sacred hill.
3.5: I sleep and wake up refreshed because you, LORD, protect me.
3.6: Ten thousand enemies attack from every side, but I am not afraid.
3.7: Come and save me, LORD God! Break my enemies' jaws and shatter their teeth,
3.8: because you protect and bless your people.

4.1: You are my God and protector. Please answer my prayer. I was in terrible distress, but you set me free. Now have pity and listen as I pray.
4.2: How long will you people refuse to respect me? You love foolish things, and you run after what is worthless.
4.3: The LORD has chosen everyone who is faithful to be his very own, and he answers my prayers.
4.4: But each of you had better tremble and turn from your sins. Silently search your heart as you lie in bed.
4.5: Offer the proper sacrifices and trust the LORD.
4.6: There are some who ask, "Who will be good to us?" Let your kindness, LORD, shine brightly on us.
4.7: You brought me more happiness than a rich harvest of grain and grapes.
4.8: I can lie down and sleep soundly because you, LORD, will keep me safe.

5.1: Listen, LORD, as I pray! Pay attention when I groan.
5.2: You are my King and my God. Answer my cry for help because I pray to you.
5.3: Each morning you listen to my prayer, as I bring my requests to you and wait for your reply.
5.4: You are not the kind of God who is pleased with evil. Sinners can't stay with you.
5.5: No one who boasts can stand in your presence, LORD, and you hate evil people.
5.6: You destroy every liar, and you despise violence and deceit.
5.7: Because of your great mercy, I come to your house, LORD, and I am filled with wonder as I bow down to worship at your holy temple.
5.8: You do what is right, and I ask you to guide me. Make your teaching clear because of my enemies.
5.9: Nothing they say is true! They just want to destroy. Their words are deceitful like a hidden pit, and their tongues are good only for telling lies.
5.10: Punish them, God, and let their own plans bring their downfall. Get rid of them! They keep committing crimes and turning against you.
5.11: Let all who run to you for protection always sing joyful songs. Provide shelter for those who truly love you and let them rejoice.
5.12: Our LORD, you bless those who live right, and you shield them with your kindness.

6.1: Don't punish me, LORD, or even correct me when you are angry!
6.2: Have pity on me and heal my feeble body. My bones tremble with fear,
6.3: and I am in deep distress. How long will it be?
6.4: Turn and come to my rescue. Show your wonderful love and save me, LORD.
6.5: If I die, I cannot praise you or even remember you.
6.6: My groaning has worn me out. At night my bed and pillow are soaked with tears.
6.7: Sorrow has made my eyes dim, and my sight has failed because of my enemies.
6.8: You, LORD, heard my crying, and those hateful people had better leave me alone.
6.9: You have answered my prayer and my plea for mercy.
6.10: My enemies will be ashamed and terrified, as they quickly run away in complete disgrace.

7.1: You, LORD God, are my protector. Rescue me and keep me safe from all who chase me.
7.2: Or else they will rip me apart like lions attacking a victim, and no one will save me.
7.3: I am innocent, LORD God!
7.4: I have not betrayed a friend or had pity on an enemy who attacks for no reason.
7.5: If I have done any of this, then let my enemies chase and capture me. Let them stomp me to death and leave me in the dirt.
7.6: Get angry, LORD God! Do something! Attack my furious enemies. See that justice is done.
7.7: Make the nations come to you, as you sit on your throne above them all.
7.8: Our LORD, judge the nations! Judge me and show that I am honest and innocent.
7.9: You know every heart and mind, and you always do right. Now make violent people stop, but protect all of us who obey you.
7.10: You, God, are my shield, the protector of everyone whose heart is right.
7.11: You see that justice is done, and each day you take revenge.
7.12: Whenever your enemies refuse to change their ways, you sharpen your sword and string your bow.
7.13: Your deadly arrows are ready with flaming tips.
7.14: An evil person is like a woman about to give birth to a hateful, deceitful, and rebellious child.
7.15: Such people dig a deep hole, then fall in it themselves.
7.16: The trouble they cause comes back on them, and their heads are crushed by their own evil deeds.
7.17: I will praise you, LORD! You always do right. I will sing about you, the LORD Most High.

8.1: Our LORD and Ruler, your name is wonderful everywhere on earth! You let your glory be seen in the heavens above.
8.2: With praises from children and from tiny infants, you have built a fortress. It makes your enemies silent, and all who turn against you are left speechless.
8.3: I often think of the heavens your hands have made, and of the moon and stars you put in place.
8.4: Then I ask, "Why do you care about us humans? Why are you concerned for us weaklings?"
8.5: You made us a little lower than you yourself, and you have crowned us with glory and honor.
8.6: You let us rule everything your hands have made. And you put all of it under our power--
8.7: the sheep and the cattle, and every wild animal,
8.8: the birds in the sky, the fish in the sea, and all ocean creatures.
8.9: Our LORD and Ruler, your name is wonderful everywhere on earth!

9.1: I will praise you, LORD, with all my heart and tell about the wonders you have worked.
9.2: God Most High, I will rejoice; I will celebrate and sing because of you.
9.3: When my enemies face you, they run away and stumble and are destroyed.
9.4: You take your seat as judge, and your fair decisions prove that I was in the right.
9.5: You warn the nations and destroy evil people; you wipe out their names forever and ever.
9.6: Our enemies are destroyed completely for all time. Their cities are torn down, and they will never be remembered again.
9.7: You rule forever, LORD, and you are on your throne, ready for judgment.
9.8: You judge the world fairly and treat all nations with justice.
9.9: The poor can run to you because you are a fortress in times of trouble.
9.10: Everyone who honors your name can trust you, because you are faithful to all who depend on you.
9.11: You rule from Zion, LORD, and we sing about you to let the nations know everything you have done.
9.12: You did not forget to punish the guilty or listen to the cries of those in need.
9.13: Please have mercy, LORD! My enemies mistreat me. Keep me from the gates that lead to death,
9.14: and I will sing about you at the gate to Zion. I will be happy there because you rescued me.
9.15: Our LORD, the nations fell into their own pits, and their feet were caught in their own traps.
9.16: You showed what you are like, and you made certain that justice is done, but evil people are trapped by their own evil deeds.
9.17: The wicked will go down to the world of the dead to be with those nations that forgot about you.
9.18: The poor and the homeless won't always be forgotten and without hope.
9.19: Do something, LORD! Don't let the nations win. Make them stand trial in your court of law.
9.20: Make the nations afraid and let them all discover just how weak they are.

10.1: Why are you far away, LORD? Why do you hide yourself when I am in trouble?
10.2: Proud and brutal people hunt down the poor. But let them get caught by their own evil plans!
10.3: The wicked brag about their deepest desires. Those greedy people hate and curse you, LORD.
10.4: The wicked are too proud to turn to you or even think about you.
10.5: They are always successful, though they can't understand your teachings, and they keep sneering at their enemies.
10.6: In their hearts they say, "Nothing can hurt us! We'll always be happy and free from trouble."
10.7: They curse and tell lies, and all they talk about is how to be cruel or how to do wrong.
10.8: They hide outside villages, waiting to strike and murder some innocent victim.
10.9: They are hungry lions hiding in the bushes, hoping to catch some helpless passerby. They trap the poor in nets and drag them away.
10.10: They crouch down and wait to grab a victim.
10.11: They say, "God can't see! He's got on a blindfold."
10.12: Do something, LORD God, and use your powerful arm to help those in need.
10.13: The wicked don't respect you. In their hearts they say, "God won't punish us!"
10.14: But you see the trouble and the distress, and you will do something. The poor can count on you, and so can orphans.
10.15: Now break the arms of all merciless people. Punish them for doing wrong and make them stop.
10.16: Our LORD, you will always rule, but nations will vanish from the earth.
10.17: You listen to the longings of those who suffer. You offer them hope, and you pay attention to their cries for help.
10.18: You defend orphans and everyone else in need, so that no one on earth can terrify others again.

11.1: The LORD is my fortress! Don't say to me, "Escape like a bird to the mountains!"
11.2: You tell me, "Watch out! Those evil people have put their arrows on their bows, and they are standing in the shadows, aiming at good people.
11.3: What can an honest person do when everything crumbles?"
11.4: The LORD is sitting in his sacred temple on his throne in heaven. He knows everything we do because he sees us all.
11.5: The LORD tests honest people, but despises those who are cruel and love violence.
11.6: He will send fiery coals and flaming sulfur down on the wicked, and they will drink nothing but a scorching wind.
11.7: The LORD always does right and wants justice done. Everyone who does right will see his face.

12.1: Please help me, LORD! All who were faithful and all who were loyal have disappeared.
12.2: Everyone tells lies, and no one is sincere.
12.3: Won't you chop off all flattering tongues that brag so loudly?
12.4: They say to themselves, "We are great speakers. No one else has a chance."
12.5: But you, LORD, tell them, "I will do something! The poor are mistreated and helpless people moan. I'll rescue all who suffer."
12.6: Our LORD, you are true to your promises, and your word is like silver heated seven times in a fiery furnace.
12.7: You will protect us and always keep us safe from those people.
12.8: But all who are wicked will keep on strutting, while everyone praises their shameless deeds.

13.1: How much longer, LORD, will you forget about me? Will it be forever? How long will you hide?
13.2: How long must I be confused and miserable all day? How long will my enemies keep beating me down?
13.3: Please listen, LORD God, and answer my prayers. Make my eyes sparkle again, or else I will fall into the sleep of death.
13.4: My enemies will say, "Now we've won!" They will be greatly pleased when I am defeated.
13.5: I trust your love, and I feel like celebrating because you rescued me.
13.6: You have been good to me, LORD, and I will sing about you.

14.1: Only a fool would say, "There is no God!" People like that are worthless; they are heartless and cruel and never do right.
14.2: From heaven the LORD looks down to see if anyone is wise enough to search for him.
14.3: But all of them are corrupt; no one does right.
14.4: Won't you evil people learn? You refuse to pray, and you gobble down the LORD's people.
14.5: But you will be frightened, because God is on the side of every good person.
14.6: You may spoil the plans of the poor, but the LORD protects them.
14.7: I long for someone from Zion to come and save Israel! Our LORD, when you bless your people again, Jacob's family will be glad, and Israel will celebrate.

15.1: Who may stay in God's temple or live on the holy mountain of the LORD?
15.2: Only those who obey God and do as they should. They speak the truth
15.3: and don't spread gossip; they treat others fairly and don't say cruel things.
15.4: They hate worthless people, but show respect for all who worship the LORD. And they keep their promises, no matter what the cost.
15.5: They lend their money without charging interest, and they don't take bribes to hurt the innocent. Those who do these things will always stand firm.

16.1: Protect me, LORD God! I run to you for safety,
16.2: and I have said, "Only you are my Lord! Every good thing I have is a gift from you."
16.3: Your people are wonderful, and they make me happy,
16.4: but worshipers of other gods will have much sorrow. I refuse to offer sacrifices of blood to those gods or worship in their name.
16.5: You, LORD, are all I want! You are my choice, and you keep me safe.
16.6: You make my life pleasant, and my future is bright.
16.7: I praise you, LORD, for being my guide. Even in the darkest night, your teachings fill my mind.
16.8: I will always look to you, as you stand beside me and protect me from fear.
16.9: With all my heart, I will celebrate, and I can safely rest.
16.10: I am your chosen one. You won't leave me in the grave or let my body decay.
16.11: You have shown me the path to life, and you make me glad by being near to me. Sitting at your right side, I will always be joyful.

17.1: I am innocent, LORD! Won't you listen as I pray and beg for help? I am honest! Please hear my prayer.
17.2: Only you can say that I am innocent, because only your eyes can see the truth.
17.3: You know my heart, and even during the night you have tested me and found me innocent. I have made up my mind never to tell a lie.
17.4: I don't do like others. I obey your teachings and am not cruel.
17.5: I have followed you, without ever stumbling.
17.6: I pray to you, God, because you will help me. Listen and answer my prayer!
17.7: Show your wonderful love. Your mighty arm protects those who run to you for safety from their enemies.
17.8: Protect me as you would your very own eyes; hide me in the shadow of your wings.
17.9: Don't let my brutal enemies attack from all sides and kill me.
17.10: They refuse to show mercy, and they keep bragging.
17.11: They have caught up with me! My enemies are everywhere, eagerly hoping to smear me in the dirt.
17.12: They are like hungry lions hunting for food, or like young lions hiding in ambush.
17.13: Do something, LORD! Attack and defeat them. Take your sword and save me from those evil people.
17.14: Use your powerful arm and rescue me from the hands of mere humans whose world won't last. You provide food for those you love. Their children have plenty, and their grandchildren will have more than enough.
17.15: I am innocent, LORD, and I will see your face! When I awake, all I want is to see you as you are.

18.1: I love you, LORD God, and you make me strong.
18.2: You are my mighty rock, my fortress, my protector, the rock where I am safe, my shield, my powerful weapon, and my place of shelter.
18.3: I praise you, LORD! I prayed, and you rescued me from my enemies.
18.4: Death had wrapped its ropes around me, and I was almost swallowed by its flooding waters.
18.5: Ropes from the world of the dead had coiled around me, and death had set a trap in my path.
18.6: I was in terrible trouble when I called out to you, but from your temple you heard me and answered my prayer.
18.7: The earth shook and shivered, and the mountains trembled down to their roots. You were angry
18.8: and breathed out smoke. Scorching heat and fiery flames spewed from your mouth.
18.9: You opened the heavens like curtains, and you came down with storm clouds under your feet.
18.10: You rode on the backs of flying creatures and swooped down with the wind as wings.
18.11: Darkness was your robe; thunderclouds filled the sky, hiding you from sight.
18.12: Hailstones and fiery coals lit up the sky in front of you.
18.13: LORD Most High, your voice thundered from the heavens, as hailstones and fiery coals poured down like rain.
18.14: You scattered your enemies with arrows of lightning.
18.15: You roared at the sea, and its deepest channels could be seen. You snorted, and the earth shook to its foundations.
18.16: You reached down from heaven, and you lifted me from deep in the ocean.
18.17: You rescued me from enemies, who were hateful and too powerful for me.
18.18: On the day disaster struck, they came and attacked, but you defended me.
18.19: When I was fenced in, you freed and rescued me because you love me.
18.20: You are good to me, LORD, because I do right, and you reward me because I am innocent.
18.21: I do what you want and never turn to do evil.
18.22: I keep your laws in mind and never look away from your teachings.
18.23: I obey you completely and guard against sin.
18.24: You have been good to me because I do right; you have rewarded me for being innocent by your standards.
18.25: You are always loyal to your loyal people, and you are faithful to the faithful.
18.26: With all who are sincere, you are sincere, but you treat the unfaithful as their deeds deserve.
18.27: You rescue the humble, but you put down all who are proud.
18.28: You, the LORD God, keep my lamp burning and turn darkness to light.
18.29: You help me defeat armies and capture cities.
18.30: Your way is perfect, LORD, and your word is correct. You are a shield for those who run to you for help.
18.31: You alone are God! Only you are a mighty rock.
18.32: You give me strength and guide me right.
18.33: You make my feet run as fast as those of a deer, and you help me stand on the mountains.
18.34: You teach my hands to fight and my arms to use a bow of bronze.
18.35: You alone are my shield. Your right hand supports me, and by coming to help me, you have made me famous.
18.36: You clear the way for me, and now I won't stumble.
18.37: I kept chasing my enemies, until I caught them and destroyed them.
18.38: I stuck my sword through my enemies, and they were crushed under my feet.
18.39: You helped me win victories, and you forced my attackers to fall victim to me.
18.40: You made my enemies run, and I killed them.
18.41: They cried out for help, but no one saved them; they called out to you, but there was no answer.
18.42: I ground them to dust blown by the wind, and I poured them out like mud in the streets.
18.43: You rescued me from stubborn people, and you made me the leader of foreign nations, who are now my slaves.
18.45: They have lost all courage, and from their fortresses, they come trembling.
18.46: You are the living LORD! I will praise you. You are a mighty rock. I will honor you for keeping me safe.
18.47: You took revenge for me, and you put nations in my power.
18.48: You protected me from violent enemies and made me much greater than all of them.
18.49: I will praise you, LORD, and I will honor you among the nations.
18.50: You give glorious victories to your chosen king. Your faithful love for David and for his descendants will never end.

19.1: The heavens keep telling the wonders of God, and the skies declare what he has done.
19.2: Each day informs the following day; each night announces to the next.
19.3: They don't speak a word, and there is never the sound of a voice.
19.4: Yet their message reaches all the earth, and it travels around the world. In the heavens a tent is set up for the sun.
19.5: It rises like a bridegroom and gets ready like a hero eager to run a race.
19.6: It travels all the way across the sky. Nothing hides from its heat.
19.7: The Law of the LORD is perfect; it gives us new life. His teachings last forever, and they give wisdom to ordinary people.
19.8: The LORD's instruction is right; it makes our hearts glad. His commands shine brightly, and they give us light.
19.9: Worshiping the LORD is sacred; he will always be worshiped. All of his decisions are correct and fair.
19.10: They are worth more than the finest gold and are sweeter than honey from a honeycomb.
19.11: By your teachings, Lord, I am warned; by obeying them, I am greatly rewarded.
19.12: None of us know our faults. Forgive me when I sin without knowing it.
19.13: Don't let me do wrong on purpose, Lord, or let sin have control over my life. Then I will be innocent, and not guilty of some terrible fault.
19.14: Let my words and my thoughts be pleasing to you, LORD, because you are my mighty rock and my protector.

20.1: I pray that the LORD will listen when you are in trouble, and that the God of Jacob will keep you safe.
20.2: May the LORD send help from his temple and come to your rescue from Mount Zion.
20.3: May he remember your gifts and be pleased with what you bring.
20.4: May God do what you want most and let all go well for you.
20.5: Then you will win victories, and we will celebrate, while raising our banners in the name of our God. May the LORD answer all of your prayers!
20.6: I am certain, LORD, that you will help your chosen king. You will answer my prayers from your holy place in heaven, and you will save me with your mighty arm.
20.7: Some people trust the power of chariots or horses, but we trust you, LORD God.
20.8: Others will stumble and fall, but we will be strong and stand firm.
20.9: Give the king victory, LORD, and answer our prayers.

21.1: Our LORD, your mighty power makes the king glad, and he celebrates victories that you have given him.
21.2: You did what he wanted most and never told him "No."
21.3: You truly blessed the king, and you placed on him a crown of finest gold.
21.4: He asked to live a long time, and you promised him life that never ends.
21.5: The king is highly honored. You have let him win victories that have made him famous.
21.6: You have given him blessings that will last forever, and you have made him glad by being so near to him.
21.7: LORD Most High, the king trusts you, and your kindness keeps him from defeat.
21.8: With your mighty arm, LORD, you will strike down all of your hateful enemies.
21.9: They will be destroyed by fire once you are here, and because of your anger, flames will swallow them.
21.10: You will wipe their families from the earth, and they will disappear.
21.11: All their plans to harm you will come to nothing.
21.12: You will make them run away by shooting your arrows at their faces.
21.13: Show your strength, LORD, so that we may sing and praise your power.

22.1: My God, my God, why have you deserted me? Why are you so far away? Won't you listen to my groans and come to my rescue?
22.2: I cry out day and night, but you don't answer, and I can never rest.
22.3: Yet you are the holy God, ruling from your throne and praised by Israel.
22.4: Our ancestors trusted you, and you rescued them.
22.5: When they cried out for help, you saved them, and you did not let them down when they depended on you.
22.6: But I am merely a worm, far less than human, and I am hated and rejected by people everywhere.
22.7: Everyone who sees me makes fun and sneers. They shake their heads,
22.8: and say, "Trust the LORD! If you are his favorite, let him protect you and keep you safe."
22.9: You, LORD, brought me safely through birth, and you protected me when I was a baby at my mother's breast.
22.10: From the day I was born, I have been in your care, and from the time of my birth, you have been my God.
22.11: Don't stay far off when I am in trouble with no one to help me.
22.12: Enemies are all around like a herd of wild bulls. Powerful bulls from Bashan are everywhere.
22.13: My enemies are like lions roaring and attacking with jaws open wide.
22.14: I have no more strength than a few drops of water. All my bones are out of joint; my heart is like melted wax.
22.15: My strength has dried up like a broken clay pot, and my tongue sticks to the roof of my mouth. You, God, have left me to die in the dirt.
22.16: Brutal enemies attack me like a pack of dogs, tearing at my hands and my feet.
22.17: I can count all my bones, and my enemies just stare and sneer at me.
22.18: They took my clothes and gambled for them.
22.19: Don't stay far away, LORD! My strength comes from you, so hurry and help.
22.20: Rescue me from enemy swords and save me from those dogs.
22.21: Don't let lions eat me. You rescued me from the horns of wild bulls,
22.22: and when your people meet, I will praise you, LORD.
22.23: All who worship the LORD, now praise him! You belong to Jacob's family and to the people of Israel, so fear and honor the LORD!
22.24: The LORD doesn't hate or despise the helpless in all of their troubles. When I cried out, he listened and did not turn away.
22.25: When your people meet, you will fill my heart with your praises, LORD, and everyone will see me keep my promises to you.
22.26: The poor will eat and be full, and all who worship you will be thankful and live in hope.
22.27: Everyone on this earth will remember you, LORD. People all over the world will turn and worship you,
22.28: because you are in control, the ruler of all nations.
22.29: All who are rich and have more than enough will bow down to you, Lord. Even those who are dying and almost in the grave will come and bow down.
22.30: In the future, everyone will worship and learn about you, our Lord.
22.31: People not yet born will be told, "The Lord has saved us!"

23.1: You, LORD, are my shepherd. I will never be in need.
23.2: You let me rest in fields of green grass. You lead me to streams of peaceful water,
23.3: and you refresh my life. You are true to your name, and you lead me along the right paths.
23.4: I may walk through valleys as dark as death, but I won't be afraid. You are with me, and your shepherd's rod makes me feel safe.
23.5: You treat me to a feast, while my enemies watch. You honor me as your guest, and you fill my cup until it overflows.
23.6: Your kindness and love will always be with me each day of my life, and I will live forever in your house, LORD.

24.1: The earth and everything on it belong to the LORD. The world and its people belong to him.
24.2: The LORD placed it all on the oceans and rivers.
24.3: Who may climb the LORD's hill or stand in his holy temple?
24.4: Only those who do right for the right reasons, and don't worship idols or tell lies under oath.
24.5: The LORD God, who saves them, will bless and reward them,
24.6: because they worship and serve the God of Jacob.
24.7: Open the ancient gates, so that the glorious king may come in.
24.8: Who is this glorious king? He is our LORD, a strong and mighty warrior.
24.9: Open the ancient gates, so that the glorious king may come in.
24.10: Who is this glorious king? He is our LORD, the All-Powerful!

25.1: I offer you my heart, LORD God,
25.2: and I trust you. Don't make me ashamed or let enemies defeat me.
25.3: Don't disappoint any of your worshipers, but disappoint all deceitful liars.
25.4: Show me your paths and teach me to follow;
25.5: guide me by your truth and instruct me. You keep me safe, and I always trust you.
25.6: Please, LORD, remember, you have always been patient and kind.
25.7: Forget each wrong I did when I was young. Show how truly kind you are and remember me.
25.8: You are honest and merciful, and you teach sinners how to follow your path.
25.9: You lead humble people to do what is right and to stay on your path.
25.10: In everything you do, you are kind and faithful to everyone who keeps our agreement with you.
25.11: Be true to your name, LORD, by forgiving each one of my terrible sins.
25.12: You will show the right path to all who worship you.
25.13: They will have plenty, and then their children will receive the land.
25.14: Our LORD, you are the friend of your worshipers, and you make an agreement with all of us.
25.15: I always look to you, because you rescue me from every trap.
25.16: I am lonely and troubled. Show that you care and have pity on me.
25.17: My awful worries keep growing. Rescue me from sadness.
25.18: See my troubles and misery and forgive my sins.
25.19: Look at all my enemies! See how much they hate me.
25.20: I come to you for shelter. Protect me, keep me safe, and don't disappoint me.
25.21: I obey you with all my heart, and I trust you, knowing that you will save me.
25.22: Our God, please save Israel from all of its troubles.

26.1: Show that I am right, LORD! I stay true to myself, and I have trusted you without doubting.
26.2: Test my thoughts and find out what I am like.
26.3: I never forget your kindness, and I am always faithful to you.
26.4: I don't spend my time with worthless liars
26.6: I wash my hands, LORD, to show my innocence, and I worship at your altar,
26.7: while gratefully singing about your wonders.
26.8: I love the temple where you live, and where your glory shines.
26.9: Don't sweep me away, as you do sinners. Don't punish me with death as you do those people who are brutal
26.10: or full of meanness or who bribe others.
26.11: I stay true to myself. Be kind and rescue me.
26.12: Now I stand on solid ground! And when your people meet, I will praise you, LORD.

27.1: You, LORD, are the light that keeps me safe. I am not afraid of anyone. You protect me, and I have no fears.
27.2: Brutal people may attack and try to kill me, but they will stumble. Fierce enemies may attack, but they will fall.
27.3: Armies may surround me, but I won't be afraid; war may break out, but I will trust you.
27.4: I ask only one thing, LORD: Let me live in your house every day of my life to see how wonderful you are and to pray in your temple.
27.5: In times of trouble, you will protect me. You will hide me in your tent and keep me safe on top of a mighty rock.
27.6: You will let me defeat all of my enemies. Then I will celebrate, as I enter your tent with animal sacrifices and songs of praise.
27.7: Please listen when I pray! Have pity. Answer my prayer.
27.8: My heart tells me to pray. I am eager to see your face,
27.9: so don't hide from me. I am your servant, and you have helped me. Don't turn from me in anger. You alone keep me safe. Don't reject or desert me.
27.10: Even if my father and mother should desert me, you will take care of me.
27.11: Teach me to follow, LORD, and lead me on the right path because of my enemies.
27.12: Don't let them do to me what they want. People tell lies about me and make terrible threats,
27.13: but I know I will live to see how kind you are.
27.14: Trust the LORD! Be brave and strong and trust the LORD.

28.1: Only you, LORD, are a mighty rock! Don't refuse to help me when I pray. If you don't answer me, I will soon be dead.
28.2: Please listen to my prayer and my cry for help, as I lift my hands toward your holy temple.
28.3: Don't drag me away, LORD, with those cruel people, who speak kind words, while planning trouble.
28.4: Treat them as they deserve! Punish them for their sins.
28.5: They don't pay any attention to your wonderful deeds. Now you will destroy them and leave them in ruin.
28.6: I praise you, LORD, for answering my prayers.
28.7: You are my strong shield, and I trust you completely. You have helped me, and I will celebrate and thank you in song.
28.8: You give strength to your people, LORD, and you save and protect your chosen ones.
28.9: Come save us and bless us. Be our shepherd and always carry us in your arms.

29.1: All of you angels in heaven, honor the glory and power of the LORD!
29.2: Honor the wonderful name of the LORD, and worship the LORD most holy and glorious.
29.3: The voice of the LORD echoes over the oceans. The glorious LORD God thunders above the roar of the raging sea,
29.4: and his voice is mighty and marvelous.
29.5: The voice of the LORD destroys the cedar trees; the LORD shatters cedars on Mount Lebanon.
29.6: God makes Mount Lebanon skip like a calf and Mount Hermon jump like a wild ox.
29.7: The voice of the LORD makes lightning flash
