14.22: The LORD All-Powerful has promised to attack Babylonia and destroy everyone there, so that none of them will ever be remembered again.
14.23: The LORD will sweep out the people, and the land will become a swamp for wild animals. Assyria Will Be Punished
14.24: The LORD All-Powerful has made this promise: Everything I have planned will happen just as I said.
14.25: I will wipe out every Assyrian in my country, and I will crush those on my mountains. I will free my people from slavery to the Assyrians.
14.26: I have planned this for the whole world, and my mighty arm controls every nation.
14.27: I, the LORD All-Powerful, have made these plans. No one can stop me now! The Philistines Will Be Punished
14.28: This message came from the LORD in the year King Ahaz died:
14.29: Philistines, don't be happy just because the rod that punished you is broken. That rod will become a poisonous snake, and then a flying fiery dragon.
14.30: The poor and needy will find pastures for their sheep and will live in safety. But I will starve some of you, and others will be killed.
14.31: Cry and weep in the gates of your towns, you Philistines! Smoke blows in from the north, and every soldier is ready.
14.32: If a messenger comes from a distant nation, you must say: "The LORD built Zion. Even the poorest of his people will find safety there."

15.1: This is a message about Moab: The towns of Ar and Kir were destroyed in a night. Moab is left in ruins!
15.2: Everyone in Dibon has gone up to the temple and the shrines to cry and weep. All of Moab is crying. Heads and beards are shaved because of what happened at Nebo and Medeba.
15.3: In the towns and at home, everyone wears sackcloth and cries loud and long.
15.4: From Heshbon and Elealeh, weeping is heard in Jahaz; Moab's warriors scream while trembling with fear. Pity Moab
15.5: I pity Moab! Its people are running to Zoar and to Eglath-Shelishiyah. They cry on their way up to the town of Luhith; on the road to Horonaim they tell of disasters.
15.6: The streams of Nimrim and the grasslands have dried up. Every plant is parched.
15.7: The people of Moab are leaving, crossing over Willow Creek, taking everything they own and have worked for.
15.8: In the towns of Eglaim and of Beerelim and everywhere else in Moab mournful cries are heard.
15.9: The streams near Dimon are flowing with blood. But the Lord will bring even worse trouble to Dimon, because all in Moab who escape will be attacked by lions.

16.1: Send lambs as gifts to the ruler of the land. Send them across the desert from Sela to Mount Zion.
16.2: The women of Moab crossing the Arnon River are like a flock of birds scattered from their nests.
16.3: Moab's messengers say to the people of Judah, "Be kind and help us! Shade us from the heat of the noonday sun. Hide our refugees! Don't turn them away.
16.4: Let our people live in your country and find safety here." Moab, your cruel enemies will disappear; they will no longer attack and destroy your land.
16.5: Then a kingdom of love will be set up, and someone from David's family will rule with fairness. He will do what is right and quickly bring justice. Moab's Pride Is Destroyed
16.6: We have heard of Moab's pride. Its people strut and boast, but without reason.
16.7: Tell everyone in Moab to mourn for their nation. Tell them to cry and weep for those fancy raisins of Kir-Hareseth.
16.8: Vineyards near Heshbon and Sibmah have turned brown. The rulers of nations used to get drunk on wine from those vineyards that spread to Jazer, then across the desert and beyond the sea.
16.9: Now I mourn like Jazer for the vineyards of Sibmah. I shed tears for Heshbon and for Elealeh. There will be no more harvest celebrations
16.10: or joyful and happy times, while bringing in the crops. Singing and shouting are gone from the vineyards. There are no joyful shouts where grapes were pressed. God has silenced them all.
16.11: Deep in my heart I hurt for Moab and Kir-Heres.
16.12: It's useless for Moab's people to wear themselves out by going to their altars to worship and pray.
16.13: The LORD has already said all of this about Moab.
16.14: Now he says, "The contract of a hired worker is good for three years, but Moab's glory and greatness won't last any longer than that. Only a few of its people will survive, and they will be left helpless."

17.1: This is a message about Damascus: Damascus is doomed! It will end up in ruins.
17.2: The villages around Aroer will be deserted, with only sheep living there and no one to bother them.
17.3: Israel will lose its fortresses. The kingdom of Damascus will be destroyed; its survivors will suffer the same fate as Israel. The LORD All-Powerful has promised this. Sin and Suffering
17.4: When that time comes, the glorious nation of Israel will be brought down; its prosperous people will be skin and bones.
17.5: Israel will be like wheat fields in Rephaim Valley picked clean of grain.
17.6: It will be like an olive tree beaten with a stick, leaving two or three olives or maybe four or five on the highest or most fruitful branches. The LORD God of Israel has promised this.
17.7: At that time the people will turn and trust their Creator, the holy God of Israel.
17.8: They have built altars and places for burning incense to their goddess Asherah, and they have set up sacred poles for her. But they will stop worshiping at these places.
17.9: Israel captured powerful cities and chased out the people who lived there. But these cities will lie in ruins, covered over with weeds and underbrush.
17.10: Israel, you have forgotten the God who saves you, the one who is the mighty rock where you find protection. You plant the finest flowers to honor a foreign god.
17.11: The plants may sprout and blossom that very same morning, but it will do you no good, because you will suffer endless agony. God Defends His People
17.12: The nations are a noisy, thunderous sea.
17.13: But even if they roar like a fearsome flood, God will give the command to turn them back. They will be like dust, or like a tumbleweed blowing across the hills in a windstorm.
17.14: In the evening their attack is fierce, but by morning they are destroyed. This is what happens to those who raid and rob us.

18.1: Downstream from Ethiopia lies the country of Egypt, swarming with insects.
18.2: Egypt sends messengers up the Nile River on ships made of reeds. Send them fast to Ethiopia, whose people are tall and have smooth skin. Their land is divided by rivers; they are strong and brutal, feared all over the world.
18.3: Everyone on this earth, listen with care! A signal will be given on the mountains, and you will hear a trumpet.
18.4: The LORD said to me, "I will calmly look down from my home above-- as calmly as the sun at noon or clouds in the heat of harvest season."
18.5: Before the blossoms can turn into grapes, God will cut off the sprouts and hack off the branches.
18.6: Ethiopians will be food for mountain buzzards during the summer and for wild animals during the winter.
18.7: Those Ethiopians are tall and their skin is smooth. They are feared all over the world, because they are strong and brutal. But at that time they will come from their land divided by rivers, and they will bring gifts to the LORD All-Powerful, who is worshiped on Mount Zion.

19.1: This is a message about Egypt: The LORD comes to Egypt, riding swiftly on a cloud. The people are weak from fear. Their idols tremble as he approaches and says,
19.2: "I will punish Egypt with civil war-- neighbors, cities, and kingdoms will fight each other.
19.3: "Egypt will be discouraged when I confuse their plans. They will try to get advice from their idols, from the spirits of the dead, and from fortunetellers.
19.4: I will put the Egyptians under the power of a cruel, heartless king. I, the LORD All-Powerful, have promised this." Trouble along the Nile
19.5: The Nile River will dry up and become parched land.
19.6: Its streams will stink, Egypt will have no water, and the reeds and tall grass will dry up.
19.7: Fields along the Nile will be completely barren; every plant will disappear.
19.8: Those who fish in the Nile will be discouraged and mourn.
19.9: None of the cloth makers will know what to do, and they will turn pale.
19.10: Weavers will be confused; paid workers will cry and mourn. Egypt's Helpless Leaders
19.11: The king's officials in Zoan are foolish themselves and give stupid advice. How can they say to him, "We are very wise, and our families go back to kings of long ago?"
19.12: Where are those wise men now? If they can, let them say what the LORD All-Powerful intends for Egypt.
19.13: The royal officials in Zoan and in Memphis are foolish and deceived. The leaders in every state have given bad advice to the nation.
19.14: The LORD has confused Egypt; its leaders have made it stagger and vomit like a drunkard.
19.15: No one in Egypt can do a thing, no matter who they are.
19.16: When the LORD All-Powerful punishes Egypt with his mighty arm, the Egyptians will become terribly weak and will tremble with fear.
19.17: They will be so terrified of Judah that they will be frightened by the very mention of its name. This will happen because of what the LORD All-Powerful is planning against Egypt. The LORD Will Bless Egypt, Assyria, and Israel
19.18: The time is coming when Hebrew will be spoken in five Egyptian cities, and their people will become followers of the LORD. One of these cities will be called City of the Sun.
19.19: In the heart of Egypt an altar will be set up for the LORD; at its border a shrine will be built to honor him.
19.20: These will remind the Egyptians that the LORD All-Powerful is with them. And when they are in trouble and ask for help, he will send someone to rescue them from their enemies.
19.21: The LORD will show the Egyptians who he is, and they will know and worship the LORD. They will bring him sacrifices and offerings, and they will keep their promises to him.
19.22: After the LORD has punished Egypt, the people will turn to him. Then he will answer their prayers, and the Egyptians will be healed.
19.23: At that time a good road will run from Egypt to Assyria. The Egyptians and the Assyrians will travel back and forth from Egypt to Assyria, and they will worship together.
19.24: Israel will join with these two countries. They will be a blessing to everyone on earth,
19.25: then the LORD All-Powerful will bless them by saying, "The Egyptians are my people. I created the Assyrians and chose the Israelites."

20.1: King Sargon of Assyria gave orders for his army commander to capture the city of Ashdod.
20.2: About this same time the LORD had told me, "Isaiah, take off everything, including your sandals!" I did this and went around naked and barefoot
20.3: for three years. Then the LORD said: What Isaiah has done is a warning to Egypt and Ethiopia.
20.4: Everyone in these two countries will be led away naked and barefoot by the king of Assyria. Young or old, they will be taken prisoner, and Egypt will be disgraced.
20.5: They will be confused and frustrated, because they depended on Ethiopia and bragged about Egypt.
20.6: When this happens, the people who live along the coast will say, "Look what happened to them! We ran to them for safety, hoping they would protect us from the king of Assyria. But now, there is no escape for us."

21.1: This is a message about a desert beside the sea: Enemies from a hostile nation attack like a whirlwind from the Southern Desert.
21.2: What a horrible vision was shown to me-- a vision of betrayal and destruction. Tell Elam and Media to surround and attack the Babylonians. The LORD has sworn to end the suffering they caused.
21.3: I'm in terrible pain like a woman giving birth. I'm shocked and hurt so much that I can't hear or see.
21.4: My head spins; I'm horrified! Early evening, my favorite time, has become a nightmare.
21.5: In Babylon the high officials were having a feast. They were eating and drinking, when someone shouted, "Officers, take your places! Grab your shields."
21.6: The LORD said to me, "Send guards to find out what's going on.
21.7: When they see cavalry troops and columns of soldiers on donkeys and camels, tell them to be ready!"
21.8: Then a guard said, "I have stood day and night on this watchtower, Lord.
21.9: Now I see column after column of cavalry troops." Right away someone shouted, "Babylon has fallen! Every idol in the city lies broken on the ground."
21.10: Then I said, "My people, you have suffered terribly, but I have a message for you from the LORD All-Powerful, the God of Israel." How Much Longer?
21.11: This is a message about Dumah: From the country of Seir, someone shouts to me, "Guard, how much longer before daylight?"
21.12: From my guard post, I answered, "Morning will soon be here, but night will return. If you want to know more, come back later."
21.13: This is a message for Arabs who live in the barren desert in the region of Dedan: You must order your caravans
21.14: to bring water for those who are thirsty. You people of Tema must bring food for the hungry refugees.
21.15: They are worn out and weary from being chased by enemies with swords and arrows.
21.16: The Lord said to me: A year from now the glory of the people of Kedar will all come to an end, just as a worker's contract ends after a year.
21.17: Only a few of their warriors will be left with bows and arrows. This is a promise that I, the LORD God of Israel, have made.

22.1: This is a message about Vision Valley: Why are you celebrating on the flat roofs of your houses?
22.2: Your city is filled with noisy shouts. Those who lie drunk in your streets were not killed in battle.
22.3: Your leaders ran away, but they were captured without a fight. No matter how far they ran, they were found and caught.
22.4: Then I said, "Leave me alone! Let me cry bitter tears. My people have been destroyed, so don't try to comfort me."
22.5: The LORD All-Powerful had chosen a time for noisy shouts and confusion to fill Vision Valley, and for everyone to beg the mountains for help.
22.6: The people of Elam and Kir attacked with chariots and carried shields.
22.7: Your most beautiful valleys were covered with chariots; your cities were surrounded by cavalry troops.
22.8: Judah was left defenseless. At that time you trusted in the weapons you had stored in Forest Palace.
22.9: You saw the holes in the outer wall of Jerusalem, and you brought water from the lower pool.
22.10: You counted the houses in Jerusalem and tore down some of them, so you could get stones to repair the city wall.
22.11: Then you built a large tank between the walls to store the water. But you refused to trust the God who planned this long ago and made it happen. A Time To Weep
22.12: When all of this happened, the LORD All-Powerful told you to weep and mourn, to shave your heads, and wear sackcloth.
22.13: But instead, you celebrated by feasting on beef and lamb and by drinking wine, because you said, "Let's eat and drink! Tomorrow we may die."
22.14: The LORD All-Powerful has spoken to me this solemn promise: "I won't forgive them for this, not as long as they live." Selfish Officials Are Doomed
22.15: The LORD All-Powerful is sending you with this message for Shebna, the prime minister:
22.16: Shebna, what gives you the right to have a tomb carved out of rock in this burial place of royalty? None of your relatives are buried here.
22.17: You may be powerful, but the LORD is about to snatch you up and throw you away.
22.18: He will roll you into a ball and throw you into a wide open country, where you will die and your chariots will be destroyed. You're a disgrace to those you serve.
22.19: The LORD is going to take away your job!
22.20: He will give your official robes and your authority to his servant Eliakim son of Hilkiah. Eliakim will be like a father to the people of Jerusalem and to the royal family of Judah.
22.22: The LORD will put him in charge of the key that belongs to King David's family. No one will be able to unlock what he locks, and no one will be able to lock what he unlocks.
22.23: The LORD will make him as firm in his position as a tent peg hammered in the ground, and Eliakim will bring honor to his family.
22.24: His children and relatives will be supported by him, like pans hanging from a peg on the wall.
22.25: That peg is fastened firmly now, but someday it will be shaken loose and fall down. Then everything that was hanging on it will be destroyed. This is what the LORD All-Powerful has promised.

23.1: This is a message from distant islands about the city of Tyre: Cry, you seagoing ships! Tyre and its houses lie in ruins.
23.2: Mourn in silence, you shop owners of Sidon, you people on the coast. Your sailors crossed oceans, making your city rich.
23.3: Your merchants sailed the seas, making you wealthy by trading with nation after nation. They brought back grain that grew along the Nile.
23.4: Sidon, you are a mighty fortress built along the sea. But you will be disgraced like a married woman who never had children.
23.5: When Egypt hears about Tyre, it will tremble.
23.6: All of you along the coast had better cry and sail far across the ocean.
23.7: Can this be the happy city that has stood for centuries? Its people have spread to distant lands;
23.8: its merchants were kings honored all over the world. Who planned to destroy Tyre?
23.9: The LORD All-Powerful planned it to bring shame and disgrace to those who are honored by everyone on earth.
23.10: People of Tyre, your harbor is destroyed! You will have to become farmers just like the Egyptians. Tyre Will Be Forgotten
23.11: The LORD's hand has reached across the sea, upsetting the nations. He has given a command to destroy fortresses in the land of Canaan.
23.12: The LORD has said to the people of Sidon, "Your celebrating is over-- you are crushed. Even if you escape to Cyprus, you won't find peace."
23.13: Look what the Assyrians have done to Babylonia! They have attacked, destroying every palace in the land. Now wild animals live among the ruins.
23.14: Not a fortress will be left standing, so tell all the seagoing ships to mourn.
23.15: The city of Tyre will be forgotten for seventy years, which is the lifetime of a king. Then Tyre will be like that evil woman in the song:
23.16: You're gone and forgotten, you evil woman! So strut through the town, singing and playing your favorite tune to be remembered again.
23.17: At the end of those seventy years, the LORD will let Tyre get back into business. The city will be like a woman who sells her body to everyone of every nation on earth,
23.18: but none of what is earned will be kept in the city. That money will belong to the LORD, and it will be used to buy more than enough food and good clothes for those who worship the LORD.

24.1: The LORD is going to twist the earth out of shape and turn it into a desert. Everyone will be scattered,
24.2: including ordinary people and priests, slaves and slave owners, buyers and sellers, lenders and borrowers, the rich and the poor.
24.3: The earth will be stripped bare and left that way. This is what the LORD has promised.
24.4: The earth wilts away; its mighty leaders melt to nothing.
24.5: The earth is polluted because its people disobeyed the laws of God, breaking their agreement that was to last forever.
24.6: The earth is under a curse; its people are dying out because of their sins.
24.7: Grapevines have dried up: wine is almost gone-- mournful sounds are heard instead of joyful shouts.
24.8: No one plays tambourines or stringed instruments; all noisy celebrating has come to an end.
24.9: They no longer sing as they drink their wine, and it tastes sour.
24.10: Towns are crushed and in chaos; houses are locked tight.
24.11: Happy times have disappeared from the earth, and people shout in the streets, "We're out of wine!"
24.12: Cities are destroyed; their gates are torn down.
24.13: Nations will be stripped bare, like olive trees or vineyards after the harvest season. Praise the God of Justice
24.14: People in the west shout; they joyfully praise the majesty of the LORD.
24.15: And so, everyone in the east and those on the islands should praise the LORD, the God of Israel.
24.16: From all over the world songs of praise are heard for the God of justice. But I feel awful, terribly miserable. Can anyone be trusted? So many are treacherous! There's No Escape
24.17: Terror, traps, and pits are waiting for everyone.
24.18: If you are terrified and run, you will fall into a pit; if you crawl out of the pit, you will get caught in a trap. The sky has split apart like a window thrown open. The foundations of the earth have been shaken;
24.19: the earth is shattered, ripped to pieces.
24.20: It staggers and shakes like a drunkard or a hut in a windstorm. It is burdened down with sin; the earth will fall, never again to get up.
24.21: On that day the LORD will punish the powers in the heavens and the kings of the earth.
24.22: He will put them in a pit and keep them prisoner. Then later on, he will punish them.
24.23: The moon and sun will both be embarrassed and ashamed. The LORD All-Powerful will rule on Mount Zion in Jerusalem, where he will show its rulers his wonderful glory.

25.1: You, LORD, are my God! I will praise you for doing the wonderful things you had planned and promised since ancient times.
25.2: You have destroyed the fortress of our enemies, leaving their city in ruins. Nothing in that foreign city will ever be rebuilt.
25.3: Now strong and cruel nations will fear and honor you.
25.4: You have been a place of safety for the poor and needy in times of trouble. Brutal enemies pounded us like a heavy rain or the heat of the sun at noon, but you were our shelter.
25.5: Those wild foreigners struck like scorching desert heat. But you were like a cloud, protecting us from the sun. You kept our enemies from singing songs of victory. The LORD Has Saved Us
25.6: On this mountain the LORD All-Powerful will prepare for all nations a feast of the finest foods. Choice wines and the best meats will be served.
25.7: Here the LORD will strip away the burial clothes that cover the nations.
25.8: The LORD All-Powerful will destroy the power of death and wipe away all tears. No longer will his people be insulted everywhere. The LORD has spoken!
25.9: At that time, people will say, "The LORD has saved us! Let's celebrate. We waited and hoped-- now our God is here."
25.10: The powerful arm of the LORD will protect this mountain. The Moabites will be put down and trampled on like straw in a pit of manure.
25.11: They will struggle to get out, but God will humiliate them no matter how hard they try.
25.12: The walls of their fortresses will be knocked down and scattered in the dirt.

26.1: The time is coming when the people of Judah will sing this song: "Our city is protected. The LORD is our fortress, and he gives us victory.
26.2: Open the city gates for a law-abiding nation that is faithful to God.
26.3: The LORD gives perfect peace to those whose faith is firm.
26.4: So always trust the LORD because he is forever our mighty rock.
26.5: God has put down our enemies in their mountain city and rubbed it in the dirt.
26.6: Now the poor and abused stomp all over that city." The LORD Can Be Trusted
26.7: Our LORD, you always do right, and you make the path smooth for those who obey you.
26.8: You are the one we trust to bring about justice; above all else we want your name to be honored.
26.9: Throughout the night, my heart searches for you, because your decisions show everyone on this earth how to live right.
26.10: Even when the wicked are treated with mercy in this land of justice, they do wrong and are blind to your glory, our LORD.
26.11: Your hand is raised and ready to punish them, but they don't see it. Put them to shame! Show how much you care for us and throw them into the fire intended for your enemies.
26.12: You will give us peace, LORD, because everything we have done was by your power.
26.13: Others have ruled over us besides you, our LORD God, but we obey only you.
26.14: Those enemies are now dead and can never live again. You have punished them-- they are destroyed, completely forgotten.
26.15: Our nation has grown because of you, our LORD. We have more land than before, and you are honored. The LORD Gives Life to the Dead
26.16: When you punished our people, they turned and prayed to you, our LORD.
26.17: Because of what you did to us, we suffered like a woman about to give birth.
26.18: But instead of having a child, our terrible pain produced only wind. We have won no victories, and we have no descendants to take over the earth.
26.19: Your people will rise to life! Tell them to leave their graves and celebrate with shouts. You refresh the earth like morning dew; you give life to the dead.
26.20: Go inside and lock the doors, my people. Hide there for a little while, until the LORD is no longer angry. The Earth and the Sea Will Be Punished
26.21: The LORD will come out to punish everyone on earth for their sins. And when he does, those who did violent crimes will be known and punished.

27.1: On that day, Leviathan, the sea monster, will squirm and try to escape, but the LORD will kill him with a cruel, sharp sword. Protection and ForgivenessThe LORD said:
27.2: At that time you must sing about a fruitful vineyard.
27.3: I, the LORD, will protect it and always keep it watered. I will guard it day and night to keep it from harm.
27.4: I am no longer angry. But if it produces thorns, I will go to war against it and burn it to the ground.
27.5: Yet if the vineyard depends on me for protection, it will become my friend and be at peace with me.
27.6: Someday Israel will take root like a vine. It will blossom and bear fruit that covers the earth.
27.7: I, the LORD, didn't punish and kill the people of Israel as fiercely as I punished and killed their enemies.
27.8: I carefully measured out Israel's punishment and sent the scorching heat to chase them far away.
27.9: There's only one way that Israel's sin and guilt can be completely forgiven: They must crush the stones of every pagan altar and place of worship. The LORD Will Bring His People Together
27.10: Fortress cities are left like a desert where no one lives. Cattle walk through the ruins, stripping the trees bare.
27.11: When broken branches fall to the ground, women pick them up to feed the fire. But these people are so stupid that the God who created them will show them no mercy.
27.12: The time is coming when the LORD will shake the land between the Euphrates River and the border of Egypt, and one by one he will bring all of his people together.
27.13: A loud trumpet will be heard. Then the people of Israel who were dragged away to Assyria and Egypt will return to worship the LORD on his holy mountain in Jerusalem.

28.1: The city of Samaria above a fertile valley is in for trouble! Its leaders are drunkards, who stuff themselves with food and wine. But they will be like flowers that dry up and wilt.
28.2: Only the Lord is strong and powerful! His mighty hand will strike them down with the force of a hailstorm or a mighty whirlwind or an overwhelming flood.
28.3: Every drunkard in Ephraim takes pride in Samaria, but it will be crushed.
28.4: Samaria above a fertile valley will quickly lose its glory. It will be gobbled down like the first ripe fig at harvest season.
28.5: When this time comes, the LORD All-Powerful will be a glorious crown for his people who survive.
28.6: He will see that justice rules and that his people are able to defend their cities. Corrupt Leaders Will Be Punished
28.7: Priests and prophets stumble because they are drunk. Their minds are too confused to receive God's messages or give honest decisions.
28.8: Their tables are covered, completely covered, with their stinking vomit.
28.9: You drunken leaders are like babies! How can you possibly understand or teach the LORD's message?
28.10: You don't even listen-- all you hear is senseless sound after senseless sound.
28.11: So, the Lord will speak to his people in strange sounds and foreign languages.
28.12: He promised you perfect peace and rest, but you refused to listen.
28.13: Now his message to you will be senseless sound after senseless sound. Then you will fall backwards, injured and trapped. False Security Is Fatal
28.14: You rulers of Jerusalem do nothing but sneer; now you must listen to what the LORD says.
28.15: Do you think you have an agreement with death and the world of the dead? Why do you trust in your lies to keep you safe from danger and the mighty flood?
28.16: And so the LORD says, "I'm laying a firm foundation for the city of Zion. It's a valuable cornerstone proven to be trustworthy; no one who trusts it will ever be disappointed.
28.17: Justice and fairness will be the measuring lines that help me build." Hailstones and floods will destroy and wash away your shelter of lies.
28.18: Your agreement with death and the world of the dead will be broken. Then angry, roaring waves will sweep over you.
28.19: Morning, noon, and night an overwhelming flood will wash you away. The terrible things that happen will teach you this lesson:
28.20: Your bed is too short, your blanket too skimpy.
28.21: The LORD will fiercely attack as he did at Mount Perazim and in Gibeon Valley. But this time the LORD will do something surprising, not what you expect.
28.22: So you had better stop sneering or you will be in worse shape than ever before. I heard the LORD All-Powerful threaten the whole country with destruction. All Wisdom Comes from the LORD
28.23: Pay close attention to what I am saying.
28.24: Farmers don't just plow and break up the ground.
28.25: When a field is ready, they scatter the seeds of dill and cumin; they plant the seeds of wheat and barley in the proper places.
28.26: They learn this from their God.
28.27: After dill and cumin have been harvested, the stalks are pounded, not run over with a wagon.
28.28: Wheat and barley are pounded, but not beaten to pulp; they are run over with a wagon, but not ground to dust.
28.29: This wonderful knowledge comes from the LORD All-Powerful, who has such great wisdom.

29.1: Jerusalem, city of David, the place of my altar, you are in for trouble! Celebrate your festivals year after year.
29.2: I will still make you suffer, and your people will cry when I make an altar of you.
29.3: I will surround you and prepare to attack from all sides.
29.4: From deep in the earth, you will call out for help with only a faint whisper.
29.5: Then your cruel enemies will suddenly be swept away like dust in a windstorm.
29.6: I, the LORD All-Powerful, will come to your rescue with a thundering earthquake and a fiery whirlwind.
29.7: Every brutal nation that attacks Jerusalem and makes it suffer will disappear like a dream when night is over.
29.8: Those nations that attack Mount Zion will suffer from hunger and thirst. They will dream of food and drink but wake up weary and hungry and thirsty as ever. Prophets Who Fool Themselves
29.9: Be shocked and stunned, you prophets! Refuse to see. Get drunk and stagger, but not from wine.
29.10: The LORD has made you drowsy; he put you into a deep sleep and covered your head.
29.11: Now his message is like a sealed letter to you. Some of you say, "We can't read it, because it's sealed."
29.12: Others say, "We can't read it, because we don't know how to read."
29.13: The Lord has said: "These people praise me with their words, but they never really think about me. They worship me by repeating rules made up by humans.
29.14: So once again I will do things that shock and amaze them, and I will destroy the wisdom of those who claim to know and understand."
29.15: You are in for trouble, if you try to hide your plans from the LORD! Or if you think what you do in the dark can't be seen.
29.16: You have it all backwards. A clay dish doesn't say to the potter, "You didn't make me. You don't even know how." Hope for the Future
29.17: Soon the forest of Lebanon will become a field with crops, thick as a forest.
29.18: The deaf will be able to hear whatever is read to them; the blind will be freed from a life of darkness.
29.19: The poor and the needy will celebrate and shout because of the LORD, the holy God of Israel.
29.20: All who are cruel and arrogant will be gone forever. Those who live by crime will disappear,
29.21: together with everyone who tells lies in court and keeps innocent people from getting a fair trial.
29.22: The LORD who rescued Abraham has this to say about Jacob's descendants: "They will no longer be ashamed and disgraced.
29.23: When they see how great I have made their nation, they will praise and honor me, the holy God of Israel.
29.24: Everyone who is confused will understand, and all who have complained will obey my teaching."

30.1: This is the LORD's message for his rebellious people: "You follow your own plans instead of mine; you make treaties without asking me, and you keep on sinning.
30.2: You trust Egypt for protection. So you refuse my advice and send messengers to Egypt to beg their king for help.
30.3: You will be disappointed, completely disgraced for trusting Egypt.
30.4: The king's power reaches from the city of Zoan as far south as Hanes.
30.5: But Egypt can't protect you, and to trust that nation is useless and foolish."
30.6: This is a message about the animals of the Southern Desert: You people carry treasures on donkeys and camels. You travel to a feeble nation through a troublesome desert filled with lions and flying fiery dragons.
30.7: Egypt can't help you! That's why I call that nation a helpless monster." Israel Refuses To Listen
30.8: The LORD told me to write down his message for his people, so that it would be there forever.
30.9: They have turned against the LORD and can't be trusted. They have refused his teaching
30.10: and have said to his messengers and prophets: Don't tell us what God has shown you and don't preach the truth. Just say what we want to hear, even if it's false.
30.11: Stop telling us what God has said! We don't want to hear any more about the holy God of Israel.
30.12: Now this is the answer of the holy God of Israel: "You rejected my message, and you trust in violence and lies.
30.13: This sin is like a crack that makes a high wall quickly crumble
30.14: and shatter like a crushed bowl. There's not a piece left big enough to carry hot coals or to dip out water." Trust the LORD
30.15: The holy LORD God of Israel had told all of you, "I will keep you safe if you turn back to me and calm down. I will make you strong if you quietly trust me." Then you stubbornly
30.16: said, "No! We will safely escape on speedy horses." But those who chase you will be even faster.
30.17: As few as five of them, or even one, will be enough to chase a thousand of you. Finally, all that will be left will be a few survivors as lonely as a flag pole on a barren hill. The LORD Will Show Mercy
30.18: The LORD God is waiting to show how kind he is and to have pity on you. The LORD always does right; he blesses those who trust him.
30.19: People of Jerusalem, you don't need to cry anymore. The Lord is kind, and as soon as he hears your cries for help, he will come.
30.20: The Lord has given you trouble and sorrow as your food and drink. But now you will again see the Lord, your teacher, and he will guide you.
30.21: Whether you turn to the right or to the left, you will hear a voice saying, "This is the road! Now follow it."
30.22: Then you will treat your idols of silver and gold like garbage; you will throw them away like filthy rags.
30.23: The Lord will send rain to water the seeds you have planted--your fields will produce more crops than you need, and your cattle will graze in open pastures.
30.24: Even the oxen and donkeys that plow your fields will be fed the finest grain.
30.25: On that day people will be slaughtered and towers destroyed, but streams of water will flow from high hills and towering mountains.
30.26: Then the LORD will bandage his people's injuries and heal the wounds he has caused. The moon will shine as bright as the sun, and the sun will shine seven times brighter than usual. It will be like the light of seven days all at once. Assyria Will Be Punished
30.27: The LORD is coming from far away with his fiery anger and thick clouds of smoke. His angry words flame up like a destructive fire;
30.28: he breathes out a flood that comes up to the neck. He sifts the nations and destroys them. Then he puts a bridle in every foreigner's mouth and leads them to doom.
30.29: The LORD's people will sing as they do when they celebrate a religious festival at night. The LORD is Israel's mighty rock, and his people will be as happy as they are when they follow the sound of flutes to the mountain where he is worshiped.
30.30: The LORD will get furious. His fearsome voice will be heard, his arm will be seen ready to strike, and his anger will be like a destructive fire, followed by thunderstorms and hailstones.
30.31: When the Assyrians hear the LORD's voice and see him striking with his iron rod, they will be terrified.
30.32: He will attack them in battle, and each time he strikes them, it will be to the music of tambourines and harps.
30.33: Long ago the LORD got a place ready for burning the body of the dead king. The place for the fire is deep and wide, the wood is piled high, and the LORD will start the fire by breathing out flaming sulfur.

31.1: You are in for trouble if you go to Egypt for help, or if you depend on an army of chariots or a powerful cavalry. Instead you should depend on and trust the holy LORD God of Israel.
31.2: The LORD isn't stupid! He does what he promises, and he can bring doom. If you are cruel yourself, or help those who are evil, you will be destroyed.
31.3: The Egyptians are mere humans. They aren't God. Their horses are made of flesh; they can't live forever. When the LORD shows his power, he will destroy the Egyptians and all who depend on them. Together they will fall.
31.4: The LORD All-Powerful said to me, "I will roar and attack like a fearless lion not frightened by the shouts of shepherds trying to protect their sheep. That's how I will come down and fight on Mount Zion.
31.5: I, the LORD All-Powerful, will protect Jerusalem like a mother bird circling over her nest." Come Back to the LORD
31.6: People of Israel, come back! You have completely turned from the LORD.
31.7: The time is coming when you will throw away your idols of silver and gold, made by your sinful hands.
31.8: The Assyrians will be killed, but not by the swords of humans. Their young men will try to escape, but they will be captured and forced into slavery.
31.9: Their fortress will fall when terror strikes; their army officers will be frightened and run from the battle. This is what the LORD has said, the LORD whose fiery furnace is built on Mount Zion.

32.1: A king and his leaders will rule with justice.
32.2: They will be a place of safety from stormy winds, a stream in the desert, and a rock that gives shade from the heat of the sun.
32.3: Then everyone who has eyes will open them and see, and those who have ears will pay attention.
32.4: All who are impatient will take time to think; everyone who stutters will talk clearly.
32.5: Fools will no longer be highly respected, and crooks won't be given positions of honor.
32.6: Fools talk foolishness. They always make plans to do sinful things, to lie about the LORD, to let the hungry starve, and to keep water from those who are thirsty.
32.7: Cruel people tell lies-- they do evil things, and make cruel plans to destroy the poor and needy, even when they beg for justice.
32.8: But helpful people can always be trusted to make helpful plans. Punishment for the Women of Jerusalem
32.9: Listen to what I say, you women who are carefree and careless!
32.10: You may not have worries now, but in about a year, the grape harvest will fail, and you will tremble.
32.11: Shake and shudder, you women without a care! Strip off your clothes-- put on sackcloth.
32.12: Slap your breasts in sorrow because of what happened to the fruitful fields and vineyards,
32.13: and to the happy homes in Jerusalem. The land of my people is covered with thorns.
32.14: The palace will be deserted, the crowded city empty. Fortresses and towers will forever become playgrounds for wild donkeys and pastures for sheep. God's Spirit Makes the Difference
32.15: When the Spirit is given to us from heaven, deserts will become orchards thick as fertile forests.
32.16: Honesty and justice will prosper there,
32.17: and justice will produce lasting peace and security.
32.18: You, the LORD's people, will live in peace, calm and secure,
32.19: even if hailstones flatten forests and cities.
32.20: You will have God's blessing, as you plant your crops beside streams, while your donkeys and cattle roam freely about.

33.1: You defeated my people. Now you're in for trouble! You've never been destroyed, but you will be destroyed; you've never been betrayed, but you will be betrayed. When you have finished destroying and betraying, you will be destroyed and betrayed in return.
33.2: Please, LORD, be kind to us! We depend on you. Make us strong each morning, and come to save us when we are in trouble.
33.3: Nations scatter when you roar and show your greatness.
33.4: We attack our enemies like swarms of locusts; we take everything that belongs to them.
33.5: You, LORD, are above all others, and you live in the heavens. You have brought justice and fairness to Jerusalem;
33.6: you are the foundation on which we stand today. You always save us and give true wisdom and knowledge. Nothing means more to us than obeying you. The LORD Will Do Something
33.7: Listen! Our bravest soldiers are running through the streets, screaming for help. Our messengers hoped for peace, but came home crying.
33.8: No one travels anymore; every road is empty. Treaties are broken, and no respect is shown to any who keep promises.
33.9: Fields are dry and barren; Mount Lebanon wilts with shame. Sharon Valley is a desert; the forests of Bashan and Carmel have lost their leaves.
33.10: But the LORD says, "Now I will do something and be greatly praised.
33.11: Your deeds are straw that will be set on fire by your very own breath.
33.12: You will be burned to ashes like thorns in a fire.
33.13: Everyone, both far and near, come look at what I have done. See my mighty power!" Punishment and Rewards
33.14: Those terrible sinners on Mount Zion tremble as they ask in fear, "How can we possibly live where a raging fire never stops burning?"
33.15: But there will be rewards for those who live right and tell the truth, for those who refuse to take money by force or accept bribes, for all who hate murder and violent crimes.
33.16: They will live in a fortress high on a rocky cliff, where they will have food and plenty of water. The LORD Is Our King
33.17: With your own eyes you will see the glorious King; you will see his kingdom reaching far and wide.
33.18: Then you will ask yourself, "Where are those officials who terrified us and forced us to pay such heavy taxes?"
33.19: You will never again have to see the proud people who spoke a strange and foreign language you could not understand.
33.20: Look to Mount Zion where we celebrate our religious festivals. You will see Jerusalem, secure as a tent with pegs that cannot be pulled up and fastened with ropes that can never be broken.
33.21: Our wonderful LORD will be with us! There will be deep rivers and wide streams safe from enemy ships. The LORD Is Our Judge
33.22: The LORD is our judge and our ruler; the LORD is our king and will keep us safe.
33.23: But your nation is a ship with its rigging loose, its mast shaky, and its sail not spread. Someday even you that are lame will take everything you want from your enemies.
33.24: The LORD will forgive your sins, and none of you will say, "I feel sick."

34.1: Everyone of every nation, the entire earth, and all of its creatures, come here and listen!
34.2: The LORD is terribly angry with the nations; he has condemned them to be slaughtered.
34.3: Their dead bodies will be left to rot and stink; their blood will flow down the mountains.
34.4: Each star will disappear-- the sky will roll up like a scroll. Everything in the sky will dry up and wilt like leaves on a vine or fruit on a tree. Trouble for Edom
34.5: After the sword of the LORD has done what it wants to the skies above, it will come down on Edom, the nation that the LORD has doomed for destruction.
34.6: The sword of the LORD is covered with blood from lambs and goats, together with fat from kidneys of rams. This is because the LORD will slaughter many people and make a sacrifice of them in the city of Bozrah and everywhere else in Edom.
34.7: Edom's leaders are wild oxen. They are powerful bulls, but they will die with the others. Their country will be soaked with their blood, and its soil made fertile with their fat.
34.8: The LORD has chosen the year and the day, when he will take revenge and come to Zion's defense.
34.9: Edom's streams will turn into tar and its soil into sulfur-- then the whole country will go up in flames.
34.10: It will burn night and day and never stop smoking. Edom will be a desert, generation after generation; no one will ever travel through that land.
34.11: Owls, hawks, and wild animals will make it their home. God will leave it in ruins, merely a pile of rocks. The End of Edom
34.12: Edom will be called "Kingdom of Nothing." Its rulers will also be nothing.
34.13: Its palaces and fortresses will be covered with thorns; only wolves and ostriches will make their home there.
34.14: Wildcats and hyenas will hunt together, demons will scream to demons, and creatures of the night will live among the ruins.
34.15: Owls will nest there to raise their young among its shadows, while families of buzzards circle around.
34.16: In The Book of the LORD you can search and find where it is written, "The LORD brought together all of his creatures by the power of his Spirit. Not one is missing."
34.17: The LORD has decided where they each should live; they will be there forever, generation after generation.

35.1: Thirsty deserts will be glad; barren lands will celebrate and blossom with flowers.
35.2: Deserts will bloom everywhere and sing joyful songs. They will be as majestic as Mount Lebanon, as glorious as Mount Carmel or Sharon Valley. Everyone will see the wonderful splendor of the LORD our God. God Changes Everything
35.3: Here is a message for all who are weak, trembling, and worried:
35.4: "Cheer up! Don't be afraid. Your God is coming to punish your enemies. God will take revenge on them and rescue you."
35.5: The blind will see, and the ears of the deaf will be healed.
35.6: Those who were lame will leap around like deer; tongues once silent will begin to shout. Water will rush through the desert.
35.7: Scorching sand will turn into a lake, and thirsty ground will flow with fountains. Grass will grow in wetlands, where packs of wild dogs once made their home. God's Sacred Highway
35.8: A good road will be there, and it will be named "God's Sacred Highway." It will be for God's people; no one unfit to worship God will walk on that road. And no fools can travel on that highway.
35.9: No lions or other wild animals will come near that road; only those the LORD has saved will travel there.
35.10: The people the LORD has rescued will come back singing as they enter Zion. Happiness will be a crown they will always wear. They will celebrate and shout because all sorrows and worries will be gone far away.

36.1: Hezekiah had been king of Judah for fourteen years when King Sennacherib of Assyria invaded the country and captured every walled city
36.2: except Jerusalem. The Assyrian king ordered his army commander to leave the city of Lachish and to take a large army to Jerusalem. The commander went there and stood on the road near the cloth makers' shops along the canal from the upper pool.
36.3: Three of the king's highest officials came out of Jerusalem to meet him. One of them was Hilkiah's son Eliakim, who was the prime minister. The other two were Shebna, assistant to the prime minister, and Joah son of Asaph, keeper of the government records.
36.4: The Assyrian commander told them: I have a message for Hezekiah from the great king of Assyria. Ask Hezekiah why he feels so sure of himself.
36.5: Does he think he can plan and win a war with nothing but words? Who is going to help him, now that he has turned against the king of Assyria?
36.6: Is he depending on Egypt and its king? That's the same as leaning on a broken stick, and it will go right through his hand.
36.7: Is Hezekiah now depending on the LORD, your God? Didn't Hezekiah tear down all except one of the LORD's altars and places of worship? Didn't he tell the people of Jerusalem and Judah to worship at that one place?
36.8: The king of Assyria wants to make a bet with you people! He will give you two thousand horses, if you have enough troops to ride them.
36.9: How could you even defeat our lowest ranking officer, when you have to depend on Egypt for chariots and cavalry?
36.10: Don't forget that it was the LORD who sent me here with orders to destroy your nation!
36.11: Eliakim, Shebna, and Joah said, "Sir, we don't want the people listening from the city wall to understand what you are saying. So please speak to us in Aramaic instead of Hebrew."
36.12: The Assyrian army commander answered, "My king sent me to speak to everyone, not just to you leaders. These people will soon have to eat their own body waste and drink their own urine! And so will the three of you!"
36.13: Then, in a voice loud enough for everyone to hear, he shouted out in Hebrew: Listen to what the great king of Assyria says!
36.14: Don't be fooled by Hezekiah. He can't save you.
36.15: Don't trust him when he tells you that the LORD will protect you from the king of Assyria.
36.16: Stop listening to Hezekiah. Pay attention to my king. Surrender to him. He will let you keep your own vineyards, fig trees, and cisterns
36.17: for a while. Then he will come and take you away to a country just like yours, where you can plant vineyards and raise your own grain.
36.18: Hezekiah claims the LORD will save you. But don't be fooled by him. Were any other gods able to defend their land against the king of Assyria?
36.19: What happened to the gods of Hamath, Arpad, and Sepharvaim? Were the gods of Samaria able to protect their land against the Assyrian forces?
36.20: None of these gods kept their people safe from the king of Assyria. Do you think the LORD, your God, can do any better?
36.21: Eliakim, Shebna, and Joah had been warned by King Hezekiah not to answer the Assyrian commander. So they tore their clothes in sorrow and reported to Hezekiah everything the commander had said.

37.1: As soon as Hezekiah heard the news, he tore off his clothes in sorrow and put on sackcloth. Then he went into the temple of the LORD.
37.2: He told Prime Minister Eliakim, Assistant Prime Minister Shebna, and the senior priests to dress in sackcloth and tell me:
37.3: Isaiah, these are difficult and disgraceful times. Our nation is like a woman too weak to give birth, when it's time for her baby to be born.
37.4: Please pray for those of us who are left alive. The king of Assyria sent his army commander to insult the living God. Perhaps the LORD heard what he said and will do something, if you will pray.
37.5: When these leaders came to me,
37.6: I told them that the LORD had this message for Hezekiah: I am the LORD. Don't worry about the insulting things that have been said about me by these messengers from the king of Assyria.
37.7: I will upset him with rumors about what's happening in his own country. He will go back, and there I will make him die a violent death.
37.8: Meanwhile the commander of the Assyrian forces heard that his king had left the town of Lachish and was now attacking Libnah. So he went there.
37.9: About this same time, the king of Assyria learned that King Tirhakah of Ethiopia was on his way to attack him. Then the king of Assyria sent some messengers with this note for Hezekiah:
37.10: Don't trust your God or be fooled by his promise to defend Jerusalem against me.
37.11: You have heard how we Assyrian kings have completely wiped out other nations. What makes you feel so safe?
37.12: The Assyrian kings before me destroyed the towns of Gozan, Haran, Rezeph, and everyone from Eden who lived in Telassar. What good did their gods do them?
37.13: The kings of Hamath, Arpad, Sepharvaim, Hena, and Ivvah have all disappeared. Hezekiah Prays(2 Kings 19.14-19)
37.14: After Hezekiah had read the note from the king of Assyria, he took it to the temple and spread it out for the LORD to see.
37.16: LORD God All-Powerful of Israel, your throne is above the winged creatures. You created the heavens and the earth, and you alone rule the kingdoms of this world.
37.17: Just look and see how Sennacherib has insulted you, the living God.
37.18: It is true, our LORD, that Assyrian kings have turned nations into deserts.
37.19: They destroyed the idols of wood and stone that the people of those nations had made and worshiped.
37.20: But you are our LORD and our God! We ask you to keep us safe from the Assyrian king. Then everyone in every kingdom on earth will know that you are the only LORD. Isaiah Gives the LORD's Answer to Hezekiah(2 Kings 19.20-34)
37.21: I went to Hezekiah and told him that the LORD God of Israel had said: Hezekiah, you prayed to me about King Sennacherib of Assyria. Now this is what I say to that king: The people of Jerusalem hate and make fun of you; they laugh behind your back.
37.23: Sennacherib, you cursed, shouted, and sneered at me, the holy God of Israel.
37.24: You let your officials insult me, the Lord. And here is what you have said about yourself, "I led my chariots to the highest heights of Lebanon's mountains. I went deep into its forest, cutting down the best cedar and cypress trees.
37.25: I dried up every stream in the land of Egypt, and I drank water from wells I had dug."
37.26: Sennacherib, now listen to me, the LORD. I planned all of this long ago. And you don't even know that I alone am the one who decided that you would do these things. I let you make ruins of fortified cities.
37.27: Their people became weak, terribly confused. They were like wild flowers or like tender young grass growing on a flat roof or like a field of grain before it matures.
37.28: I know all about you, even how fiercely angry you are with me.
37.29: I have seen your pride and the tremendous hatred you have for me. Now I will put a hook in your nose, a bit in your mouth, then I will send you back to where you came from.
37.30: Hezekiah, I will tell you what's going to happen. This year you will eat crops that grow on their own, and the next year you will eat whatever springs up where those crops grew. But the third year, you will plant grain and vineyards, and you will eat what you harvest.
37.31: Those who survive in Judah will be like a vine that puts down deep roots and bears fruit.
37.32: I, the LORD All-Powerful, will see to it that some who live in Jerusalem will survive.
37.33: I promise that the king of Assyria won't get into Jerusalem, or shoot an arrow into the city, or even surround it and prepare to attack.
37.34: As surely as I am the LORD, he will return by the way he came and will never enter Jerusalem.
37.35: I will protect it for the sake of my own honor and because of the promise I made to my servant David. The Death of King Sennacherib(2 Kings 19.35-37)
37.36: The LORD sent an angel to the camp of the Assyrians, and he killed one hundred eighty-five thousand of them all in one night. The next morning, the camp was full of dead bodies.
37.37: After this, King Sennacherib went back to Assyria and lived in the city of Nineveh.
37.38: One day he was worshiping in the temple of his god Nisroch, when his sons, Adrammelech and Sharezer, killed him with their swords. They escaped to the land of Ararat, and his son Esarhaddon became king.

38.1: About this time, Hezekiah got sick and was almost dead. So I went in and told him, "The LORD says you won't ever get well. You are going to die, and so you had better start doing what needs to be done."
38.2: Hezekiah turned toward the wall and prayed,
38.3: "Don't forget that I have been faithful to you, LORD. I have obeyed you with all my heart, and I do whatever you say is right." After this, he cried hard.
38.5: with this message for Hezekiah: I am the LORD God, who was worshiped by your ancestor David. I heard you pray, and I saw you cry. I will let you live fifteen years more,
38.6: while I protect you and your city from the king of Assyria.
38.7: Now I will prove to you that I will keep my promise.
38.8: Do you see the shadow made by the setting sun on the stairway built for King Ahaz? I will make the shadow go back ten steps. Then the shadow went back ten steps. King Hezekiah's Song of Praise
38.9: This is what Hezekiah wrote after he got well:
38.10: I thought I would die during my best years and stay as a prisoner forever in the world of the dead.
38.11: I thought I would never again see you, my LORD, or any of the people who live on this earth.
38.12: My life was taken from me like the tent that a shepherd pulls up and moves. You cut me off like thread from a weaver's loom; you make a wreck of me day and night.
38.13: Until morning came, I thought you would crush my bones just like a hungry lion; both night and day you make a wreck of me.
38.14: I cry like a swallow; I mourn like a dove. My eyes are red from looking to you, LORD. I am terribly abused. Please come and help me.
38.15: There's nothing I can say in answer to you, since you are the one who has done this to me. My life has turned sour; I will limp until I die.
38.16: Your words and your deeds bring life to everyone, including me. Please make me healthy and strong again.
38.17: It was for my own good that I had such hard times. But your love protected me from doom in the deep pit, and you turned your eyes away from my sins.
38.18: No one in the world of the dead can thank you or praise you; none of those in the deep pit can hope for you to show them how faithful you are.
38.19: Only the living can thank you, as I am doing today. Each generation tells the next about your faithfulness.
38.20: You, LORD, will save me, and every day that we live we will sing in your temple to the music of stringed instruments. Isaiah's Advice to Hezekiah
38.21: I had told King Hezekiah's servants to put some mashed figs on the king's open sore, and he would get well.
38.22: Then Hezekiah asked for proof that he would again worship in the LORD's temple.

39.1: Merodach Baladan, the son of Baladan, was now king of Babylonia. And when he learned that Hezekiah was well, he sent messengers with letters and a gift for him.
39.2: Hezekiah welcomed the messengers and showed them all the silver, the gold, the spices, and the fine oils that were in his storehouse. He even showed them where he kept his weapons. Nothing in his palace or in his entire kingdom was kept hidden from them.
39.3: I asked Hezekiah, "Where did these men come from? What did they want?" "They came all the way from Babylonia," Hezekiah answered.
39.4: "What did you show them?" I asked. Hezekiah answered, "I showed them everything in my kingdom."
39.5: Then I told Hezekiah: I have a message for you from the LORD All-Powerful.
39.6: One day everything you and your ancestors have stored up will be taken to Babylonia. The LORD has promised that nothing will be left.
39.7: Some of your own sons will be taken to Babylonia, where they will be disgraced and made to serve in the king's palace.
39.8: Hezekiah thought, "At least our nation will be at peace for a while." So he told me, "The message you brought from the LORD is good."

40.1: Our God has said: "Encourage my people! Give them comfort.
40.2: Speak kindly to Jerusalem and announce: Your slavery is past; your punishment is over. I, the LORD, made you pay double for your sins."
40.3: Someone is shouting: "Clear a path in the desert! Make a straight road for the LORD our God.
40.4: Fill in the valleys; flatten every hill and mountain. Level the rough and rugged ground.
40.5: Then the glory of the LORD will appear for all to see. The LORD has promised this!"
40.6: Someone told me to shout, and I asked, "What should I shout?" We humans are merely grass, and we last no longer than wild flowers.
40.7: At the LORD's command, flowers and grass disappear, and so do we.
40.8: Flowers and grass fade away, but what our God has said will never change. Your God Is Here!
40.9: There is good news for the city of Zion. Shout it as loud as you can from the highest mountain. Don't be afraid to shout to the towns of Judah, "Your God is here!"
40.10: Look! The powerful LORD God is coming to rule with his mighty arm. He brings with him what he has taken in war, and he rewards his people.
40.11: The LORD cares for his nation, just as shepherds care for their flocks. He carries the lambs in his arms, while gently leading the mother sheep. Who Compares with God?
40.12: Did any of you measure the ocean by yourself or stretch out the sky with your own hands? Did you put the soil of the earth in a bucket or weigh the hills and mountains on balance scales?
40.13: Has anyone told the LORD what he must do or given him advice?
40.14: Did the LORD ask anyone to teach him wisdom and justice? Who gave him knowledge and understanding?
40.15: To the LORD, all nations are merely a drop in a bucket or dust on balance scales; all of the islands are but a handful of sand.
40.16: The cattle on Lebanon's mountains would not be enough to offer as a sacrifice to God, and the trees would not be enough for the fire.
40.17: God thinks of the nations as far less than nothing.
40.18: Who compares with God? Is anything like him?
40.19: Is an idol at all like God? It is made of bronze with a thin layer of gold, and decorated with silver.
40.20: Or special wood may be chosen because it doesn't rot-- then skilled hands take care to make an idol that won't fall on its face. God Rules the Whole Earth
40.21: Don't you know? Haven't you heard? Isn't it clear that God created the world?
40.22: God is the one who rules the whole earth, and we that live here are merely insects. He spread out the heavens like a curtain or an open tent.
40.23: God brings down rulers and turns them into nothing.
40.24: They are like flowers freshly sprung up and starting to grow. But when God blows on them, they wilt and are carried off like straw in a storm.
40.25: The holy God asks, "Who compares with me? Is anyone my equal?"
40.26: Look at the evening sky! Who created the stars? Who gave them each a name? Who leads them like an army? The LORD is so powerful that none of the stars are ever missing. The LORD Gives Strength
40.27: You people of Israel, say, "God pays no attention to us! He doesn't care if we are treated unjustly." But how can you say that?
40.28: Don't you know? Haven't you heard? The LORD is the eternal God, Creator of the earth. He never gets weary or tired; his wisdom cannot be measured.
40.29: The LORD gives strength to those who are weary.
40.30: Even young people get tired, then stumble and fall.
40.31: But those who trust the LORD will find new strength. They will be strong like eagles soaring upward on wings; they will walk and run without getting tired.

41.1: Be silent and listen, every island in the sea. Have courage and come near, every one of you nations. Let's settle this matter!
41.2: Who appointed this ruler from the east? Who puts nations and kings in his power? His sword and his arrows turn them to dust blown by the wind.
41.3: He goes after them so quickly that his feet barely touch the ground-- he doesn't even get hurt.
41.4: Who makes these things happen? Who controls human events? I do! I am the LORD. I was there at the beginning; I will be there at the end.
41.5: Islands and foreign nations saw what I did and trembled as they came near. What Can Idols Do?
41.6: Worshipers of idols comfort each other, saying, "Don't worry!"
41.7: Woodcarvers, goldsmiths, and other workers encourage one another and say, "We've done a great job!" Then they nail the idol down, so it won't fall over. The LORD's Chosen Servant
41.8: Israel, you are my servant. I chose you, the family of my friend Abraham.
41.9: From far across the earth I brought you here and said, "You are my chosen servant. I haven't forgotten you."
41.10: Don't be afraid. I am with you. Don't tremble with fear. I am your God. I will make you strong, as I protect you with my arm and give you victories.
41.11: Everyone who hates you will be terribly disgraced; those who attack will vanish into thin air.
41.12: You will look around for those brutal enemies, but you won't find them because they will be gone.
41.13: I am the LORD your God. I am holding your hand, so don't be afraid. I am here to help you.
41.14: People of Israel, don't worry, though others may say, "Israel is only a worm!" I am the holy God of Israel, who saves and protects you.
41.15: I will let you be like a log covered with sharp spikes. You will grind and crush every mountain and hill until they turn to dust.
41.16: A strong wind will scatter them in all directions. Then you will celebrate and praise me, your LORD, the holy God of Israel. The LORD Helps the Poor
41.17: When the poor and needy are dying of thirst and cannot find water, I, the LORD God of Israel, will come to their rescue. I won't forget them.
41.18: I will make rivers flow on mountain peaks. I will send streams to fill the valleys. Dry and barren land will flow with springs and become a lake.
41.19: I will fill the desert with all kinds of trees-- cedars, acacias, and myrtles; olive and cypress trees; fir trees and pines.
41.20: Everyone will see this and know that I, the holy LORD God of Israel, created it all. Idols Are Useless
41.21: I am the LORD, the King of Israel! Come argue your case with me. Present your evidence.
41.22: Come near me, you idols. Tell us about the past, and we will think about it. Tell us about the future, so we will know what is going to happen.
41.23: Prove that you are gods by making your predictions come true. Do something good or evil, so we can be amazed and terrified.
41.24: You idols are nothing, and you are powerless. To worship you would be disgusting.
41.25: I, the LORD, appointed a ruler in the north; now he comes from the east to honor my name. He tramples kings like mud, as potters trample clay.
41.26: Did any of you idols predict what would happen? Did any of you get it right? None of you told about this or even spoke a word.
41.27: I was the first to tell the people of Jerusalem, "Look, it's happening!" I was the one who announced this good news to Zion.
41.28: None of these idols are able to give advice or answer questions.
41.29: They are nothing, and they can do nothing-- they are less than a passing breeze.

42.1: Here is my servant! I have made him strong. He is my chosen one; I am pleased with him. I have given him my Spirit, and he will bring justice to the nations.
42.2: He won't shout or yell or call out in the streets.
42.3: He won't break off a bent reed or put out a dying flame, but he will make sure that justice is done.
42.4: He won't quit or give up until he brings justice everywhere on earth, and people in foreign nations long for his teaching.
42.5: I am the LORD God. I created the heavens like an open tent above. I made the earth and everything that grows on it. I am the source of life for all who live on this earth, so listen to what I say.
42.6: I chose you to bring justice, and I am here at your side. I selected and sent you to bring light and my promise of hope to the nations.
42.7: You will give sight to the blind; you will set prisoners free from dark dungeons.
42.8: My name is the LORD! I won't let idols or humans share my glory and praise.
42.9: Everything has happened just as I said it would; now I will announce what will happen next. Sing Praises to the LORD
42.10: Tell the whole world to sing a new song to the LORD! Tell those who sail the ocean and those who live far away to join in the praise.
42.11: Tell the tribes of the desert and everyone in the mountains to celebrate and sing.
42.12: Let them announce his praises everywhere.
42.13: The LORD is marching out like an angry soldier, shouting with all his might while attacking his enemies. The LORD Will Help His People
42.14: For a long time, I, the LORD, have held my temper; now I will scream and groan like a woman giving birth.
42.15: I will destroy the mountains and what grows on them; I will dry up rivers and ponds.
42.16: I will lead the blind on roads they have never known; I will guide them on paths they have never traveled. Their road is dark and rough, but I will give light to keep them from stumbling. This is my solemn promise.
42.17: Everyone who worships idols as though they were gods will be terribly ashamed. God's People Won't Obey
42.18: You people are deaf and blind, but the LORD commands you to listen and to see.
42.19: No one is as blind or deaf as his messenger, his chosen servant,
42.20: who sees and hears so much, but pays no attention.
42.21: The LORD always does right, and so he wanted his Law to be greatly praised.
42.22: But his people were trapped and imprisoned in holes with no one to rescue them. All they owned had been taken, and no one was willing to give it back.
42.23: Why won't his people ever learn to listen?
42.24: Israel sinned and refused to obey the LORD or follow his instructions. So the LORD let them be robbed of everything they owned.
42.25: He was furious with them and punished their nation with the fires of war. Still they paid no attention. They didn't even care when they were surrounded and scorched by flames.

43.1: Descendants of Jacob, I, the LORD, created you and formed your nation. Israel, don't be afraid. I have rescued you. I have called you by name; now you belong to me.
43.2: When you cross deep rivers, I will be with you, and you won't drown. When you walk through fire, you won't be burned or scorched by the flames.
43.3: I am the LORD, your God, the Holy One of Israel, the God who saves you. I gave up Egypt, Ethiopia, and the region of Seba in exchange for you.
43.4: To me, you are very dear, and I love you. That's why I gave up nations and people to rescue you.
43.5: Don't be afraid! I am with you. From both east and west I will bring you together.
43.6: I will say to the north and to the south, "Free my sons and daughters! Let them return from distant lands.
43.7: They are my people-- I created each of them to bring honor to me." The LORD Alone Is GodThe LORD said:
43.8: Bring my people together. They have eyes and ears, but they can't see or hear.
43.9: Tell everyone of every nation to gather around. None of them can honestly say, "We told you so!" If someone heard them say this, then tell us about it now.
43.10: My people, you are my witnesses and my chosen servant. I want you to know me, to trust me, and understand that I alone am God. I have always been God; there can be no others.
43.11: I alone am the LORD; only I can rescue you.
43.12: I promised to save you, and I kept my promise. You are my witnesses that no other god did this. I, the LORD, have spoken.
43.13: I am God now and forever. No one can snatch you from me or stand in my way. The LORD Will Prepare the Way
43.14: I, the LORD, will rescue you! I am Israel's holy God, and this is my promise: For your sake, I will send an army against Babylon to drag its people away, crying as they go.
43.15: I am the LORD, your holy God, Israel's Creator and King.
43.16: I am the one who cut a path through the mighty ocean.
43.17: I sent an army to chase you with chariots and horses; now they lie dead, unable to move. They are like an oil lamp with the flame snuffed out. Forget the PastThe LORD said:
43.18: Forget what happened long ago! Don't think about the past.
43.19: I am creating something new. There it is! Do you see it? I have put roads in deserts, streams in thirsty lands.
43.20: Every wild animal honors me, even jackals and owls. I provide water in deserts-- streams in thirsty lands for my chosen people.
43.21: I made them my own nation, so they would praise me.
43.22: I, the LORD, said to Israel: You have become weary, but not from worshiping me.
43.23: You have not honored me by sacrificing sheep or other animals. And I have not burdened you with demands for sacrifices or sweet-smelling incense.
43.24: You have not brought delicious spices for me or given me the best part of your sacrificed animals. Instead, you burden me down with your terrible sins.
43.25: But I wipe away your sins because of who I am. And so, I will forget the wrongs you have done.
43.26: Meet me in court! State your case and prove that you are right.
43.27: Your earliest ancestor and all of your leaders rebelled against me.
43.28: That's why I don't allow your priests to serve me; I let Israel be destroyed and your people disgraced.

44.1: People of Israel, I have chosen you as my servant.
44.2: I am your Creator. You were in my care even before you were born. Israel, don't be terrified! You are my chosen servant, my very favorite.
44.3: I will bless the thirsty land by sending streams of water; I will bless your descendants by giving them my Spirit.
44.4: They will spring up like grass or like willow trees near flowing streams.
44.5: They will worship me and become my people. They will write my name on the back of their hands.
44.6: I am the LORD All-Powerful, the first and the last, the one and only God. Israel, I have rescued you! I am your King.
44.7: Can anyone compare with me? If so, let them speak up and tell me now. Let them say what has happened since I made my nation long ago, and let them tell what is going to happen.
44.8: Don't tremble with fear! Didn't I tell you long ago? Didn't you hear me? I alone am God-- no one else is a mighty rock. Idols Can't Do a ThingThe LORD said:
44.9: Those people who make idols are nothing themselves, and the idols they treasure are just as worthless. Worshipers of idols are blind, stupid, and foolish.
44.10: Why make an idol or an image that can't do a thing?
44.11: Everyone who makes idols and all who worship them are mere humans, who will end up sadly disappointed. Let them face me in court and be terrified. Idols and Firewood
44.12: A metalworker shapes an idol by using a hammer and heat from the fire. In his powerful hand he holds a hammer, as he pounds the metal into the proper shape. But he gets hungry and thirsty and loses his strength.
44.13: Some woodcarver measures a piece of wood, then draws an outline. The idol is carefully carved with each detail exact. At last it looks like a person and is placed in a temple.
44.14: Either cedar, cypress, oak, or any tree from the forest may be chosen. Or even a pine tree planted by the woodcarver and watered by the rain.
44.15: Some of the wood is used to make a fire for heating or for cooking. One piece is made into an idol, then the woodcarver bows down and worships it.
44.16: He enjoys the warm fire and the meat that was roasted over the burning coals.
44.17: Afterwards, he bows down to worship the wooden idol. "Protect me!" he says. "You are my god."
44.18: Those who worship idols are stupid and blind!
44.19: They don't have enough sense to say to themselves, "I made a fire with half of the wood and cooked my bread and meat on it. Then I made something worthless with the other half. Why worship a block of wood?"
44.20: How can anyone be stupid enough to trust something that can be burned to ashes? No one can save themselves like that. Don't they realize that the idols they hold in their hands are not really gods? The LORD Won't Forget His People
44.21: People of Israel, you are my servant, so remember all of this. Israel, I created you, and you are my servant. I won't forget you.
44.22: Turn back to me! I have rescued you and swept away your sins as though they were clouds. Sing Praises to the LORD
44.23: Tell the heavens and the earth to start singing! Tell the mountains and every tree in the forest to join in the song! The LORD has rescued his people; now they will worship him. The LORD Created Everything
44.24: Israel, I am your LORD. I am your source of life, and I have rescued you. I created everything from the sky above to the earth below.
44.25: I make liars of false prophets and fools of fortunetellers. I take human wisdom and turn it into nonsense.
44.26: I will make the message of my prophets come true. They are saying, "Jerusalem will be filled with people, and the LORD will rebuild the towns of Judah."
44.27: I am the one who commands the sea and its streams to run dry.
44.28: I am also the one who says, "Cyrus will lead my people and obey my orders. Jerusalem and the temple will be rebuilt."

45.1: The LORD said to Cyrus, his chosen one: I have taken hold of your right hand to help you capture nations and remove kings from power. City gates will open for you; not one will stay closed.
45.2: As I lead you, I will level mountains and break the iron bars on bronze gates of cities.
45.3: I will give you treasures hidden in dark and secret places. Then you will know that I, the LORD God of Israel, have called you by name.
45.4: Cyrus, you don't even know me! But I have called you by name and highly honored you because of Israel, my chosen servant.
45.5: Only I am the LORD! There are no other gods. I have made you strong, though you don't know me.
45.6: Now everyone from east to west will learn that I am the LORD. No other gods are real.
45.7: I create light and darkness, happiness and sorrow. I, the LORD, do all of this.
45.8: Tell the heavens to send down justice like showers of rain. Prepare the earth for my saving power to sprout and produce justice that I, the LORD, create. The LORD's Mighty PowerThe LORD said:
45.9: Israel, you have no right to argue with your Creator. You are merely a clay pot shaped by a potter. The clay doesn't ask, "Why did you make me this way? Where are the handles?"
45.10: Children don't have the right to demand of their parents, "What have you done to make us what we are?"
45.11: I am the LORD, the Creator, the holy God of Israel. Do you dare question me about my own nation or about what I have done?
45.12: I created the world and covered it with people; I stretched out the sky and filled it with stars.
45.13: I have done the right thing by placing Cyrus in power, and I will make the roads easy for him to follow. I am the LORD All-Powerful! Cyrus will rebuild my city and set my people free without being paid a thing. I, the LORD, have spoken. The LORD Alone Can Save
45.14: My people, I, the LORD, promise that the riches of Egypt and the treasures of Ethiopia will belong to you. You will force into slavery those tall people of Seba. They will bow down and say, "The only true God is with you; there are no other gods."
45.15: People of Israel, your God is a mystery, though he alone can save.
45.16: Anyone who makes idols will be confused and terribly disgraced.
45.17: But Israel, I, the LORD, will always keep you safe and free from shame. Everyone Is Invited
45.18: The LORD alone is God! He created the heavens and made a world where people can live, instead of creating an empty desert. The LORD alone is God; there are no others.
45.19: The LORD did not speak in a dark secret place or command Jacob's descendants to search for him in vain. The LORD speaks the truth, and this is what he says
45.20: to every survivor from every nation: "Gather around me! Learn how senseless it is to worship wooden idols or pray to helpless gods.
