2.14: Israel, I, the LORD, will lure you into the desert and speak gently to you.
2.15: I will return your vineyards, and then Trouble Valley will become Hopeful Valley. You will say " Yes" to me as you did in your youth, when leaving Egypt.
2.16: I promise that from that day on, you will call me your husband instead of your master.
2.17: I will no longer even let you mention the names of those pagan gods that you called " Master."
2.18: And I will agree to let you live in peace--you will no longer be attacked by wild animals and birds or by weapons of war.
2.19: I will accept you as my wife forever, and instead of a bride price I will give you justice, fairness, love, kindness,
2.20: and faithfulness. Then you will truly know who I am.
2.21: I will command the sky to send rain on the earth,
2.22: and it will produce grain, grapes, and olives in Jezreel Valley.
2.23: I will scatter the seeds and show mercy to Lo-Ruhamah. I will say to Lo-Ammi, " You are my people," and they will answer, " You are our God."

3.1: Once again the LORD spoke to me. And this time he said, " Hosea, fall in love with an unfaithful woman who has a lover. Do this to show that I love the people of Israel, even though they worship idols and enjoy the offering cakes made with fruit."
3.2: So I paid fifteen pieces of silver and about ten bushels of grain for such a woman.
3.3: Then I said, " Now you are mine! You will have to remain faithful to me, though it will be a long time before we sleep together."
3.4: It will also be a long time before Israel has a king or before sacrifices are offered at the temple or before there is any way to get guidance from God.
3.5: But later, Israel will turn back to the LORD their God and to David their king. At that time they will come to the LORD with fear and trembling, and he will be good to them.

4.1: Israel, listen as the LORD accuses everyone in the land! No one is faithful or loyal or truly cares about God.
4.2: Cursing, dishonesty, murder, robbery, unfaithfulness-- these happen all the time. Violence is everywhere.
4.3: And so your land is a desert. Every living creature is dying-- people and wild animals, birds and fish. The LORD Warns the Priests
4.4: Don't accuse just anyone! Not everyone is at fault. My case is against you, the priests.
4.5: You and the prophets will stumble day and night; I'll silence your mothers.
4.6: You priests have rejected me, and my people are destroyed by refusing to obey. Now I'll reject you and forget your children, because you have forgotten my Law.
4.7: By adding more of you priests, you multiply the number of people who sin. Now I'll change your pride into shame.
4.8: You encourage others to sin, so you can stuff yourselves on their sin offerings.
4.9: That's why I will punish the people for their deeds, just as I will punish you priests.
4.10: Their food won't satisfy, and having sex at pagan shrines won't produce children. My people have rebelled
4.11: and have been unfaithful to me, their LORD. My people, you are foolish because of too much pleasure and too much wine. God Condemns Israel's Idolatry
4.12: You expect wooden idols and other objects of wood to give you advice. Lusting for sex at pagan shrines has made you unfaithful to me, your God.
4.13: You offer sacrifices on mountaintops and hills, under oak trees, and wherever good shade is found. Your own daughters and daughters-in-law sell themselves for sex.
4.14: But I won't punish them. You men are to blame, because you go to prostitutes and offer sacrifices with them at pagan shrines. Your own foolishness will lead to your ruin.
4.15: Israel, you are unfaithful, but don't lead Judah to sin. Stop worshiping at Gilgal or at sinful Bethel. And quit making promises in my name-- the name of the living LORD.
4.16: You are nothing more than a stubborn cow-- so stubborn that I, the LORD, cannot feed you like lambs in an open pasture.
4.17: You people of Israel are charmed by idols. Leave them alone!
4.18: You get drunk, then sleep with prostitutes; you would rather be vulgar than lead a decent life.
4.19: And so you will be swept away in a whirlwind for sacrificing to idols.

5.1: Listen, you priests! Pay attention, Israel! Listen, you members of the royal family. Justice was your duty. But at Mizpah and Mount Tabor you trapped the people.
5.2: At the place of worship you were a treacherous pit, and I will punish you.
5.3: Israel, I know all about you, and because of your unfaithfulness, I find you unacceptable.
5.4: Your evil deeds are the reason you won't return to me, your LORD God. And your constant craving for sex keeps you from knowing me.
5.5: Israel, your pride testifies to your guilt; it makes you stumble, and Judah stumbles too.
5.6: You offer sheep and cattle as sacrifices to me, but I have turned away and refuse to be found.
5.7: You have been unfaithful to me, your LORD; you have had children by prostitutes. So at the New Moon Festival, you and your crops will be destroyed. The LORD Warns Israel and Judah
5.8: Give a warning on the trumpet! Let it be heard in Gibeah, Ramah, and sinful Bethel. Benjamin, watch out!
5.9: I, the LORD, will punish and wipe out Israel. This is my solemn promise to every tribe of Israel.
5.10: Judah's leaders are like crooks who move boundary markers; that's why I will flood them with my anger.
5.11: Israel was brutally crushed. They got what they deserved for worshiping useless idols.
5.12: Now I, the LORD, will fill Israel with maggots and make Judah rot.
5.13: When Israel and Judah saw their sickness and wounds, Israel asked help from Assyria and its mighty king. But the king cannot cure them or heal their wounds.
5.14: So I'll become a fierce lion attacking Israel and Judah. I'll snatch and carry off what I want, and no one can stop me.
5.15: Then I'll return to my temple until they confess their guilt and worship me, until they are desperate and beg for my help.

6.1: Let's return to the LORD. He has torn us to shreds, but he will bandage our wounds and make us well.
6.2: In two or three days he will heal us and restore our strength that we may live with him.
6.3: Let's do our best to know the LORD. His coming is as certain as the morning sun; he will refresh us like rain renewing the earth in the springtime. The LORD Speaks to Israel and Judah
6.4: People of Israel and Judah, what can I do with you? Your love for me disappears more quickly than mist or dew at sunrise.
6.5: That's why I slaughtered you with the words of my prophets. That's why my judgments blazed like the dawning sun.
6.6: I'd rather for you to be faithful and to know me than to offer sacrifices.
6.7: At a place named Adam, you betrayed me by breaking our agreement.
6.8: Everyone in Gilead is evil; your hands are stained with the blood of victims.
6.9: You priests are like a gang of robbers in ambush. On the road to Shechem you murder and commit other horrible crimes.
6.10: I have seen a terrible thing in Israel-- you are unfaithful and unfit to worship me.
6.11: People of Judah, your time is coming too. I, the LORD, would like to make my nation prosper again

7.1: and to heal its wounds. But then I see the crimes in Israel and Samaria. Everyone is deceitful; robbers roam the streets.
7.2: No one realizes that I have seen their sins surround them like a flood.
7.3: The king and his officials take great pleasure in their sin and deceit.
7.4: Everyone burns with desire-- they are like coals in an oven, ready to burst into flames.
7.5: On the day their king was crowned, his officials got him drunk, and he joined in their foolishness.
7.6: Their anger is a fire that smolders all night, then flares up at dawn.
7.7: They are flames destroying their leaders. And their kings are powerless; none of them trust me.
7.8: The people of Israel have mixed with foreigners; they are a thin piece of bread scorched on one side.
7.9: They don't seem to realize how weak and feeble they are; their hair has turned gray, while foreigners rule.
7.10: I am the LORD, their God, but in all of their troubles their pride keeps them from returning to me. No Help from Foreign NationsThe LORD said:
7.11: Israel is a senseless bird, fluttering back and forth between Egypt and Assyria.
7.12: But I will catch them in a net as hunters trap birds; I threatened to punish them, and indeed I will.
7.13: Trouble and destruction will be their reward for rejecting me. I would have rescued them, but they told me lies.
7.14: They don't really pray to me; they just howl in their beds. They have rejected me for Baal and slashed themselves, in the hope that Baal will bless their crops.
7.15: I taught them what they know, and I made them strong. Now they plot against me
7.16: and refuse to obey. They are more useless than a crooked arrow. Their leaders will die in war for saying foolish things. Egyptians will laugh at them.

8.1: Sound a warning! Israel, you broke our agreement and ignored my teaching. Now an eagle is swooping down to attack my land.
8.2: Israel, you say, " We claim you, the LORD, as our God."
8.3: But your enemies will chase you for rejecting our good agreement.
8.4: You chose kings and leaders without consulting me; you made silver and gold idols that led to your downfall.
8.5: City of Samaria, I'm angry because of your idol in the shape of a calf. When will you ever be innocent again?
8.6: Someone from Israel built that idol for you, but only I am God. And so it will be smashed to pieces.
8.7: If you scatter wind instead of wheat, you will harvest a whirlwind and have no wheat. Even if you harvest grain, enemies will steal it all.
8.8: Israel, you are ruined, and now the nations consider you worthless.
8.9: You are like a wild donkey that goes its own way. You've run off to Assyria and hired them as allies.
8.10: You can bargain with nations, but I'll catch you anyway. Soon you will suffer abuse by kings and rulers.
8.11: Israel, you have built many altars where you offer sacrifices for sin. But these altars have become places for sin.
8.12: My instructions for sacrifices were written in detail, but you ignored them.
8.13: You sacrifice your best animals and eat the sacrificial meals, but I, the LORD, refuse your offerings. I will remember your sins and punish you. Then you will return to Egypt.
8.14: Israel, I created you, but you forgot me. You and Judah built palaces and many strong cities. Now I will send fire to destroy your towns and fortresses.

9.1: Israel, don't celebrate or make noisy shouts like other nations. You have been unfaithful to your God. Wherever grain is threshed, you behave like prostitutes because you enjoy the money you receive.
9.2: But you will run short of grain and wine,
9.3: and you will have to leave the land of the LORD. Some of you will go to Egypt; others will go to Assyria and eat unclean food.
9.4: You won't be able to offer sacrifices of wine to the LORD. None of your sacrifices will please him-- they will be unclean like food offered to the dead. Your food will only be used to satisfy your hunger; none of it will be brought to the LORD's temple.
9.5: You will no longer be able to celebrate the festival of the LORD.
9.6: Even if you escape alive, you will end up in Egypt and be buried in Memphis. Your silver treasures will be lost among weeds; thorns will sprout in your tents.
9.7: Israel, the time has come. You will get what you deserve, and you will know it. " Prophets are fools," you say. " And God's messengers are crazy." Your terrible guilt has filled you with hatred.
9.8: Israel, the LORD sent me to look after you. But you trap his prophets and flood his temple with your hatred.
9.9: You are brutal and corrupt, as were the men of Gibeah. But God remembers your sin, and you will be punished. Sin's Terrible Results
9.10: Israel, when I, the LORD, found you long ago it was like finding grapes in a barren desert or tender young figs. Then you worshiped Baal Peor, that disgusting idol, and you became as disgusting as the idol you loved.
9.11: And so, Israel, your glory will fly away like birds-- your women will no longer be able to give birth.
9.12: Even if you do have children, I will take them all and leave you to mourn. I will turn away, and you will sink down in deep trouble.
9.13: Israel, when I first met you, I thought of you as palm trees growing in fertile ground. Now you lead your people out, only to be slaughtered. Hosea's Advice
9.14: Our LORD, do just one thing for your people-- make their women unable to have children or to nurse their babies. The LORD's Judgment on Israel
9.15: Israel, I first began to hate you because you did evil at Gilgal. Now I will chase you out of my house. No longer will I love you; your leaders betrayed me.
9.16: Israel, you are a vine with dried-up roots and fruitless branches. Even if you had more children and loved them dearly, I would slaughter them all. Hosea Warns Israel
9.17: Israel, you disobeyed my God. Now he will force you to roam from nation to nation.

10.1: You were a healthy vine covered with grapes. But the more grapes you grew, the more altars you built; the better off you became, the better shrines you set up for pagan gods.
10.2: You are deceitful and disloyal. So you will pay for your sins, because the LORD will destroy your altars and images.
10.3: " We don't have a king," you will say. " We don't fear the LORD. And what good are kings?"
10.4: Israel, you break treaties and don't keep promises; you turn justice into poisonous weeds where healthy plants should grow.
10.5: All who live in Samaria tremble with concern for the idols at sinful Bethel. The idol there was the pride of the priests, but it has been put to shame; now everyone will cry.
10.6: It will be taken to Assyria and given to the great king. Then Israel will be disgraced for worshiping that idol.
10.7: Like a twig in a stream, the king of Samaria will be swept away.
10.8: The altars at sinful Bethel will be destroyed for causing Israel to sin; they will be grown over with thorns and thistles. Then everyone will beg the mountains and hills to cover and protect them. The LORD Promises To Punish Israel
10.9: Israel, you have never stopped sinning since that time at Gibeah. That's why you will be attacked at Gibeah.
10.10: Your sins have doubled, and you are rebellious. Now I have decided to send nations to attack and put you in chains.
10.11: Once you were obedient like a calf that loved to thresh grain. But I will put a harness on your powerful neck; you and Judah must plow and cultivate the ground.
10.12: Plow your fields, scatter seeds of justice, and harvest faithfulness. Worship me, the LORD, and I will send my saving power down like rain.
10.13: You have planted evil, harvested injustice, and eaten the fruit of your lies. You trusted your own strength and your powerful forces.
10.14: So war will break out, and your fortresses will be destroyed. Your enemies will do to you what Shalman did to the people of Beth-Arbel-- mothers and their children will be beaten to death against rocks.
10.15: Bethel, this will be your fate because of your evil. Israel, at dawn your king will be killed.

11.1: When Israel was a child, I loved him, and I called my son out of Egypt.
11.2: But as the saying goes, " The more they were called, the more they rebelled." They never stopped offering incense and sacrifices to the idols of Baal.
11.3: I took Israel by the arm and taught them to walk. But they would not admit that I was the one who had healed them.
11.4: I led them with kindness and with love, not with ropes. I held them close to me; I bent down to feed them.
11.5: But they trusted Egypt instead of returning to me; now Assyria will rule them.
11.6: War will visit their cities, and their plans will fail.
11.7: My people are determined to reject me for a god they think is stronger, but he can't help.
11.8: Israel, I can't let you go. I can't give you up. How could I possibly destroy you as I did the towns of Admah and Zeboiim? I just can't do it. My feelings for you are much too strong.
11.9: Israel, I won't lose my temper and destroy you again. I am the Holy God-- not merely some human, and I won't stay angry.
11.10: I, the LORD, will roar like a lion, and my children will return, trembling from the west.
11.11: They will come back, fluttering like birds from Egypt or like doves from Assyria. Then I will bring them back to their homes. I, the LORD, have spoken! Israel and Judah Compared
11.12: Israel is deceitful to me, their loyal and holy God; they surround me with lies, and Judah worships other gods.

12.1: All day long Israel chases wind from the desert; deceit and violence are found everywhere. Treaties are made with Assyria; olive oil is taken to Egypt. Israel and Judah Condemned
12.2: The LORD also brings charges against the people of Judah, the descendants of Jacob. He will punish them for what they have done.
12.3: Even before Jacob was born, he cheated his brother, and when he grew up, he fought against God.
12.4: At Bethel, Jacob wrestled with an angel and won; then with tears in his eyes, he asked for a blessing, and God spoke to us there.
12.5: God's name is the LORD, the LORD God All-Powerful.
12.6: So return to your God. Patiently trust him, and show love and justice.
12.7: Israel, you enjoy cheating and taking advantage of others.
12.8: You say to yourself, " I'm rich! I earned it all on my own, without committing a sin." The LORD Is Still the God of Israel
12.9: Israel, I, the LORD, am still your God, just as I have been since the time you were in Egypt. Now I will force you to live in tents once again, as you did in the desert.
12.10: I spoke to the prophets-- often I spoke in visions. And so, I will send my prophets with messages of doom.
12.11: Gilead is terribly sinful and will end up ruined. Bulls are sacrificed in Gilgal on altars made of stones, but those stones will be scattered in every field.
12.12: Jacob escaped to Syria where he tended sheep to earn himself a wife.
12.13: I sent the prophet Moses to lead Israel from Egypt and to keep them safe.
12.14: Israel, I will make you pay for your terrible sins and for insulting me.

13.1: When your leaders spoke, everyone in Israel trembled and showed great respect. But you sinned by worshiping Baal, and you were destroyed.
13.2: Now you continue to sin by designing and making idols of silver in the shape of calves. You are told to sacrifice to these idols -- yes, even to kiss them.
13.3: And so, all of you will vanish like the mist or the dew of early morning, or husks of grain in the wind or smoke from a chimney.
13.4: I, the LORD, have been your God since the time you were in Egypt. I am the only God you know, the only one who can save.
13.5: I took care of you in a thirsty desert.
13.6: I fed you till you were satisfied, then you became proud and forgot about me.
13.7: Now I will attack like a lion, ambush you like a leopard,
13.8: and rip you apart like a bear robbed of her cubs. I will gnaw on your bones, as though I were a lion or some other wild animal.
13.9: Israel, you are done for. Don't expect help from me.
13.10: You wanted a king and rulers. Where is your king now? What cities have rulers?
13.11: In my anger, I gave you a king; in my fury, I took him away. Israel's Terrible FateThe LORD said:
13.12: Israel, your terrible sins are written down and stored away.
13.13: You are like a senseless child who refuses to be born at the proper time.
13.14: Should I, the LORD, rescue you from death and the grave? No! I call death and the grave to strike you like a plague. I refuse to show mercy.
13.15: No matter how much you prosper more than the other tribes, I, the LORD, will wipe you out, just as a scorching desert wind dries up streams of water. I will take away your precious treasures.
13.16: Samaria will be punished for turning against me. It will be destroyed in war-- children will be beaten against rocks, and pregnant women will be ripped open.

14.1: Israel, return! Come back to the LORD, your God. Sin has made you fall.
14.2: Return to the LORD and say, " Please forgive our sins. Accept our good sacrifices of praise instead of bulls.
14.3: Assyria can't save us, and chariots can't help. So we will no longer worship the idols we have made. Our LORD, you show mercy to orphans." The LORD Promises To Forgive
14.4: Israel, you have rejected me, but my anger is gone; I will heal you and love you without limit.
14.5: I will be like the dew-- then you will blossom like lilies and have roots like a tree.
14.6: Your branches will spread with the beauty of an olive tree and with the aroma of Lebanon Forest.
14.7: You will rest in my shade, and your grain will grow. You will blossom like a vineyard and be famous as the wine from Lebanon.
14.8: Israel, give up your idols! I will answer your prayers and take care of you. I am that glorious tree, the source of your fruit.
14.9: If you are wise, you will know and understand what I mean. I am the LORD, and I lead you along the right path. If you obey me, we will walk together, but if you are wicked, you will stumble.

1.1: I am Joel the son of Pethuel. And this is the message the LORD gave to me. Locusts Cover the Land
1.2: Listen, you leaders and everyone else in the land. Has anything like this ever happened before?
1.3: Tell our children! Let it be told to our grandchildren and their children too.
1.4: Swarm after swarm of locusts has attacked our crops, eating everything in sight.
1.5: Sober up, you drunkards! Cry long and loud; your wine supply is gone.
1.6: A powerful nation with countless troops has invaded our land. They have the teeth and jaws of powerful lions.
1.7: Our grapevines and fig trees are stripped bare; only naked branches remain.
1.8: Grieve like a young woman mourning for the man she was to marry.
1.9: Offerings of grain and wine are no longer brought to the LORD's temple. His servants, the priests, are deep in sorrow.
1.10: Barren fields mourn; grain, grapes, and olives are scorched and shriveled.
1.11: Mourn for our farms and our vineyards! There's no wheat or barley growing in our fields.
1.12: Grapevines have dried up and so has every tree-- figs and pomegranates, date palms and apples. All happiness has faded away. Return to God
1.13: Mourn, you priests who serve at the altar of my God. Spend your days and nights wearing sackcloth. Offerings of grain and wine are no longer brought to the LORD's temple.
1.14: Tell the leaders and people to come together at the temple. Order them to go without eating and to pray sincerely.
1.15: We are in for trouble! Soon the LORD All-Powerful will bring disaster.
1.16: Our food is already gone; there's no more celebrating at the temple of our God.
1.17: Seeds dry up in the ground; no harvest is possible. Our barns are in bad shape, with no grain to store in them.
1.18: Our cattle wander aimlessly, moaning for lack of pasture, and sheep are suffering.
1.19: I cry out to you, LORD. Grasslands and forests are eaten by the scorching heat.
1.20: Wild animals have no water because of you; rivers and streams are dry, and pastures are parched.

2.1: Sound the trumpet on Zion, the LORD's sacred hill. Warn everyone to tremble! The judgment day of the LORD is coming soon.
2.2: It will be dark and gloomy with storm clouds overhead. Troops will cover the mountains like thunderclouds. No army this powerful has ever been gathered before or will ever be again.
2.3: Fiery flames surround them; no one escapes. Before they invaded, the land was like Eden; now only a desert remains.
2.4: They look like horses and charge like cavalry.
2.5: They roar over mountains like noisy chariots, or a mighty army ready for battle. They are a forest fire that feasts on straw.
2.6: The very sight of them is frightening.
2.7: They climb over walls like warriors; they march in columns and never turn aside.
2.8: They charge straight ahead, without pushing each other; even arrows and spears cannot make them retreat.
2.9: They swarm over city walls and enter our homes; they crawl in through windows, just like thieves.
2.10: They make the earth tremble and the heavens shake; the sun and moon turn dark, and stars stop shining.
2.11: The LORD God leads this army of countless troops, and they obey his commands. The day of his judgment is so terrible that no one can stand it. The LORD's Invitation
2.12: The LORD said: It isn't too late. You can still return to me with all your heart. Start crying and mourning! Go without eating.
2.13: Don't rip your clothes to show your sorrow. Instead, turn back to me with broken hearts. I am merciful, kind, and caring. I don't easily lose my temper, and I don't like to punish.
2.14: I am the LORD your God. Perhaps I will change my mind and treat you with mercy. Then you will be blessed with enough grain and wine for offering sacrifices to me.
2.15: Sound the trumpet on Zion! Call the people together. Show your sorrow by going without food.
2.16: Make sure that everyone is fit to worship me. Bring adults, children, babies, and even bring newlyweds from their festivities.
2.17: Tell my servants, the priests, to cry inside the temple and to offer this prayer near the altar: "Save your people, LORD God! Don't let foreign nations make jokes about us. Don't let them laugh and ask, 'Where is your God?'" The LORD Will Bless the Land
2.18: The LORD was deeply concerned about his land and had pity on his people.
2.19: In answer to their prayers he said, "I will give you enough grain, wine, and olive oil to satisfy your needs. No longer will I let you be insulted by the nations.
2.20: An army attacked from the north, but I will chase it into a scorching desert. There it will rot and stink from the Dead Sea to the Mediterranean." The LORD works wonders
2.21: and does great things. So tell the soil to celebrate
2.22: and wild animals to stop being afraid. Grasslands are green again; fruit trees and fig trees are loaded with fruit. Grapevines are covered with grapes.
2.23: People of Zion, celebrate in honor of the LORD your God! He is generous and has sent the autumn and spring rains in the proper seasons.
2.24: Grain will cover your threshing places; jars will overflow with wine and olive oil. The LORD Will Rescue His People
2.25: I, the LORD your God, will make up for the losses caused by those swarms and swarms of locusts I sent to attack you.
2.26: My people, you will eat until you are satisfied. Then you will praise me for the wonderful things I have done. Never again will you be put to shame.
2.27: Israel, you will know that I stand at your side. I am the LORD your God-- there are no other gods. Never again will you be put to shame. The LORD Will Work WondersThe LORD said:
2.28: Later, I will give my Spirit to everyone. Your sons and daughters will prophesy. Your old men will have dreams, and your young men will see visions.
2.29: In those days I will even give my Spirit to my servants, both men and women.
2.30: I will work wonders in the sky above and on the earth below. There will be blood and fire and clouds of smoke.
2.31: The sun will turn dark, and the moon will be as red as blood before that great and terrible day when I appear.
2.32: Then the LORD will save everyone who faithfully worships him. He has promised there will be survivors on Mount Zion and in Jerusalem, and among them will be his chosen ones.

3.1: At that time I, the LORD, will make Judah and Jerusalem prosperous again.
3.2: Then in Judgment Valley I will bring together the nations that scattered my people Israel everywhere in the world, and I will bring charges against those nations. They divided up my land
3.3: and gambled to see who would get my people; they sold boys and girls to pay for prostitutes and wine.
3.4: You people of Tyre and Sidon and you Philistines, why are you doing this? Are you trying to get even with me? I'll strike back before you know what's happened.
3.5: You've taken my prized possessions, including my silver and gold, and carried them off to your temples.
3.6: You have dragged the people of Judah and Jerusalem from their land and sold them to the Greeks.
3.7: But I'll make the people of Judah determined to come home, and what happened to them will happen to you.
3.8: I'll hand over your sons and daughters to the people of Judah, and they will sell them to the Sabeans, who live far away. I, the LORD, have spoken! Judgment in Judgment Valley
3.9: Say to the nations: "Get ready for war! Be eager to fight. Line up for battle and prepare to attack.
3.10: Make swords out of plows and spears out of garden tools. Strengthen every weakling."
3.11: Hurry, all you nations! Come quickly. Ask the LORD to bring his warriors along.
3.12: You must come now to Judgment Valley, where the LORD will judge the surrounding nations.
3.13: They are a field of ripe crops. Bring in the harvest! They are grapes piled high. Start trampling them now! If our enemy's sins were wine, every jar would overflow.
3.14: Crowds fill Decision Valley. The judgment day of the LORD will soon be here--
3.15: no light from the sun or moon, and stars no longer shine.
3.16: From the heart of Jerusalem the LORD roars like a lion, shaking the earth and sky. But the LORD is a fortress, a place of safety for his people Israel. God Will Bless His People
3.17: I am the LORD your God. And you will know I live on Zion, my sacred hill, because Jerusalem will be sacred, untouched by foreign troops.
3.18: On that day, fruitful vineyards will cover the mountains. And your cattle and goats that graze on the hills will produce a lot of milk. Streams in Judah will never run dry; a stream from my house will flow in Acacia Valley.
3.19: Egypt and Edom were cruel and brutal to Judah, without a reason. Now their countries will become a barren desert,
3.20: but Judah and Jerusalem will always have people.
3.21: I, the LORD, live on Mount Zion. I will punish the guilty and defend the innocent.

1.1: I am Amos. And I raised sheep near the town of Tekoa when Uzziah was king of Judah and Jeroboam son of Jehoash was king of Israel. Two years before the earthquake, the LORD gave me several messages about Israel,
1.2: and I said: When the LORD roars from Jerusalem, pasturelands and Mount Carmel dry up and turn brown. Judgment on Syria
1.3: The LORD said: I will punish Syria for countless crimes, and I won't change my mind. They dragged logs with spikes over the people of Gilead.
1.4: Now I will burn down the palaces and fortresses of King Hazael and of King Benhadad.
1.5: I will break through the gates of Damascus. I will destroy the people of Wicked Valley and the ruler of Beth-Eden. Then the Syrians will be dragged as prisoners to Kir. I, the LORD, have spoken! Judgment on Philistia
1.6: The LORD said: I will punish Philistia for countless crimes, and I won't change my mind. They dragged off my people from town after town to sell them as slaves to the Edomites.
1.7: That's why I will burn down the walls and fortresses of the city of Gaza.
1.8: I will destroy the king of Ashdod and the ruler of Ashkelon. I will strike down Ekron, and that will be the end of the Philistines. I, the LORD, have spoken! Judgment on Phoenicia
1.9: The LORD said: I will punish Phoenicia for countless crimes, and I won't change my mind. They broke their treaty and dragged off my people from town after town to sell them as slaves to the Edomites.
1.10: That's why I will send flames to burn down the city of Tyre along with its fortresses. Judgment on Edom
1.11: The LORD said: I will punish Edom for countless crimes, and I won't change my mind. They killed their own relatives and were so terribly furious that they showed no mercy.
1.12: Now I will send fire to wipe out the fortresses of Teman and Bozrah. Judgment on Ammon
1.13: The LORD said: I will punish Ammon for countless crimes, and I won't change my mind. In Gilead they ripped open pregnant women, just to take the land.
1.14: Now I will send fire to destroy the walls and fortresses of Rabbah. Enemies will shout and attack like a whirlwind.
1.15: Ammon's king and leaders will be dragged away. I, the LORD, have spoken!

2.1: The LORD said: I will punish Moab for countless crimes, and I won't change my mind. They made lime from the bones of the king of Edom.
2.2: Now I will send fire to destroy the fortresses of Kerioth. Battle shouts and trumpet blasts will be heard as I destroy Moab
2.3: with its king and leaders. I, the LORD, have spoken! Judgment on Judah
2.4: The LORD said: I will punish Judah for countless crimes, and I won't change my mind. They have rejected my teachings and refused to obey me. They were led astray by the same false gods their ancestors worshiped.
2.5: Now I will send fire on Judah and destroy the fortresses of Jerusalem. Judgment on Israel
2.6: The LORD said: I will punish Israel for countless crimes, and I won't change my mind. They sell honest people for money, and the needy are sold for the price of sandals.
2.7: They smear the poor in the dirt and push aside those who are helpless. My holy name is dishonored, because fathers and sons sleep with the same young women.
2.8: They lie down beside altars on clothes taken as security for loans. And they drink wine in my temple, wine bought with the money they received from fines.
2.9: Israel, the Amorites were there when you entered Canaan. They were tall as cedars and strong as oaks. But I wiped them out-- I destroyed their branches and their roots.
2.10: I had rescued you from Egypt, and for forty years I had led you through the desert. Then I gave you the land of the Amorites.
2.11: I chose some of you to be prophets and others to be Nazirites. People of Israel, you know this is true. I, the LORD, have spoken!
2.12: But you commanded the prophets not to speak their message, and you pressured the Nazirites into drinking wine.
2.13: And so I will crush you, just as a wagon full of grain crushes the ground.
2.14: No matter how fast you run, you won't escape. No matter how strong you are, you will lose your strength and your life.
2.15: Even if you are an expert with a bow and arrow, you will retreat. And you won't get away alive, not even if you run fast or ride a horse.
2.16: You may be brave and strong, but you will run away, stripped naked. I, the LORD, have spoken!

3.1: People of Israel, I rescued you from Egypt. Now listen to my judgment against you.
3.2: Of all nations on earth, you are the only one I have chosen. That's why I will punish you because of your sins. The Work of a Prophet
3.3: Can two people walk together without agreeing to meet?
3.4: Does a lion roar in the forest unless it has caught a victim? Does it growl in its den unless it is eating?
3.5: How can anyone catch a bird without using a net? Does a trap spring shut unless something is caught?
3.6: Isn't the whole city frightened when the trumpet signals an attack? Isn't it the LORD who brings disaster on a city?
3.7: Whatever the LORD God plans to do, he tells his servants, the prophets.
3.8: Everyone is terrified when a lion roars-- and ordinary people become prophets when the LORD God speaks. Samaria Is Doomed
3.9: Here is a message for the leaders of Philistia and Egypt-- tell everyone to come together on the hills of Samaria. Let them see the injustice and the lawlessness in that city.
3.10: The LORD has said that they don't even know how to do right. They have become rich from violence and robbery.
3.11: And so the LORD God has sworn that they will be surrounded. Enemies will break through their defenses and steal their treasures.
3.12: The LORD has promised that only a few from Samaria will escape with their lives and with some broken pieces of their beds and couches. It will be like when a shepherd rescues two leg bones and part of a sheep's ear from the jaws of a lion. The Altars at Bethel
3.13: The LORD God All-Powerful told me to speak this message against Jacob's descendants:
3.14: When I, the LORD, punish Israel for their sins, I will destroy the altars at Bethel. Even the corners of the altar will be left in the dirt.
3.15: I will tear down winter homes and summer homes. Houses decorated with ivory and all other mansions will be gone forever. I, the LORD, have spoken!

4.1: You women of Samaria are fat cows! You mistreat and abuse the poor and needy, then you say to your husbands, "Bring us more drinks!"
4.2: I, the LORD God, have sworn by my own name that your time is coming. Not one of you will be left-- you will be taken away by sharp hooks.
4.3: You will be dragged through holes in your city walls, and you will be thrown toward Harmon. I, the LORD, have spoken! Israel Refuses To ObeyThe LORD said:
4.4: Come to Bethel and Gilgal. Sin all you want! Offer sacrifices the next morning and bring a tenth of your crops on the third day.
4.5: Bring offerings to show me how thankful you are. Gladly bring more offerings than I have demanded. You really love to do this. I, the LORD God, have spoken! How the LORD Warned Israel
4.6: I, the LORD, took away the food from every town and village, but still you rejected me.
4.7: Three months before harvest, I kept back the rain. Sometimes I would let it fall on one town or field but not on another, and pastures dried up.
4.8: People from two or three towns would go to a town that still had water, but it wasn't enough. Even then you rejected me. I, the LORD, have spoken!
4.9: I dried up your grain fields; your gardens and vineyards turned brown. Locusts ate your fig trees and olive orchards, but even then you rejected me. I, the LORD, have spoken!
4.10: I did terrible things to you, just as I did to Egypt-- I killed your young men in war; I let your horses be stolen, and I made your camp stink with dead bodies. Even then you rejected me. I, the LORD, have spoken!
4.11: I destroyed many of you, just as I did the cities of Sodom and Gomorrah. You were a burning stick I rescued from the fire. Even then you rejected me. I, the LORD, have spoken!
4.12: Now, Israel, I myself will deal with you. Get ready to face your God!
4.13: I created the mountains and the wind. I let humans know what I am thinking. I bring darkness at dawn and step over hills. I am the LORD God All-Powerful!

5.1: Listen, nation of Israel, to my mournful message:
5.2: You, dearest Israel, have fallen, never to rise again-- you lie deserted in your own land, with no one to help you up.
5.3: The LORD God has warned, "From every ten soldiers only one will be left; from a thousand troops, only a hundred will survive."
5.4: The LORD keeps saying, "Israel, turn back to me and you will live!
5.5: Don't go to Gilgal or Bethel or even to Beersheba. Gilgal will be dragged away, and Bethel will end up as nothing."
5.6: Turn back to the LORD, you descendants of Joseph, and you will live. If you don't, the LORD will attack like fire. Bethel will burn to the ground, and no one can save it.
5.7: You people are doomed! You twist the truth and stomp on justice.
5.8: But the LORD created the stars and put them in place. He turns darkness to dawn and daylight to darkness; he scoops up the ocean and empties it on the earth.
5.9: God destroys mighty soldiers and strong fortresses. Choose Good Instead of Evil!The LORD said:
5.10: You people hate judges and honest witnesses;
5.11: you abuse the poor and demand heavy taxes from them. You have built expensive homes, but you won't enjoy them; you have planted vineyards, but you will get no wine.
5.12: I am the LORD, and I know your terrible sins. You cheat honest people and take bribes; you rob the poor of justice.
5.13: Times are so evil that anyone with good sense will keep quiet.
5.14: If you really want to live, you must stop doing wrong and start doing right. I, the LORD God All-Powerful, will then be on your side, just as you claim I am.
5.15: Choose good instead of evil! See that justice is done. Maybe I, the LORD All-Powerful, will be kind to what's left of your people. Judgment Is Coming
5.16: This is what the LORD has sworn: Noisy crying will be heard in every town and street. Even farmers will be told to mourn for the dead, together with those who are paid to mourn.
5.17: Your vineyards will be filled with crying and weeping, because I will punish you. I, the LORD, have spoken! When the LORD Judges
5.18: You look forward to the day when the LORD comes to judge. But you are in for trouble! It won't be a time of sunshine; all will be darkness.
5.19: You will run from a lion, only to meet a bear. You will escape to your house, rest your hand on the wall, and be bitten by a snake.
5.20: The day when the LORD judges will be dark, very dark, without a ray of light. What the LORD Demands
5.21: I, the LORD, hate and despise your religious celebrations and your times of worship.
5.22: I won't accept your offerings or animal sacrifices-- not even your very best.
5.23: No more of your noisy songs! I won't listen when you play your harps.
5.24: But let justice and fairness flow like a river that never runs dry.
5.25: Israel, for forty years you wandered in the desert, without bringing offerings or sacrifices to me.
5.26: Now you will have to carry the two idols you made-- Sakkuth, the one you call king, and Kaiwan, the one you built in the shape of a star.
5.27: I will force you to march as captives beyond Damascus. I, the LORD God All-Powerful, have spoken!

6.1: Do you rulers in Jerusalem and in the city of Samaria feel safe and at ease? Everyone bows down to you, and you think you are better than any other nation. But you are in for trouble!
6.2: Look what happened to the cities of Calneh, powerful Hamath, and Gath in Philistia. Are you greater than any of those kingdoms?
6.3: You are cruel, and you forget the coming day of judgment.
6.4: You rich people lounge around on beds with ivory posts, while dining on the meat of your lambs and calves.
6.5: You sing foolish songs to the music of harps, and you make up new tunes, just as David used to do.
6.6: You drink all the wine you want and wear expensive perfume, but you don't care about the ruin of your nation.
6.7: So you will be the first to be dragged off as captives; your good times will end.
6.8: The LORD God All-Powerful has sworn by his own name: "You descendants of Jacob make me angry by your pride, and I hate your fortresses. And so I will surrender your city and possessions to your enemies."
6.9: If only ten of you survive by hiding in a house you will still die.
6.10: As you carry out a corpse to prepare it for burial, your relative in the house will ask, "Are there others?" You will answer, "No!" Then your relative will reply, "Be quiet! Don't dare mention the name of the LORD."
6.11: At the LORD's command, houses great and small will be smashed to pieces.
6.12: Horses can't gallop on rocks; oceans can't be plowed. But you have turned justice and fairness into bitter poison.
6.13: You celebrate the defeat of Lo-Debar and Karnaim, and you boast by saying, "We did it on our own."
6.14: But the LORD God All-Powerful will send a nation to attack you people of Israel. They will capture Lebo-Hamath in the north, Arabah Creek in the south, and everything in between.

7.1: The LORD God showed me that he is going to send locusts to attack your crops. It will happen after the king has already been given his share of the grain and before the rest of the grain has been harvested.
7.2: In my vision the locusts ate every crop in the land, and I said to the LORD, "Forgive me for asking, but how can the nation survive? It's so weak."
7.3: Then the LORD felt sorry and answered, "I won't let it be destroyed." A Vision of Fire
7.4: The LORD showed me that he is going to send a ball of fire to burn up everything on earth, including the ocean.
7.5: Then I said, "Won't you please stop? How can our weak nation survive?"
7.6: Again the LORD felt sorry and answered, "I won't let it be destroyed." A Vision of a Measuring Line
7.7: The LORD showed me a vision of himself standing beside a wall and holding a string with a weight tied to the end of it. The string and weight had been used to measure the straightness of the wall.
7.8: Then he asked, "Amos, what do you see?" "A measuring line," I answered. The LORD said, "I'm using this measuring line to show that my people Israel don't measure up, and I won't forgive them any more.
7.9: Their sacred places will be destroyed, and I will send war against the nation of King Jeroboam." Amos and Amaziah
7.10: Amaziah the priest at Bethel sent this message to King Jeroboam of Israel, "Amos is plotting against you in the very heart of Israel. Our nation cannot put up with his message for very long.
7.11: Here is what he is saying: 'Jeroboam will be put to death, and the people will be taken to a foreign country.'"
7.12: Then Amaziah told me, "Amos, take your visions and get out! Go back to Judah and earn your living there as a prophet.
7.13: Don't do any more preaching at Bethel. The king worships here at our national temple."
7.14: I answered: I'm not a prophet! And I wasn't trained to be a prophet. I am a shepherd, and I take care of fig trees.
7.15: But the LORD told me to leave my herds and preach to the people of Israel.
7.16: And here you are, telling me not to preach!
7.17: Now, listen to what the LORD says about you: Your wife will become a prostitute in the city, your sons and daughters will be killed in war, and your land will be divided among others. You will die in a country of foreigners, and the people of Israel will be dragged from their homeland.

8.1: The LORD God showed me a basket of ripe fruit
8.2: and asked, "Amos, what do you see?" "A basket of ripe fruit," I replied. Then he said, "This is the end for my people Israel. I won't forgive them again.
8.3: Instead of singing in the temple, they will cry and weep. Dead bodies will be everywhere. So keep silent! I, the LORD, have spoken!" Israel Is DoomedThe LORD said:
8.4: You people crush those in need and wipe out the poor.
8.5: You say to yourselves, "How much longer before the end of the New Moon Festival? When will the Sabbath be over? Our wheat is ready, and we want to sell it now. We can't wait to cheat and charge high prices for the grain we sell. We will use dishonest scales
8.6: and mix dust in the grain. Those who are needy and poor don't have any money. We will make them our slaves for the price of a pair of sandals."
8.7: I, the LORD, won't forget any of this, though you take great pride in your ancestor Jacob.
8.8: Your country will tremble, and you will mourn. It will be like the Nile River that rises and overflows, then sinks back down.
8.9: On that day, I, the LORD God, will make the sun go down at noon, and I will turn daylight into darkness.
8.10: Your festivals and joyful singing will turn into sorrow. You will wear sackcloth and shave your heads, as you would at the death of your only son. It will be a horrible day.
8.11: I, the LORD, also promise you a terrible shortage, but not of food and water. You will hunger and thirst to hear my message.
8.12: You will search everywhere-- from north to south, from east to west. You will go all over the earth, seeking a message from me, the LORD. But you won't find one.
8.13: Your beautiful young women and your young men will faint from thirst.
8.14: You made promises in the name of Ashimah, the goddess of Samaria. And you made vows in my name at the shrines of Dan and Beersheba. But you will fall and never get up.

9.1: I saw a vision of the LORD standing by the temple altar, and he said, "Shake the columns until the tops fall loose, and the doorposts crumble. Then make the pieces fall on the people below. I will take a sword and kill anyone who escapes.
9.2: "If they dig deep into the earth or climb to the sky, I'll reach out and get them.
9.3: If they escape to the peaks of Mount Carmel, I'll search and find them. And if they hide from me at the bottom of the ocean, I'll command a sea monster to bite them.
9.4: I'll send a sword to kill them, wherever their enemies drag them off as captives. I'm determined to hurt them, not to help them." His Name Is the LORD
9.5: When the LORD God All-Powerful touches the earth, it melts, and its people mourn. God makes the earth rise and then fall, just like the Nile River.
9.6: He built his palace in the heavens and let its foundations rest on the earth. He scoops up the ocean and empties it on the earth. His name is the LORD. The LORD Is God
9.7: Israel, I am the LORD God, and the Ethiopians are no less important to me than you are. I brought you out of Egypt, but I also brought the Philistines from Crete and the Arameans from Kir.
9.8: My eyes have seen what a sinful nation you are, and I'll wipe you out. But I will leave a few of Jacob's descendants. I, the LORD, have spoken!
9.9: At my command, all of you will be sifted like grain. Israelites who remain faithful will be scattered among the nations. And the others will be trapped like trash in a sifter.
9.10: Some of you are evil, and you deny that you will ever get caught. But you will be killed. The LORD's Promise to Israel
9.11: In the future, I will rebuild David's fallen kingdom. I will build it from its ruins and set it up again, just as it used to be.
9.12: Then you will capture Edom and the other nations that are mine. I, the LORD, have spoken, and my words will come true.
9.13: You will have such a harvest that you won't be able to bring in all of your wheat before plowing time. You will have grapes left over from season to season; your fruitful vineyards will cover the mountains.
9.14: I'll make Israel prosper again. You will rebuild your towns and live in them. You will drink wine from your own vineyards and eat the fruit you grow.
9.15: I'll plant your roots deep in the land I have given you, and you won't ever be uprooted again. I, the LORD God, have spoken!

1.1: The LORD God gave Obadiah a message about Edom, and this is what we heard: "I, the LORD, have sent a messenger with orders for the nations to attack Edom."
1.2: The LORD said to Edom: I will make you the weakest and most despised nation.
1.3: You live in a mountain fortress, because your pride makes you feel safe from attack, but you are mistaken.
1.4: I will still bring you down, even if you fly higher than an eagle or nest among the stars. I, the LORD, have spoken!
1.5: If thieves break in at night, they steal only what they want. And people who harvest grapes always leave some unpicked. But, Edom, you are doomed!
1.6: Everything you treasure most will be taken from you.
1.7: Your allies can't be trusted. They will force you out of your own country. Your best friends will trick and trap you, even before you know it.
1.8: Edom, when this happens, I, the LORD, will destroy all your marvelous wisdom.
1.9: Warriors from the city of Teman will be terrified, and you descendants of Esau will be wiped out. The LORD Condemns Edom's Cruelty
1.10: You were cruel to your relatives, the descendants of Jacob. Now you will be destroyed, disgraced forever.
1.11: You stood there and watched as foreigners entered Jerusalem and took what they wanted. In fact, you were no better than those foreigners.
1.12: Why did you celebrate when such a dreadful disaster struck your relatives? Why were you so pleased when everyone in Judah was suffering?
1.13: They are my people, and you were cruel to them. You went through their towns, sneering and stealing whatever was left.
1.14: In their time of torment, you ambushed refugees and handed them over to their attackers. The LORD Will Judge the Nations
1.15: The day is coming when I, the LORD, will judge the nations. And, Edom, you will pay in full for what you have done.
1.16: I forced the people of Judah to drink the wine of my anger on my sacred mountain. Soon the neighboring nations must drink their fill-- then vanish without a trace. Victory for Israel
1.17: The LORD's people who escape will go to Mount Zion, and it will be holy. Then Jacob's descendants will capture the land of those who took their land.
1.18: Israel will be a fire, and Edom will be straw going up in flames. The LORD has spoken!
1.19: The people of Israel who live in the Southern Desert will take the land of Edom. Those who live in the hills will capture Philistia, Ephraim, and Samaria. And the tribe of Benjamin will conquer Gilead.
1.20: Those who return from captivity will control Phoenicia as far as Zarephath. Captives from Jerusalem who were taken to Sepharad will capture the towns of the Southern Desert.
1.21: Those the LORD has saved will live on Mount Zion and rule over Edom. Then the kingdom will belong to the LORD.

1.1: One day the LORD told Jonah, the son of Amittai,
1.2: to go to the great city of Nineveh and say to the people, "The LORD has seen your terrible sins. You are doomed!"
1.3: Instead, Jonah ran from the LORD. He went to the seaport of Joppa and bought a ticket on a ship that was going to Spain. Then he got on the ship and sailed away to escape.
1.4: But the LORD made a strong wind blow, and such a bad storm came up that the ship was about to be broken to pieces.
1.5: The sailors were frightened, and they all started praying to their gods. They even threw the ship's cargo overboard to make the ship lighter. All this time, Jonah was down below deck, sound asleep.
1.6: The ship's captain went to him and said, "How can you sleep at a time like this? Get up and pray to your God! Maybe he will have pity on us and keep us from drowning."
1.7: Finally, the sailors got together and said, "Let's ask our gods to show us who caused all this trouble." It turned out to be Jonah.
1.8: They started asking him, "Are you the one who brought all this trouble on us? What business are you in? Where do you come from? What is your country? Who are your people?"
1.9: Jonah answered, "I'm a Hebrew, and I worship the LORD God of heaven, who made the sea and the dry land."
1.10: When the sailors heard this, they were frightened, because Jonah had already told them he was running from the LORD. Then they said, "Do you know what you have done?"
1.11: The storm kept getting worse, until finally the sailors asked him, "What should we do with you to make the sea calm down?"
1.12: Jonah told them, "Throw me into the sea, and it will calm down. I'm the cause of this terrible storm."
1.13: The sailors tried their best to row to the shore. But they could not do it, and the storm kept getting worse every minute.
1.14: So they prayed to the LORD, "Please don't let us drown for taking this man's life. Don't hold us guilty for killing an innocent man. All of this happened because you wanted it to."
1.15: Then they threw Jonah overboard, and the sea calmed down.
1.16: The sailors were so terrified that they offered a sacrifice to the LORD and made all kinds of promises.
1.17: The LORD sent a big fish to swallow Jonah, and Jonah was inside the fish for three days and three nights.

2.1: From inside the fish, Jonah prayed to the LORD his God:
2.2: When I was in trouble, LORD, I prayed to you, and you listened to me. From deep in the world of the dead, I begged for your help, and you answered my prayer.
2.3: You threw me down to the bottom of the sea. The water was churning all around; I was completely covered by your mighty waves.
2.4: I thought I was swept away from your sight, never again to see your holy temple.
2.5: I was almost drowned by the swirling waters that surrounded me. Seaweed had wrapped around my head.
2.6: I had sunk down below the underwater mountains; I knew that forever, I would be a prisoner there. But, you, LORD God, rescued me from that pit.
2.7: When my life was slipping away, I remembered you-- and in your holy temple you heard my prayer.
2.8: All who worship worthless idols turn from the God who offers them mercy.
2.9: But with shouts of praise, I will offer a sacrifice to you, my LORD. I will keep my promise, because you are the one with power to save.
2.10: The LORD commanded the fish to vomit up Jonah on the shore. And it did.

3.1: Once again the LORD told Jonah
3.2: to go to that great city of Nineveh and preach his message of doom.
3.3: Jonah obeyed the LORD and went to Nineveh. The city was so big that it took three days just to walk through it.
3.4: After walking for a day, Jonah warned the people, "Forty days from now, Nineveh will be destroyed!"
3.5: They believed God's message and set a time when they would go without eating to show their sorrow. Then everyone in the city, no matter who they were, dressed in sackcloth.
3.6: When the king of Nineveh heard what was happening, he also dressed in sackcloth; he left the royal palace and sat in dust.
3.7: Then he and his officials sent out an order for everyone in the city to obey. It said: None of you or your animals may eat or drink a thing. Each of you must wear sackcloth, and you must even put sackcloth on your animals. You must also pray to the LORD God with all your heart and stop being sinful and cruel. Maybe God will change his mind and have mercy on us, so we won't be destroyed.
3.10: When God saw that the people had stopped doing evil things, he had pity and did not destroy them as he had planned.

4.1: Jonah was really upset and angry.
4.2: So he prayed: Our LORD, I knew from the very beginning that you wouldn't destroy Nineveh. That's why I left my own country and headed for Spain. You are a kind and merciful God, and you are very patient. You always show love, and you don't like to punish anyone, not even foreigners.
4.3: Now let me die! I'd be better off dead.
4.4: The LORD replied, "What right do you have to be angry?"
4.5: Jonah then left through the east gate of the city and made a shelter to protect himself from the sun. He sat under the shelter, waiting to see what would happen to Nineveh.
4.6: The LORD made a vine grow up to shade Jonah's head and protect him from the sun. Jonah was very happy to have the vine,
4.7: but early the next morning the LORD sent a worm to chew on the vine, and the vine dried up.
4.8: During the day the LORD sent a scorching wind, and the sun beat down on Jonah's head, making him feel faint. Jonah was ready to die, and he shouted, "I wish I were dead!"
4.9: But the LORD asked, "Jonah, do you have the right to be angry about the vine?" "Yes, I do," he answered, "and I'm angry enough to die."
4.10: But the LORD said: You are concerned about a vine that you did not plant or take care of, a vine that grew up in one night and died the next.
4.11: In that city of Nineveh there are more than a hundred twenty thousand people who cannot tell right from wrong, and many cattle are also there. Don't you think I should be concerned about that big city?

1.1: I am Micah from Moresheth. And this is the message about Samaria and Jerusalem that the LORD gave to me when Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezekiah were the kings of Judah. Judgment on Samaria
1.2: Listen, all of you! Earth and everything on it, pay close attention. The LORD God accuses you from his holy temple.
1.3: And he will come down to crush underfoot every pagan altar.
1.4: Mountains will melt beneath his feet like wax beside a fire. Valleys will vanish like water rushing down a ravine.
1.5: This will happen because of the terrible sins of Israel, the descendants of Jacob. Samaria has led Israel to sin, and pagan altars at Jerusalem have made Judah sin.
1.6: So the LORD will leave Samaria in ruins-- merely an empty field where vineyards are planted. He will scatter its stones and destroy its foundations.
1.7: Samaria's idols will be smashed, and the wages of temple prostitutes will be destroyed by fire. Silver and gold from those idols will then be used by foreigners as payment for prostitutes. Judah Is Doomed
1.8: Because of this tragedy, I go barefoot and naked. My crying and weeping sound like howling wolves or ostriches.
1.9: The nation is fatally wounded. Judah is doomed. Jerusalem will fall.
1.10: Don't tell it in Gath! Don't even cry. Instead, roll in the dust at Beth-Leaphrah.
1.11: Depart naked and ashamed, you people of Shaphir. The town of Bethezel mourns because no one from Zaanan went out to help.
1.12: Everyone in Maroth hoped for the best, but the LORD sent disaster down on Jerusalem.
1.13: Get the war chariots ready, you people of Lachish. You led Jerusalem into sin, just as Israel did.
1.14: Now you will have to give a going-away gift to Moresheth. Israel's kings will discover that they cannot trust the town of Achzib.
1.15: People of Mareshah, the LORD will send someone to capture your town. Then Israel's glorious king will be forced to hide in Adullam Cave.
1.16: Judah, shave your head as bald as a buzzard and start mourning. Your precious children will be dragged off to a foreign country.

2.1: Doomed! You're doomed! At night you lie in bed, making evil plans. And when morning comes, you do what you've planned because you have the power.
2.2: You grab any field or house that you want; you cheat families out of homes and land.
2.3: But here is what the LORD says: "I am planning trouble for you. Your necks will be caught in a noose, and you will be disgraced in this time of disaster."
2.4: When that happens, this sorrowful song will be sung about you: "Ruined! Completely ruined! The LORD has taken our land and given it to traitors."
2.5: And so you will never again own property among the LORD's people.
2.6: "Enough of your preaching!" That's what you tell me. "We won't be disgraced, so stop preaching!"
2.7: Descendants of Jacob, is it right for you to claim that the LORD did what he did because he was angry? Doesn't he always bless those who do right?
2.8: My people, you have even stolen clothes right off the backs of your unsuspecting soldiers returning home from battle.
2.9: You take over lovely homes that belong to the women of my nation. Then you cheat their children out of the inheritance that comes from the LORD.
2.10: Get out of here, you crooks! You'll find no rest here. You're not fit to belong to the LORD's people, and you will be destroyed.
2.11: The only prophet you want is a liar who will say, "Drink and get drunk!" A Promise of Hope
2.12: I, the LORD, promise to bring together the people of Israel who have survived. I will gather them, just as a shepherd brings sheep together, and there will be many.
2.13: I will break down the gate and lead them out-- then I will be their king.

3.1: Listen to me, you rulers of Israel! You know right from wrong,
3.2: but you prefer to do evil instead of what is right. You skin my people alive. You strip off their flesh,
3.3: break their bones, cook it all in a pot, and gulp it down.
3.4: Someday you will beg the LORD to help you, but he will turn away because of your sins.
3.5: You lying prophets promise security for anyone who gives you food, but disaster for anyone who refuses to feed you. Here is what the LORD says to you prophets:
3.6: "You will live in the dark, far from the sight of the sun, with no message from me.
3.7: You prophets and fortunetellers will all be disgraced, with no message from me."
3.8: But the LORD has filled me with power and his Spirit. I have been given the courage to speak about justice and to tell you people of Israel that you have sinned.
3.9: So listen to my message, you rulers of Israel! You hate justice and twist the truth.
3.10: You make cruelty and murder a way of life in Jerusalem.
3.11: You leaders accept bribes for dishonest decisions. You priests and prophets teach and preach, but only for money. Then you say, "The LORD is on our side. No harm will come to us."
3.12: And so, because of you, Jerusalem will be plowed under and left in ruins. Thorns will cover the mountain where the temple now stands.

4.1: In the future, the mountain with the LORD's temple will be the highest of all. It will reach above the hills, and every nation will rush to it.
4.2: People of many nations will come and say, "Let's go up to the mountain of the LORD God of Jacob and worship in his temple." The LORD will teach us his Law from Jerusalem, and we will obey him.
4.3: He will settle arguments between distant and powerful nations. They will pound their swords and their spears into rakes and shovels; they will never again make war or attack one another.
4.4: Everyone will find rest beneath their own fig trees or grape vines, and they will live in peace. This is a solemn promise of the LORD All-Powerful.
4.5: Others may follow their gods, but we will always follow the LORD our God. The LORD Will Lead His People Home
4.6: The LORD said: At that time I will gather my people-- the lame and the outcasts, and all into whose lives I have brought sorrow.
4.7: Then the lame and the outcasts will belong to my people and become a strong nation. I, the LORD, will rule them from Mount Zion forever.
4.8: Mount Zion in Jerusalem, guardian of my people, you will rule again.
4.9: Jerusalem, why are you crying? Don't you have a king? Have your advisors gone? Are you suffering like a woman in childbirth?
4.10: Keep on groaning with pain, you people of Jerusalem! If you escape from your city to the countryside, you will still be taken as prisoners to Babylonia. But later I will rescue you from your enemies.
4.11: Zion, because of your sins you are surrounded by many nations who say, "We can hardly wait to see you disgraced."
4.12: But they don't know that I, the LORD, have gathered them here to grind them like grain.
4.13: Smash them to pieces, Zion! I'll let you be like a bull with iron horns and bronze hoofs. Crush those nations and bring their wealth to me, the LORD of the earth.

5.1: Jerusalem, enemy troops have surrounded you; they have struck Israel's ruler in the face with a stick.
5.2: Bethlehem Ephrath, you are one of the smallest towns in the nation of Judah. But the LORD will choose one of your people to rule the nation-- someone whose family goes back to ancient times.
5.3: The LORD will abandon Israel only until this ruler is born, and the rest of his family returns to Israel.
5.4: Like a shepherd taking care of his sheep, this ruler will lead and care for his people by the power and glorious name of the LORD his God. His people will live securely, and the whole earth will know his true greatness,
5.5: because he will bring peace. Let Assyria attack our country and our palaces. We will counterattack, led by a number of rulers Assyria Will Be Defeated
5.6: whose strong army will defeat the nation of Assyria. Yes, our leaders will rescue us, if those Assyrians dare to invade our land. The Survivors Will Be Safe
5.7: A few of Jacob's descendants survived and are scattered among the nations. But the LORD will let them cover the earth like dew and rain that refreshes the soil.
5.8: At present they are scattered, but later they will attack, as though they were fierce lions pouncing on sheep. Their enemies will be torn to shreds, with no one to save them;
5.9: they will be helpless, completely destroyed. Idols Will Be Destroyed in Israel
5.10: The LORD said: At that time I will wipe out your cavalry and chariots,
5.11: as well as your cities and your fortresses.
5.12: I will stop you from telling fortunes and practicing witchcraft.
5.13: You will no longer worship the idols or stone images you have made-- I will destroy them,
5.14: together with the sacred poles and even your towns.
5.15: I will become furious and take revenge on the nations that refuse to obey me.

6.1: The LORD said to his people: Come and present your case to the hills and mountains.
6.2: Israel, I am bringing charges against you-- I call upon the mountains and the earth's firm foundation to be my witnesses.
6.3: My people, have I wronged you in any way at all? Please tell me.
6.4: I rescued you from Egypt, where you were slaves. I sent Moses, Aaron, and Miriam to be your leaders.
6.5: Don't forget the evil plans of King Balak of Moab or what Balaam son of Beor said to him. Remember how I, the LORD, saved you many times on your way from Acacia to Gilgal. True Obedience
6.6: What offering should I bring when I bow down to worship the LORD God Most High? Should I try to please him by sacrificing calves a year old?
6.7: Will thousands of sheep or rivers of olive oil make God satisfied with me? Should I sacrifice to the LORD my first-born child as payment for my terrible sins?
6.8: The LORD God has told us what is right and what he demands: "See that justice is done, let mercy be your first concern, and humbly obey your God." Cheating and Violence
6.9: I am the LORD, and it makes sense to respect my power to punish. So listen to my message for the city of Jerusalem:
6.10: You store up stolen treasures and use dishonest scales.
6.11: But I, the LORD, will punish you for cheating with weights and with measures.
6.12: You rich people are violent, and everyone tells lies.
6.13: Because of your sins, I will wound you and leave you ruined and defenseless.
6.14: You will eat, but still be hungry; you will store up goods, but lose everything-- I, the LORD, will let it all be captured in war.
6.15: You won't harvest what you plant or use the oil from your olive trees or drink the wine from grapes you grow.
6.16: Jerusalem, this will happen because you followed the sinful example of kings Omri and Ahab. Now I will destroy you and your property. Then the people of every nation will make fun and insult you.

7.1: I feel so empty inside-- like someone starving for grapes or figs, after the vines and trees have all been picked clean.
7.2: No one is loyal to God; no one does right. Everyone is brutal and eager to deceive everyone else.
7.3: People cooperate to commit crime. Judges and leaders demand bribes, and rulers cheat in court.
7.4: The most honest of them is worse than a thorn patch. Your doom has come! Lookouts sound the warning, and everyone panics.
7.5: Don't trust anyone, not even your best friend, and be careful what you say to the one you love.
7.6: Sons refuse to respect their own fathers, daughters rebel against their own mothers, and daughters-in-law despise their mothers-in-law. Your family is now your enemy.
7.7: But I trust the LORD God to save me, and I will wait for him to answer my prayer. The Nation Turns to God
7.8: My enemies, don't be glad because of my troubles! I may have fallen, but I will get up; I may be sitting in the dark, but the LORD is my light.
7.9: I have sinned against the LORD. And so I must endure his anger, until he comes to my defense. But I know that I will see him making things right for me and leading me to the light.
7.10: You, my enemies, said, "The LORD God is helpless." Now each of you will be disgraced and put to shame. I will see you trampled like mud in the street. A Bright Future
7.11: Towns of Judah, the day is coming when your walls will be rebuilt, and your boundaries enlarged.
7.12: People will flock to you from Assyria and Egypt, from Babylonia and everywhere else.
7.13: Those nations will suffer disaster because of what they did. Micah's Prayer and the LORD's Answer
7.14: Lead your people, LORD! Come and be our shepherd. Grasslands surround us, but we live in a forest. So lead us to Bashan and Gilead, and let us find pasture as we did long ago.
7.15: I, the LORD, will work miracles just as I did when I led you out of Egypt.
7.16: Nations will see this and be ashamed because of their helpless armies. They will be in shock, unable to speak or hear,
7.17: because of their fear of me, your LORD and God. Then they will come trembling, crawling out of their fortresses like insects or snakes, lapping up the dust. No One Is Like GodThe people said:
7.18: Our God, no one is like you. We are all that is left of your chosen people, and you freely forgive our sin and guilt. You don't stay angry forever; you're glad to have pity
7.19: and pleased to be merciful. You will trample on our sins and throw them in the sea.
7.20: You will keep your word and be faithful to Jacob and to Abraham, as you promised our ancestors many years ago.

1.1: I am Nahum from Elkosh. And this is the message that I wrote down about Nineveh. The Fierce Anger of the LORD
1.2: The LORD God demands loyalty. In his anger, he takes revenge on his enemies.
1.3: The LORD is powerful, yet patient; he makes sure that the guilty are always punished. He can be seen in storms and in whirlwinds; clouds are the dust from his feet.
1.4: At the LORD's command, oceans and rivers dry up. Bashan, Mount Carmel, and Lebanon wither, and their flowers fade.
1.5: At the sight of the LORD, mountains and hills tremble and melt; the earth and its people shudder and shake.
1.6: Who can stand the heat of his furious anger? It flashes out like fire and shatters stones. The Power of Assyria Will Be Broken
1.7: The LORD is good. He protects those who trust him in times of trouble.
1.8: But like a roaring flood, the LORD chases his enemies into dark places and destroys them.
1.9: So don't plot against the LORD! He wipes out his enemies, and they never revive.
1.10: They are like drunkards overcome by wine, or like dry thornbushes burning in a fire.
1.11: Assyria, one of your rulers has made evil plans against the LORD.
1.12: But the LORD says, "Assyria, no matter how strong you are, you are doomed! My people Judah, I have troubled you before, but I won't do it again.
1.13: I'll snap your chains and set you free from the Assyrians."
1.14: Assyria, this is what else the LORD says to you: "Your name will be forgotten. I will destroy every idol in your temple, and I will send you to the grave, because you are worthless."
1.15: Look toward the mountains, people of Judah! Here comes a messenger with good news of peace. Celebrate your festivals. Keep your promises to God. Your evil enemies are destroyed and will never again invade your country.

2.1: Nineveh, someone is coming to attack and scatter you. Guard your fortresses! Watch the road! Be brave! Prepare for battle!
2.2: Judah and Israel are like trees with branches broken by their enemies. But the LORD is going to restore their power and glory.
2.3: Nineveh, on this day of attack, your enemies' shields are red; their uniforms are crimson.
2.4: Their horses prance, and their armored chariots dart around like lightning or flaming torches.
2.5: An officer gives a command. But his soldiers stumble, as they hasten to build a shelter to protect themselves against rocks thrown down from the city wall.
2.6: The river gates fly open, and panic floods the palace.
2.7: Nineveh is disgraced. The queen is dragged off. Her servant women mourn; they sound like doves, and they beat their breasts in sorrow.
2.8: Nineveh is like a pond with leaking water. Shouts of "Stop! Don't go!" can be heard everywhere. But everyone is leaving.
2.9: Enemy soldiers shout, "The city is full of treasure and all kinds of wealth. Steal her silver! Grab her gold!"
2.10: Nineveh is doomed! Destroyed! Her people tremble with fear; their faces turn pale.
2.11: What happened to this city? They were safer there than powerful lions in a den, with no one to disturb them.
2.12: These are the same lions that ferociously attacked their victims, then dragged away the flesh to feed their young.
2.13: The LORD All-Powerful is against you, Nineveh. God will burn your chariots and send an army to kill those young lions of yours. You will never again make victims of others or send messengers to threaten everyone on this earth.

3.1: Doom to the crime capital! Nineveh, city of murder and treachery,
3.2: here is your fate-- cracking whips, churning wheels; galloping horses, roaring chariots;
3.3: cavalry attacking, swords and spears flashing; soldiers stumbling over piles of dead bodies.
3.4: You were nothing more than a prostitute using your magical charms and witchcraft to attract and trap nations.
3.5: But I, the LORD All-Powerful, am now your enemy. I will pull up your skirt and let nations and kingdoms stare at your nakedness.
3.6: I will cover you with garbage, treat you like trash, and rub you in the dirt.
3.7: Everyone who sees you will turn away and shout, "Nineveh is done for! Is anyone willing to mourn or to give her comfort?" Nineveh's Fate Is Sealed
3.8: Nineveh, do you feel safer than the city of Thebes? The Nile River was its wall of defense.
3.9: Thebes trusted the mighty power of Ethiopia and Egypt; the nations of Put and Libya were her allies.
3.10: But she was captured and taken to a foreign country. Her children were murdered at every street corner. The members of her royal family were auctioned off, and her high officials were bound in chains.
3.11: Nineveh, now it's your turn! You will get drunk and try to hide from your enemy.
3.12: Your fortresses are fig trees with ripe figs. Merely shake the trees, and fruit will fall into every open mouth.
3.13: Your army is weak. Fire has destroyed the crossbars on your city gates; now they stand wide open to your enemy.
3.14: Your city is under attack. Haul in extra water! Strengthen your defenses! Start making bricks! Stir the mortar!
3.15: You will still go up in flames and be cut down by swords that will wipe you out like wheat attacked by grasshoppers. So, go ahead and increase like a swarm of locusts!
3.16: More merchants are in your city than there are stars in the sky-- but they are like locusts that eat everything, then fly away.
3.17: Your guards and your officials are swarms of locusts. On a chilly day they settle on a fence, but when the sun comes out, they take off to who-knows-where.
3.18: King of Assyria, your officials and leaders sleep the eternal sleep, while your people are scattered in the mountains. Yes, your people are sheep without a shepherd.
3.19: You're fatally wounded. There's no hope for you. But everyone claps when they hear this news, because your constant cruelty has caused them pain.

1.1: I am Habakkuk the prophet. And this is the message that the LORD gave me. Habakkuk Complains to the LORD
1.2: Our LORD, how long must I beg for your help before you listen? How long before you save us from all this violence?
1.3: Why do you make me watch such terrible injustice? Why do you allow violence, lawlessness, crime, and cruelty to spread everywhere?
1.4: Laws cannot be enforced; justice is always the loser; criminals crowd out honest people and twist the laws around. The LORD Answers Habakkuk
1.5: Look and be amazed at what's happening among the nations! Even if you were told, you would never believe what's taking place now.
1.6: I am sending the Babylonians. They are fierce and cruel-- marching across the land, conquering cities and towns.
1.7: How fearsome and frightening. Their only laws and rules are the ones they make up.
1.8: Their cavalry troops are faster than leopards, more ferocious than wolves hunting at sunset, and swifter than hungry eagles suddenly swooping down.
1.9: They are eager to destroy, and they gather captives like handfuls of sand.
1.10: They make fun of rulers and laugh at fortresses, while building dirt mounds so they can capture cities.
1.11: Then suddenly they disappear like a gust of wind-- those sinful people who worship their own strength. Habakkuk Complains Again
1.12: Holy LORD God, mighty rock, you are eternal, and we are safe from death. You are using those Babylonians to judge and punish others.
1.13: But you can't stand sin or wrong. So don't sit by in silence while they gobble down people who are better than they are.
1.14: The people you put on this earth are like fish or reptiles without a leader.
1.15: Then an enemy comes along and takes them captive with hooks and nets. It makes him so happy
1.16: that he offers sacrifices to his fishing nets, because they make him rich and provide choice foods.
1.17: Will he keep hauling in his nets and destroying nations without showing mercy?

2.1: While standing guard on the watchtower, I waited for the LORD's answer, before explaining the reason for my complaint.
2.2: Then the LORD told me: "I will give you my message in the form of a vision. Write it clearly enough to be read at a glance.
