9.21: She had said to herself, "If I can just touch his clothes, I will get well."
9.22: Jesus turned. He saw the woman and said, "Don't worry! You are now well because of your faith." At that moment she was healed.
9.23: When Jesus went into the home of the official and saw the musicians and the crowd of mourners,
9.24: he said, "Get out of here! The little girl isn't dead. She is just asleep." Everyone started laughing at Jesus.
9.25: But after the crowd had been sent out of the house, Jesus went to the girl's bedside. He took her by the hand and helped her up.
9.26: News about this spread all over that part of the country. Jesus Heals Two Blind Men
9.27: As Jesus was walking along, two blind men began following him and shouting, "Son of David, have pity on us!"
9.28: After Jesus had gone indoors, the two blind men came up to him. He asked them, "Do you believe I can make you well?" "Yes, Lord," they answered.
9.29: Jesus touched their eyes and said, "Because of your faith, you will be healed."
9.30: They were able to see, and Jesus strictly warned them not to tell anyone about him.
9.31: But they left and talked about him to everyone in that part of the country. Jesus Heals a Man Who Could Not Talk
9.32: As Jesus and his disciples were on their way, some people brought to him a man who could not talk because a demon was in him.
9.33: After Jesus had forced the demon out, the man started talking. The crowds were so amazed that they began saying, "Nothing like this has ever happened in Israel!"
9.34: But the Pharisees said, "The leader of the demons gives him the power to force out demons." Jesus Has Pity on People
9.35: Jesus went to every town and village. He taught in their meeting places and preached the good news about God's kingdom. Jesus also healed every kind of disease and sickness.
9.36: When he saw the crowds, he felt sorry for them. They were confused and helpless, like sheep without a shepherd.
9.37: He said to his disciples, "A large crop is in the fields, but there are only a few workers.
9.38: Ask the Lord in charge of the harvest to send out workers to bring it in."

10.1: Jesus called together his twelve disciples. He gave them the power to force out evil spirits and to heal every kind of disease and sickness.
10.2: The first of the twelve apostles was Simon, better known as Peter. His brother Andrew was an apostle, and so were James and John, the two sons of Zebedee.
10.3: Philip, Bartholomew, Thomas, Matthew the tax collector, James the son of Alphaeus, and Thaddaeus were also apostles.
10.4: The others were Simon, known as the Eager One, and Judas Iscariot, who later betrayed Jesus. Instructions for the Twelve Apostles(Mark 6.7-13; Luke 9.1-6)
10.5: Jesus sent out the twelve apostles with these instructions: Stay away from the Gentiles and don't go to any Samaritan town.
10.6: Go only to the people of Israel, because they are like a flock of lost sheep.
10.7: As you go, announce that the kingdom of heaven will soon be here.
10.8: Heal the sick, raise the dead to life, heal people who have leprosy, and force out demons. You received without paying, now give without being paid.
10.9: Don't take along any gold, silver, or copper coins.
10.10: And don't carry a traveling bag or an extra shirt or sandals or a walking stick. Workers deserve their food.
10.11: So when you go to a town or a village, find someone worthy enough to have you as their guest and stay with them until you leave.
10.12: When you go to a home, give it your blessing of peace.
10.13: If the home is deserving, let your blessing remain with them. But if the home isn't deserving, take back your blessing of peace.
10.14: If someone won't welcome you or listen to your message, leave their home or town. And shake the dust from your feet at them.
10.15: I promise you that the day of judgment will be easier for the towns of Sodom and Gomorrah than for that town. Warning about Trouble(Mark 13.9-13; Luke 21.12-17)
10.16: I am sending you like lambs into a pack of wolves. So be as wise as snakes and as innocent as doves.
10.17: Watch out for people who will take you to court and have you beaten in their meeting places.
10.18: Because of me, you will be dragged before rulers and kings to tell them and the Gentiles about your faith.
10.19: But when someone arrests you, don't worry about what you will say or how you will say it. At that time you will be given the words to say.
10.20: But you will not really be the one speaking. The Spirit from your Father will tell you what to say.
10.21: Brothers and sisters will betray one another and have each other put to death. Parents will betray their own children, and children will turn against their parents and have them killed.
10.22: Everyone will hate you because of me. But if you remain faithful until the end, you will be saved.
10.23: When people mistreat you in one town, hurry to another one. I promise you that before you have gone to all the towns of Israel, the Son of Man will come.
10.24: Disciples are not better than their teacher, and slaves are not better than their master.
10.25: It is enough for disciples to be like their teacher and for slaves to be like their master. If people call the head of the family Satan, what will they say about the rest of the family? The One To Fear(Luke 12.2-7)
10.26: Don't be afraid of anyone! Everything that is hidden will be found out, and every secret will be known.
10.27: Whatever I say to you in the dark, you must tell in the light. And you must announce from the housetops whatever I have whispered to you.
10.28: Don't be afraid of people. They can kill you, but they cannot harm your soul. Instead, you should fear God who can destroy both your body and your soul in hell.
10.29: Aren't two sparrows sold for only a penny? But your Father knows when any one of them falls to the ground.
10.30: Even the hairs on your head are counted.
10.31: So don't be afraid! You are worth much more than many sparrows. Telling Others about Christ(Luke 12.8,9)
10.32: If you tell others that you belong to me, I will tell my Father in heaven that you are my followers.
10.33: But if you reject me, I will tell my Father in heaven that you don't belong to me. Not Peace, but Trouble(Luke 12.51-53; 14.26,27)
10.34: Don't think that I came to bring peace to the earth! I came to bring trouble, not peace.
10.35: I came to turn sons against their fathers, daughters against their mothers, and daughters-in-law against their mothers-in-law.
10.36: Your worst enemies will be in your own family.
10.37: If you love your father or mother or even your sons and daughters more than me, you are not fit to be my disciples.
10.38: And unless you are willing to take up your cross and come with me, you are not fit to be my disciples.
10.39: If you try to save your life, you will lose it. But if you give it up for me, you will surely find it. Rewards(Mark 9.41)
10.40: Anyone who welcomes you welcomes me. And anyone who welcomes me also welcomes the one who sent me.
10.41: Anyone who welcomes a prophet, just because that person is a prophet, will be given the same reward as a prophet. Anyone who welcomes a good person, just because that person is good, will be given the same reward as a good person.
10.42: And anyone who gives one of my most humble followers a cup of cool water, just because that person is my follower, will surely be rewarded.

11.1: After Jesus had finished instructing his twelve disciples, he left and began teaching and preaching in the towns.
11.2: John was in prison when he heard what Christ was doing. So John sent some of his followers
11.3: to ask Jesus, "Are you the one we should be looking for? Or must we wait for someone else?"
11.4: Jesus answered, "Go and tell John what you have heard and seen.
11.5: The blind are now able to see, and the lame can walk. People with leprosy are being healed, and the deaf can hear. The dead are raised to life, and the poor are hearing the good news.
11.6: God will bless everyone who doesn't reject me because of what I do."
11.7: As John's followers were going away, Jesus spoke to the crowds about John: What sort of person did you go out into the desert to see? Was he like tall grass blown about by the wind?
11.8: What kind of man did you go out to see? Was he someone dressed in fine clothes? People who dress like that live in the king's palace.
11.9: What did you really go out to see? Was he a prophet? He certainly was. I tell you that he was more than a prophet.
11.10: In the Scriptures God says about him, "I am sending my messenger ahead of you to get things ready for you."
11.11: I tell you that no one ever born on this earth is greater than John the Baptist. But whoever is least in the kingdom of heaven is greater than John.
11.12: From the time of John the Baptist until now, violent people have been trying to take over the kingdom of heaven by force.
11.13: All the Books of the Prophets and the Law of Moses told what was going to happen up to the time of John.
11.14: And if you believe them, John is Elijah, the prophet you are waiting for.
11.15: If you have ears, pay attention!
11.16: You people are like children sitting in the market and shouting to each other,
11.17: "We played the flute, but you would not dance! We sang a funeral song, but you would not mourn!"
11.18: John the Baptist did not go around eating and drinking, and you said, "That man has a demon in him!"
11.19: But the Son of Man goes around eating and drinking, and you say, "That man eats and drinks too much! He is even a friend of tax collectors and sinners." Yet Wisdom is shown to be right by what it does. The Unbelieving Towns(Luke 10.13-15)
11.20: In the towns where Jesus had worked most of his miracles, the people refused to turn to God. So Jesus was upset with them and said:
11.21: You people of Chorazin are in for trouble! You people of Bethsaida are in for trouble too! If the miracles that took place in your towns had happened in Tyre and Sidon, the people there would have turned to God long ago. They would have dressed in sackcloth and put ashes on their heads.
11.22: I tell you that on the day of judgment the people of Tyre and Sidon will get off easier than you will.
11.23: People of Capernaum, do you think you will be honored in heaven? You will go down to hell! If the miracles that took place in your town had happened in Sodom, that town would still be standing.
11.24: So I tell you that on the day of judgment the people of Sodom will get off easier than you. Come to Me and Rest(Luke 10.21,22)
11.25: At that moment Jesus said: My Father, Lord of heaven and earth, I am grateful that you hid all this from wise and educated people and showed it to ordinary people.
11.26: Yes, Father, that is what pleased you.
11.27: My Father has given me everything, and he is the only one who knows the Son. The only one who truly knows the Father is the Son. But the Son wants to tell others about the Father, so that they can know him too.
11.28: If you are tired from carrying heavy burdens, come to me and I will give you rest.
11.29: Take the yoke I give you. Put it on your shoulders and learn from me. I am gentle and humble, and you will find rest.
11.30: This yoke is easy to bear, and this burden is light.

12.1: One Sabbath, Jesus and his disciples were walking through some wheat fields. His disciples were hungry and began picking and eating grains of wheat.
12.2: Some Pharisees noticed this and said to Jesus, "Why are your disciples picking grain on the Sabbath? They are not supposed to do that!"
12.3: Jesus answered: You surely must have read what David did when he and his followers were hungry.
12.4: He went into the house of God, and then they ate the sacred loaves of bread that only priests are supposed to eat.
12.5: Haven't you read in the Law of Moses that the priests are allowed to work in the temple on the Sabbath? But no one says that they are guilty of breaking the law of the Sabbath.
12.6: I tell you that there is something here greater than the temple.
12.7: Don't you know what the Scriptures mean when they say, "Instead of offering sacrifices to me, I want you to be merciful to others?" If you knew what this means, you would not condemn these innocent disciples of mine.
12.8: So the Son of Man is Lord over the Sabbath. A Man with a Crippled Hand(Mark 3.1-6; Luke 6.6-11)
12.9: Jesus left and went into one of the Jewish meeting places,
12.10: where there was a man whose hand was crippled. Some Pharisees wanted to accuse Jesus of doing something wrong, and they asked him, "Is it right to heal someone on the Sabbath?"
12.11: Jesus answered, "If you had a sheep that fell into a ditch on the Sabbath, wouldn't you lift it out?
12.12: People are worth much more than sheep, and so it is right to do good on the Sabbath."
12.13: Then Jesus told the man, "Hold out your hand." The man did, and it became as healthy as the other one.
12.14: The Pharisees left and started making plans to kill Jesus. God's Chosen Servant
12.15: When Jesus found out what was happening, he left there and large crowds followed him. He healed all of their sick,
12.16: but warned them not to tell anyone about him.
12.17: So God's promise came true, just as Isaiah the prophet had said,
12.18: "Here is my chosen servant! I love him, and he pleases me. I will give him my Spirit, and he will bring justice to the nations.
12.19: He won't shout or yell or call out in the streets.
12.20: He won't break off a bent reed or put out a dying flame, but he will make sure that justice is done.
12.21: All nations will place their hope in him." Jesus and the Ruler of the Demons(Mark 3.20-30; Luke 11.14-23; 12.10)
12.22: Some people brought to Jesus a man who was blind and could not talk because he had a demon in him. Jesus healed the man, and then he was able to talk and see.
12.23: The crowds were so amazed that they asked, "Could Jesus be the Son of David?"
12.24: When the Pharisees heard this, they said, "He forces out demons by the power of Beelzebul, the ruler of the demons!"
12.25: Jesus knew what they were thinking, and he said to them: Any kingdom where people fight each other will end up ruined. And a town or family that fights will soon destroy itself.
12.26: So if Satan fights against himself, how can his kingdom last?
12.27: If I use the power of Beelzebul to force out demons, whose power do your own followers use to force them out? Your followers are the ones who will judge you.
12.28: But when I force out demons by the power of God's Spirit, it proves that God's kingdom has already come to you.
12.29: How can anyone break into a strong man's house and steal his things, unless he first ties up the strong man? Then he can take everything.
12.30: If you are not on my side, you are against me. If you don't gather in the harvest with me, you scatter it.
12.31: I tell you that any sinful thing you do or say can be forgiven. Even if you speak against the Son of Man, you can be forgiven. But if you speak against the Holy Spirit, you can never be forgiven, either in this life or in the life to come. A Tree and Its Fruit(Luke 6.43-45)
12.33: A good tree produces only good fruit, and a bad tree produces bad fruit. You can tell what a tree is like by the fruit it produces.
12.34: You are a bunch of evil snakes, so how can you say anything good? Your words show what is in your hearts.
12.35: Good people bring good things out of their hearts, but evil people bring evil things out of their hearts.
12.36: I promise you that on the day of judgment, everyone will have to account for every careless word they have spoken.
12.37: On that day they will be told that they are either innocent or guilty because of the things they have said. A Sign from Heaven(Mark 8.11,12; Luke 11.29-32)
12.38: Some Pharisees and teachers of the Law of Moses said, "Teacher, we want you to show us a sign from heaven."
12.39: But Jesus replied: You want a sign because you are evil and won't believe! But the only sign you will get is the sign of the prophet Jonah.
12.40: He was in the stomach of a big fish for three days and nights, just as the Son of Man will be deep in the earth for three days and nights.
12.41: On the day of judgment the people of Nineveh will stand there with you and condemn you. They turned to God when Jonah preached, and yet here is something far greater than Jonah.
12.42: The Queen of the South will also stand there with you and condemn you. She traveled a long way to hear Solomon's wisdom, and yet here is something much greater than Solomon. Return of an Evil Spirit(Luke 11.24-26)
12.43: When an evil spirit leaves a person, it travels through the desert, looking for a place to rest. But when the demon doesn't find a place,
12.44: it says, "I will go back to the home I left." When it gets there and finds the place empty, clean, and fixed up,
12.45: it goes off and finds seven other evil spirits even worse than itself. They all come and make their home there, and the person ends up in worse shape than before. That's how it will be with you evil people of today. Jesus' Mother and Brothers(Mark 3.31-35; Luke 8.19-21)
12.46: While Jesus was still speaking to the crowds, his mother and brothers came and stood outside because they wanted to talk with him.
12.47: Someone told Jesus, "Your mother and brothers are standing outside and want to talk with you."
12.48: Jesus answered, "Who is my mother and who are my brothers?"
12.49: Then he pointed to his disciples and said, "These are my mother and my brothers!
12.50: Anyone who obeys my Father in heaven is my brother or sister or mother."

13.1: That same day Jesus left the house and went out beside Lake Galilee, where he sat down to teach.
13.2: Such large crowds gathered around him that he had to sit in a boat, while the people stood on the shore.
13.3: Then he taught them many things by using stories. He said: A farmer went out to scatter seed in a field.
13.4: While the farmer was scattering the seed, some of it fell along the road and was eaten by birds.
13.5: Other seeds fell on thin, rocky ground and quickly started growing because the soil wasn't very deep.
13.6: But when the sun came up, the plants were scorched and dried up, because they did not have enough roots.
13.7: Some other seeds fell where thornbushes grew up and choked the plants.
13.8: But a few seeds did fall on good ground where the plants produced a hundred or sixty or thirty times as much as was scattered.
13.9: If you have ears, pay attention! Why Jesus Used Stories(Mark 4.10-12; Luke 8.9,10)
13.10: Jesus' disciples came to him and asked, "Why do you use nothing but stories when you speak to the people?"
13.11: Jesus answered: I have explained the secrets about the kingdom of heaven to you, but not to others.
13.12: Everyone who has something will be given more. But people who don't have anything will lose even what little they have.
13.13: I use stories when I speak to them because when they look, they cannot see, and when they listen, they cannot hear or understand.
13.14: So God's promise came true, just as the prophet Isaiah had said, "These people will listen and listen, but never understand. They will look and look, but never see.
13.15: All of them have stubborn minds! Their ears are stopped up, and their eyes are covered. They cannot see or hear or understand. If they could, they would turn to me, and I would heal them."
13.16: But God has blessed you, because your eyes can see and your ears can hear!
13.17: Many prophets and good people were eager to see what you see and to hear what you hear. But I tell you that they did not see or hear. Jesus Explains the Story about the Farmer(Mark 4.13-20; Luke 8.11-15)
13.18: Now listen to the meaning of the story about the farmer:
13.19: The seeds that fell along the road are the people who hear the message about the kingdom, but don't understand it. Then the evil one comes and snatches the message from their hearts.
13.20: The seeds that fell on rocky ground are the people who gladly hear the message and accept it right away.
13.21: But they don't have deep roots, and they don't last very long. As soon as life gets hard or the message gets them in trouble, they give up.
13.22: The seeds that fell among the thornbushes are also people who hear the message. But they start worrying about the needs of this life and are fooled by the desire to get rich. So the message gets choked out, and they never produce anything.
13.23: The seeds that fell on good ground are the people who hear and understand the message. They produce as much as a hundred or sixty or thirty times what was planted. Weeds among the Wheat
13.24: Jesus then told them this story: The kingdom of heaven is like what happened when a farmer scattered good seed in a field.
13.25: But while everyone was sleeping, an enemy came and scattered weed seeds in the field and then left.
13.26: When the plants came up and began to ripen, the farmer's servants could see the weeds.
13.27: The servants came and asked, "Sir, didn't you scatter good seed in your field? Where did these weeds come from?"
13.28: "An enemy did this," he replied. His servants then asked, "Do you want us to go out and pull up the weeds?"
13.29: "No!" he answered. "You might also pull up the wheat.
13.30: Leave the weeds alone until harvest time. Then I'll tell my workers to gather the weeds and tie them up and burn them. But I'll have them store the wheat in my barn." Stories about a Mustard Seed and Yeast(Mark 4.30-32; Luke 13.18-21)
13.31: Jesus told them another story: The kingdom of heaven is like what happens when a farmer plants a mustard seed in a field.
13.32: Although it is the smallest of all seeds, it grows larger than any garden plant and becomes a tree. Birds even come and nest on its branches.
13.33: Jesus also said: The kingdom of heaven is like what happens when a woman mixes a little yeast into three big batches of flour. Finally, all the dough rises. The Reason for Teaching with Stories(Mark 4.33,34)
13.34: Jesus used stories when he spoke to the people. In fact, he did not tell them anything without using stories.
13.35: So God's promise came true, just as the prophet had said, "I will use stories to speak my message and to explain things that have been hidden since the creation of the world." Jesus Explains the Story about the Weeds
13.36: After Jesus left the crowd and went inside, his disciples came to him and said, "Explain to us the story about the weeds in the wheat field."
13.37: Jesus answered: The one who scattered the good seed is the Son of Man.
13.38: The field is the world, and the good seeds are the people who belong to the kingdom. The weed seeds are those who belong to the evil one,
13.39: and the one who scattered them is the devil. The harvest is the end of time, and angels are the ones who bring in the harvest.
13.40: Weeds are gathered and burned. That's how it will be at the end of time.
13.41: The Son of Man will send out his angels, and they will gather from his kingdom everyone who does wrong or causes others to sin.
13.42: Then he will throw them into a flaming furnace, where people will cry and grit their teeth in pain.
13.43: But everyone who has done right will shine like the sun in their Father's kingdom. If you have ears, pay attention! A Hidden Treasure
13.44: The kingdom of heaven is like what happens when someone finds a treasure hidden in a field and buries it again. A person like that is happy and goes and sells everything in order to buy that field. A Valuable Pearl
13.45: The kingdom of heaven is like what happens when a shop owner is looking for fine pearls.
13.46: After finding a very valuable one, the owner goes and sells everything in order to buy that pearl. A Fish Net
13.47: The kingdom of heaven is like what happens when a net is thrown into a lake and catches all kinds of fish.
13.48: When the net is full, it is dragged to the shore, and the fishermen sit down to separate the fish. They keep the good ones, but throw the bad ones away.
13.49: That's how it will be at the end of time. Angels will come and separate the evil people from the ones who have done right.
13.50: Then those evil people will be thrown into a flaming furnace, where they will cry and grit their teeth in pain. New and Old Treasures
13.51: Jesus asked his disciples if they understood all these things. They said, "Yes, we do."
13.52: So he told them, "Every student of the Scriptures who becomes a disciple in the kingdom of heaven is like someone who brings out new and old treasures from the storeroom." The People of Nazareth Turn against Jesus(Mark 6.1-6; Luke 4.16-30)
13.53: When Jesus had finished telling these stories, he left
13.54: and went to his hometown. He taught in their meeting place, and the people were so amazed that they asked, "Where does he get all this wisdom and the power to work these miracles?
13.55: Isn't he the son of the carpenter? Isn't Mary his mother, and aren't James, Joseph, Simon, and Judas his brothers?
13.56: Don't his sisters still live here in our town? How can he do all this?"
13.57: So the people were very unhappy because of what he was doing. But Jesus said, "Prophets are honored by everyone, except the people of their hometown and their own family."
13.58: And because the people did not have any faith, Jesus did not work many miracles there.

14.1: About this time Herod the ruler heard the news about Jesus
14.2: and told his officials, "This is John the Baptist! He has come back from death, and that's why he has the power to work these miracles."
14.3: Herod had earlier arrested John and had him chained and put in prison. He did this because John had told him, "It isn't right for you to take Herodias, the wife of your brother Philip."
14.5: Herod wanted to kill John. But the people thought John was a prophet, and Herod was afraid of what they might do.
14.6: When Herod's birthday came, the daughter of Herodias danced for the guests. She pleased Herod
14.7: so much that he swore to give her whatever she wanted.
14.8: But the girl's mother told her to say, "Here on a platter I want the head of John the Baptist!"
14.9: The king was sorry for what he had said. But he did not want to break the promise he had made in front of his guests. So he ordered a guard
14.10: to go to the prison and cut off John's head.
14.11: It was taken on a platter to the girl, and she gave it to her mother.
14.12: John's followers took his body and buried it. Then they told Jesus what had happened. Jesus Feeds Five Thousand(Mark 6.30-44; Luke 9.10-17; John 6.1-14)
14.13: After Jesus heard about John, he crossed Lake Galilee to go to some place where he could be alone. But the crowds found out and followed him on foot from the towns.
14.14: When Jesus got out of the boat, he saw the large crowd. He felt sorry for them and healed everyone who was sick.
14.15: That evening the disciples came to Jesus and said, "This place is like a desert, and it is already late. Let the crowds leave, so they can go to the villages and buy some food."
14.16: Jesus replied, "They don't have to leave. Why don't you give them something to eat?"
14.17: But they said, "We have only five small loaves of bread and two fish."
14.18: Jesus asked his disciples to bring the food to him,
14.19: and he told the crowd to sit down on the grass. Jesus took the five loaves and the two fish. He looked up toward heaven and blessed the food. Then he broke the bread and handed it to his disciples, and they gave it to the people.
14.20: After everyone had eaten all they wanted, Jesus' disciples picked up twelve large baskets of leftovers.
14.21: There were about five thousand men who ate, not counting the women and children. Jesus Walks on the Water(Mark 6.45-52; John 6.15-21)
14.22: Right away, Jesus made his disciples get into a boat and start back across the lake. But he stayed until he had sent the crowds away.
14.23: Then he went up on a mountain where he could be alone and pray. Later that evening, he was still there.
14.24: By this time the boat was a long way from the shore. It was going against the wind and was being tossed around by the waves.
14.25: A little while before morning, Jesus came walking on the water toward his disciples.
14.26: When they saw him, they thought he was a ghost. They were terrified and started screaming.
14.27: At once, Jesus said to them, "Don't worry! I am Jesus. Don't be afraid."
14.28: Peter replied, "Lord, if it is really you, tell me to come to you on the water."
14.29: "Come on!" Jesus said. Peter then got out of the boat and started walking on the water toward him.
14.30: But when Peter saw how strong the wind was, he was afraid and started sinking. "Save me, Lord!" he shouted.
14.31: Right away, Jesus reached out his hand. He helped Peter up and said, "You surely don't have much faith. Why do you doubt?"
14.32: When Jesus and Peter got into the boat, the wind died down.
14.33: The men in the boat worshiped Jesus and said, "You really are the Son of God!" Jesus Heals Sick People in Gennesaret(Mark 6.53-56)
14.34: Jesus and his disciples crossed the lake and came to shore near the town of Gennesaret.
14.35: The people found out that he was there, and they sent word to everyone who lived in that part of the country. So they brought all the sick people to Jesus.
14.36: They begged him just to let them touch his clothes, and everyone who did was healed.

15.1: About this time some Pharisees and teachers of the Law of Moses came from Jerusalem. They asked Jesus,
15.2: "Why don't your disciples obey what our ancestors taught us to do? They don't even wash their hands before they eat."
15.3: Jesus answered: Why do you disobey God and follow your own teaching?
15.4: Didn't God command you to respect your father and mother? Didn't he tell you to put to death all who curse their parents?
15.5: But you let people get by without helping their parents when they should. You let them say that what they have has been offered to God.
15.6: Is this any way to show respect to your parents? You ignore God's commands in order to follow your own teaching.
15.7: And you are nothing but show-offs! Isaiah the prophet was right when he wrote that God had said,
15.8: "All of you praise me with your words, but you never really think about me.
15.9: It is useless for you to worship me, when you teach rules made up by humans." What Really Makes People Unclean(Mark 7.14-23)
15.10: Jesus called the crowd together and said, "Pay attention and try to understand what I mean.
15.11: The food that you put into your mouth doesn't make you unclean and unfit to worship God. The bad words that come out of your mouth are what make you unclean."
15.12: Then his disciples came over to him and asked, "Do you know that you insulted the Pharisees by what you said?"
15.13: Jesus answered, "Every plant that my Father in heaven did not plant will be pulled up by the roots.
15.14: Stay away from those Pharisees! They are like blind people leading other blind people, and all of them will fall into a ditch."
15.15: Peter replied, "What did you mean when you talked about the things that make people unclean?"
15.16: Jesus then said: Don't any of you know what I am talking about by now?
15.17: Don't you know that the food you put into your mouth goes into your stomach and then out of your body?
15.18: But the words that come out of your mouth come from your heart. And they are what make you unfit to worship God.
15.19: Out of your heart come evil thoughts, murder, unfaithfulness in marriage, vulgar deeds, stealing, telling lies, and insulting others.
15.20: These are what make you unclean. Eating without washing your hands will not make you unfit to worship God. A Woman's Faith(Mark 7.24-30)
15.21: Jesus left and went to the territory near the cities of Tyre and Sidon.
15.22: Suddenly a Canaanite woman from there came out shouting, "Lord and Son of David, have pity on me! My daughter is full of demons."
15.23: Jesus did not say a word. But the woman kept following along and shouting, so his disciples came up and asked him to send her away.
15.24: Jesus said, "I was sent only to the people of Israel! They are like a flock of lost sheep."
15.25: The woman came closer. Then she knelt down and begged, "Please help me, Lord!"
15.26: Jesus replied, "It isn't right to take food away from children and feed it to dogs."
15.27: "Lord, that's true," the woman said, "but even dogs get the crumbs that fall from their owner's table."
15.28: Jesus answered, "Dear woman, you really do have a lot of faith, and you will be given what you want." At that moment her daughter was healed. Jesus Heals Many People
15.29: From there, Jesus went along Lake Galilee. Then he climbed a hill and sat down.
15.30: Large crowds came and brought many people who were crippled or blind or lame or unable to talk. They placed them, and many others, in front of Jesus, and he healed them all.
15.31: Everyone was amazed at what they saw and heard. People who had never spoken could now speak. The lame were healed, the crippled could walk, and the blind were able to see. Everyone was praising the God of Israel. Jesus Feeds Four Thousand(Mark 8.1-10)
15.32: Jesus called his disciples together and told them, "I feel sorry for these people. They have been with me for three days, and they don't have anything to eat. I don't want to send them away hungry. They might faint on their way home."
15.33: His disciples said, "This place is like a desert. Where can we find enough food to feed such a crowd?"
15.34: Jesus asked them how much food they had. They replied, "Seven small loaves of bread and a few little fish."
15.35: After Jesus had told the people to sit down,
15.36: he took the seven loaves of bread and the fish and gave thanks. He then broke them and handed them to his disciples, who passed them around to the crowds.
15.37: Everyone ate all they wanted, and the leftovers filled seven large baskets.
15.38: There were four thousand men who ate, not counting the women and children.
15.39: After Jesus had sent the crowds away, he got into a boat and sailed across the lake. He came to shore near the town of Magadan.

16.1: The Pharisees and Sadducees came to Jesus and tried to test him by asking for a sign from heaven.
16.2: He told them: If the sky is red in the evening, you say the weather will be good.
16.3: But if the sky is red and gloomy in the morning, you say it is going to rain. You can tell what the weather will be like by looking at the sky. But you don't understand what is happening now.
16.4: You want a sign because you are evil and won't believe! But the only sign you will be given is what happened to Jonah. Then Jesus left. The Yeast of the Pharisees and Sadducees(Mark 8.14-21)
16.5: The disciples had forgotten to bring any bread when they crossed the lake.
16.6: Jesus then warned them, "Watch out! Guard against the yeast of the Pharisees and Sadducees."
16.7: The disciples talked this over and said to each other, "He must be saying this because we didn't bring along any bread."
16.8: Jesus knew what they were thinking and said: You surely don't have much faith! Why are you talking about not having any bread?
16.9: Don't you understand? Have you forgotten about the five thousand people and all those baskets of leftovers from just five loaves of bread?
16.10: And what about the four thousand people and all those baskets of leftovers from only seven loaves of bread?
16.11: Don't you know by now that I am not talking to you about bread? Watch out for the yeast of the Pharisees and Sadducees!
16.12: Finally, the disciples understood that Jesus wasn't talking about the yeast used to make bread, but about the teaching of the Pharisees and Sadducees. Who Is Jesus?(Mark 8.27-30; Luke 9.18-21)
16.13: When Jesus and his disciples were near the town of Caesarea Philippi, he asked them, "What do people say about the Son of Man?"
16.14: The disciples answered, "Some people say you are John the Baptist or maybe Elijah or Jeremiah or some other prophet."
16.15: Then Jesus asked them, "But who do you say I am?"
16.16: Simon Peter spoke up, "You are the Messiah, the Son of the living God."
16.17: Jesus told him: Simon, son of Jonah, you are blessed! You didn't discover this on your own. It was shown to you by my Father in heaven.
16.18: So I will call you Peter, which means "a rock." On this rock I will build my church, and death itself will not have any power over it.
16.19: I will give you the keys to the kingdom of heaven, and God in heaven will allow whatever you allow on earth. But he will not allow anything that you don't allow.
16.20: Jesus told his disciples not to tell anyone that he was the Messiah. Jesus Speaks about His Suffering and Death(Mark 8.31--9.1; Luke 9.22-27)
16.21: From then on, Jesus began telling his disciples what would happen to him. He said, "I must go to Jerusalem. There the nation's leaders, the chief priests, and the teachers of the Law of Moses will make me suffer terribly. I will be killed, but three days later I will rise to life."
16.22: Peter took Jesus aside and told him to stop talking like that. He said, "God would never let this happen to you, Lord!"
16.23: Jesus turned to Peter and said, "Satan, get away from me! You're in my way because you think like everyone else and not like God."
16.24: Then Jesus said to his disciples: If any of you want to be my followers, you must forget about yourself. You must take up your cross and follow me.
16.25: If you want to save your life, you will destroy it. But if you give up your life for me, you will find it.
16.26: What will you gain, if you own the whole world but destroy yourself? What would you give to get back your soul?
16.27: The Son of Man will soon come in the glory of his Father and with his angels to reward all people for what they have done.
16.28: I promise you that some of those standing here will not die before they see the Son of Man coming with his kingdom.

17.1: Six days later Jesus took Peter and the brothers James and John with him. They went up on a very high mountain where they could be alone.
17.2: There in front of the disciples, Jesus was completely changed. His face was shining like the sun, and his clothes became white as light.
17.3: All at once Moses and Elijah were there talking with Jesus.
17.4: So Peter said to him, "Lord, it is good for us to be here! Let us make three shelters, one for you, one for Moses, and one for Elijah."
17.5: While Peter was still speaking, the shadow of a bright cloud passed over them. From the cloud a voice said, "This is my own dear Son, and I am pleased with him. Listen to what he says!"
17.6: When the disciples heard the voice, they were so afraid that they fell flat on the ground.
17.7: But Jesus came over and touched them. He said, "Get up and don't be afraid!"
17.8: When they opened their eyes, they saw only Jesus.
17.9: On their way down from the mountain, Jesus warned his disciples not to tell anyone what they had seen until after the Son of Man had been raised from death.
17.10: The disciples asked Jesus, "Don't the teachers of the Law of Moses say that Elijah must come before the Messiah does?"
17.11: Jesus told them, "Elijah certainly will come and get everything ready.
17.12: In fact, he has already come. But the people did not recognize him and treated him just as they wanted to. They will soon make the Son of Man suffer in the same way."
17.13: Then the disciples understood that Jesus was talking to them about John the Baptist. Jesus Heals a Boy(Mark 9.14-29; Luke 9.37-43a)
17.14: Jesus and his disciples returned to the crowd. A man knelt in front of him
17.15: and said, "Lord, have pity on my son! He has a bad case of epilepsy and often falls into a fire or into water.
17.16: I brought him to your disciples, but none of them could heal him."
17.17: Jesus said, "You people are too stubborn to have any faith! How much longer must I be with you? Why do I have to put up with you? Bring the boy here."
17.18: Then Jesus spoke sternly to the demon. It went out of the boy, and right then he was healed.
17.19: Later the disciples went to Jesus in private and asked him, "Why couldn't we force out the demon?"
17.20: Jesus replied: It is because you don't have enough faith! But I can promise you this. If you had faith no larger than a mustard seed, you could tell this mountain to move from here to there. And it would. Everything would be possible for you. Jesus Again Speaks about His Death(Mark 9.30-32; Luke 9.43b-45)
17.22: While Jesus and his disciples were going from place to place in Galilee, he told them, "The Son of Man will be handed over to people
17.23: who will kill him. But three days later he will rise to life." All of this made the disciples very sad. Paying the Temple Tax
17.24: When Jesus and the others arrived in Capernaum, the collectors for the temple tax came to Peter and asked, "Does your teacher pay the temple tax?"
17.25: "Yes, he does," Peter answered. After they had returned home, Jesus went up to Peter and asked him, "Simon, what do you think? Do the kings of this earth collect taxes and fees from their own people or from foreigners?"
17.26: Peter answered, "From foreigners." Jesus replied, "Then their own people don't have to pay.
17.27: But we don't want to cause trouble. So go cast a line into the lake and pull out the first fish you hook. Open its mouth, and you will find a coin. Use it to pay your taxes and mine."

18.1: About this time the disciples came to Jesus and asked him who would be the greatest in the kingdom of heaven.
18.2: Jesus called a child over and had the child stand near him.
18.3: Then he said: I promise you this. If you don't change and become like a child, you will never get into the kingdom of heaven.
18.4: But if you are as humble as this child, you are the greatest in the kingdom of heaven.
18.5: And when you welcome one of these children because of me, you welcome me. Temptations To Sin(Mark 9.42-48; Luke 17.1,2)
18.6: It will be terrible for people who cause even one of my little followers to sin. Those people would be better off thrown into the deepest part of the ocean with a heavy stone tied around their necks!
18.7: The world is in for trouble because of the way it causes people to sin. There will always be something to cause people to sin, but anyone who does this will be in for trouble.
18.8: If your hand or foot causes you to sin, chop it off and throw it away! You would be better off to go into life crippled or lame than to have two hands or two feet and be thrown into the fire that never goes out.
18.9: If your eye causes you to sin, poke it out and get rid of it. You would be better off to go into life with only one eye than to have two eyes and be thrown into the fires of hell. The Lost Sheep(Luke 15.3-7)
18.10: Don't be cruel to any of these little ones! I promise you that their angels are always with my Father in heaven.
18.12: Let me ask you this. What would you do if you had a hundred sheep and one of them wandered off? Wouldn't you leave the ninety-nine on the hillside and go look for the one that had wandered away?
18.13: I am sure that finding it would make you happier than having the ninety-nine that never wandered off.
18.14: That's how it is with your Father in heaven. He doesn't want any of these little ones to be lost. When Someone Sins(Luke 17.3)
18.15: If one of my followers sins against you, go and point out what was wrong. But do it in private, just between the two of you. If that person listens, you have won back a follower.
18.16: But if that one refuses to listen, take along one or two others. The Scriptures teach that every complaint must be proven true by two or more witnesses.
18.17: If the follower refuses to listen to them, report the matter to the church. Anyone who refuses to listen to the church must be treated like an unbeliever or a tax collector. Allowing and Not Allowing
18.18: I promise you that God in heaven will allow whatever you allow on earth, but he will not allow anything you don't allow.
18.19: I promise that when any two of you on earth agree about something you are praying for, my Father in heaven will do it for you.
18.20: Whenever two or three of you come together in my name, I am there with you. An Official Who Refused To Forgive
18.21: Peter came up to the Lord and asked, "How many times should I forgive someone who does something wrong to me? Is seven times enough?"
18.22: Jesus answered: Not just seven times, but seventy-seven times!
18.23: This story will show you what the kingdom of heaven is like: One day a king decided to call in his officials and ask them to give an account of what they owed him.
18.24: As he was doing this, one official was brought in who owed him fifty million silver coins.
18.25: But he didn't have any money to pay what he owed. The king ordered him to be sold, along with his wife and children and all he owned, in order to pay the debt.
18.26: The official got down on his knees and began begging, "Have pity on me, and I will pay you every cent I owe!"
18.27: The king felt sorry for him and let him go free. He even told the official that he did not have to pay back the money.
18.28: As the official was leaving, he happened to meet another official, who owed him a hundred silver coins. So he grabbed the man by the throat. He started choking him and said, "Pay me what you owe!"
18.29: The man got down on his knees and began begging, "Have pity on me, and I will pay you back."
18.30: But the first official refused to have pity. Instead, he went and had the other official put in jail until he could pay what he owed.
18.31: When some other officials found out what had happened, they felt sorry for the man who had been put in jail. Then they told the king what had happened.
18.32: The king called the first official back in and said, "You're an evil man! When you begged for mercy, I said you did not have to pay back a cent.
18.33: Don't you think you should show pity to someone else, as I did to you?"
18.34: The king was so angry that he ordered the official to be tortured until he could pay back everything he owed.
18.35: That is how my Father in heaven will treat you, if you don't forgive each of my followers with all your heart.

19.1: When Jesus finished teaching, he left Galilee and went to the part of Judea that is east of the Jordan River.
19.2: Large crowds followed him, and he healed their sick people.
19.3: Some Pharisees wanted to test Jesus. They came up to him and asked, "Is it right for a man to divorce his wife for just any reason?"
19.4: Jesus answered, "Don't you know that in the beginning the Creator made a man and a woman?
19.5: That's why a man leaves his father and mother and gets married. He becomes like one person with his wife.
19.6: Then they are no longer two people, but one. And no one should separate a couple that God has joined together."
19.7: The Pharisees asked Jesus, "Why did Moses say that a man could write out divorce papers and send his wife away?"
19.8: Jesus replied, "You are so heartless! That's why Moses allowed you to divorce your wife. But from the beginning God did not intend it to be that way.
19.9: I say that if your wife has not committed some terrible sexual sin, you must not divorce her to marry someone else. If you do, you are unfaithful."
19.10: The disciples said, "If that's how it is between a man and a woman, it's better not to get married."
19.11: Jesus told them, "Only those people who have been given the gift of staying single can accept this teaching.
19.12: Some people are unable to marry because of birth defects or because of what someone has done to their bodies. Others stay single for the sake of the kingdom of heaven. Anyone who can accept this teaching should do so." Jesus Blesses Little Children(Mark 10.13-16; Luke 18.15-17)
19.13: Some people brought their children to Jesus, so that he could place his hands on them and pray for them. His disciples told the people to stop bothering him.
19.14: But Jesus said, "Let the children come to me, and don't try to stop them! People who are like these children belong to God's kingdom."
19.15: After Jesus had placed his hands on the children, he left. A Rich Young Man(Mark 10.17-31; Luke 18.18-30)
19.16: A man came to Jesus and asked, "Teacher, what good thing must I do to have eternal life?"
19.17: Jesus said to him, "Why do you ask me about what is good? Only God is good. If you want to have eternal life, you must obey his commandments."
19.18: "Which ones?" the man asked. Jesus answered, "Do not murder. Be faithful in marriage. Do not steal. Do not tell lies about others.
19.19: Respect your father and mother. And love others as much as you love yourself."
19.20: The young man said, "I have obeyed all of these. What else must I do?"
19.21: Jesus replied, "If you want to be perfect, go sell everything you own! Give the money to the poor, and you will have riches in heaven. Then come and be my follower."
19.22: When the young man heard this, he was sad, because he was very rich.
19.23: Jesus said to his disciples, "It's terribly hard for rich people to get into the kingdom of heaven!
19.24: In fact, it's easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle than for a rich person to get into God's kingdom."
19.25: When the disciples heard this, they were greatly surprised and asked, "How can anyone ever be saved?"
19.26: Jesus looked straight at them and said, "There are some things that people cannot do, but God can do anything."
19.27: Peter replied, "Remember, we have left everything to be your followers! What will we get?"
19.28: Jesus answered: Yes, all of you have become my followers. And so in the future world, when the Son of Man sits on his glorious throne, I promise that you will sit on twelve thrones to judge the twelve tribes of Israel.
19.29: All who have given up home or brothers and sisters or father and mother or children or land for me will be given a hundred times as much. They will also have eternal life.
19.30: But many who are now first will be last, and many who are last will be first.

20.1: As Jesus was telling what the kingdom of heaven would be like, he said: Early one morning a man went out to hire some workers for his vineyard.
20.2: After he had agreed to pay them the usual amount for a day's work, he sent them off to his vineyard.
20.3: About nine that morning, the man saw some other people standing in the market with nothing to do.
20.4: He said he would pay them what was fair, if they would work in his vineyard.
20.5: So they went. At noon and again about three in the afternoon he returned to the market. And each time he made the same agreement with others who were loafing around with nothing to do.
20.6: Finally, about five in the afternoon the man went back and found some others standing there. He asked them, "Why have you been standing here all day long doing nothing?"
20.7: "Because no one has hired us," they answered. Then he told them to go work in his vineyard.
20.8: That evening the owner of the vineyard told the man in charge of the workers to call them in and give them their money. He also told the man to begin with the ones who were hired last.
20.9: When the workers arrived, the ones who had been hired at five in the afternoon were given a full day's pay.
20.10: The workers who had been hired first thought they would be given more than the others. But when they were given the same,
20.11: they began complaining to the owner of the vineyard.
20.12: They said, "The ones who were hired last worked for only one hour. But you paid them the same that you did us. And we worked in the hot sun all day long!"
20.13: The owner answered one of them, "Friend, I didn't cheat you. I paid you exactly what we agreed on.
20.14: Take your money now and go! What business is it of yours if I want to pay them the same that I paid you?
20.15: Don't I have the right to do what I want with my own money? Why should you be jealous, if I want to be generous?"
20.16: Jesus then said, "So it is. Everyone who is now first will be last, and everyone who is last will be first." Jesus Again Tells about His Death(Mark 10.32-34; Luke 18.31-34)
20.17: As Jesus was on his way to Jerusalem, he took his twelve disciples aside and told them in private:
20.18: We are now on our way to Jerusalem, where the Son of Man will be handed over to the chief priests and the teachers of the Law of Moses. They will sentence him to death,
20.19: and then they will hand him over to foreigners who will make fun of him. They will beat him and nail him to a cross. But on the third day he will rise from death. A Mother's Request(Mark 10.35-45)
20.20: The mother of James and John came to Jesus with her two sons. She knelt down and started begging him to do something for her.
20.21: Jesus asked her what she wanted, and she said, "When you come into your kingdom, please let one of my sons sit at your right side and the other at your left."
20.22: Jesus answered, "Not one of you knows what you are asking. Are you able to drink from the cup that I must soon drink from?" James and John said, "Yes, we are!"
20.23: Jesus replied, "You certainly will drink from my cup! But it isn't for me to say who will sit at my right side and at my left. That is for my Father to say."
20.24: When the ten other disciples heard this, they were angry with the two brothers.
20.25: But Jesus called the disciples together and said: You know that foreign rulers like to order their people around. And their great leaders have full power over everyone they rule.
20.26: But don't act like them. If you want to be great, you must be the servant of all the others.
20.27: And if you want to be first, you must be the slave of the rest.
20.28: The Son of Man did not come to be a slave master, but a slave who will give his life to rescue many people. Jesus Heals Two Blind Men(Mark 10.46-52; Luke 18.35-43)
20.29: Jesus was followed by a large crowd as he and his disciples were leaving Jericho.
20.30: Two blind men were sitting beside the road. And when they heard that Jesus was coming their way, they shouted, "Lord and Son of David, have pity on us!"
20.31: The crowd told them to be quiet, but they shouted even louder, "Lord and Son of David, have pity on us!"
20.32: When Jesus heard them, he stopped and asked, "What do you want me to do for you?"
20.33: They answered, "Lord, we want to see!"
20.34: Jesus felt sorry for them and touched their eyes. Right away they could see, and they became his followers.

21.1: When Jesus and his disciples came near Jerusalem, he went to Bethphage on the Mount of Olives and sent two of them on ahead.
21.2: He told them, "Go into the next village, where you will at once find a donkey and her colt. Untie the two donkeys and bring them to me.
21.3: If anyone asks why you are doing that, just say, 'The Lord needs them.' Right away he will let you have the donkeys."
21.4: So God's promise came true, just as the prophet had said,
21.5: "Announce to the people of Jerusalem: 'Your king is coming to you! He is humble and rides on a donkey. He comes on the colt of a donkey.'"
21.6: The disciples left and did what Jesus had told them to do.
21.7: They brought the donkey and its colt and laid some clothes on their backs. Then Jesus got on.
21.8: Many people spread clothes in the road, while others put down branches which they had cut from trees.
21.9: Some people walked ahead of Jesus and others followed behind. They were all shouting, "Hooray for the Son of David! God bless the one who comes in the name of the Lord. Hooray for God in heaven above!"
21.10: When Jesus came to Jerusalem, everyone in the city was excited and asked, "Who can this be?"
21.11: The crowd answered, "This is Jesus, the prophet from Nazareth in Galilee." Jesus in the Temple(Mark 11.15-19; Luke 19.45-48; John 2.13-22)
21.12: Jesus went into the temple and chased out everyone who was selling or buying. He turned over the tables of the moneychangers and the benches of the ones who were selling doves.
21.13: He told them, "The Scriptures say, 'My house should be called a place of worship.' But you have turned it into a place where robbers hide."
21.14: Blind and lame people came to Jesus in the temple, and he healed them.
21.15: But the chief priests and the teachers of the Law of Moses were angry when they saw his miracles and heard the children shouting praises to the Son of David.
21.16: The men said to Jesus, "Don't you hear what those children are saying?" "Yes, I do!" Jesus answered. "Don't you know that the Scriptures say, 'Children and infants will sing praises'?"
21.17: Then Jesus left the city and went out to the village of Bethany, where he spent the night. Jesus Puts a Curse on a Fig Tree(Mark 11.12-14,20-24)
21.18: When Jesus got up the next morning, he was hungry. He started out for the city,
21.19: and along the way he saw a fig tree. But when he came to it, he found only leaves and no figs. So he told the tree, "You will never again grow any fruit!" Right then the fig tree dried up.
21.20: The disciples were shocked when they saw how quickly the tree had dried up.
21.21: But Jesus said to them, "If you have faith and don't doubt, I promise that you can do what I did to this tree. And you will be able to do even more. You can tell this mountain to get up and jump into the sea, and it will.
21.22: If you have faith when you pray, you will be given whatever you ask for." A Question about Jesus' Authority(Mark 11.27-33; Luke 20.1-8)
21.23: Jesus had gone into the temple and was teaching when the chief priests and the leaders of the people came up to him. They asked, "What right do you have to do these things? Who gave you this authority?"
21.24: Jesus answered, "I have just one question to ask you. If you answer it, I will tell you where I got the right to do these things.
21.25: Who gave John the right to baptize? Was it God in heaven or merely some human being?" They thought it over and said to each other, "We can't say that God gave John this right. Jesus will ask us why we didn't believe John.
21.26: On the other hand, these people think that John was a prophet, and we are afraid of what they might do to us. That's why we can't say that it was merely some human who gave John the right to baptize."
21.27: So they told Jesus, "We don't know." Jesus said, "Then I won't tell you who gave me the right to do what I do." A Story about Two Sons
21.28: Jesus said: I will tell you a story about a man who had two sons. Then you can tell me what you think. The father went to the older son and said, "Go work in the vineyard today!"
21.29: His son told him that he would not do it, but later he changed his mind and went.
21.30: The man then told his younger son to go work in the vineyard. The boy said he would, but he didn't go.
21.31: Which one of the sons obeyed his father? "The older one," the chief priests and leaders answered. Then Jesus told them: You can be sure that tax collectors and prostitutes will get into the kingdom of God before you ever will!
21.32: When John the Baptist showed you how to do right, you would not believe him. But these evil people did believe. And even when you saw what they did, you still would not change your minds and believe. Renters of a Vineyard(Mark 12.1-12; Luke 20.9-19)
21.33: Jesus told the chief priests and leaders to listen to this story: A land owner once planted a vineyard. He built a wall around it and dug a pit to crush the grapes in. He also built a lookout tower. Then he rented out his vineyard and left the country.
21.34: When it was harvest time, the owner sent some servants to get his share of the grapes.
21.35: But the renters grabbed those servants. They beat up one, killed one, and stoned one of them to death.
21.36: He then sent more servants than he did the first time. But the renters treated them in the same way.
21.37: Finally, the owner sent his own son to the renters, because he thought they would respect him.
21.38: But when they saw the man's son, they said, "Someday he will own the vineyard. Let's kill him! Then we can have it all for ourselves."
21.39: So they grabbed him, threw him out of the vineyard, and killed him.
21.40: Jesus asked, "When the owner of that vineyard comes, what do you suppose he will do to those renters?"
21.41: The chief priests and leaders answered, "He will kill them in some horrible way. Then he will rent out his vineyard to people who will give him his share of grapes at harvest time."
21.42: Jesus replied, "You surely know that the Scriptures say, 'The stone that the builders tossed aside is now the most important stone of all. This is something the Lord has done, and it is amazing to us.'
21.43: I tell you that God's kingdom will be taken from you and given to people who will do what he demands.
21.44: Anyone who stumbles over this stone will be crushed, and anyone it falls on will be smashed to pieces."
21.45: When the chief priests and the Pharisees heard these stories, they knew that Jesus was talking about them.
21.46: So they looked for a way to arrest Jesus. But they were afraid to, because the people thought he was a prophet.

22.1: Once again Jesus used stories to teach the people:
22.2: The kingdom of heaven is like what happened when a king gave a wedding banquet for his son.
22.3: The king sent some servants to tell the invited guests to come to the banquet, but the guests refused.
22.4: He sent other servants to say to the guests, "The banquet is ready! My cattle and prize calves have all been prepared. Everything is ready. Come to the banquet!"
22.5: But the guests did not pay any attention. Some of them left for their farms, and some went to their places of business.
22.6: Others grabbed the servants, then beat them up and killed them.
22.7: This made the king so furious that he sent an army to kill those murderers and burn down their city.
22.8: Then he said to the servants, "It is time for the wedding banquet, and the invited guests don't deserve to come.
22.9: Go out to the street corners and tell everyone you meet to come to the banquet."
22.10: They went out on the streets and brought in everyone they could find, good and bad alike. And the banquet room was filled with guests.
22.11: When the king went in to meet the guests, he found that one of them wasn't wearing the right kind of clothes for the wedding.
22.12: The king asked, "Friend, why didn't you wear proper clothes for the wedding?" But the guest had no excuse.
22.13: So the king gave orders for that person to be tied hand and foot and to be thrown outside into the dark. That's where people will cry and grit their teeth in pain.
22.14: Many are invited, but only a few are chosen. Paying Taxes(Mark 12.13-17; Luke 20.20-26)
22.15: The Pharisees got together and planned how they could trick Jesus into saying something wrong.
22.16: They sent some of their followers and some of Herod's followers to say to him, "Teacher, we know that you are honest. You teach the truth about what God wants people to do. And you treat everyone with the same respect, no matter who they are.
22.17: Tell us what you think! Should we pay taxes to the Emperor or not?"
22.18: Jesus knew their evil thoughts and said, "Why are you trying to test me? You show-offs!
22.19: Let me see one of the coins used for paying taxes." They brought him a silver coin,
22.20: and he asked, "Whose picture and name are on it?"
22.21: "The Emperor's," they answered. Then Jesus told them, "Give the Emperor what belongs to him and give God what belongs to God."
22.22: His answer surprised them so much that they walked away. Life in the Future World(Mark 12.18-27; Luke 20.27-40)
22.23: The Sadducees did not believe that people would rise to life after death. So that same day some of the Sadducees came to Jesus and said:
22.24: Teacher, Moses wrote that if a married man dies and has no children, his brother should marry the widow. Their first son would then be thought of as the son of the dead brother.
22.25: Once there were seven brothers who lived here. The first one married, but died without having any children. So his wife was left to his brother.
22.26: The same thing happened to the second and third brothers and finally to all seven of them.
22.28: When God raises people from death, whose wife will this woman be? She had been married to all seven brothers.
22.29: Jesus answered: You are completely wrong! You don't know what the Scriptures teach. And you don't know anything about the power of God.
22.30: When God raises people to life, they won't marry. They will be like the angels in heaven.
22.31: And as for people being raised to life, God was speaking to you when he said,
22.32: "I am the God worshiped by Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob." He isn't the God of the dead, but of the living.
22.33: The crowds were surprised to hear what Jesus was teaching. The Most Important Commandment(Mark 12.28-34; Luke 10.25-28)
22.34: After Jesus had made the Sadducees look foolish, the Pharisees heard about it and got together.
22.35: One of them was an expert in the Jewish Law. So he tried to test Jesus by asking,
22.36: "Teacher, what is the most important commandment in the Law?"
22.37: Jesus answered: Love the Lord your God with all your heart, soul, and mind.
22.38: This is the first and most important commandment.
22.39: The second most important commandment is like this one. And it is, "Love others as much as you love yourself."
22.40: All the Law of Moses and the Books of the Prophets are based on these two commandments. About David's Son(Mark 12.35-37; Luke 20.41-44)
22.41: While the Pharisees were still there, Jesus asked them,
22.42: "What do you think about the Messiah? Whose family will he come from?" They answered, "He will be a son of King David."
22.43: Jesus replied, "How then could the Spirit lead David to call the Messiah his Lord? David said,
22.44: 'The Lord said to my Lord: Sit at my right side until I make your enemies into a footstool for you.'
22.45: If David called the Messiah his Lord, how can the Messiah be a son of King David?"
22.46: No one was able to give Jesus an answer, and from that day on, no one dared ask him any more questions.

23.1: Jesus said to the crowds and to his disciples:
23.2: The Pharisees and the teachers of the Law are experts in the Law of Moses.
23.3: So obey everything they teach you, but don't do as they do. After all, they say one thing and do something else.
23.4: They pile heavy burdens on people's shoulders and won't lift a finger to help.
23.5: Everything they do is just to show off in front of others. They even make a big show of wearing Scripture verses on their foreheads and arms, and they wear big tassels for everyone to see.
23.6: They love the best seats at banquets and the front seats in the meeting places.
23.7: And when they are in the market, they like to have people greet them as their teachers.
23.8: But none of you should be called a teacher. You have only one teacher, and all of you are like brothers and sisters.
23.9: Don't call anyone on earth your father. All of you have the same Father in heaven.
23.10: None of you should be called the leader. The Messiah is your only leader.
23.11: Whoever is the greatest should be the servant of the others.
23.12: If you put yourself above others, you will be put down. But if you humble yourself, you will be honored.
23.13: You Pharisees and teachers of the Law of Moses are in for trouble! You're nothing but show-offs. You lock people out of the kingdom of heaven. You won't go in yourselves, and you keep others from going in.
23.15: You Pharisees and teachers of the Law of Moses are in for trouble! You're nothing but show-offs. You travel over land and sea to win one follower. And when you have done so, you make that person twice as fit for hell as you are.
23.16: You are in for trouble! You are supposed to lead others, but you are blind. You teach that it doesn't matter if a person swears by the temple. But you say that it does matter if someone swears by the gold in the temple.
23.17: You blind fools! Which is greater, the gold or the temple that makes the gold sacred?
23.18: You also teach that it doesn't matter if a person swears by the altar. But you say that it does matter if someone swears by the gift on the altar.
23.19: Are you blind? Which is more important, the gift or the altar that makes the gift sacred?
23.20: Anyone who swears by the altar also swears by everything on it.
23.21: And anyone who swears by the temple also swears by God, who lives there.
23.22: To swear by heaven is the same as swearing by God's throne and by the one who sits on that throne.
23.23: You Pharisees and teachers are show-offs, and you're in for trouble! You give God a tenth of the spices from your garden, such as mint, dill, and cumin. Yet you neglect the more important matters of the Law, such as justice, mercy, and faithfulness. These are the important things you should have done, though you should not have left the others undone either.
23.24: You blind leaders! You strain out a small fly but swallow a camel.
23.25: You Pharisees and teachers are show-offs, and you're in for trouble! You wash the outside of your cups and dishes, while inside there is nothing but greed and selfishness.
23.26: You blind Pharisee! First clean the inside of a cup, and then the outside will also be clean.
23.27: You Pharisees and teachers are in for trouble! You're nothing but show-offs. You're like tombs that have been whitewashed. On the outside they are beautiful, but inside they are full of bones and filth.
23.28: That's what you are like. Outside you look good, but inside you are evil and only pretend to be good.
23.29: You Pharisees and teachers are nothing but show-offs, and you're in for trouble! You build monuments for the prophets and decorate the tombs of good people.
23.30: And you claim that you would not have taken part with your ancestors in killing the prophets.
23.31: But you prove that you really are the relatives of the ones who killed the prophets.
23.32: So keep on doing everything they did.
23.33: You are nothing but snakes and the children of snakes! How can you escape going to hell?
23.34: I will send prophets and wise people and experts in the Law of Moses to you. But you will kill them or nail them to a cross or beat them in your meeting places or chase them from town to town.
23.35: That's why you will be held guilty for the murder of every good person, beginning with the good man Abel. This also includes Barachiah's son Zechariah, the man you murdered between the temple and the altar.
23.36: I can promise that you people living today will be punished for all these things! Jesus Loves Jerusalem(Luke 13.34,35)
23.37: Jerusalem, Jerusalem! Your people have killed the prophets and have stoned the messengers who were sent to you. I have often wanted to gather your people, as a hen gathers her chicks under her wings. But you wouldn't let me.
23.38: And now your temple will be deserted.
23.39: You won't see me again until you say, "Blessed is the one who comes in the name of the Lord."

24.1: After Jesus left the temple, his disciples came over and said, "Look at all these buildings!"
24.2: Jesus replied, "Do you see these buildings? They will certainly be torn down! Not one stone will be left in place." Warning about Trouble(Mark 13.3-13; Luke 21.7-19)
24.3: Later, as Jesus was sitting on the Mount of Olives, his disciples came to him in private and asked, "When will this happen? What will be the sign of your coming and of the end of the world?"
24.4: Jesus answered: Don't let anyone fool you.
24.5: Many will come and claim to be me. They will say that they are the Messiah, and they will fool many people.
24.6: You will soon hear about wars and threats of wars, but don't be afraid. These things will have to happen first, but that isn't the end.
24.7: Nations and kingdoms will go to war against each other. People will starve to death, and in some places there will be earthquakes.
24.8: But this is just the beginning of troubles.
24.9: You will be arrested, punished, and even killed. Because of me, you will be hated by people of all nations.
24.10: Many will give up and will betray and hate each other.
24.11: Many false prophets will come and fool a lot of people.
24.12: Evil will spread and cause many people to stop loving others.
24.13: But if you keep on being faithful right to the end, you will be saved.
24.14: When the good news about the kingdom has been preached all over the world and told to all nations, the end will come. The Horrible Thing(Mark 13.14-23; Luke 21.20-24)
24.15: Someday you will see that "Horrible Thing" in the holy place, just as the prophet Daniel said. Everyone who reads this must try to understand!
24.16: If you are living in Judea at that time, run to the mountains.
24.17: If you are on the roof of your house, don't go inside to get anything.
24.18: If you are out in the field, don't go back for your coat.
24.19: It will be a terrible time for women who are expecting babies or nursing young children.
24.20: And pray that you won't have to escape in winter or on a Sabbath.
24.21: This will be the worst time of suffering since the beginning of the world, and nothing this terrible will ever happen again.
24.22: If God doesn't make the time shorter, no one will be left alive. But because of God's chosen ones, he will make the time shorter.
24.23: Someone may say, "Here is the Messiah!" or "There he is!" But don't believe it.
24.24: False messiahs and false prophets will come and work great miracles and signs. They will even try to fool God's chosen ones.
24.25: But I have warned you ahead of time.
24.26: If you are told that the Messiah is out in the desert, don't go there! And if you are told that he is in some secret place, don't believe it!
24.27: The coming of the Son of Man will be like lightning that can be seen from east to west.
24.28: Where there is a corpse, there will always be buzzards. When the Son of Man Appears(Mark 13.24-27; Luke 21.25-28)
24.29: Right after those days of suffering, "The sun will become dark, and the moon will no longer shine. The stars will fall, and the powers in the sky will be shaken."
24.30: Then a sign will appear in the sky. And there will be the Son of Man. All nations on earth will weep when they see the Son of Man coming on the clouds of heaven with power and great glory.
24.31: At the sound of a loud trumpet, he will send his angels to bring his chosen ones together from all over the earth. A Lesson from a Fig Tree(Mark 13.28-31; Luke 21.29-33)
24.32: Learn a lesson from a fig tree. When its branches sprout and start putting out leaves, you know that summer is near.
24.33: So when you see all these things happening, you will know that the time has almost come.
24.34: I can promise you that some of the people of this generation will still be alive when all this happens.
24.35: The sky and the earth won't last forever, but my words will. No One Knows the Day or Time(Mark 13.32-37; Luke 17.26-30,34-36)
24.36: No one knows the day or hour. The angels in heaven don't know, and the Son himself doesn't know. Only the Father knows.
24.37: When the Son of Man appears, things will be just as they were when Noah lived.
24.38: People were eating, drinking, and getting married right up to the day that the flood came and Noah went into the big boat.
24.39: They didn't know anything was happening until the flood came and swept them all away. That is how it will be when the Son of Man appears.
24.40: Two men will be in the same field, but only one will be taken. The other will be left.
24.41: Two women will be together grinding grain, but only one will be taken. The other will be left.
24.42: So be on your guard! You don't know when your Lord will come.
24.43: Homeowners never know when a thief is coming, and they are always on guard to keep one from breaking in.
24.44: Always be ready! You don't know when the Son of Man will come. Faithful and Unfaithful Servants(Luke 12.35-48)
24.45: Who are faithful and wise servants? Who are the ones the master will put in charge of giving the other servants their food supplies at the proper time?
24.46: Servants are fortunate if their master comes and finds them doing their job.
24.47: You may be sure that a servant who is always faithful will be put in charge of everything the master owns.
24.48: But suppose one of the servants thinks that the master won't return until late.
24.49: Suppose that evil servant starts beating the other servants and eats and drinks with people who are drunk.
24.50: If that happens, the master will surely come on a day and at a time when the servant least expects him.
24.51: That servant will then be punished and thrown out with the ones who only pretended to serve their master. There they will cry and grit their teeth in pain.

25.1: The kingdom of heaven is like what happened one night when ten girls took their oil lamps and went to a wedding to meet the groom.
25.2: Five of the girls were foolish and five were wise.
25.3: The foolish ones took their lamps, but no extra oil.
25.4: The ones who were wise took along extra oil for their lamps.
25.5: The groom was late arriving, and the girls became drowsy and fell asleep.
25.6: Then in the middle of the night someone shouted, "Here's the groom! Come to meet him!"
25.7: When the girls got up and started getting their lamps ready,
25.8: the foolish ones said to the others, "Let us have some of your oil! Our lamps are going out."
25.9: The girls who were wise answered, "There's not enough oil for all of us! Go and buy some for yourselves."
25.10: While the foolish girls were on their way to get some oil, the groom arrived. The girls who were ready went into the wedding, and the doors were closed.
25.11: Later the other girls returned and shouted, "Sir, sir! Open the door for us!"
25.12: But the groom replied, "I don't even know you!"
25.13: So, my disciples, always be ready! You don't know the day or the time when all this will happen. A Story about Three Servants(Luke 19.11-27)
25.14: The kingdom is also like what happened when a man went away and put his three servants in charge of all he owned.
25.15: The man knew what each servant could do. So he handed five thousand coins to the first servant, two thousand to the second, and one thousand to the third. Then he left the country.
25.16: As soon as the man had gone, the servant with the five thousand coins used them to earn five thousand more.
25.17: The servant who had two thousand coins did the same with his money and earned two thousand more.
25.18: But the servant with one thousand coins dug a hole and hid his master's money in the ground.
25.19: Some time later the master of those servants returned. He called them in and asked what they had done with his money.
25.20: The servant who had been given five thousand coins brought them in with the five thousand that he had earned. He said, "Sir, you gave me five thousand coins, and I have earned five thousand more."
25.21: "Wonderful!" his master replied. "You are a good and faithful servant. I left you in charge of only a little, but now I will put you in charge of much more. Come and share in my happiness!"
25.22: Next, the servant who had been given two thousand coins came in and said, "Sir, you gave me two thousand coins, and I have earned two thousand more."
25.23: "Wonderful!" his master replied. "You are a good and faithful servant. I left you in charge of only a little, but now I will put you in charge of much more. Come and share in my happiness!"
25.24: The servant who had been given one thousand coins then came in and said, "Sir, I know that you are hard to get along with. You harvest what you don't plant and gather crops where you haven't scattered seed.
