25.25: I was frightened and went out and hid your money in the ground. Here is every single coin!"
25.26: The master of the servant told him, "You are lazy and good-for-nothing! You know that I harvest what I don't plant and gather crops where I haven't scattered seed.
25.27: You could have at least put my money in the bank, so that I could have earned interest on it."
25.28: Then the master said, "Now your money will be taken away and given to the servant with ten thousand coins!
25.29: Everyone who has something will be given more, and they will have more than enough. But everything will be taken from those who don't have anything.
25.30: You are a worthless servant, and you will be thrown out into the dark where people will cry and grit their teeth in pain." The Final Judgment
25.31: When the Son of Man comes in his glory with all of his angels, he will sit on his royal throne.
25.32: The people of all nations will be brought before him, and he will separate them, as shepherds separate their sheep from their goats.
25.33: He will place the sheep on his right and the goats on his left.
25.34: Then the king will say to those on his right, "My father has blessed you! Come and receive the kingdom that was prepared for you before the world was created.
25.35: When I was hungry, you gave me something to eat, and when I was thirsty, you gave me something to drink. When I was a stranger, you welcomed me,
25.36: and when I was naked, you gave me clothes to wear. When I was sick, you took care of me, and when I was in jail, you visited me."
25.37: Then the ones who pleased the Lord will ask, "When did we give you something to eat or drink?
25.38: When did we welcome you as a stranger or give you clothes to wear
25.39: or visit you while you were sick or in jail?"
25.40: The king will answer, "Whenever you did it for any of my people, no matter how unimportant they seemed, you did it for me."
25.41: Then the king will say to those on his left, "Get away from me! You are under God's curse. Go into the everlasting fire prepared for the devil and his angels!
25.42: I was hungry, but you did not give me anything to eat, and I was thirsty, but you did not give me anything to drink.
25.43: I was a stranger, but you did not welcome me, and I was naked, but you did not give me any clothes to wear. I was sick and in jail, but you did not take care of me."
25.44: Then the people will ask, "Lord, when did we fail to help you when you were hungry or thirsty or a stranger or naked or sick or in jail?"
25.45: The king will say to them, "Whenever you failed to help any of my people, no matter how unimportant they seemed, you failed to do it for me."
25.46: Then Jesus said, "Those people will be punished forever. But the ones who pleased God will have eternal life."

26.1: When Jesus had finished teaching, he told his disciples,
26.2: "You know that two days from now will be Passover. That is when the Son of Man will be handed over to his enemies and nailed to a cross."
26.3: At that time the chief priests and the nation's leaders were meeting at the home of Caiaphas the high priest.
26.4: They planned how they could sneak around and have Jesus arrested and put to death.
26.5: But they said, "We must not do it during Passover, because the people will riot." At Bethany(Mark 14.3-9; John 12.1-8)
26.6: Jesus was in the town of Bethany, eating at the home of Simon, who had leprosy.
26.7: A woman came in with a bottle of expensive perfume and poured it on Jesus' head.
26.8: But when his disciples saw this, they became angry and complained, "Why such a waste?
26.9: We could have sold this perfume for a lot of money and given it to the poor."
26.10: Jesus knew what they were thinking, and he said: Why are you bothering this woman? She has done a beautiful thing for me.
26.11: You will always have the poor with you, but you won't always have me.
26.12: She has poured perfume on my body to prepare it for burial.
26.13: You may be sure that wherever the good news is told all over the world, people will remember what she has done. And they will tell others. Judas and the Chief Priests(Mark 14.10,11; Luke 22.3-6)
26.14: Judas Iscariot was one of the twelve disciples. He went to the chief priests
26.15: and asked, "How much will you give me if I help you arrest Jesus?" They paid Judas thirty silver coins,
26.16: and from then on he started looking for a good chance to betray Jesus. Jesus Eats the Passover Meal with His Disciples(Mark 14.12-21; Luke 22.7-13; John 13.21-30)
26.17: On the first day of the Festival of Thin Bread, Jesus' disciples came to him and asked, "Where do you want us to prepare the Passover meal?"
26.18: Jesus told them to go to a certain man in the city and tell him, "Our teacher says, 'My time has come! I want to eat the Passover meal with my disciples in your home.'"
26.19: They did as Jesus told them and prepared the meal.
26.20: When Jesus was eating with his twelve disciples that evening, he said, "One of you will surely hand me over to my enemies."
26.22: The disciples were very sad, and each one said to Jesus, "Lord, you can't mean me!"
26.23: He answered, "One of you men who has eaten with me from this dish will betray me.
26.24: The Son of Man will die, as the Scriptures say. But it's going to be terrible for the one who betrays me! That man would be better off if he had never been born."
26.25: Judas said, "Teacher, you surely don't mean me!" "That's what you say!" Jesus replied. But later, Judas did betray him. The Lord's Supper(Mark 14.22-26; Luke 22.14-23; 1 Corinthians 11.23-25)
26.26: During the meal Jesus took some bread in his hands. He blessed the bread and broke it. Then he gave it to his disciples and said, "Take this and eat it. This is my body."
26.27: Jesus picked up a cup of wine and gave thanks to God. He then gave it to his disciples and said, "Take this and drink it.
26.28: This is my blood, and with it God makes his agreement with you. It will be poured out, so that many people will have their sins forgiven.
26.29: From now on I am not going to drink any wine, until I drink new wine with you in my Father's kingdom."
26.30: Then they sang a hymn and went out to the Mount of Olives. Peter's Promise(Mark 14.27-31; Luke 22.31-34; John 13.36-38)
26.31: Jesus said to his disciples, "During this very night, all of you will reject me, as the Scriptures say, 'I will strike down the shepherd, and the sheep will be scattered.'
26.32: But after I am raised to life, I will go to Galilee ahead of you."
26.33: Peter spoke up, "Even if all the others reject you, I never will!"
26.34: Jesus replied, "I promise you that before a rooster crows tonight, you will say three times that you don't know me."
26.35: But Peter said, "Even if I have to die with you, I will never say I don't know you." All the others said the same thing. Jesus Prays(Mark 14.32-42; Luke 22.39-46)
26.36: Jesus went with his disciples to a place called Gethsemane. When they got there, he told them, "Sit here while I go over there and pray."
26.37: Jesus took along Peter and the two brothers, James and John. He was very sad and troubled,
26.38: and he said to them, "I am so sad that I feel as if I am dying. Stay here and keep awake with me."
26.39: Jesus walked on a little way. Then he knelt with his face to the ground and prayed, "My Father, if it is possible, don't make me suffer by having me drink from this cup. But do what you want, and not what I want."
26.40: He came back and found his disciples sleeping. So he said to Peter, "Can't any of you stay awake with me for just one hour?
26.41: Stay awake and pray that you won't be tested. You want to do what is right, but you are weak."
26.42: Again Jesus went to pray and said, "My Father, if there is no other way, and I must suffer, I will still do what you want."
26.43: Jesus came back and found them sleeping again. They simply could not keep their eyes open.
26.44: He left them and prayed the same prayer once more.
26.45: Finally, Jesus returned to his disciples and said, "Are you still sleeping and resting? The time has come for the Son of Man to be handed over to sinners.
26.46: Get up! Let's go. The one who will betray me is already here." Jesus Is Arrested(Mark 14.43-50; Luke 22.47-53; John 18.3-12)
26.47: Jesus was still speaking, when Judas the betrayer came up. He was one of the twelve disciples, and a large mob armed with swords and clubs was with him. They had been sent by the chief priests and the nation's leaders.
26.48: Judas had told them ahead of time, "Arrest the man I greet with a kiss."
26.49: Judas walked right up to Jesus and said, "Hello, teacher." Then Judas kissed him.
26.50: Jesus replied, "My friend, why are you here?" The men grabbed Jesus and arrested him.
26.51: One of Jesus' followers pulled out a sword. He struck the servant of the high priest and cut off his ear.
26.52: But Jesus told him, "Put your sword away. Anyone who lives by fighting will die by fighting.
26.53: Don't you know that I could ask my Father, and right away he would send me more than twelve armies of angels?
26.54: But then, how could the words of the Scriptures come true, which say that this must happen?"
26.55: Jesus said to the mob, "Why do you come with swords and clubs to arrest me like a criminal? Day after day I sat and taught in the temple, and you didn't arrest me.
26.56: But all this happened, so that what the prophets wrote would come true." All of Jesus' disciples left him and ran away. Jesus Is Questioned by the Council(Mark 14.53-65; Luke 22.54,55,63-71; John 18.13,14,19-24)
26.57: After Jesus had been arrested, he was led off to the house of Caiaphas the high priest. The nation's leaders and the teachers of the Law of Moses were meeting there.
26.58: But Peter followed along at a distance and came to the courtyard of the high priest's palace. He went in and sat down with the guards to see what was going to happen.
26.59: The chief priests and the whole council wanted to put Jesus to death. So they tried to find some people who would tell lies about him in court.
26.60: But they could not find any, even though many did come and tell lies. At last, two men came forward
26.61: and said, "This man claimed that he would tear down God's temple and build it again in three days."
26.62: The high priest stood up and asked Jesus, "Why don't you say something in your own defense? Don't you hear the charges they are making against you?"
26.63: But Jesus did not answer. So the high priest said, "With the living God looking on, you must tell the truth. Tell us, are you the Messiah, the Son of God?"
26.64: "That is what you say!" Jesus answered. "But I tell all of you, 'Soon you will see the Son of Man sitting at the right side of God All-Powerful and coming on the clouds of heaven.'"
26.65: The high priest then tore his robe and said, "This man claims to be God! We don't need any more witnesses! You have heard what he said.
26.66: What do you think?" They answered, "He is guilty and deserves to die!"
26.67: Then they spit in his face and hit him with their fists. Others slapped him
26.68: and said, "You think you are the Messiah! So tell us who hit you!" Peter Says He Doesn't Know Jesus(Mark 14.66-72; Luke 22.56-62; John 18.15-18,25-27)
26.69: While Peter was sitting out in the courtyard, a servant girl came up to him and said, "You were with Jesus from Galilee."
26.70: But in front of everyone Peter said, "That isn't so! I don't know what you are talking about!"
26.71: When Peter had gone out to the gate, another servant girl saw him and said to some people there, "This man was with Jesus from Nazareth."
26.72: Again Peter denied it, and this time he swore, "I don't even know that man!"
26.73: A little while later some people standing there walked over to Peter and said, "We know that you are one of them. We can tell it because you talk like someone from Galilee."
26.74: Peter began to curse and swear, "I don't know that man!" Right then a rooster crowed,
26.75: and Peter remembered that Jesus had said, "Before a rooster crows, you will say three times that you don't know me." Then Peter went out and cried hard.

27.1: Early the next morning all the chief priests and the nation's leaders met and decided that Jesus should be put to death.
27.2: They tied him up and led him away to Pilate the governor. The Death of Judas(Acts 1.18,19)
27.3: Judas had betrayed Jesus, but when he learned that Jesus had been sentenced to death, he was sorry for what he had done. He returned the thirty silver coins to the chief priests and leaders
27.4: and said, "I have sinned by betraying a man who has never done anything wrong." "So what? That's your problem," they replied.
27.5: Judas threw the money into the temple and then went out and hanged himself.
27.6: The chief priests picked up the money and said, "This money was paid to have a man killed. We can't put it in the temple treasury."
27.7: Then they had a meeting and decided to buy a field that belonged to someone who made clay pots. They wanted to use it as a graveyard for foreigners.
27.8: That's why people still call that place "Field of Blood."
27.9: So the words of the prophet Jeremiah came true, "They took the thirty silver coins, the price of a person among the people of Israel.
27.10: They paid it for a potter's field, as the Lord had commanded me." Pilate Questions Jesus(Mark 15.2-5; Luke 23.3-5; John 18.33-38)
27.11: Jesus was brought before Pilate the governor, who asked him, "Are you the king of the Jews?" "Those are your words!" Jesus answered.
27.12: And when the chief priests and leaders brought their charges against him, he did not say a thing.
27.13: Pilate asked him, "Don't you hear what crimes they say you have done?"
27.14: But Jesus did not say anything, and the governor was greatly amazed. The Death Sentence(Mark 15.6-15; Luke 23.13-26; John 18.39--19.16)
27.15: During Passover the governor always freed a prisoner chosen by the people.
27.16: At that time a well-known terrorist named Jesus Barabbas was in jail.
27.17: So when the crowd came together, Pilate asked them, "Which prisoner do you want me to set free? Do you want Jesus Barabbas or Jesus who is called the Messiah?"
27.18: Pilate knew that the leaders had brought Jesus to him because they were jealous.
27.19: While Pilate was judging the case, his wife sent him a message. It said, "Don't have anything to do with that innocent man. I have had nightmares because of him."
27.20: But the chief priests and the leaders convinced the crowds to ask for Barabbas to be set free and for Jesus to be killed.
27.21: Pilate asked the crowd again, "Which of these two men do you want me to set free?" "Barabbas!" they replied.
27.22: Pilate asked them, "What am I to do with Jesus, who is called the Messiah?" They all yelled, "Nail him to a cross!"
27.23: Pilate answered, "But what crime has he done?" "Nail him to a cross!" they yelled even louder.
27.24: Pilate saw that there was nothing he could do and that the people were starting to riot. So he took some water and washed his hands in front of them and said, "I won't have anything to do with killing this man. You are the ones doing it!"
27.25: Everyone answered, "We and our own families will take the blame for his death!"
27.26: Pilate set Barabbas free. Then he ordered his soldiers to beat Jesus with a whip and nail him to a cross. Soldiers Make Fun of Jesus(Mark 15.16-21; John 19.2,3)
27.27: The governor's soldiers led Jesus into the fortress and brought together the rest of the troops.
27.28: They stripped off Jesus' clothes and put a scarlet robe on him.
27.29: They made a crown out of thorn branches and placed it on his head, and they put a stick in his right hand. The soldiers knelt down and pretended to worship him. They made fun of him and shouted, "Hey, you king of the Jews!"
27.30: Then they spit on him. They took the stick from him and beat him on the head with it. Jesus Is Nailed to a Cross(Mark 15.22-32; Luke 23.27-43; John 19.17-27)
27.31: When the soldiers had finished making fun of Jesus, they took off the robe. They put his own clothes back on him and led him off to be nailed to a cross.
27.32: On the way they met a man from Cyrene named Simon, and they forced him to carry Jesus' cross.
27.33: They came to a place named Golgotha, which means "Place of a Skull."
27.34: There they gave Jesus some wine mixed with a drug to ease the pain. But when Jesus tasted what it was, he refused to drink it.
27.35: The soldiers nailed Jesus to a cross and gambled to see who would get his clothes.
27.36: Then they sat down to guard him.
27.37: Above his head they put a sign that told why he was nailed there. It read, "This is Jesus, the King of the Jews."
27.38: The soldiers also nailed two criminals on crosses, one to the right of Jesus and the other to his left.
27.39: People who passed by said terrible things about Jesus. They shook their heads and
27.40: shouted, "So you're the one who claimed you could tear down the temple and build it again in three days! If you are God's Son, save yourself and come down from the cross!"
27.41: The chief priests, the leaders, and the teachers of the Law of Moses also made fun of Jesus. They said,
27.42: "He saved others, but he can't save himself. If he is the king of Israel, he should come down from the cross! Then we will believe him.
27.43: He trusted God, so let God save him, if he wants to. He even said he was God's Son."
27.44: The two criminals also said cruel things to Jesus. The Death of Jesus(Mark 15.33-41; Luke 23.44-49; John 19.28-30)
27.45: At noon the sky turned dark and stayed that way until three o'clock.
27.46: Then about that time Jesus shouted, "Eli, Eli, lema sabachthani?" which means, "My God, my God, why have you deserted me?"
27.47: Some of the people standing there heard Jesus and said, "He's calling for Elijah."
27.48: One of them at once ran and grabbed a sponge. He soaked it in wine, then put it on a stick and held it up to Jesus.
27.49: Others said, "Wait! Let's see if Elijah will come and save him."
27.50: Once again Jesus shouted, and then he died.
27.51: At once the curtain in the temple was torn in two from top to bottom. The earth shook, and rocks split apart.
27.52: Graves opened, and many of God's people were raised to life.
27.53: Then after Jesus had risen to life, they came out of their graves and went into the holy city, where they were seen by many people.
27.54: The officer and the soldiers guarding Jesus felt the earthquake and saw everything else that happened. They were frightened and said, "This man really was God's Son!"
27.55: Many women had come with Jesus from Galilee to be of help to him, and they were there, looking on at a distance.
27.56: Mary Magdalene, Mary the mother of James and Joseph, and the mother of James and John were some of these women. Jesus Is Buried(Mark 15.42-47; Luke 23.50-56; John 19.38-42)
27.57: That evening a rich disciple named Joseph from the town of Arimathea
27.58: went and asked for Jesus' body. Pilate gave orders for it to be given to Joseph,
27.59: who took the body and wrapped it in a clean linen cloth.
27.60: Then Joseph put the body in his own tomb that had been cut into solid rock and had never been used. He rolled a big stone against the entrance to the tomb and went away.
27.61: All this time Mary Magdalene and the other Mary were sitting across from the tomb.
27.62: On the next day, which was a Sabbath, the chief priests and the Pharisees went together to Pilate.
27.63: They said, "Sir, we remember what that liar said while he was still alive. He claimed that in three days he would come back from death.
27.64: So please order the tomb to be carefully guarded for three days. If you don't, his disciples may come and steal his body. They will tell the people that he has been raised to life, and this last lie will be worse than the first one."
27.65: Pilate said to them, "All right, take some of your soldiers and guard the tomb as well as you know how."
27.66: So they sealed it tight and placed soldiers there to guard it.

28.1: The Sabbath was over, and it was almost daybreak on Sunday when Mary Magdalene and the other Mary went to see the tomb.
28.2: Suddenly a strong earthquake struck, and the Lord's angel came down from heaven. He rolled away the stone and sat on it.
28.3: The angel looked as bright as lightning, and his clothes were white as snow.
28.4: The guards shook from fear and fell down, as though they were dead.
28.5: The angel said to the women, "Don't be afraid! I know you are looking for Jesus, who was nailed to a cross.
28.6: He isn't here! God has raised him to life, just as Jesus said he would. Come, see the place where his body was lying.
28.7: Now hurry! Tell his disciples that he has been raised to life and is on his way to Galilee. Go there, and you will see him. That is what I came to tell you."
28.8: The women were frightened and yet very happy, as they hurried from the tomb and ran to tell his disciples.
28.9: Suddenly Jesus met them and greeted them. They went near him, held on to his feet, and worshiped him.
28.10: Then Jesus said, "Don't be afraid! Tell my followers to go to Galilee. They will see me there." Report of the Guard
28.11: While the women were on their way, some soldiers who had been guarding the tomb went into the city. They told the chief priests everything that had happened.
28.12: So the chief priests met with the leaders and decided to bribe the soldiers with a lot of money.
28.13: They said to the soldiers, "Tell everyone that Jesus' disciples came during the night and stole his body while you were asleep.
28.14: If the governor hears about this, we will talk to him. You won't have anything to worry about."
28.15: The soldiers took the money and did what they were told. The Jewish people still tell each other this story. What Jesus' Followers Must Do(Mark 16.14-18; Luke 24.36-49; John 20.19-23; Acts 1.6-8)
28.16: Jesus' eleven disciples went to a mountain in Galilee, where Jesus had told them to meet him.
28.17: They saw him and worshiped him, but some of them doubted.
28.18: Jesus came to them and said: I have been given all authority in heaven and on earth!
28.19: Go to the people of all nations and make them my disciples. Baptize them in the name of the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit,
28.20: and teach them to do everything I have told you. I will be with you always, even until the end of the world.

1.1: This is the good news about Jesus Christ, the Son of God.
1.2: It began just as God had said in the book written by Isaiah the prophet, "I am sending my messenger to get the way ready for you.
1.3: In the desert someone is shouting, 'Get the road ready for the Lord! Make a straight path for him.'"
1.4: So John the Baptist showed up in the desert and told everyone, "Turn back to God and be baptized! Then your sins will be forgiven."
1.5: From all Judea and Jerusalem crowds of people went to John. They told how sorry they were for their sins, and he baptized them in the Jordan River.
1.6: John wore clothes made of camel's hair. He had a leather strap around his waist and ate grasshoppers and wild honey.
1.7: John also told the people, "Someone more powerful is going to come. And I am not good enough even to stoop down and untie his sandals.
1.8: I baptize you with water, but he will baptize you with the Holy Spirit!" The Baptism of Jesus(Matthew 3.13-17; Luke 3.21,22)
1.9: About that time Jesus came from Nazareth in Galilee, and John baptized him in the Jordan River.
1.10: As soon as Jesus came out of the water, he saw the sky open and the Holy Spirit coming down to him like a dove.
1.11: A voice from heaven said, "You are my own dear Son, and I am pleased with you." Jesus and Satan(Matthew 4.1-11; Luke 4.1-13)
1.12: Right away God's Spirit made Jesus go into the desert.
1.13: He stayed there for forty days while Satan tested him. Jesus was with the wild animals, but angels took care of him. Jesus Begins His Work(Matthew 4.12-17; Luke 4.14,15)
1.14: After John was arrested, Jesus went to Galilee and told the good news that comes from God.
1.15: He said, "The time has come! God's kingdom will soon be here. Turn back to God and believe the good news!" Jesus Chooses Four Fishermen(Matthew 4.18-22; Luke 5.1-11)
1.16: As Jesus was walking along the shore of Lake Galilee, he saw Simon and his brother Andrew. They were fishermen and were casting their nets into the lake.
1.17: Jesus said to them, "Come with me! I will teach you how to bring in people instead of fish."
1.18: Right then the two brothers dropped their nets and went with him.
1.19: Jesus walked on and soon saw James and John, the sons of Zebedee. They were in a boat, mending their nets.
1.20: At once Jesus asked them to come with him. They left their father in the boat with the hired workers and went with him. A Man with an Evil Spirit(Luke 4.31-37)
1.21: Jesus and his disciples went to the town of Capernaum. Then on the next Sabbath he went into the Jewish meeting place and started teaching.
1.22: Everyone was amazed at his teaching. He taught with authority, and not like the teachers of the Law of Moses.
1.23: Suddenly a man with an evil spirit in him entered the meeting place and yelled,
1.24: "Jesus from Nazareth, what do you want with us? Have you come to destroy us? I know who you are! You are God's Holy One."
1.25: Jesus told the evil spirit, "Be quiet and come out of the man!"
1.26: The spirit shook him. Then it gave a loud shout and left.
1.27: Everyone was completely surprised and kept saying to each other, "What is this? It must be some new kind of powerful teaching! Even the evil spirits obey him."
1.28: News about Jesus quickly spread all over Galilee. Jesus Heals Many People(Matthew 8.14-17; Luke 4.38-41)
1.29: As soon as Jesus left the meeting place with James and John, they went home with Simon and Andrew.
1.30: When they got there, Jesus was told that Simon's mother-in-law was sick in bed with fever.
1.31: Jesus went to her. He took hold of her hand and helped her up. The fever left her, and she served them a meal.
1.32: That evening after sunset, all who were sick or had demons in them were brought to Jesus.
1.33: In fact, the whole town gathered around the door of the house.
1.34: Jesus healed all kinds of terrible diseases and forced out a lot of demons. But the demons knew who he was, and he did not let them speak.
1.35: Very early the next morning, Jesus got up and went to a place where he could be alone and pray.
1.36: Simon and the others started looking for him.
1.37: And when they found him, they said, "Everyone is looking for you!"
1.38: Jesus replied, "We must go to the nearby towns, so that I can tell the good news to those people. This is why I have come."
1.39: Then Jesus went to Jewish meeting places everywhere in Galilee, where he preached and forced out demons. Jesus Heals a Man(Matthew 8.1-4; Luke 5.12-16)
1.40: A man with leprosy came to Jesus and knelt down. He begged, "You have the power to make me well, if only you wanted to."
1.41: Jesus felt sorry for the man. So he put his hand on him and said, "I want to! Now you are well."
1.42: At once the man's leprosy disappeared, and he was well.
1.43: After Jesus strictly warned the man, he sent him on his way.
1.44: He said, "Don't tell anyone about this. Just go and show the priest that you are well. Then take a gift to the temple as Moses commanded, and everyone will know that you have been healed."
1.45: The man talked about it so much and told so many people, that Jesus could no longer go openly into a town. He had to stay away from the towns, but people still came to him from everywhere.

2.1: Jesus went back to Capernaum, and a few days later people heard that he was at home.
2.2: Then so many of them came to the house that there wasn't even standing room left in front of the door. Jesus was still teaching
2.3: when four people came up, carrying a crippled man on a mat.
2.4: But because of the crowd, they could not get him to Jesus. So they made a hole in the roof above him and let the man down in front of everyone.
2.5: When Jesus saw how much faith they had, he said to the crippled man, "My friend, your sins are forgiven."
2.6: Some of the teachers of the Law of Moses were sitting there. They started wondering,
2.7: "Why would he say such a thing? He must think he is God! Only God can forgive sins."
2.8: Right away, Jesus knew what they were thinking, and he said, "Why are you thinking such things?
2.9: Is it easier for me to tell this crippled man that his sins are forgiven or to tell him to get up and pick up his mat and go on home?
2.10: I will show you that the Son of Man has the right to forgive sins here on earth." So Jesus said to the man,
2.11: "Get up! Pick up your mat and go on home."
2.12: The man got right up. He picked up his mat and went out while everyone watched in amazement. They praised God and said, "We have never seen anything like this!" Jesus Chooses Levi(Matthew 9.9-13; Luke 5.27-32)
2.13: Once again, Jesus went to the shore of Lake Galilee. A large crowd gathered around him, and he taught them.
2.14: As he walked along, he saw Levi, the son of Alphaeus. Levi was sitting at the place for paying taxes, and Jesus said to him, "Come with me!" So he got up and went with Jesus.
2.15: Later, Jesus and his disciples were having dinner at Levi's house. Many tax collectors and other sinners had become followers of Jesus, and they were also guests at the dinner.
2.16: Some of the teachers of the Law of Moses were Pharisees, and they saw that Jesus was eating with sinners and tax collectors. So they asked his disciples, "Why does he eat with tax collectors and sinners?"
2.17: Jesus heard them and answered, "Healthy people don't need a doctor, but sick people do. I didn't come to invite good people to be my followers. I came to invite sinners." People Ask about Going without Eating(Matthew 9.14-17; Luke 5.33-39)
2.18: The followers of John the Baptist and the Pharisees often went without eating. Some people came and asked Jesus, "Why do the followers of John and those of the Pharisees often go without eating, while your disciples never do?"
2.19: Jesus answered: The friends of a bridegroom don't go without eating while he is still with them.
2.20: But the time will come when he will be taken from them. Then they will go without eating.
2.21: No one patches old clothes by sewing on a piece of new cloth. The new piece would shrink and tear a bigger hole.
2.22: No one pours new wine into old wineskins. The wine would swell and burst the old skins. Then the wine would be lost, and the skins would be ruined. New wine must be put into new wineskins. A Question about the Sabbath(Matthew 12.1-8; Luke 6.1-5)
2.23: One Sabbath Jesus and his disciples were walking through some wheat fields. His disciples were picking grains of wheat as they went along.
2.24: Some Pharisees asked Jesus, "Why are your disciples picking grain on the Sabbath? They are not supposed to do that!"
2.25: Jesus answered, "Haven't you read what David did when he and his followers were hungry and in need?
2.26: It was during the time of Abiathar the high priest. David went into the house of God and ate the sacred loaves of bread that only priests are allowed to eat. He also gave some to his followers."
2.27: Jesus finished by saying, "People were not made for the good of the Sabbath. The Sabbath was made for the good of people.
2.28: So the Son of Man is Lord over the Sabbath."

3.1: The next time that Jesus went into the meeting place, a man with a crippled hand was there.
3.2: The Pharisees wanted to accuse Jesus of doing something wrong, and they kept watching to see if Jesus would heal him on the Sabbath.
3.3: Jesus told the man to stand up where everyone could see him.
3.4: Then he asked, "On the Sabbath should we do good deeds or evil deeds? Should we save someone's life or destroy it?" But no one said a word.
3.5: Jesus was angry as he looked around at the people. Yet he felt sorry for them because they were so stubborn. Then he told the man, "Stretch out your hand." He did, and his bad hand was healed.
3.6: The Pharisees left. And right away they started making plans with Herod's followers to kill Jesus. Large Crowds Come to Jesus
3.7: Jesus led his disciples down to the shore of the lake. Large crowds followed him from Galilee, Judea,
3.8: and Jerusalem. People came from Idumea, as well as other places east of the Jordan River. They also came from the region around the cities of Tyre and Sidon. All of these crowds came because they had heard what Jesus was doing.
3.9: He even had to tell his disciples to get a boat ready to keep him from being crushed by the crowds.
3.10: After Jesus had healed many people, the other sick people begged him to let them touch him.
3.11: And whenever any evil spirits saw Jesus, they would fall to the ground and shout, "You are the Son of God!"
3.12: But Jesus warned the spirits not to tell who he was. Jesus Chooses His Twelve Apostles(Matthew 10.1-4; Luke 6.12-16)
3.13: Jesus decided to ask some of his disciples to go up on a mountain with him, and they went.
3.14: Then he chose twelve of them to be his apostles, so that they could be with him. He also wanted to send them out to preach
3.15: and to force out demons.
3.16: Simon was one of the twelve, and Jesus named him Peter.
3.17: There were also James and John, the two sons of Zebedee. Jesus called them Boanerges, which means "Thunderbolts."
3.18: Andrew, Philip, Bartholomew, Matthew, Thomas, James son of Alphaeus, and Thaddaeus were also apostles. The others were Simon, known as the Eager One,
3.19: and Judas Iscariot, who later betrayed Jesus. Jesus and the Ruler of Demons(Matthew 12.22-32; Luke 11.14-23; 12.10)
3.20: Jesus went back home, and once again such a large crowd gathered that there was no chance even to eat.
3.21: When Jesus' family heard what he was doing, they thought he was crazy and went to get him under control.
3.22: Some teachers of the Law of Moses came from Jerusalem and said, "This man is under the power of Beelzebul, the ruler of demons! He is even forcing out demons with the help of Beelzebul."
3.23: Jesus told the people to gather around him. Then he spoke to them in riddles and said: How can Satan force himself out?
3.24: A nation whose people fight each other won't last very long.
3.25: And a family that fights won't last long either.
3.26: So if Satan fights against himself, that will be the end of him.
3.27: How can anyone break into the house of a strong man and steal his things, unless he first ties up the strong man? Then he can take everything.
3.28: I promise you that any of the sinful things you say or do can be forgiven, no matter how terrible those things are.
3.29: But if you speak against the Holy Spirit, you can never be forgiven. That sin will be held against you forever.
3.30: Jesus said this because the people were saying that he had an evil spirit in him. Jesus' Mother and Brothers(Matthew 12.46-50; Luke 8.19-21)
3.31: Jesus' mother and brothers came and stood outside. Then they sent someone with a message for him to come out to them.
3.32: The crowd that was sitting around Jesus told him, "Your mother and your brothers and sisters are outside and want to see you."
3.33: Jesus asked, "Who is my mother and who are my brothers?"
3.34: Then he looked at the people sitting around him and said, "Here are my mother and my brothers.
3.35: Anyone who obeys God is my brother or sister or mother."

4.1: The next time Jesus taught beside Lake Galilee, a big crowd gathered. It was so large that he had to sit in a boat out on the lake, while the people stood on the shore.
4.2: He used stories to teach them many things, and this is part of what he taught:
4.3: Now listen! A farmer went out to scatter seed in a field.
4.4: While the farmer was scattering the seed, some of it fell along the road and was eaten by birds.
4.5: Other seeds fell on thin, rocky ground and quickly started growing because the soil wasn't very deep.
4.6: But when the sun came up, the plants were scorched and dried up, because they did not have enough roots.
4.7: Some other seeds fell where thornbushes grew up and choked out the plants. So they did not produce any grain.
4.8: But a few seeds did fall on good ground where the plants grew and produced thirty or sixty or even a hundred times as much as was scattered.
4.9: Then Jesus said, "If you have ears, pay attention." Why Jesus Used Stories(Matthew 13.10-17; Luke 8.9,10)
4.10: When Jesus was alone with the twelve apostles and some others, they asked him about these stories.
4.11: He answered: I have explained the secret about God's kingdom to you, but for others I can use only stories.
4.12: The reason is, "These people will look and look, but never see. They will listen and listen, but never understand. If they did, they would turn to God, and he would forgive them." Jesus Explains the Story about the Farmer(Matthew 13.18-23; Luke 8.11-15)
4.13: Jesus told them: If you don't understand this story, you won't understand any others.
4.14: What the farmer is spreading is really the message about the kingdom.
4.15: The seeds that fell along the road are the people who hear the message. But Satan soon comes and snatches it away from them.
4.16: The seeds that fell on rocky ground are the people who gladly hear the message and accept it right away.
4.17: But they don't have any roots, and they don't last very long. As soon as life gets hard or the message gets them in trouble, they give up.
4.18: The seeds that fell among the thornbushes are also people who hear the message.
4.19: But they start worrying about the needs of this life. They are fooled by the desire to get rich and to have all kinds of other things. So the message gets choked out, and they never produce anything.
4.20: The seeds that fell on good ground are the people who hear and welcome the message. They produce thirty or sixty or even a hundred times as much as was planted. Light(Luke 8.16-18)
4.21: Jesus also said: You don't light a lamp and put it under a clay pot or under a bed. Don't you put a lamp on a lampstand?
4.22: There is nothing hidden that will not be made public. There is no secret that will not be well known.
4.23: If you have ears, pay attention!
4.24: Listen carefully to what you hear! The way you treat others will be the way you will be treated--and even worse.
4.25: Everyone who has something will be given more. But people who don't have anything will lose what little they have. Another Story about Seeds
4.26: Again Jesus said: God's kingdom is like what happens when a farmer scatters seed in a field.
4.27: The farmer sleeps at night and is up and around during the day. Yet the seeds keep sprouting and growing, and he doesn't understand how.
4.28: It is the ground that makes the seeds sprout and grow into plants that produce grain.
4.29: Then when harvest season comes and the grain is ripe, the farmer cuts it with a sickle. A Mustard Seed(Matthew 13.31,32; Luke 13.18,19)
4.30: Finally, Jesus said: What is God's kingdom like? What story can I use to explain it?
4.31: It is like what happens when a mustard seed is planted in the ground. It is the smallest seed in all the world.
4.32: But once it is planted, it grows larger than any garden plant. It even puts out branches that are big enough for birds to nest in its shade. The Reason for Teaching with Stories(Matthew 13.34,35)
4.33: Jesus used many other stories when he spoke to the people, and he taught them as much as they could understand.
4.34: He did not tell them anything without using stories. But when he was alone with his disciples, he explained everything to them. A Storm(Matthew 8.23-27; Luke 8.22-25)
4.35: That evening, Jesus said to his disciples, "Let's cross to the east side."
4.36: So they left the crowd, and his disciples started across the lake with him in the boat. Some other boats followed along.
4.37: Suddenly a windstorm struck the lake. Waves started splashing into the boat, and it was about to sink.
4.38: Jesus was in the back of the boat with his head on a pillow, and he was asleep. His disciples woke him and said, "Teacher, don't you care that we're about to drown?"
4.39: Jesus got up and ordered the wind and the waves to be quiet. The wind stopped, and everything was calm.
4.40: Jesus asked his disciples, "Why were you afraid? Don't you have any faith?"
4.41: Now they were more afraid than ever and said to each other, "Who is this? Even the wind and the waves obey him!"

5.1: Jesus and his disciples crossed Lake Galilee and came to shore near the town of Gerasa.
5.2: When he was getting out of the boat, a man with an evil spirit quickly ran to him
5.3: from the graveyard where he had been living. No one was able to tie the man up anymore, not even with a chain.
5.4: He had often been put in chains and leg irons, but he broke the chains and smashed the leg irons. No one could control him.
5.5: Night and day he was in the graveyard or on the hills, yelling and cutting himself with stones.
5.6: When the man saw Jesus in the distance, he ran up to him and knelt down.
5.7: He shouted, "Jesus, Son of God in heaven, what do you want with me? Promise me in God's name that you won't torture me!"
5.8: The man said this because Jesus had already told the evil spirit to come out of him.
5.9: Jesus asked, "What is your name?" The man answered, "My name is Lots, because I have 'lots' of evil spirits."
5.10: He then begged Jesus not to send them away.
5.11: Over on the hillside a large herd of pigs was feeding.
5.12: So the evil spirits begged Jesus, "Send us into those pigs! Let us go into them."
5.13: Jesus let them go, and they went out of the man and into the pigs. The whole herd of about two thousand pigs rushed down the steep bank into the lake and drowned.
5.14: The men taking care of the pigs ran to the town and the farms to spread the news. Then the people came out to see what had happened.
5.15: When they came to Jesus, they saw the man who had once been full of demons. He was sitting there with his clothes on and in his right mind, and they were terrified.
5.16: Everyone who had seen what had happened told about the man and the pigs.
5.17: Then the people started begging Jesus to leave their part of the country.
5.18: When Jesus was getting into the boat, the man begged to go with him.
5.19: But Jesus would not let him. Instead, he said, "Go home to your family and tell them how much the Lord has done for you and how good he has been to you."
5.20: The man went away into the region near the ten cities known as Decapolis and began telling everyone how much Jesus had done for him. Everyone who heard what had happened was amazed. A Dying Girl and a Sick Woman(Matthew 9.18-26; Luke 8.40-56)
5.21: Once again Jesus got into the boat and crossed Lake Galilee. Then as he stood on the shore, a large crowd gathered around him.
5.22: The person in charge of the Jewish meeting place was also there. His name was Jairus, and when he saw Jesus, he went over to him. He knelt at Jesus' feet
5.23: and started begging him for help. He said, "My daughter is about to die! Please come and touch her, so she will get well and live."
5.24: Jesus went with Jairus. Many people followed along and kept crowding around.
5.25: In the crowd was a woman who had been bleeding for twelve years.
5.26: She had gone to many doctors, and they had not done anything except cause her a lot of pain. She had paid them all the money she had. But instead of getting better, she only got worse.
5.27: The woman had heard about Jesus, so she came up behind him in the crowd and barely touched his clothes.
5.28: She had said to herself, "If I can just touch his clothes, I will get well."
5.29: As soon as she touched them, her bleeding stopped, and she knew she was well.
5.30: At that moment Jesus felt power go out from him. He turned to the crowd and asked, "Who touched my clothes?"
5.31: His disciples said to him, "Look at all these people crowding around you! How can you ask who touched you?"
5.32: But Jesus turned to see who had touched him.
5.33: The woman knew what had happened to her. She came shaking with fear and knelt down in front of Jesus. Then she told him the whole story.
5.34: Jesus said to the woman, "You are now well because of your faith. May God give you peace! You are healed, and you will no longer be in pain."
5.35: While Jesus was still speaking, some men came from Jairus' home and said, "Your daughter has died! Why bother the teacher anymore?"
5.36: Jesus heard what they said, and he said to Jairus, "Don't worry. Just have faith!"
5.37: Jesus did not let anyone go with him except Peter and the two brothers, James and John.
5.38: They went home with Jairus and saw the people crying and making a lot of noise.
5.39: Then Jesus went inside and said to them, "Why are you crying and carrying on like this? The child isn't dead. She is just asleep."
5.40: But the people laughed at him. After Jesus had sent them all out of the house, he took the girl's father and mother and his three disciples and went to where she was.
5.41: He took the twelve-year-old girl by the hand and said, "Talitha, koum!" which means, "Little girl, get up!" The girl got right up and started walking around. Everyone was greatly surprised.
5.43: But Jesus ordered them not to tell anyone what had happened. Then he said, "Give her something to eat."

6.1: Jesus left and returned to his hometown with his disciples.
6.2: The next Sabbath he taught in the Jewish meeting place. Many of the people who heard him were amazed and asked, "How can he do all this? Where did he get such wisdom and the power to work these miracles?
6.3: Isn't he the carpenter, the son of Mary? Aren't James, Joseph, Judas, and Simon his brothers? Don't his sisters still live here in our town?" The people were very unhappy because of what he was doing.
6.4: But Jesus said, "Prophets are honored by everyone, except the people of their hometown and their relatives and their own family."
6.5: Jesus could not work any miracles there, except to heal a few sick people by placing his hands on them.
6.6: He was surprised that the people did not have any faith. Jesus taught in all the neighboring villages. Instructions for the Twelve Apostles(Matthew 10.5-15; Luke 9.1-6)
6.7: Then he called together his twelve apostles and sent them out two by two with power over evil spirits.
6.8: He told them, "You may take along a walking stick. But don't carry food or a traveling bag or any money.
6.9: It's all right to wear sandals, but don't take along a change of clothes.
6.10: When you are welcomed into a home, stay there until you leave that town.
6.11: If any place won't welcome you or listen to your message, leave and shake the dust from your feet as a warning to them."
6.12: The apostles left and started telling everyone to turn to God.
6.13: They forced out many demons and healed a lot of sick people by putting olive oil on them. The Death of John the Baptist(Matthew 14.1-12; Luke 9.7-9)
6.14: Jesus became so well-known that Herod the ruler heard about him. Some people thought he was John the Baptist, who had come back to life with the power to work miracles.
6.15: Others thought he was Elijah or some other prophet who had lived long ago.
6.16: But when Herod heard about Jesus, he said, "This must be John! I had his head cut off, and now he has come back to life."
6.17: Herod had earlier married Herodias, the wife of his brother Philip. But John had told him, "It isn't right for you to take your brother's wife!" So, in order to please Herodias, Herod arrested John and put him in prison.
6.19: Herodias had a grudge against John and wanted to kill him. But she could not do it
6.20: because Herod was afraid of John and protected him. He knew that John was a good and holy man. Even though Herod was confused by what John said, he was glad to listen to him. And he often did.
6.21: Finally, Herodias got her chance when Herod gave a great birthday celebration for himself and invited his officials, his army officers, and the leaders of Galilee.
6.22: The daughter of Herodias came in and danced for Herod and his guests. She pleased them so much that Herod said, "Ask for anything, and it's yours!
6.23: I swear that I will give you as much as half of my kingdom, if you want it."
6.24: The girl left and asked her mother, "What do you think I should ask for?" Her mother answered, "The head of John the Baptist!"
6.25: The girl hurried back and told Herod, "Right now on a platter I want the head of John the Baptist!"
6.26: The king was very sorry for what he had said. But he did not want to break the promise he had made in front of his guests.
6.27: At once he ordered a guard to cut off John's head there in prison.
6.28: The guard put the head on a platter and took it to the girl. Then she gave it to her mother.
6.29: When John's followers learned that he had been killed, they took his body and put it in a tomb. Jesus Feeds Five Thousand(Matthew 14.13-21; Luke 9.10-17; John 6.1-14)
6.30: After the apostles returned to Jesus, they told him everything they had done and taught.
6.31: But so many people were coming and going that Jesus and the apostles did not even have a chance to eat. Then Jesus said, "Let's go to a place where we can be alone and get some rest."
6.32: They left in a boat for a place where they could be alone.
6.33: But many people saw them leave and figured out where they were going. So people from every town ran on ahead and got there first.
6.34: When Jesus got out of the boat, he saw the large crowd that was like sheep without a shepherd. He felt sorry for the people and started teaching them many things.
6.35: That evening the disciples came to Jesus and said, "This place is like a desert, and it is already late.
6.36: Let the crowds leave, so they can go to the farms and villages near here and buy something to eat."
6.37: Jesus replied, "You give them something to eat." But they asked him, "Don't you know that it would take almost a year's wages to buy all of these people something to eat?"
6.38: Then Jesus said, "How much bread do you have? Go and see!" They found out and answered, "We have five small loaves of bread and two fish."
6.39: Jesus told his disciples to have the people sit down on the green grass.
6.40: They sat down in groups of a hundred and groups of fifty.
6.41: Jesus took the five loaves and the two fish. He looked up toward heaven and blessed the food. Then he broke the bread and handed it to his disciples to give to the people. He also divided the two fish, so that everyone could have some.
6.42: After everyone had eaten all they wanted,
6.43: Jesus' disciples picked up twelve large baskets of leftover bread and fish.
6.44: There were five thousand men who ate the food. Jesus Walks on the Water(Matthew 14.22-33; John 6.15-21)
6.45: Right away, Jesus made his disciples get into the boat and start back across to Bethsaida. But he stayed until he had sent the crowds away.
6.46: Then he told them good-by and went up on the side of a mountain to pray.
6.47: Later that evening he was still there by himself, and the boat was somewhere in the middle of the lake.
6.48: He could see that the disciples were struggling hard, because they were rowing against the wind. Not long before morning, Jesus came toward them. He was walking on the water and was about to pass the boat.
6.49: When the disciples saw Jesus walking on the water, they thought he was a ghost, and they started screaming.
6.50: All of them saw him and were terrified. But at that same time he said, "Don't worry! I am Jesus. Don't be afraid."
6.51: He then got into the boat with them, and the wind died down. The disciples were completely confused.
6.52: Their minds were closed, and they could not understand the true meaning of the loaves of bread. Jesus Heals Sick People in Gennesaret(Matthew 14.34-36)
6.53: Jesus and his disciples crossed the lake and brought the boat to shore near the town of Gennesaret.
6.54: As soon as they got out of the boat, the people recognized Jesus.
6.55: So they ran all over that part of the country to bring their sick people to him on mats. They brought them each time they heard where he was.
6.56: In every village or farm or marketplace where Jesus went, the people brought their sick to him. They begged him to let them just touch his clothes, and everyone who did was healed.

7.1: Some Pharisees and several teachers of the Law of Moses from Jerusalem came and gathered around Jesus.
7.2: They noticed that some of his disciples ate without first washing their hands.
7.3: The Pharisees and many other Jewish people obey the teachings of their ancestors. They always wash their hands in the proper way before eating.
7.4: None of them will eat anything they buy in the market until it is washed. They also follow a lot of other teachings, such as washing cups, pitchers, and bowls.
7.5: The Pharisees and teachers asked Jesus, "Why don't your disciples obey what our ancestors taught us to do? Why do they eat without washing their hands?"
7.6: Jesus replied: You are nothing but show-offs! The prophet Isaiah was right when he wrote that God had said, "All of you praise me with your words, but you never really think about me.
7.7: It is useless for you to worship me, when you teach rules made up by humans."
7.8: You disobey God's commands in order to obey what humans have taught.
7.9: You are good at rejecting God's commands so that you can follow your own teachings!
7.10: Didn't Moses command you to respect your father and mother? Didn't he tell you to put to death all who curse their parents?
7.11: But you let people get by without helping their parents when they should. You let them say that what they own has been offered to God.
7.12: You won't let those people help their parents.
7.13: And you ignore God's commands in order to follow your own teaching. You do a lot of other things that are just as bad. What Really Makes People Unclean(Matthew 15.10-20)
7.14: Jesus called the crowd together again and said, "Pay attention and try to understand what I mean.
7.15: The food that you put into your mouth doesn't make you unclean and unfit to worship God. The bad words that come out of your mouth are what make you unclean."
7.17: After Jesus and his disciples had left the crowd and had gone into the house, they asked him what these sayings meant.
7.18: He answered, "Don't you know what I am talking about by now? You surely know that the food you put into your mouth cannot make you unclean.
7.19: It doesn't go into your heart, but into your stomach, and then out of your body." By saying this, Jesus meant that all foods were fit to eat.
7.20: Then Jesus said: What comes from your heart is what makes you unclean.
7.21: Out of your heart come evil thoughts, vulgar deeds, stealing, murder,
7.22: unfaithfulness in marriage, greed, meanness, deceit, indecency, envy, insults, pride, and foolishness.
7.23: All of these come from your heart, and they are what make you unfit to worship God. A Woman's Faith(Matthew 15.21-28)
7.24: Jesus left and went to the region near the city of Tyre, where he stayed in someone's home. He did not want people to know he was there, but they found out anyway.
7.25: A woman whose daughter had an evil spirit in her heard where Jesus was. And right away she came and knelt down at his feet.
7.26: The woman was Greek and had been born in the part of Syria known as Phoenicia. She begged Jesus to force the demon out of her daughter.
7.27: But Jesus said, "The children must first be fed! It isn't right to take away their food and feed it to dogs."
7.28: The woman replied, "Lord, even dogs eat the crumbs that children drop from the table."
7.29: Jesus answered, "That's true! You may go now. The demon has left your daughter."
7.30: When the woman got back home, she found her child lying on the bed. The demon had gone. Jesus Heals a Man Who Was Deaf and Could Hardly Talk
7.31: Jesus left the region around Tyre and went by way of Sidon toward Lake Galilee. He went through the land near the ten cities known as Decapolis.
7.32: Some people brought to him a man who was deaf and could hardly talk. They begged Jesus just to touch him.
7.33: After Jesus had taken him aside from the crowd, he stuck his fingers in the man's ears. Then he spit and put it on the man's tongue.
7.34: Jesus looked up toward heaven, and with a groan he said, "Effatha!" which means "Open up!"
7.35: At once the man could hear, and he had no more trouble talking clearly.
7.36: Jesus told the people not to say anything about what he had done. But the more he told them, the more they talked about it.
7.37: They were completely amazed and said, "Everything he does is good! He even heals people who cannot hear or talk."

8.1: One day another large crowd gathered around Jesus. They had not brought along anything to eat. So Jesus called his disciples together and said,
8.2: "I feel sorry for these people. They have been with me for three days, and they don't have anything to eat.
8.3: Some of them live a long way from here. If I send them away hungry, they might faint on their way home."
8.4: The disciples said, "This place is like a desert. Where can we find enough food to feed such a crowd?"
8.5: Jesus asked them how much food they had. They replied, "Seven small loaves of bread."
8.6: After Jesus told the crowd to sit down, he took the seven loaves and blessed them. He then broke the loaves and handed them to his disciples, who passed them out to the crowd.
8.7: They also had a few little fish, and after Jesus had blessed these, he told the disciples to pass them around.
8.8: The crowd of about four thousand people ate all they wanted, and the leftovers filled seven large baskets. As soon as Jesus had sent the people away,
8.10: he got into the boat with the disciples and crossed to the territory near Dalmanutha. A Sign from Heaven(Matthew 16.1-4)
8.11: The Pharisees came out and started an argument with Jesus. They wanted to test him by asking for a sign from heaven.
8.12: Jesus groaned and said, "Why are you always looking for a sign? I can promise you that you will not be given one!"
8.13: Then he left them. He again got into a boat and crossed over to the other side of the lake. The Yeast of the Pharisees and of Herod(Matthew 16.5-12)
8.14: The disciples had forgotten to bring any bread, and they had only one loaf with them in the boat.
8.15: Jesus warned them, "Watch out! Guard against the yeast of the Pharisees and of Herod."
8.16: The disciples talked this over and said to each other, "He must be saying this because we don't have any bread."
8.17: Jesus knew what they were thinking and asked, "Why are you talking about not having any bread? Don't you understand? Are your minds still closed?
8.18: Are your eyes blind and your ears deaf? Don't you remember
8.19: how many baskets of leftovers you picked up when I fed those five thousand people with only five small loaves of bread?" "Yes," the disciples answered. "There were twelve baskets."
8.20: Jesus then asked, "And how many baskets of leftovers did you pick up when I broke seven small loaves of bread for those four thousand people?" "Seven," they answered.
8.21: "Don't you know what I am talking about by now?" Jesus asked. Jesus Heals a Blind Man at Bethsaida
8.22: As Jesus and his disciples were going into Bethsaida, some people brought a blind man to him and begged him to touch the man.
8.23: Jesus took him by the hand and led him out of the village, where he spit into the man's eyes. He placed his hands on the blind man and asked him if he could see anything.
8.24: The man looked up and said, "I see people, but they look like trees walking around."
8.25: Once again Jesus placed his hands on the man's eyes, and this time the man stared. His eyes were healed, and he saw everything clearly.
8.26: Jesus said to him, "You may return home now, but don't go into the village." Who Is Jesus?(Matthew 16.13-20; Luke 9.18-21)
8.27: Jesus and his disciples went to the villages near the town of Caesarea Philippi. As they were walking along, he asked them, "What do people say about me?"
8.28: The disciples answered, "Some say you are John the Baptist or maybe Elijah. Others say you are one of the prophets."
8.29: Then Jesus asked them, "But who do you say I am?" "You are the Messiah!" Peter replied.
8.30: Jesus warned the disciples not to tell anyone about him. Jesus Speaks about His Suffering and Death(Matthew 16.21-28; Luke 9.22-27)
8.31: Jesus began telling his disciples what would happen to him. He said, "The nation's leaders, the chief priests, and the teachers of the Law of Moses will make the Son of Man suffer terribly. He will be rejected and killed, but three days later he will rise to life."
8.32: Then Jesus explained clearly what he meant. Peter took Jesus aside and told him to stop talking like that.
8.33: But when Jesus turned and saw the disciples, he corrected Peter. He said to him, "Satan, get away from me! You are thinking like everyone else and not like God."
8.34: Jesus then told the crowd and the disciples to come closer, and he said: If any of you want to be my followers, you must forget about yourself. You must take up your cross and follow me.
8.35: If you want to save your life, you will destroy it. But if you give up your life for me and for the good news, you will save it.
8.36: What will you gain, if you own the whole world but destroy yourself?
8.37: What could you give to get back your soul?
8.38: Don't be ashamed of me and my message among these unfaithful and sinful people! If you are, the Son of Man will be ashamed of you when he comes in the glory of his Father with the holy angels.

9.1: I can assure you that some of the people standing here will not die before they see God's kingdom come with power. The True Glory of Jesus(Matthew 17.1-13; Luke 9.28-36)
9.2: Six days later Jesus took Peter, James, and John with him. They went up on a high mountain, where they could be alone. There in front of the disciples, Jesus was completely changed.
9.3: And his clothes became much whiter than any bleach on earth could make them.
9.4: Then Moses and Elijah were there talking with Jesus.
9.5: Peter said to Jesus, "Teacher, it is good for us to be here! Let us make three shelters, one for you, one for Moses, and one for Elijah."
9.6: But Peter and the others were terribly frightened, and he did not know what he was talking about.
9.7: The shadow of a cloud passed over and covered them. From the cloud a voice said, "This is my Son, and I love him. Listen to what he says!"
9.8: At once the disciples looked around, but they saw only Jesus.
9.9: As Jesus and his disciples were coming down the mountain, he told them not to say a word about what they had seen, until the Son of Man had been raised from death.
9.10: So they kept it to themselves. But they wondered what he meant by the words "raised from death."
9.11: The disciples asked Jesus, "Don't the teachers of the Law of Moses say that Elijah must come before the Messiah does?"
9.12: Jesus answered: Elijah certainly will come to get everything ready. But don't the Scriptures also say that the Son of Man must suffer terribly and be rejected?
9.13: I can assure you that Elijah has already come. And people treated him just as they wanted to, as the Scriptures say they would. Jesus Heals a Boy(Matthew 17.14-20; Luke 9.37-43a)
9.14: When Jesus and his three disciples came back down, they saw a large crowd around the other disciples. The teachers of the Law of Moses were arguing with them.
9.15: The crowd was really surprised to see Jesus, and everyone hurried over to greet him.
9.16: Jesus asked, "What are you arguing about?"
9.17: Someone from the crowd answered, "Teacher, I brought my son to you. A demon keeps him from talking.
9.18: Whenever the demon attacks my son, it throws him to the ground and makes him foam at the mouth and grit his teeth in pain. Then he becomes stiff. I asked your disciples to force out the demon, but they couldn't do it."
9.19: Jesus said, "You people don't have any faith! How much longer must I be with you? Why do I have to put up with you? Bring the boy to me."
9.20: They brought the boy, and as soon as the demon saw Jesus, it made the boy shake all over. He fell down and began rolling on the ground and foaming at the mouth.
9.21: Jesus asked the boy's father, "How long has he been like this?" The man answered, "Ever since he was a child.
9.22: The demon has often tried to kill him by throwing him into a fire or into water. Please have pity and help us if you can!"
9.23: Jesus replied, "Why do you say 'if you can'? Anything is possible for someone who has faith!"
9.24: Right away the boy's father shouted, "I do have faith! Please help me to have even more."
9.25: When Jesus saw that a crowd was gathering fast, he spoke sternly to the evil spirit that had kept the boy from speaking or hearing. He said, "I order you to come out of the boy! Don't ever bother him again."
9.26: The spirit screamed and made the boy shake all over. Then it went out of him. The boy looked dead, and almost everyone said he was.
9.27: But Jesus took hold of his hand and helped him stand up.
9.28: After Jesus and the disciples had gone back home and were alone, they asked him, "Why couldn't we force out that demon?"
9.29: Jesus answered, "Only prayer can force out that kind of demon." Jesus Again Speaks about His Death(Matthew 17.22,23; Luke 9.43b-45)
9.30: Jesus left with his disciples and started through Galilee. He did not want anyone to know about it,
9.31: because he was teaching the disciples that the Son of Man would be handed over to people who would kill him. But three days later he would rise to life.
9.32: The disciples did not understand what Jesus meant, and they were afraid to ask. Who Is the Greatest?(Matthew 18.1-5; Luke 9.46-48)
9.33: Jesus and his disciples went to his home in Capernaum. After they were inside the house, Jesus asked them, "What were you arguing about along the way?"
9.34: They had been arguing about which one of them was the greatest, and so they did not answer.
9.35: After Jesus sat down and told the twelve disciples to gather around him, he said, "If you want the place of honor, you must become a slave and serve others!"
9.36: Then Jesus had a child stand near him. He put his arm around the child and said,
9.37: "When you welcome even a child because of me, you welcome me. And when you welcome me, you welcome the one who sent me." For or against Jesus(Luke 9.49,50)
9.38: John said, "Teacher, we saw a man using your name to force demons out of people. But he wasn't one of us, and we told him to stop."
9.39: Jesus said to his disciples: Don't stop him! No one who works miracles in my name will soon turn and say something bad about me.
9.40: Anyone who isn't against us is for us.
9.41: And anyone who gives you a cup of water in my name, just because you belong to me, will surely be rewarded. Temptations To Sin(Matthew 18.6-9; Luke 17.1,2)
9.42: It will be terrible for people who cause even one of my little followers to sin. Those people would be better off thrown into the ocean with a heavy stone tied around their necks.
9.43: So if your hand causes you to sin, cut it off! You would be better off to go into life crippled than to have two hands and be thrown into the fires of hell that never go out.
9.45: If your foot causes you to sin, chop it off. You would be better off to go into life lame than to have two feet and be thrown into hell.
9.47: If your eye causes you to sin, get rid of it. You would be better off to go into God's kingdom with only one eye than to have two eyes and be thrown into hell.
9.48: The worms there never die, and the fire never stops burning.
9.49: Everyone must be salted with fire.
9.50: Salt is good. But if it no longer tastes like salt, how can it be made salty again? Have salt among you and live at peace with each other.

10.1: After Jesus left, he went to Judea and then on to the other side of the Jordan River. Once again large crowds came to him, and as usual, he taught them.
10.2: Some Pharisees wanted to test Jesus. So they came up to him and asked if it was right for a man to divorce his wife.
10.3: Jesus asked them, "What does the Law of Moses say about that?"
10.4: They answered, "Moses allows a man to write out divorce papers and send his wife away."
10.5: Jesus replied, "Moses gave you this law because you are so heartless.
10.6: But in the beginning God made a man and a woman.
10.7: That's why a man leaves his father and mother and gets married.
10.8: He becomes like one person with his wife. Then they are no longer two people, but one.
10.9: And no one should separate a couple that God has joined together."
10.10: When Jesus and his disciples were back in the house, they asked him about what he had said.
10.11: He told them, "A man who divorces his wife and marries someone else is unfaithful to his wife.
10.12: A woman who divorces her husband and marries again is also unfaithful." Jesus Blesses Little Children(Matthew 19.13-15; Luke 18.15-17)
10.13: Some people brought their children to Jesus so that he could bless them by placing his hands on them. But his disciples told the people to stop bothering him.
10.14: When Jesus saw this, he became angry and said, "Let the children come to me! Don't try to stop them. People who are like these little children belong to the kingdom of God.
10.15: I promise you that you cannot get into God's kingdom, unless you accept it the way a child does."
10.16: Then Jesus took the children in his arms and blessed them by placing his hands on them. A Rich Man(Matthew 19.16-30; Luke 18.18-30)
10.17: As Jesus was walking down a road, a man ran up to him. He knelt down, and asked, "Good teacher, what can I do to have eternal life?"
10.18: Jesus replied, "Why do you call me good? Only God is good.
10.19: You know the commandments. 'Do not murder. Be faithful in marriage. Do not steal. Do not tell lies about others. Do not cheat. Respect your father and mother.'"
10.20: The man answered, "Teacher, I have obeyed all these commandments since I was a young man."
10.21: Jesus looked closely at the man. He liked him and said, "There's one thing you still need to do. Go sell everything you own. Give the money to the poor, and you will have riches in heaven. Then come with me."
10.22: When the man heard Jesus say this, he went away gloomy and sad because he was very rich.
10.23: Jesus looked around and said to his disciples, "It's hard for rich people to get into God's kingdom!"
10.24: The disciples were shocked to hear this. So Jesus told them again, "It's terribly hard to get into God's kingdom!
10.25: In fact, it's easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle than for a rich person to get into God's kingdom."
10.26: Jesus' disciples were even more amazed. They asked each other, "How can anyone ever be saved?"
10.27: Jesus looked at them and said, "There are some things that people cannot do, but God can do anything."
10.28: Peter replied, "Remember, we left everything to be your followers!"
10.29: Jesus told him: You can be sure that anyone who gives up home or brothers or sisters or mother or father or children or land for me and for the good news
10.30: will be rewarded. In this world they will be given a hundred times as many houses and brothers and sisters and mothers and children and pieces of land, though they will also be mistreated. And in the world to come, they will have eternal life.
10.31: But many who are now first will be last, and many who are now last will be first. Jesus Again Tells about His Death(Matthew 20.17-19; Luke 18.31-34)
10.32: The disciples were confused as Jesus led them toward Jerusalem, and his other followers were afraid. Once again, Jesus took the twelve disciples aside and told them what was going to happen to him. He said:
10.33: We are now on our way to Jerusalem where the Son of Man will be handed over to the chief priests and the teachers of the Law of Moses. They will sentence him to death and hand him over to foreigners,
10.34: who will make fun of him and spit on him. They will beat him and kill him. But three days later he will rise to life. The Request of James and John(Matthew 20.20-28)
10.35: James and John, the sons of Zebedee, came up to Jesus and asked, "Teacher, will you do us a favor?"
10.36: Jesus asked them what they wanted,
10.37: and they answered, "When you come into your glory, please let one of us sit at your right side and the other at your left."
10.38: Jesus told them, "You don't really know what you're asking! Are you able to drink from the cup that I must soon drink from or be baptized as I must be baptized?"
10.39: "Yes, we are!" James and John answered. Then Jesus replied, "You certainly will drink from the cup from which I must drink. And you will be baptized just as I must!
10.40: But it isn't for me to say who will sit at my right side and at my left. That is for God to decide."
10.41: When the ten other disciples heard this, they were angry with James and John.
10.42: But Jesus called the disciples together and said: You know that those foreigners who call themselves kings like to order their people around. And their great leaders have full power over the people they rule.
10.43: But don't act like them. If you want to be great, you must be the servant of all the others.
10.44: And if you want to be first, you must be everyone's slave.
10.45: The Son of Man did not come to be a slave master, but a slave who will give his life to rescue many people. Jesus Heals Blind Bartimaeus(Matthew 20.29-34; Luke 18.35-43)
10.46: Jesus and his disciples went to Jericho. And as they were leaving, they were followed by a large crowd. A blind beggar by the name of Bartimaeus son of Timaeus was sitting beside the road.
10.47: When he heard that it was Jesus from Nazareth, he shouted, "Jesus, Son of David, have pity on me!"
10.48: Many people told the man to stop, but he shouted even louder, "Son of David, have pity on me!"
10.49: Jesus stopped and said, "Call him over!" They called out to the blind man and said, "Don't be afraid! Come on! He is calling for you."
10.50: The man threw off his coat as he jumped up and ran to Jesus.
10.51: Jesus asked, "What do you want me to do for you?" The blind man answered, "Master, I want to see!"
10.52: Jesus told him, "You may go. Your eyes are healed because of your faith." Right away the man could see, and he went down the road with Jesus.

11.1: Jesus and his disciples reached Bethphage and Bethany near the Mount of Olives. When they were getting close to Jerusalem, Jesus sent two of them on ahead.
11.2: He told them, "Go into the next village. As soon as you enter it, you will find a young donkey that has never been ridden. Untie the donkey and bring it here.
11.3: If anyone asks why you are doing that, say, 'The Lord needs it and will soon bring it back.'"
11.4: The disciples left and found the donkey tied near a door that faced the street. While they were untying it,
11.5: some of the people standing there asked, "Why are you untying the donkey?"
11.6: They told them what Jesus had said, and the people let them take it.
11.7: The disciples led the donkey to Jesus. They put some of their clothes on its back, and Jesus got on.
11.8: Many people spread clothes on the road, while others went to cut branches from the fields.
11.9: In front of Jesus and behind him, people went along shouting, "Hooray! God bless the one who comes in the name of the Lord!
11.10: God bless the coming kingdom of our ancestor David. Hooray for God in heaven above!"
11.11: After Jesus had gone to Jerusalem, he went into the temple and looked around at everything. But since it was already late in the day, he went back to Bethany with the twelve disciples. Jesus Puts a Curse on a Fig Tree(Matthew 21.18,19)
11.12: When Jesus and his disciples left Bethany the next morning, he was hungry.
11.13: From a distance Jesus saw a fig tree covered with leaves, and he went to see if there were any figs on the tree. But there were not any, because it wasn't the season for figs.
11.14: So Jesus said to the tree, "Never again will anyone eat fruit from this tree!" The disciples heard him say this. Jesus in the Temple(Matthew 21.12-17; Luke 19.45-48; John 2.13-22)
11.15: After Jesus and his disciples reached Jerusalem, he went into the temple and began chasing out everyone who was selling and buying. He turned over the tables of the moneychangers and the benches of those who were selling doves.
11.16: Jesus would not let anyone carry things through the temple.
11.17: Then he taught the people and said, "The Scriptures say, 'My house should be called a place of worship for all nations.' But you have made it a place where robbers hide!"
11.18: The chief priests and the teachers of the Law of Moses heard what Jesus said, and they started looking for a way to kill him. They were afraid of him, because the crowds were completely amazed at his teaching.
11.19: That evening, Jesus and the disciples went outside the city. A Lesson from the Fig Tree(Matthew 21.20-22)
11.20: As the disciples walked past the fig tree the next morning, they noticed that it was completely dried up, roots and all.
11.21: Peter remembered what Jesus had said to the tree. Then Peter said, "Teacher, look! The tree you put a curse on has dried up."
11.22: Jesus told his disciples: Have faith in God!
11.23: If you have faith in God and don't doubt, you can tell this mountain to get up and jump into the sea, and it will.
11.24: Everything you ask for in prayer will be yours, if you only have faith.
11.25: Whenever you stand up to pray, you must forgive what others have done to you. Then your Father in heaven will forgive your sins. A Question about Jesus' Authority(Matthew 21.23-27; Luke 20.1-8)
11.27: Jesus and his disciples returned to Jerusalem. And as he was walking through the temple, the chief priests, the nation's leaders, and the teachers of the Law of Moses came over to him.
11.28: They asked, "What right do you have to do these things? Who gave you this authority?"
11.29: Jesus answered, "I have just one question to ask you. If you answer it, I will tell you where I got the right to do these things.
11.30: Who gave John the right to baptize? Was it God in heaven or merely some human being?"
11.31: They thought it over and said to each other, "We can't say that God gave John this right. Jesus will ask us why we didn't believe John.
11.32: On the other hand, these people think that John was a prophet. So we can't say that it was merely some human who gave John the right to baptize." They were afraid of the crowd
11.33: and told Jesus, "We don't know." Jesus replied, "Then I won't tell you who gave me the right to do what I do."

12.1: Jesus then told them this story: A farmer once planted a vineyard. He built a wall around it and dug a pit to crush the grapes in. He also built a lookout tower. Then he rented out his vineyard and left the country.
12.2: When it was harvest time, he sent a servant to get his share of the grapes.
12.3: The renters grabbed the servant. They beat him up and sent him away without a thing.
12.4: The owner sent another servant, but the renters beat him on the head and insulted him terribly.
12.5: Then the man sent another servant, and they killed him. He kept sending servant after servant. They beat some of them and killed others.
12.6: The owner had a son he loved very much. Finally, he sent his son to the renters because he thought they would respect him.
12.7: But they said to themselves, "Someday he will own this vineyard. Let's kill him! That way we can have it all for ourselves."
