12.8: So they grabbed the owner's son and killed him. Then they threw his body out of the vineyard.
12.9: Jesus asked, "What do you think the owner of the vineyard will do? He will come and kill those renters and let someone else have his vineyard.
12.10: You surely know that the Scriptures say, 'The stone that the builders tossed aside is now the most important stone of all.
12.11: This is something the Lord has done, and it is amazing to us.'"
12.12: The leaders knew that Jesus was really talking about them, and they wanted to arrest him. But because they were afraid of the crowd, they let him alone and left. Paying Taxes(Matthew 22.15-22; Luke 20.20-26)
12.13: The Pharisees got together with Herod's followers. Then they sent some men to trick Jesus into saying something wrong.
12.14: They went to him and said, "Teacher, we know that you are honest. You treat everyone with the same respect, no matter who they are. And you teach the truth about what God wants people to do. Tell us, should we pay taxes to the Emperor or not?"
12.15: Jesus knew what they were up to, and he said, "Why are you trying to test me? Show me a coin!"
12.16: They brought him a silver coin, and he asked, "Whose picture and name are on it?" "The Emperor's," they answered.
12.17: Then Jesus told them, "Give the Emperor what belongs to him and give God what belongs to God." The men were amazed at Jesus. Life in the Future World(Matthew 22.23-33; Luke 20.27-40)
12.18: The Sadducees did not believe that people would rise to life after death. So some of them came to Jesus and said:
12.19: Teacher, Moses wrote that if a married man dies and has no children, his brother should marry the widow. Their first son would then be thought of as the son of the dead brother.
12.20: There were once seven brothers. The first one married, but died without having any children.
12.21: The second brother married his brother's widow, and he also died without having children. The same thing happened to the third brother,
12.22: and finally to all seven brothers. At last the woman died.
12.23: When God raises people from death, whose wife will this woman be? After all, she had been married to all seven brothers.
12.24: Jesus answered: You are completely wrong! You don't know what the Scriptures teach. And you don't know anything about the power of God.
12.25: When God raises people to life, they won't marry. They will be like the angels in heaven.
12.26: You surely know about people being raised to life. You know that in the story about Moses and the burning bush, God said, "I am the God worshiped by Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob."
12.27: He isn't the God of the dead, but of the living. You Sadducees are all wrong. The Most Important Commandment(Matthew 22.34-40; Luke 10.25-28)
12.28: One of the teachers of the Law of Moses came up while Jesus and the Sadducees were arguing. When he heard Jesus give a good answer, he asked him, "What is the most important commandment?"
12.29: Jesus answered, "The most important one says: 'People of Israel, you have only one Lord and God.
12.30: You must love him with all your heart, soul, mind, and strength.'
12.31: The second most important commandment says: 'Love others as much as you love yourself.' No other commandment is more important than these."
12.32: The man replied, "Teacher, you are certainly right to say there is only one God.
12.33: It is also true that we must love God with all our heart, mind, and strength, and that we must love others as much as we love ourselves. These commandments are more important than all the sacrifices and offerings that we could possibly make."
12.34: When Jesus saw that the man had given a sensible answer, he told him, "You are not far from God's kingdom." After this, no one dared ask Jesus any more questions. About David's Son(Matthew 22.41-46; Luke 20.41-44)
12.35: As Jesus was teaching in the temple, he said, "How can the teachers of the Law of Moses say that the Messiah will come from the family of King David?
12.36: The Holy Spirit led David to say, 'The Lord said to my Lord: Sit at my right side until I make your enemies into a footstool for you.'
12.37: If David called the Messiah his Lord, how can the Messiah be his son?" The large crowd enjoyed listening to Jesus teach. Jesus Condemns the Pharisees and the Teachers of the Law of Moses(Matthew 23.1-36; Luke 20.45-47)
12.38: As Jesus was teaching, he said: Guard against the teachers of the Law of Moses! They love to walk around in long robes and be greeted in the market.
12.39: They like the front seats in the meeting places and the best seats at banquets.
12.40: But they cheat widows out of their homes and pray long prayers just to show off. They will be punished most of all. A Widow's Offering(Luke 21.1-4)
12.41: Jesus was sitting in the temple near the offering box and watching people put in their gifts. He noticed that many rich people were giving a lot of money.
12.42: Finally, a poor widow came up and put in two coins that were worth only a few pennies.
12.43: Jesus told his disciples to gather around him. Then he said: I tell you that this poor widow has put in more than all the others.
12.44: Everyone else gave what they didn't need. But she is very poor and gave everything she had. Now she doesn't have a cent to live on.

13.1: As Jesus was leaving the temple, one of his disciples said to him, "Teacher, look at these beautiful stones and wonderful buildings!"
13.2: Jesus replied, "Do you see these huge buildings? They will certainly be torn down! Not one stone will be left in place." Warning about Trouble(Matthew 24.3-14; Luke 21.7-19)
13.3: Later, as Jesus was sitting on the Mount of Olives across from the temple, Peter, James, John, and Andrew came to him in private.
13.4: They asked, "When will these things happen? What will be the sign that they are about to take place?"
13.5: Jesus answered: Watch out and don't let anyone fool you!
13.6: Many will come and claim to be me. They will use my name and fool many people.
13.7: When you hear about wars and threats of wars, don't be afraid. These things will have to happen first, but that isn't the end.
13.8: Nations and kingdoms will go to war against each other. There will be earthquakes in many places, and people will starve to death. But this is just the beginning of troubles.
13.9: Be on your guard! You will be taken to courts and beaten with whips in their meeting places. And because of me, you will have to stand before rulers and kings to tell about your faith.
13.10: But before the end comes, the good news must be preached to all nations.
13.11: When you are arrested, don't worry about what you will say. You will be given the right words when the time comes. But you will not really be the ones speaking. Your words will come from the Holy Spirit.
13.12: Brothers and sisters will betray each other and have each other put to death. Parents will betray their own children, and children will turn against their parents and have them killed.
13.13: Everyone will hate you because of me. But if you keep on being faithful right to the end, you will be saved. The Horrible Thing(Matthew 24.15-21; Luke 21.20-24)
13.14: Someday you will see that "Horrible Thing" where it should not be. Everyone who reads this must try to understand! If you are living in Judea at that time, run to the mountains.
13.15: If you are on the roof of your house, don't go inside to get anything.
13.16: If you are out in the field, don't go back for your coat.
13.17: It will be an awful time for women who are expecting babies or nursing young children.
13.18: Pray that it won't happen in winter.
13.19: This will be the worst time of suffering since God created the world, and nothing this terrible will ever happen again.
13.20: If the Lord doesn't make the time shorter, no one will be left alive. But because of his chosen and special ones, he will make the time shorter.
13.21: If someone should say, "Here is the Messiah!" or "There he is!" don't believe it.
13.22: False messiahs and false prophets will come and work miracles and signs. They will even try to fool God's chosen ones.
13.23: But be on your guard! That's why I am telling you these things now. When the Son of Man Appears(Matthew 24.29-31; Luke 21.25-28)
13.24: In those days, right after that time of suffering, "The sun will become dark, and the moon will no longer shine.
13.25: The stars will fall, and the powers in the sky will be shaken."
13.26: Then the Son of Man will be seen coming in the clouds with great power and glory.
13.27: He will send his angels to gather his chosen ones from all over the earth. A Lesson from a Fig Tree(Matthew 24.32-35; Luke 21.29-33)
13.28: Learn a lesson from a fig tree. When its branches sprout and start putting out leaves, you know summer is near.
13.29: So when you see all these things happening, you will know that the time has almost come.
13.30: You can be sure that some of the people of this generation will still be alive when all this happens.
13.31: The sky and the earth will not last forever, but my words will. No One Knows the Day or Time(Matthew 24.36-44)
13.32: No one knows the day or the time. The angels in heaven don't know, and the Son himself doesn't know. Only the Father knows.
13.33: So watch out and be ready! You don't know when the time will come.
13.34: It is like what happens when a man goes away for a while and places his servants in charge of everything. He tells each of them what to do, and he orders the guard to keep alert.
13.35: So be alert! You don't know when the master of the house will come back. It could be in the evening or at midnight or before dawn or in the morning.
13.36: But if he comes suddenly, don't let him find you asleep.
13.37: I tell everyone just what I have told you. Be alert!

14.1: It was now two days before Passover and the Festival of Thin Bread. The chief priests and the teachers of the Law of Moses were planning how they could sneak around and have Jesus arrested and put to death.
14.2: They were saying, "We must not do it during the festival, because the people will riot." At Bethany(Matthew 26.6-13; John 12.1-8)
14.3: Jesus was eating in Bethany at the home of Simon, who once had leprosy, when a woman came in with a very expensive bottle of sweet-smelling perfume. After breaking it open, she poured the perfume on Jesus' head.
14.4: This made some of the guests angry, and they complained, "Why such a waste?
14.5: We could have sold this perfume for more than three hundred silver coins and given the money to the poor!" So they started saying cruel things to the woman.
14.6: But Jesus said: Leave her alone! Why are you bothering her? She has done a beautiful thing for me.
14.7: You will always have the poor with you. And whenever you want to, you can give to them. But you won't always have me here with you.
14.8: She has done all she could by pouring perfume on my body to prepare it for burial.
14.9: You may be sure that wherever the good news is told all over the world, people will remember what she has done. And they will tell others. Judas and the Chief Priests(Matthew 26.14-16; Luke 22.3-6)
14.10: Judas Iscariot was one of the twelve disciples. He went to the chief priests and offered to help them arrest Jesus.
14.11: They were glad to hear this, and they promised to pay him. So Judas started looking for a good chance to betray Jesus. Jesus Eats with His Disciples(Matthew 26.17-25; Luke 22.7-14,21-23; John 13.21-30)
14.12: It was the first day of the Festival of Thin Bread, and the Passover lambs were being killed. Jesus' disciples asked him, "Where do you want us to prepare the Passover meal?"
14.13: Jesus said to two of the disciples, "Go into the city, where you will meet a man carrying a jar of water. Follow him,
14.14: and when he goes into a house, say to the owner, 'Our teacher wants to know if you have a room where he can eat the Passover meal with his disciples.'
14.15: The owner will take you upstairs and show you a large room furnished and ready for you to use. Prepare the meal there."
14.16: The two disciples went into the city and found everything just as Jesus had told them. So they prepared the Passover meal.
14.17: While Jesus and the twelve disciples were eating together that evening, he said, "The one who will betray me is now eating with me."
14.19: This made the disciples sad, and one after another they said to Jesus, "You surely don't mean me!"
14.20: He answered, "It is one of you twelve men who is eating from this dish with me.
14.21: The Son of Man will die, just as the Scriptures say. But it is going to be terrible for the one who betrays me. That man would be better off if he had never been born." The Lord's Supper(Matthew 26.26-30; Luke 22.14-23; 1 Corinthians 11.23-25)
14.22: During the meal Jesus took some bread in his hands. He blessed the bread and broke it. Then he gave it to his disciples and said, "Take this. It is my body."
14.23: Jesus picked up a cup of wine and gave thanks to God. He gave it to his disciples, and they all drank some.
14.24: Then he said, "This is my blood, which is poured out for many people, and with it God makes his agreement.
14.25: From now on I will not drink any wine, until I drink new wine in God's kingdom."
14.26: Then they sang a hymn and went out to the Mount of Olives. Peter's Promise(Matthew 26.31-35; Luke 22.31-34; John 13.36-38)
14.27: Jesus said to his disciples, "All of you will reject me, as the Scriptures say, 'I will strike down the shepherd, and the sheep will be scattered.'
14.28: But after I am raised to life, I will go ahead of you to Galilee."
14.29: Peter spoke up, "Even if all the others reject you, I never will!"
14.30: Jesus replied, "This very night before a rooster crows twice, you will say three times that you don't know me."
14.31: But Peter was so sure of himself that he said, "Even if I have to die with you, I will never say that I don't know you!" All the others said the same thing. Jesus Prays(Matthew 26.36-46; Luke 22.39-46)
14.32: Jesus went with his disciples to a place called Gethsemane, and he told them, "Sit here while I pray."
14.33: Jesus took along Peter, James, and John. He was sad and troubled and
14.34: told them, "I am so sad that I feel as if I am dying. Stay here and keep awake with me."
14.35: Jesus walked on a little way. Then he knelt down on the ground and prayed, "Father, if it is possible, don't let this happen to me! Father, you can do anything. Don't make me suffer by having me drink from this cup. But do what you want, and not what I want."
14.37: When Jesus came back and found the disciples sleeping, he said to Simon Peter, "Are you asleep? Can't you stay awake for just one hour?
14.38: Stay awake and pray that you won't be tested. You want to do what is right, but you are weak."
14.39: Jesus went back and prayed the same prayer.
14.40: But when he returned to the disciples, he found them sleeping again. They simply could not keep their eyes open, and they did not know what to say.
14.41: When Jesus returned to the disciples the third time, he said, "Are you still sleeping and resting? Enough of that! The time has come for the Son of Man to be handed over to sinners.
14.42: Get up! Let's go. The one who will betray me is already here." Jesus Is Arrested(Matthew 26.47-56; Luke 22.47-53; John 18.3-12)
14.43: Jesus was still speaking, when Judas the betrayer came up. He was one of the twelve disciples, and a mob of men armed with swords and clubs were with him. They had been sent by the chief priests, the nation's leaders, and the teachers of the Law of Moses.
14.44: Judas had told them ahead of time, "Arrest the man I greet with a kiss. Tie him up tight and lead him away."
14.45: Judas walked right up to Jesus and said, "Teacher!" Then Judas kissed him,
14.46: and the men grabbed Jesus and arrested him.
14.47: Someone standing there pulled out a sword. He struck the servant of the high priest and cut off his ear.
14.48: Jesus said to the mob, "Why do you come with swords and clubs to arrest me like a criminal?
14.49: Day after day I was with you and taught in the temple, and you didn't arrest me. But what the Scriptures say must come true."
14.50: All of Jesus' disciples ran off and left him.
14.51: One of them was a young man who was wearing only a linen cloth. And when the men grabbed him,
14.52: he left the cloth behind and ran away naked. Jesus Is Questioned by the Council(Matthew 26.57-68; Luke 22.54,55,63-71; John 18.13,14,19-24)
14.53: Jesus was led off to the high priest. Then the chief priests, the nation's leaders, and the teachers of the Law of Moses all met together.
14.54: Peter had followed at a distance. And when he reached the courtyard of the high priest's house, he sat down with the guards to warm himself beside a fire.
14.55: The chief priests and the whole council tried to find someone to accuse Jesus of a crime, so they could put him to death. But they could not find anyone to accuse him.
14.56: Many people did tell lies against Jesus, but they did not agree on what they said.
14.57: Finally, some men stood up and lied about him. They said,
14.58: "We heard him say he would tear down this temple that we built. He also claimed that in three days he would build another one without any help."
14.59: But even then they did not agree on what they said.
14.60: The high priest stood up in the council and asked Jesus, "Why don't you say something in your own defense? Don't you hear the charges they are making against you?"
14.61: But Jesus kept quiet and did not say a word. The high priest asked him another question, "Are you the Messiah, the Son of the glorious God?"
14.62: "Yes, I am!" Jesus answered. "Soon you will see the Son of Man sitting at the right side of God All-Powerful, and coming with the clouds of heaven."
14.63: At once the high priest ripped his robe apart and shouted, "Why do we need more witnesses?
14.64: You heard him claim to be God! What is your decision?" They all agreed that he should be put to death.
14.65: Some of the people started spitting on Jesus. They blindfolded him, hit him with their fists, and said, "Tell us who hit you!" Then the guards took charge of Jesus and beat him. Peter Says He Doesn't Know Jesus(Matthew 26.69-75; Luke 22.56-62; John 18.15-18,25-27)
14.66: While Peter was still in the courtyard, a servant girl of the high priest came up
14.67: and saw Peter warming himself by the fire. She stared at him and said, "You were with Jesus from Nazareth!"
14.68: Peter replied, "That isn't true! I don't know what you're talking about. I don't have any idea what you mean." He went out to the gate, and a rooster crowed.
14.69: The servant girl saw Peter again and said to the people standing there, "This man is one of them!"
14.70: "No, I'm not!" Peter replied. A little while later some of the people said to Peter, "You certainly are one of them. You're a Galilean!"
14.71: This time Peter began to curse and swear, "I don't even know the man you're talking about!"
14.72: Right away the rooster crowed a second time. Then Peter remembered that Jesus had told him, "Before a rooster crows twice, you will say three times that you don't know me." So Peter started crying.

15.1: Early the next morning the chief priests, the nation's leaders, and the teachers of the Law of Moses met together with the whole Jewish council. They tied up Jesus and led him off to Pilate.
15.2: He asked Jesus, "Are you the king of the Jews?" "Those are your words," Jesus answered.
15.3: The chief priests brought many charges against Jesus.
15.4: Then Pilate questioned him again, "Don't you have anything to say? Don't you hear what crimes they say you have done?"
15.5: But Jesus did not answer, and Pilate was amazed. The Death Sentence(Matthew 27.15-26; Luke 23.13-25; John 18.39--19.16)
15.6: During Passover, Pilate always freed one prisoner chosen by the people.
15.7: And at that time there was a prisoner named Barabbas. He and some others had been arrested for murder during a riot.
15.8: The crowd now came and asked Pilate to set a prisoner free, just as he usually did.
15.9: Pilate asked them, "Do you want me to free the king of the Jews?"
15.10: Pilate knew that the chief priests had brought Jesus to him because they were jealous.
15.11: But the chief priests told the crowd to ask Pilate to free Barabbas.
15.12: Then Pilate asked the crowd, "What do you want me to do with this man you say is the king of the Jews?"
15.13: They yelled, "Nail him to a cross!"
15.14: Pilate asked, "But what crime has he done?" "Nail him to a cross!" they yelled even louder.
15.15: Pilate wanted to please the crowd. So he set Barabbas free. Then he ordered his soldiers to beat Jesus with a whip and nail him to a cross. Soldiers Make Fun of Jesus(Matthew 27.27-30; John 19.2,3)
15.16: The soldiers led Jesus inside the courtyard of the fortress and called together the rest of the troops.
15.17: They put a purple robe on him, and on his head they placed a crown that they had made out of thorn branches.
15.18: They made fun of Jesus and shouted, "Hey, you king of the Jews!"
15.19: Then they beat him on the head with a stick. They spit on him and knelt down and pretended to worship him.
15.20: When the soldiers had finished making fun of Jesus, they took off the purple robe. They put his own clothes back on him and led him off to be nailed to a cross.
15.21: Simon from Cyrene happened to be coming in from a farm, and they forced him to carry Jesus' cross. Simon was the father of Alexander and Rufus. Jesus Is Nailed to a Cross(Matthew 27.31-44; Luke 23.27-43; John 19.17-27)
15.22: The soldiers took Jesus to Golgotha, which means "Place of a Skull."
15.23: There they gave him some wine mixed with a drug to ease the pain, but he refused to drink it.
15.24: They nailed Jesus to a cross and gambled to see who would get his clothes.
15.25: It was about nine o'clock in the morning when they nailed him to the cross.
15.26: On it was a sign that told why he was nailed there. It read, "This is the King of the Jews."
15.27: The soldiers also nailed two criminals on crosses, one to the right of Jesus and the other to his left.
15.29: People who passed by said terrible things about Jesus. They shook their heads and shouted, "Ha! So you're the one who claimed you could tear down the temple and build it again in three days.
15.30: Save yourself and come down from the cross!"
15.31: The chief priests and the teachers of the Law of Moses also made fun of Jesus. They said to each other, "He saved others, but he can't save himself.
15.32: If he is the Messiah, the king of Israel, let him come down from the cross! Then we will see and believe." The two criminals also said cruel things to Jesus. The Death of Jesus(Matthew 27.45-56; Luke 23.44-49; John 19.28-30)
15.33: About noon the sky turned dark and stayed that way until around three o'clock.
15.34: Then about that time Jesus shouted, "Eloi, Eloi, lema sabachthani?" which means, "My God, my God, why have you deserted me?"
15.35: Some of the people standing there heard Jesus and said, "He is calling for Elijah."
15.36: One of them ran and grabbed a sponge. After he had soaked it in wine, he put it on a stick and held it up to Jesus. He said, "Let's wait and see if Elijah will come and take him down!"
15.38: At once the curtain in the temple tore in two from top to bottom.
15.39: A Roman army officer was standing in front of Jesus. When the officer saw how Jesus died, he said, "This man really was the Son of God!"
15.40: Some women were looking on from a distance. They had come with Jesus to Jerusalem. But even before this they had been his followers and had helped him while he was in Galilee. Mary Magdalene and Mary the mother of the younger James and of Joseph were two of these women. Salome was also one of them. Jesus Is Buried(Matthew 27.57-61; Luke 23.50-56; John 19.38-42)
15.42: It was now the evening before the Sabbath, and the Jewish people were getting ready for that sacred day.
15.43: A man named Joseph from Arimathea was brave enough to ask Pilate for the body of Jesus. Joseph was a highly respected member of the Jewish council, and he was also waiting for God's kingdom to come.
15.44: Pilate was surprised to hear that Jesus was already dead, and he called in the army officer to find out if Jesus had been dead very long.
15.45: After the officer told him, Pilate let Joseph have Jesus' body.
15.46: Joseph bought a linen cloth and took the body down from the cross. He had it wrapped in the cloth, and he put it in a tomb that had been cut into solid rock. Then he rolled a big stone against the entrance to the tomb.
15.47: Mary Magdalene and Mary the mother of Joseph were watching and saw where the body was placed.

16.1: After the Sabbath, Mary Magdalene, Salome, and Mary the mother of James bought some spices to put on Jesus' body.
16.2: Very early on Sunday morning, just as the sun was coming up, they went to the tomb.
16.3: On their way, they were asking one another, "Who will roll the stone away from the entrance for us?"
16.4: But when they looked, they saw that the stone had already been rolled away. And it was a huge stone!
16.5: The women went into the tomb, and on the right side they saw a young man in a white robe sitting there. They were alarmed.
16.6: The man said, "Don't be alarmed! You are looking for Jesus from Nazareth, who was nailed to a cross. God has raised him to life, and he isn't here. You can see the place where they put his body.
16.7: Now go and tell his disciples, and especially Peter, that he will go ahead of you to Galilee. You will see him there, just as he told you."
16.8: When the women ran from the tomb, they were confused and shaking all over. They were too afraid to tell anyone what had happened. ONE OLD ENDINGTO MARK'S GOSPEL Jesus Appears to Mary Magdalene(Matthew 28.9,10; John 20.11-18)
16.9: The women quickly told Peter and his friends what had happened. Later, Jesus sent the disciples to the east and to the west with his sacred and everlasting message of how people can be saved forever.
16.10: She left and told his friends, who were crying and mourning.
16.11: Even though they heard that Jesus was alive and that Mary had seen him, they would not believe it. Jesus Appears to Two Disciples(Luke 24.13-35)
16.12: Later, Jesus appeared in another form to two disciples, as they were on their way out of the city.
16.13: But when these disciples told what had happened, the others would not believe. What Jesus' Followers Must Do(Matthew 28.16-20; Luke 24.36-49; John 20.19-23; Acts 1.6-8)
16.14: Afterwards, Jesus appeared to his eleven disciples as they were eating. He scolded them because they were too stubborn to believe the ones who had seen him after he had been raised to life.
16.15: Then he told them: Go and preach the good news to everyone in the world.
16.16: Anyone who believes me and is baptized will be saved. But anyone who refuses to believe me will be condemned.
16.17: Everyone who believes me will be able to do wonderful things. By using my name they will force out demons, and they will speak new languages.
16.18: They will handle snakes and will drink poison and not be hurt. They will also heal sick people by placing their hands on them. Jesus Returns to Heaven(Luke 24.50-53; Acts 1.9-11)
16.19: After the Lord Jesus had said these things to the disciples, he was taken back up to heaven where he sat down at the right side of God.
16.20: Then the disciples left and preached everywhere. The Lord was with them, and the miracles they worked proved that their message was true. ANOTHER OLD ENDINGTO MARK'S GOSPEL

1.1: Many people have tried to tell the story of what God has done among us.
1.2: They wrote what we had been told by the ones who were there in the beginning and saw what happened.
1.3: So I made a careful study of everything and then decided to write and tell you exactly what took place. Honorable Theophilus,
1.4: I have done this to let you know the truth about what you have heard. An Angel Tells about the Birth of John
1.5: When Herod was king of Judea, there was a priest by the name of Zechariah from the priestly group of Abijah. His wife Elizabeth was from the family of Aaron.
1.6: Both of them were good people and pleased the Lord God by obeying all that he had commanded.
1.7: But they did not have children. Elizabeth could not have any, and both Zechariah and Elizabeth were already old.
1.8: One day Zechariah's group of priests were on duty, and he was serving God as a priest.
1.9: According to the custom of the priests, he had been chosen to go into the Lord's temple that day and to burn incense,
1.10: while the people stood outside praying.
1.11: All at once an angel from the Lord appeared to Zechariah at the right side of the altar.
1.12: Zechariah was confused and afraid when he saw the angel.
1.13: But the angel told him: Don't be afraid, Zechariah! God has heard your prayers. Your wife Elizabeth will have a son, and you must name him John.
1.14: His birth will make you very happy, and many people will be glad.
1.15: Your son will be a great servant of the Lord. He must never drink wine or beer, and the power of the Holy Spirit will be with him from the time he is born.
1.16: John will lead many people in Israel to turn back to the Lord their God.
1.17: He will go ahead of the Lord with the same power and spirit that Elijah had. And because of John, parents will be more thoughtful of their children. And people who now disobey God will begin to think as they ought to. That is how John will get people ready for the Lord.
1.18: Zechariah said to the angel, "How will I know this is going to happen? My wife and I are both very old."
1.19: The angel answered, "I am Gabriel, God's servant, and I was sent to tell you this good news.
1.20: You have not believed what I have said. So you will not be able to say a thing until all this happens. But everything will take place when it is supposed to."
1.21: The crowd was waiting for Zechariah and kept wondering why he was staying so long in the temple.
1.22: When he did come out, he could not speak, and they knew he had seen a vision. He motioned to them with his hands, but did not say a thing.
1.23: When Zechariah's time of service in the temple was over, he went home.
1.24: Soon after that, his wife was expecting a baby, and for five months she did not leave the house. She said to herself,
1.25: "What the Lord has done for me will keep people from looking down on me." An Angel Tells about the Birth of Jesus
1.26: One month later God sent the angel Gabriel to the town of Nazareth in Galilee
1.27: with a message for a virgin named Mary. She was engaged to Joseph from the family of King David.
1.28: The angel greeted Mary and said, "You are truly blessed! The Lord is with you."
1.29: Mary was confused by the angel's words and wondered what they meant.
1.30: Then the angel told Mary, "Don't be afraid! God is pleased with you,
1.31: and you will have a son. His name will be Jesus.
1.32: He will be great and will be called the Son of God Most High. The Lord God will make him king, as his ancestor David was.
1.33: He will rule the people of Israel forever, and his kingdom will never end."
1.34: Mary asked the angel, "How can this happen? I am not married!"
1.35: The angel answered, "The Holy Spirit will come down to you, and God's power will come over you. So your child will be called the holy Son of God.
1.36: Your relative Elizabeth is also going to have a son, even though she is old. No one thought she could ever have a baby, but in three months she will have a son.
1.38: Mary said, "I am the Lord's servant! Let it happen as you have said." And the angel left her. Mary Visits Elizabeth
1.39: A short time later Mary hurried to a town in the hill country of Judea.
1.40: She went into Zechariah's home, where she greeted Elizabeth.
1.41: When Elizabeth heard Mary's greeting, her baby moved within her. The Holy Spirit came upon Elizabeth.
1.42: Then in a loud voice she said to Mary: God has blessed you more than any other woman! He has also blessed the child you will have.
1.43: Why should the mother of my Lord come to me?
1.44: As soon as I heard your greeting, my baby became happy and moved within me.
1.45: The Lord has blessed you because you believed that he will keep his promise. Mary's Song of Praise
1.46: Mary said: With all my heart I praise the Lord,
1.47: and I am glad because of God my Savior.
1.48: He cares for me, his humble servant. From now on, all people will say God has blessed me.
1.49: God All-Powerful has done great things for me, and his name is holy.
1.50: He always shows mercy to everyone who worships him.
1.51: The Lord has used his powerful arm to scatter those who are proud.
1.52: He drags strong rulers from their thrones and puts humble people in places of power.
1.53: God gives the hungry good things to eat, and sends the rich away with nothing.
1.54: He helps his servant Israel and is always merciful to his people.
1.55: The Lord made this promise to our ancestors, to Abraham and his family forever!
1.56: Mary stayed with Elizabeth about three months. Then she went back home. The Birth of John the Baptist
1.58: her neighbors and relatives heard how kind the Lord had been to her, and they too were glad.
1.59: Eight days later they did for the child what the Law of Moses commands. They were going to name him Zechariah, after his father.
1.60: But Elizabeth said, "No! His name is John."
1.61: The people argued, "No one in your family has ever been named John."
1.62: So they motioned to Zechariah to find out what he wanted to name his son.
1.63: Zechariah asked for a writing tablet. Then he wrote, "His name is John." Everyone was amazed.
1.64: Right away, Zechariah started speaking and praising God.
1.65: All the neighbors were frightened because of what had happened, and everywhere in the hill country people kept talking about these things.
1.66: Everyone who heard about this wondered what this child would grow up to be. They knew that the Lord was with him. Zechariah Praises the Lord
1.67: The Holy Spirit came upon Zechariah, and he began to speak:
1.68: Praise the Lord, the God of Israel! He has come to save his people.
1.69: Our God has given us a mighty Savior from the family of David his servant.
1.70: Long ago the Lord promised by the words of his holy prophets
1.71: to save us from our enemies and from everyone who hates us.
1.72: God said he would be kind to our people and keep his sacred promise.
1.74: that he would rescue us from our enemies. Then we could serve him without fear,
1.75: by being holy and good as long as we live.
1.76: You, my son, will be called a prophet of God in heaven above. You will go ahead of the Lord to get everything ready for him.
1.77: You will tell his people that they can be saved when their sins are forgiven.
1.78: God's love and kindness will shine upon us like the sun that rises in the sky.
1.79: On us who live in the dark shadow of death this light will shine to guide us into a life of peace.
1.80: As John grew up, God's Spirit gave him great power. John lived in the desert until the time he was sent to the people of Israel.

2.1: About that time Emperor Augustus gave orders for the names of all the people to be listed in record books.
2.2: These first records were made when Quirinius was governor of Syria.
2.3: Everyone had to go to their own hometown to be listed.
2.4: So Joseph had to leave Nazareth in Galilee and go to Bethlehem in Judea. Long ago Bethlehem had been King David's hometown, and Joseph went there because he was from David's family.
2.5: Mary was engaged to Joseph and traveled with him to Bethlehem. She was soon going to have a baby,
2.6: and while they were there,
2.7: she gave birth to her first-born son. She dressed him in baby clothes and laid him on a bed of hay, because there was no room for them in the inn. The Shepherds
2.8: That night in the fields near Bethlehem some shepherds were guarding their sheep.
2.9: All at once an angel came down to them from the Lord, and the brightness of the Lord's glory flashed around them. The shepherds were frightened.
2.10: But the angel said, "Don't be afraid! I have good news for you, which will make everyone happy.
2.11: This very day in King David's hometown a Savior was born for you. He is Christ the Lord.
2.12: You will know who he is, because you will find him dressed in baby clothes and lying on a bed of hay."
2.13: Suddenly many other angels came down from heaven and joined in praising God. They said:
2.14: "Praise God in heaven! Peace on earth to everyone who pleases God."
2.15: After the angels had left and gone back to heaven, the shepherds said to each other, "Let's go to Bethlehem and see what the Lord has told us about."
2.16: They hurried off and found Mary and Joseph, and they saw the baby lying on a bed of hay.
2.17: When the shepherds saw Jesus, they told his parents what the angel had said about him.
2.18: Everyone listened and was surprised.
2.19: But Mary kept thinking about all this and wondering what it meant.
2.20: As the shepherds returned to their sheep, they were praising God and saying wonderful things about him. Everything they had seen and heard was just as the angel had said.
2.21: Eight days later Jesus' parents did for him what the Law of Moses commands. And they named him Jesus, just as the angel had told Mary when he promised she would have a baby. Simeon Praises the Lord
2.22: The time came for Mary and Joseph to do what the Law of Moses says a mother is supposed to do after her baby is born. They took Jesus to the temple in Jerusalem and presented him to the Lord,
2.23: just as the Law of the Lord says, "Each first-born baby boy belongs to the Lord."
2.24: The Law of the Lord also says that parents have to offer a sacrifice, giving at least a pair of doves or two young pigeons. So that is what Mary and Joseph did.
2.25: At this time a man named Simeon was living in Jerusalem. Simeon was a good man. He loved God and was waiting for God to save the people of Israel. God's Spirit came to him
2.26: and told him that he would not die until he had seen Christ the Lord.
2.27: When Mary and Joseph brought Jesus to the temple to do what the Law of Moses says should be done for a new baby, the Spirit told Simeon to go into the temple.
2.28: Simeon took the baby Jesus in his arms and praised God,
2.29: "Lord, I am your servant, and now I can die in peace, because you have kept your promise to me.
2.30: With my own eyes I have seen what you have done to save your people,
2.31: and foreign nations will also see this.
2.32: Your mighty power is a light for all nations, and it will bring honor to your people Israel."
2.33: Jesus' parents were surprised at what Simeon had said.
2.34: Then he blessed them and told Mary, "This child of yours will cause many people in Israel to fall and others to stand. The child will be like a warning sign. Many people will reject him,
2.35: and you, Mary, will suffer as though you had been stabbed by a dagger. But all this will show what people are really thinking." Anna Speaks about the Child Jesus
2.36: The prophet Anna was also there in the temple. She was the daughter of Phanuel from the tribe of Asher, and she was very old. In her youth she had been married for seven years, but her husband died.
2.37: And now she was eighty-four years old. Night and day she served God in the temple by praying and often going without eating.
2.38: At that time Anna came in and praised God. She spoke about the child Jesus to everyone who hoped for Jerusalem to be set free. The Return to Nazareth
2.39: After Joseph and Mary had done everything that the Law of the Lord commands, they returned home to Nazareth in Galilee.
2.40: The child Jesus grew. He became strong and wise, and God blessed him. The Boy Jesus in the Temple
2.41: Every year Jesus' parents went to Jerusalem for Passover.
2.42: And when Jesus was twelve years old, they all went there as usual for the celebration.
2.43: After Passover his parents left, but they did not know that Jesus had stayed on in the city.
2.44: They thought he was traveling with some other people, and they went a whole day before they started looking for him.
2.45: When they could not find him with their relatives and friends, they went back to Jerusalem and started looking for him there.
2.46: Three days later they found Jesus sitting in the temple, listening to the teachers and asking them questions.
2.47: Everyone who heard him was surprised at how much he knew and at the answers he gave.
2.48: When his parents found him, they were amazed. His mother said, "Son, why have you done this to us? Your father and I have been very worried, and we have been searching for you!"
2.49: Jesus answered, "Why did you have to look for me? Didn't you know that I would be in my Father's house?"
2.50: But they did not understand what he meant.
2.51: Jesus went back to Nazareth with his parents and obeyed them. His mother kept on thinking about all that had happened.
2.52: Jesus became wise, and he grew strong. God was pleased with him and so were the people.

3.1: For fifteen years Emperor Tiberius had ruled that part of the world. Pontius Pilate was governor of Judea, and Herod was the ruler of Galilee. Herod's brother, Philip, was the ruler in the countries of Iturea and Trachonitis, and Lysanias was the ruler of Abilene.
3.2: Annas and Caiaphas were the Jewish high priests. At that time God spoke to Zechariah's son John, who was living in the desert.
3.3: So John went along the Jordan Valley, telling the people, "Turn back to God and be baptized! Then your sins will be forgiven."
3.4: Isaiah the prophet wrote about John when he said, "In the desert someone is shouting, 'Get the road ready for the Lord! Make a straight path for him.
3.5: Fill up every valley and level every mountain and hill. Straighten the crooked paths and smooth out the rough roads.
3.6: Then everyone will see the saving power of God.'"
3.7: Crowds of people came out to be baptized, but John said to them, "You bunch of snakes! Who warned you to run from the coming judgment?
3.8: Do something to show that you really have given up your sins. Don't start saying that you belong to Abraham's family. God can turn these stones into children for Abraham.
3.9: An ax is ready to cut the trees down at their roots. Any tree that doesn't produce good fruit will be cut down and thrown into a fire."
3.10: The crowds asked John, "What should we do?"
3.11: John told them, "If you have two coats, give one to someone who doesn't have any. If you have food, share it with someone else."
3.12: When tax collectors came to be baptized, they asked John, "Teacher, what should we do?"
3.13: John told them, "Don't make people pay more than they owe."
3.14: Some soldiers asked him, "And what about us? What do we have to do?" John told them, "Don't force people to pay money to make you leave them alone. Be satisfied with your pay."
3.15: Everyone became excited and wondered, "Could John be the Messiah?"
3.16: John said, "I am just baptizing with water. But someone more powerful is going to come, and I am not good enough even to untie his sandals. He will baptize you with the Holy Spirit and with fire.
3.17: His threshing fork is in his hand, and he is ready to separate the wheat from the husks. He will store the wheat in his barn and burn the husks with a fire that never goes out."
3.18: In many different ways John preached the good news to the people.
3.19: But to Herod the ruler, he said, "It was wrong for you to take Herodias, your brother's wife." John also said that Herod had done many other bad things.
3.20: Finally, Herod put John in jail, and this was the worst thing he had done. The Baptism of Jesus(Matthew 3.13-17; Mark 1.9-11)
3.21: While everyone else was being baptized, Jesus himself was baptized. Then as he prayed, the sky opened up,
3.22: and the Holy Spirit came down upon him in the form of a dove. A voice from heaven said, "You are my own dear Son, and I am pleased with you." The Ancestors of Jesus(Matthew 1.1-17)
3.23: When Jesus began to preach, he was about thirty years old. Everyone thought he was the son of Joseph. But his family went back through Heli,
3.24: Matthat, Levi, Melchi, Jannai, Joseph,
3.25: Mattathias, Amos, Nahum, Esli, Naggai,
3.33: Amminadab, Admin, Arni, Hezron, Perez, Judah,
3.38: Enosh, and Seth. The family of Jesus went all the way back to Adam and then to God.

4.1: When Jesus returned from the Jordan River, the power of the Holy Spirit was with him, and the Spirit led him into the desert.
4.2: For forty days Jesus was tested by the devil, and during that time he went without eating. When it was all over, he was hungry.
4.3: The devil said to Jesus, "If you are God's Son, tell this stone to turn into bread."
4.4: Jesus answered, "The Scriptures say, 'No one can live only on food.'"
4.5: Then the devil led Jesus up to a high place and quickly showed him all the nations on earth.
4.6: The devil said, "I will give all this power and glory to you. It has been given to me, and I can give it to anyone I want to.
4.7: Just worship me, and you can have it all."
4.8: Jesus answered, "The Scriptures say: 'Worship the Lord your God and serve only him!'"
4.9: Finally, the devil took Jesus to Jerusalem and had him stand on top of the temple. The devil said, "If you are God's Son, jump off.
4.10: The Scriptures say: 'God will tell his angels to take care of you. They will catch you in their arms, and you will not hurt your feet on the stones.'"
4.12: Jesus answered, "The Scriptures also say, 'Don't try to test the Lord your God!'"
4.13: After the devil had finished testing Jesus in every way possible, he left him for a while. Jesus Begins His Work(Matthew 4.12-17; Mark 1.14,15)
4.14: Jesus returned to Galilee with the power of the Spirit. News about him spread everywhere.
4.15: He taught in the Jewish meeting places, and everyone praised him. The People of Nazareth Turn against Jesus(Matthew 13.53-58; Mark 6.1-6)
4.16: Jesus went back to Nazareth, where he had been brought up, and as usual he went to the meeting place on the Sabbath. When he stood up to read from the Scriptures,
4.17: he was given the book of Isaiah the prophet. He opened it and read,
4.18: "The Lord's Spirit has come to me, because he has chosen me to tell the good news to the poor. The Lord has sent me to announce freedom for prisoners, to give sight to the blind, to free everyone who suffers,
4.19: and to say, 'This is the year the Lord has chosen.'"
4.20: Jesus closed the book, then handed it back to the man in charge and sat down. Everyone in the meeting place looked straight at Jesus.
4.21: Then Jesus said to them, "What you have just heard me read has come true today."
4.22: All the people started talking about Jesus and were amazed at the wonderful things he said. They kept on asking, "Isn't he Joseph's son?"
4.23: Jesus answered: You will certainly want to tell me this saying, "Doctor, first make yourself well." You will tell me to do the same things here in my own hometown that you heard I did in Capernaum.
4.24: But you can be sure that no prophets are liked by the people of their own hometown.
4.25: Once during the time of Elijah there was no rain for three and a half years, and people everywhere were starving. There were many widows in Israel,
4.26: but Elijah was sent only to a widow in the town of Zarephath near the city of Sidon.
4.27: During the time of the prophet Elisha, many men in Israel had leprosy. But no one was healed, except Naaman who lived in Syria.
4.28: When the people in the meeting place heard Jesus say this, they became so angry
4.29: that they got up and threw him out of town. They dragged him to the edge of the cliff on which the town was built, because they wanted to throw him down from there.
4.30: But Jesus slipped through the crowd and got away. A Man with an Evil Spirit(Mark 1.21-28)
4.31: Jesus went to the town of Capernaum in Galilee and taught the people on the Sabbath.
4.32: His teaching amazed them because he spoke with power.
4.33: There in the Jewish meeting place was a man with an evil spirit. He yelled out,
4.34: "Hey, Jesus of Nazareth, what do you want with us? Are you here to get rid of us? I know who you are! You are God's Holy One."
4.35: Jesus ordered the evil spirit to be quiet and come out. The demon threw the man to the ground in front of everyone and left without harming him.
4.36: They all were amazed and kept saying to each other, "What kind of teaching is this? He has power to order evil spirits out of people!"
4.37: News about Jesus spread all over that part of the country. Jesus Heals Many People(Matthew 8.14-17; Mark 1.29-34)
4.38: Jesus left the meeting place and went to Simon's home. When Jesus got there, he was told that Simon's mother-in-law was sick with a high fever.
4.39: So Jesus went over to her and ordered the fever to go away. Right then she was able to get up and serve them a meal.
4.40: After the sun had set, people with all kinds of diseases were brought to Jesus. He put his hands on each one of them and healed them.
4.41: Demons went out of many people and shouted, "You are the Son of God!" But Jesus ordered the demons not to speak because they knew he was the Messiah.
4.42: The next morning Jesus went out to a place where he could be alone, and crowds came looking for him. When they found him, they tried to stop him from leaving.
4.43: But Jesus said, "People in other towns must hear the good news about God's kingdom. That's why I was sent."
4.44: So he kept on preaching in the Jewish meeting places in Judea.

5.1: Jesus was standing on the shore of Lake Gennesaret, teaching the people as they crowded around him to hear God's message.
5.2: Near the shore he saw two boats left there by some fishermen who had gone to wash their nets.
5.3: Jesus got into the boat that belonged to Simon and asked him to row it out a little way from the shore. Then Jesus sat down in the boat to teach the crowd.
5.4: When Jesus had finished speaking, he told Simon, "Row the boat out into the deep water and let your nets down to catch some fish."
5.5: "Master," Simon answered, "we have worked hard all night long and have not caught a thing. But if you tell me to, I will let the nets down."
5.6: They did it and caught so many fish that their nets began ripping apart.
5.7: Then they signaled for their partners in the other boat to come and help them. The men came, and together they filled the two boats so full that they both began to sink.
5.8: When Simon Peter saw this happen, he knelt down in front of Jesus and said, "Lord, don't come near me! I am a sinner."
5.9: Peter and everyone with him were completely surprised at all the fish they had caught.
5.10: His partners James and John, the sons of Zebedee, were surprised too. Jesus told Simon, "Don't be afraid! From now on you will bring in people instead of fish."
5.11: The men pulled their boats up on the shore. Then they left everything and went with Jesus. Jesus Heals a Man(Matthew 8.1-4; Mark 1.40-45)
5.12: Jesus came to a town where there was a man who had leprosy. When the man saw Jesus, he knelt down to the ground in front of Jesus and begged, "Lord, you have the power to make me well, if only you wanted to."
5.13: Jesus put his hand on him and said, "I want to! Now you are well." At once the man's leprosy disappeared.
5.14: Jesus told him, "Don't tell anyone about this, but go and show yourself to the priest. Offer a gift to the priest, just as Moses commanded, and everyone will know that you have been healed."
5.15: News about Jesus kept spreading. Large crowds came to listen to him teach and to be healed of their diseases.
5.16: But Jesus would often go to some place where he could be alone and pray. Jesus Heals a Crippled Man(Matthew 9.1-8; Mark 2.1-12)
5.17: One day some Pharisees and experts in the Law of Moses sat listening to Jesus teach. They had come from every village in Galilee and Judea and from Jerusalem. God had given Jesus the power to heal the sick,
5.18: and some people came carrying a crippled man on a mat. They tried to take him inside the house and put him in front of Jesus.
5.19: But because of the crowd, they could not get him to Jesus. So they went up on the roof, where they removed some tiles and let the mat down in the middle of the room.
5.20: When Jesus saw how much faith they had, he said to the crippled man, "My friend, your sins are forgiven."
5.21: The Pharisees and the experts began arguing, "Jesus must think he is God! Only God can forgive sins."
5.22: Jesus knew what they were thinking, and he said, "Why are you thinking that?
5.23: Is it easier for me to tell this crippled man that his sins are forgiven or to tell him to get up and walk?
5.24: But now you will see that the Son of Man has the right to forgive sins here on earth." Jesus then said to the man, "Get up! Pick up your mat and walk home."
5.25: At once the man stood up in front of everyone. He picked up his mat and went home, giving thanks to God.
5.26: Everyone was amazed and praised God. What they saw surprised them, and they said, "We have seen a great miracle today!" Jesus Chooses Levi(Matthew 9.9-13; Mark 2.13-17)
5.27: Later, Jesus went out and saw a tax collector named Levi sitting at the place for paying taxes. Jesus said to him, "Come with me."
5.28: Levi left everything and went with Jesus.
5.29: In his home Levi gave a big dinner for Jesus. Many tax collectors and other guests were also there.
5.30: The Pharisees and some of their teachers of the Law of Moses grumbled to Jesus' disciples, "Why do you eat and drink with those tax collectors and other sinners?"
5.31: Jesus answered, "Healthy people don't need a doctor, but sick people do.
5.32: I didn't come to invite good people to turn to God. I came to invite sinners." People Ask about Going without Eating(Matthew 9.14-17; Mark 2.18-22)
5.33: Some people said to Jesus, "John's followers often pray and go without eating, and so do the followers of the Pharisees. But your disciples never go without eating or drinking."
5.34: Jesus told them, "The friends of a bridegroom don't go without eating while he is still with them.
5.35: But the time will come when he will be taken from them. Then they will go without eating."
5.36: Jesus then told them these sayings: No one uses a new piece of cloth to patch old clothes. The patch would shrink and make the hole even bigger.
5.37: No one pours new wine into old wineskins. The new wine would swell and burst the old skins. Then the wine would be lost, and the skins would be ruined.
5.38: New wine must be put only into new wineskins.
5.39: No one wants new wine after drinking old wine. They say, "The old wine is better."

6.1: One Sabbath when Jesus and his disciples were walking through some wheat fields, the disciples picked some wheat. They rubbed the husks off with their hands and started eating the grain.
6.2: Some Pharisees said, "Why are you picking grain on the Sabbath? You're not supposed to do that!"
6.3: Jesus answered, "You surely have read what David did when he and his followers were hungry.
6.4: He went into the house of God and took the sacred loaves of bread that only priests were supposed to eat. He not only ate some himself, but even gave some to his followers."
6.5: Jesus finished by saying, "The Son of Man is Lord over the Sabbath." A Man with a Crippled Hand(Matthew 12.9-14; Mark 3.1-6)
6.6: On another Sabbath Jesus was teaching in a Jewish meeting place, and a man with a crippled right hand was there.
6.7: Some Pharisees and teachers of the Law of Moses kept watching Jesus to see if he would heal the man. They did this because they wanted to accuse Jesus of doing something wrong.
6.8: Jesus knew what they were thinking. So he told the man to stand up where everyone could see him. And the man stood up.
6.9: Then Jesus asked, "On the Sabbath should we do good deeds or evil deeds? Should we save someone's life or destroy it?"
6.10: After he had looked around at everyone, he told the man, "Stretch out your hand." He did, and his bad hand became completely well.
6.11: The teachers and the Pharisees were furious and started saying to each other, "What can we do about Jesus?" Jesus Chooses His Twelve Apostles(Matthew 10.1-4; Mark 3.13-19)
6.12: About that time Jesus went off to a mountain to pray, and he spent the whole night there.
6.13: The next morning he called his disciples together and chose twelve of them to be his apostles.
6.14: One was Simon, and Jesus named him Peter. Another was Andrew, Peter's brother. There were also James, John, Philip, Bartholomew,
6.15: Matthew, Thomas, and James the son of Alphaeus. The rest of the apostles were Simon, known as the Eager One,
6.16: Jude, who was the son of James, and Judas Iscariot, who later betrayed Jesus. Jesus Teaches, Preaches, and Heals(Matthew 4.23-25)
6.17: Jesus and his apostles went down from the mountain and came to some flat, level ground. Many other disciples were there to meet him. Large crowds of people from all over Judea, Jerusalem, and the coastal cities of Tyre and Sidon were there too.
6.18: These people had come to listen to Jesus and to be healed of their diseases. All who were troubled by evil spirits were also healed.
6.19: Everyone was trying to touch Jesus, because power was going out from him and healing them all. Blessings and Troubles(Matthew 5.1-12)
6.20: Jesus looked at his disciples and said: God will bless you people who are poor. His kingdom belongs to you!
6.21: God will bless you hungry people. You will have plenty to eat! God will bless you people who are crying. You will laugh!
6.22: God will bless you when others hate you and won't have anything to do with you. God will bless you when people insult you and say cruel things about you, all because you are a follower of the Son of Man.
6.23: Long ago your own people did these same things to the prophets. So when this happens to you, be happy and jump for joy! You will have a great reward in heaven.
6.24: But you rich people are in for trouble. You have already had an easy life!
6.25: You well-fed people are in for trouble. You will go hungry! You people who are laughing now are in for trouble. You are going to cry and weep!
6.26: You are in for trouble when everyone says good things about you. That is what your own people said about those prophets who told lies. Love for Enemies(Matthew 5.38-48; 7.12a)
6.27: This is what I say to all who will listen to me: Love your enemies, and be good to everyone who hates you.
6.28: Ask God to bless anyone who curses you, and pray for everyone who is cruel to you.
6.29: If someone slaps you on one cheek, don't stop that person from slapping you on the other cheek. If someone wants to take your coat, don't try to keep back your shirt.
6.30: Give to everyone who asks and don't ask people to return what they have taken from you.
6.31: Treat others just as you want to be treated.
6.32: If you love only someone who loves you, will God praise you for that? Even sinners love people who love them.
6.33: If you are kind only to someone who is kind to you, will God be pleased with you for that? Even sinners are kind to people who are kind to them.
6.34: If you lend money only to someone you think will pay you back, will God be pleased with you for that? Even sinners lend to sinners because they think they will get it all back.
6.35: But love your enemies and be good to them. Lend without expecting to be paid back. Then you will get a great reward, and you will be the true children of God in heaven. He is good even to people who are unthankful and cruel.
6.36: Have pity on others, just as your Father has pity on you. Judging Others(Matthew 7.1-5)
6.37: Jesus said: Don't judge others, and God won't judge you. Don't be hard on others, and God won't be hard on you. Forgive others, and God will forgive you.
6.38: If you give to others, you will be given a full amount in return. It will be packed down, shaken together, and spilling over into your lap. The way you treat others is the way you will be treated.
6.39: Jesus also used some sayings as he spoke to the people. He said: Can one blind person lead another blind person? Won't they both fall into a ditch?
6.40: Are students better than their teacher? But when they are fully trained, they will be like their teacher.
6.41: You can see the speck in your friend's eye. But you don't notice the log in your own eye.
6.42: How can you say, "My friend, let me take the speck out of your eye," when you don't see the log in your own eye? You show-offs! First, get the log out of your own eye. Then you can see how to take the speck out of your friend's eye. A Tree and Its Fruit(Matthew 7.17-20; 12.34b,35)
6.43: A good tree cannot produce bad fruit, and a bad tree cannot produce good fruit.
6.44: You can tell what a tree is like by the fruit it produces. You cannot pick figs or grapes from thornbushes.
6.45: Good people do good things because of the good in their hearts. Bad people do bad things because of the evil in their hearts. Your words show what is in your heart. Two Builders(Matthew 7.24-27)
6.46: Why do you keep on saying that I am your Lord, when you refuse to do what I say?
6.47: Anyone who comes and listens to me and obeys me
6.48: is like someone who dug down deep and built a house on solid rock. When the flood came and the river rushed against the house, it was built so well that it didn't even shake.
6.49: But anyone who hears what I say and doesn't obey me is like someone whose house wasn't built on solid rock. As soon as the river rushed against that house, it was smashed to pieces!

7.1: After Jesus had finished teaching the people, he went to Capernaum.
7.2: In that town an army officer's servant was sick and about to die. The officer liked this servant very much.
7.3: And when he heard about Jesus, he sent some Jewish leaders to ask him to come and heal the servant.
7.4: The leaders went to Jesus and begged him to do something. They said, "This man deserves your help!
7.5: He loves our nation and even built us a meeting place."
7.6: So Jesus went with them. When Jesus wasn't far from the house, the officer sent some friends to tell him, "Lord, don't go to any trouble for me! I am not good enough for you to come into my house.
7.7: And I am certainly not worthy to come to you. Just say the word, and my servant will get well.
7.8: I have officers who give orders to me, and I have soldiers who take orders from me. I can say to one of them, 'Go!' and he goes. I can say to another, 'Come!' and he comes. I can say to my servant, 'Do this!' and he will do it."
7.9: When Jesus heard this, he was so surprised that he turned and said to the crowd following him, "In all of Israel I've never found anyone with this much faith!"
7.10: The officer's friends returned and found the servant well. A Widow's Son
7.11: Soon Jesus and his disciples were on their way to the town of Nain, and a big crowd was going along with them.
7.12: As they came near the gate of the town, they saw people carrying out the body of a widow's only son. Many people from the town were walking along with her.
7.13: When the Lord saw the woman, he felt sorry for her and said, "Don't cry!"
7.14: Jesus went over and touched the stretcher on which the people were carrying the dead boy. They stopped, and Jesus said, "Young man, get up!"
7.15: The boy sat up and began to speak. Jesus then gave him back to his mother.
7.16: Everyone was frightened and praised God. They said, "A great prophet is here with us! God has come to his people."
7.17: News about Jesus spread all over Judea and everywhere else in that part of the country. John the Baptist(Matthew 11.1-19)
7.18: John's followers told John everything that was being said about Jesus. So he sent two of them to ask the Lord, "Are you the one we should be looking for? Or must we wait for someone else?"
7.20: When these messengers came to Jesus, they said, "John the Baptist sent us to ask, 'Are you the one we should be looking for? Or are we supposed to wait for someone else?'"
7.21: At that time Jesus was healing many people who were sick or in pain or were troubled by evil spirits, and he was giving sight to a lot of blind people.
7.22: Jesus said to the messengers sent by John, "Go and tell John what you have seen and heard. Blind people are now able to see, and the lame can walk. People who have leprosy are being healed, and the deaf can now hear. The dead are raised to life, and the poor are hearing the good news.
7.23: God will bless everyone who doesn't reject me because of what I do."
7.24: After John's messengers had gone, Jesus began speaking to the crowds about John: What kind of person did you go out to the desert to see? Was he like tall grass blown about by the wind?
7.25: What kind of man did you really go out to see? Was he someone dressed in fine clothes? People who wear expensive clothes and live in luxury are in the king's palace.
7.26: What then did you go out to see? Was he a prophet? He certainly was! I tell you that he was more than a prophet.
7.27: In the Scriptures, God calls John his messenger and says, "I am sending my messenger ahead of you to get things ready for you."
7.28: No one ever born on this earth is greater than John. But whoever is least important in God's kingdom is greater than John.
7.29: Everyone had been listening to John. Even the tax collectors had obeyed God and had done what was right by letting John baptize them.
7.30: But the Pharisees and the experts in the Law of Moses refused to obey God and be baptized by John.
7.31: Jesus went on to say: What are you people like? What kind of people are you?
7.32: You are like children sitting in the market and shouting to each other, "We played the flute, but you would not dance! We sang a funeral song, but you would not cry!"
7.33: John the Baptist did not go around eating and drinking, and you said, "John has a demon in him!"
7.34: But because the Son of Man goes around eating and drinking, you say, "Jesus eats and drinks too much! He is even a friend of tax collectors and sinners."
7.35: Yet Wisdom is shown to be right by what its followers do. Simon the Pharisee
7.36: A Pharisee invited Jesus to have dinner with him. So Jesus went to the Pharisee's home and got ready to eat.
7.37: When a sinful woman in that town found out that Jesus was there, she bought an expensive bottle of perfume.
7.38: Then she came and stood behind Jesus. She cried and started washing his feet with her tears and drying them with her hair. The woman kissed his feet and poured the perfume on them.
7.39: The Pharisee who had invited Jesus saw this and said to himself, "If this man really were a prophet, he would know what kind of woman is touching him! He would know that she is a sinner."
7.40: Jesus said to the Pharisee, "Simon, I have something to say to you." "Teacher, what is it?" Simon replied.
7.41: Jesus told him, "Two people were in debt to a moneylender. One of them owed him five hundred silver coins, and the other owed him fifty.
7.42: Since neither of them could pay him back, the moneylender said that they didn't have to pay him anything. Which one of them will like him more?"
7.43: Simon answered, "I suppose it would be the one who had owed more and didn't have to pay it back." "You are right," Jesus said.
7.44: He turned toward the woman and said to Simon, "Have you noticed this woman? When I came into your home, you didn't give me any water so I could wash my feet. But she has washed my feet with her tears and dried them with her hair.
7.45: You didn't greet me with a kiss, but from the time I came in, she has not stopped kissing my feet.
7.46: You didn't even pour olive oil on my head, but she has poured expensive perfume on my feet.
7.47: So I tell you that all her sins are forgiven, and that is why she has shown great love. But anyone who has been forgiven for only a little will show only a little love."
7.48: Then Jesus said to the woman, "Your sins are forgiven."
7.49: Some other guests started saying to one another, "Who is this who dares to forgive sins?"
7.50: But Jesus told the woman, "Because of your faith, you are now saved. May God give you peace!"

8.1: Soon after this, Jesus was going through towns and villages, telling the good news about God's kingdom. His twelve apostles were with him,
8.2: and so were some women who had been healed of evil spirits and all sorts of diseases. One of the women was Mary Magdalene, who once had seven demons in her.
8.3: Joanna, Susanna, and many others had also used what they owned to help Jesus and his disciples. Joanna's husband Chuza was one of Herod's officials. A Story about a Farmer(Matthew 13.1-9; Mark 4.1-9)
8.4: When a large crowd from several towns had gathered around Jesus, he told them this story:
8.5: A farmer went out to scatter seed in a field. While the farmer was doing it, some of the seeds fell along the road and were stepped on or eaten by birds.
8.6: Other seeds fell on rocky ground and started growing. But the plants did not have enough water and soon dried up.
8.7: Some other seeds fell where thornbushes grew up and choked the plants.
8.8: The rest of the seeds fell on good ground where they grew and produced a hundred times as many seeds. When Jesus had finished speaking, he said, "If you have ears, pay attention!" Why Jesus Used Stories(Matthew 13.10-17; Mark 4.10-12)
8.9: Jesus' disciples asked him what the story meant.
8.10: So he answered: I have explained the secrets about God's kingdom to you, but for others I can only use stories. These people look, but they don't see, and they hear, but they don't understand. Jesus Explains the Story about a Farmer(Matthew 13.18-23; Mark 4.13-20)
8.11: This is what the story means: The seed is God's message,
8.12: and the seeds that fell along the road are the people who hear the message. But the devil comes and snatches the message out of their hearts, so that they will not believe and be saved.
8.13: The seeds that fell on rocky ground are the people who gladly hear the message and accept it. But they don't have deep roots, and they believe only for a little while. As soon as life gets hard, they give up.
8.14: The seeds that fell among the thornbushes are also people who hear the message. But they are so eager for riches and pleasures that they never produce anything.
8.15: Those seeds that fell on good ground are the people who listen to the message and keep it in good and honest hearts. They last and produce a harvest. Light(Mark 4.21-25)
8.16: No one lights a lamp and puts it under a bowl or under a bed. A lamp is always put on a lampstand, so that people who come into a house will see the light.
8.17: There is nothing hidden that will not be found. There is no secret that will not be well known.
8.18: Pay attention to how you listen! Everyone who has something will be given more, but people who have nothing will lose what little they think they have. Jesus' Mother and Brothers(Matthew 12.46-50; Mark 3.31-35)
8.19: Jesus' mother and brothers went to see him, but because of the crowd they could not get near him.
8.20: Someone told Jesus, "Your mother and brothers are standing outside and want to see you."
8.21: Jesus answered, "My mother and my brothers are those people who hear and obey God's message." A Storm(Matthew 8.23-27; Mark 4.35-41)
8.22: One day, Jesus and his disciples got into a boat, and he said, "Let's cross the lake." They started out,
8.23: and while they were sailing across, he went to sleep. Suddenly a windstorm struck the lake, and the boat started sinking. They were in danger.
8.24: So they went to Jesus and woke him up, "Master, Master! We are about to drown!" Jesus got up and ordered the wind and waves to stop. They obeyed, and everything was calm.
8.25: Then Jesus asked the disciples, "Don't you have any faith?" But they were frightened and amazed. They said to each other, "Who is this? He can give orders to the wind and the waves, and they obey him!" A Man with Demons in Him(Matthew 8.28-34; Mark 5.1-20)
8.26: Jesus and his disciples sailed across Lake Galilee and came to shore near the town of Gerasa.
8.27: As Jesus was getting out of the boat, he was met by a man from that town. The man had demons in him. He had gone naked for a long time and no longer lived in a house, but in the graveyard.
8.28: The man saw Jesus and screamed. He knelt down in front of him and shouted, "Jesus, Son of God in heaven, what do you want with me? I beg you not to torture me!"
8.29: He said this because Jesus had already told the evil spirit to go out of him. The man had often been attacked by the demon. And even though he had been bound with chains and leg irons and kept under guard, he smashed whatever bound him. Then the demon would force him out into lonely places.
8.30: Jesus asked the man, "What is your name?" He answered, "My name is Lots." He said this because there were 'lots' of demons in him.
8.31: They begged Jesus not to send them to the deep pit, where they would be punished.
8.32: A large herd of pigs was feeding there on the hillside. So the demons begged Jesus to let them go into the pigs, and Jesus let them go.
8.33: Then the demons left the man and went into the pigs. The whole herd rushed down the steep bank into the lake and drowned.
8.34: When the men taking care of the pigs saw this, they ran to spread the news in the town and on the farms.
8.35: The people went out to see what had happened, and when they came to Jesus, they also found the man. The demons had gone out of him, and he was sitting there at the feet of Jesus. He had clothes on and was in his right mind. But the people were terrified.
8.36: Then all who had seen the man healed told about it.
8.37: Everyone from around Gerasa begged Jesus to leave, because they were so frightened. When Jesus got into the boat to start back,
8.38: the man who had been healed begged to go with him. But Jesus sent him off and said,
8.39: "Go back home and tell everyone how much God has done for you." The man then went all over town, telling everything that Jesus had done for him. A Dying Girl and a Sick Woman(Matthew 9.18-26; Mark 5.21-43)
8.40: Everyone had been waiting for Jesus, and when he came back, a crowd was there to welcome him.
8.41: Just then the man in charge of the Jewish meeting place came and knelt down in front of Jesus. His name was Jairus, and he begged Jesus to come to his home
8.42: because his twelve-year-old child was dying. She was his only daughter. While Jesus was on his way, people were crowding all around him.
8.43: In the crowd was a woman who had been bleeding for twelve years. She had spent everything she had on doctors, but none of them could make her well.
8.44: As soon as she came up behind Jesus and barely touched his clothes, her bleeding stopped.
8.45: "Who touched me?" Jesus asked. While everyone was denying it, Peter said, "Master, people are crowding all around and pushing you from every side."
8.46: But Jesus answered, "Someone touched me, because I felt power going out from me."
8.47: The woman knew that she could not hide, so she came trembling and knelt down in front of Jesus. She told everyone why she had touched him and that she had been healed right away.
8.48: Jesus said to the woman, "You are now well because of your faith. May God give you peace!"
8.49: While Jesus was speaking, someone came from Jairus' home and said, "Your daughter has died! Why bother the teacher anymore?"
8.50: When Jesus heard this, he told Jairus, "Don't worry! Have faith, and your daughter will get well."
8.51: Jesus went into the house, but he did not let anyone else go with him, except Peter, John, James, and the girl's father and mother.
8.52: Everyone was crying and weeping for the girl. But Jesus said, "The child isn't dead. She is just asleep."
8.53: The people laughed at him because they knew she was dead.
8.54: Jesus took hold of the girl's hand and said, "Child, get up!"
8.55: She came back to life and got right up. Jesus told them to give her something to eat.
8.56: Her parents were surprised, but Jesus ordered them not to tell anyone what had happened.

9.1: Jesus called together his twelve apostles and gave them complete power over all demons and diseases.
9.2: Then he sent them to tell about God's kingdom and to heal the sick.
9.3: He told them, "Don't take anything with you! Don't take a walking stick or a traveling bag or food or money or even a change of clothes.
9.4: When you are welcomed into a home, stay there until you leave that town.
9.5: If people won't welcome you, leave the town and shake the dust from your feet as a warning to them."
9.6: The apostles left and went from village to village, telling the good news and healing people everywhere. Herod Is Worried(Matthew 14.1-12; Mark 6.14-29)
9.7: Herod the ruler heard about all that was happening, and he was worried. Some people were saying that John the Baptist had come back to life.
9.8: Others were saying that Elijah had come or that one of the prophets from long ago had come back to life.
9.9: But Herod said, "I had John's head cut off! Who is this I hear so much about?" Herod was eager to meet Jesus. Jesus Feeds Five Thousand(Matthew 14.13-21; Mark 6.30-44; John 6.1-14)
9.10: The apostles came back and told Jesus everything they had done. He then took them with him to the village of Bethsaida, where they could be alone.
9.11: But a lot of people found out about this and followed him. Jesus welcomed them. He spoke to them about God's kingdom and healed everyone who was sick.
9.12: Late in the afternoon the twelve apostles came to Jesus and said, "Send the crowd to the villages and farms around here. They need to find a place to stay and something to eat. There is nothing in this place. It is like a desert!"
9.13: Jesus answered, "You give them something to eat." But they replied, "We have only five small loaves of bread and two fish. If we are going to feed all these people, we will have to go and buy food."
9.14: There were about five thousand men in the crowd. Jesus said to his disciples, "Have the people sit in groups of fifty."
9.15: They did this, and all the people sat down.
9.16: Jesus took the five loaves and the two fish. He looked up toward heaven and blessed the food. Then he broke the bread and fish and handed them to his disciples to give to the people.
9.17: Everyone ate all they wanted. What was left over filled twelve baskets. Who Is Jesus?(Matthew 16.13-19; Mark 8.27-29)
9.18: When Jesus was alone praying, his disciples came to him, and he asked them, "What do people say about me?"
9.19: They answered, "Some say that you are John the Baptist or Elijah or a prophet from long ago who has come back to life."
9.20: Jesus then asked them, "But who do you say I am?" Peter answered, "You are the Messiah sent from God."
9.21: Jesus strictly warned his disciples not to tell anyone about this. Jesus Speaks about His Suffering and Death(Matthew 16.20-28; Mark 8.30--9.1)
9.22: Jesus told his disciples, "The nation's leaders, the chief priests, and the teachers of the Law of Moses will make the Son of Man suffer terribly. They will reject him and kill him, but three days later he will rise to life."
9.23: Then Jesus said to all the people: If any of you want to be my followers, you must forget about yourself. You must take up your cross each day and follow me.
9.24: If you want to save your life, you will destroy it. But if you give up your life for me, you will save it.
9.25: What will you gain, if you own the whole world but destroy yourself or waste your life?
9.26: If you are ashamed of me and my message, the Son of Man will be ashamed of you when he comes in his glory and in the glory of his Father and the holy angels.
