1.16: Such people claim to know God, but their actions prove that they really don't. They are disgusting. They won't obey God, and they are too worthless to do anything good.

2.1: Titus, you must teach only what is correct.
2.2: Tell the older men to have self-control and to be serious and sensible. Their faith, love, and patience must never fail.
2.3: Tell the older women to behave as those who love the Lord should. They must not gossip about others or be slaves of wine. They must teach what is proper,
2.4: so the younger women will be loving wives and mothers.
2.5: Each of the younger women must be sensible and kind, as well as a good homemaker, who puts her own husband first. Then no one can say insulting things about God's message.
2.6: Tell the young men to have self-control in everything.
2.7: Always set a good example for others. Be sincere and serious when you teach.
2.8: Use clean language that no one can criticize. Do this, and your enemies will be too ashamed to say anything against you.
2.9: Tell slaves always to please their owners by obeying them in everything. Slaves must not talk back to their owners
2.10: or steal from them. They must be completely honest and trustworthy. Then everyone will show great respect for what is taught about God our Savior. God's Kindness and the New Life
2.11: God has shown us how kind he is by coming to save all people.
2.12: He taught us to give up our wicked ways and our worldly desires and to live decent and honest lives in this world.
2.13: We are filled with hope, as we wait for the glorious return of our great God and Savior Jesus Christ.
2.14: He gave himself to rescue us from everything that is evil and to make our hearts pure. He wanted us to be his own people and to be eager to do right.
2.15: Teach these things, as you use your full authority to encourage and correct people. Make sure you earn everyone's respect.

3.1: Remind your people to obey the rulers and authorities and not to be rebellious. They must always be ready to do something helpful
3.2: and not say cruel things or argue. They should be gentle and kind to everyone.
3.3: We used to be stupid, disobedient, and foolish, as well as slaves of all sorts of desires and pleasures. We were evil and jealous. Everyone hated us, and we hated everyone.
3.4: God our Savior showed us how good and kind he is.
3.5: He saved us because of his mercy, and not because of any good things that we have done. God washed us by the power of the Holy Spirit. He gave us new birth and a fresh beginning.
3.6: God sent Jesus Christ our Savior to give us his Spirit.
3.7: Jesus treated us much better than we deserve. He made us acceptable to God and gave us the hope of eternal life.
3.8: This message is certainly true. These teachings are useful and helpful for everyone. I want you to insist that the people follow them, so that all who have faith in God will be sure to do good deeds.
3.9: But don't have anything to do with stupid arguments about ancestors. And stay away from disagreements and quarrels about the Law of Moses. Such arguments are useless and senseless.
3.10: Warn troublemakers once or twice. Then don't have anything else to do with them.
3.11: You know that their minds are twisted, and their own sins show how guilty they are. Personal Instructions and Greetings
3.12: I plan to send Artemas or Tychicus to you. After he arrives, please try your best to meet me at Nicopolis. I have decided to spend the winter there.
3.13: When Zenas the lawyer and Apollos get ready to leave, help them as much as you can, so they won't have need of anything.
3.14: Our people should learn to spend their time doing something useful and worthwhile.
3.15: Greetings to you from everyone here. Greet all of our friends who share in our faith. I pray that the Lord will be kind to all of you!

1.1: Long ago in many ways and at many times God's prophets spoke his message to our ancestors.
1.2: But now at last, God sent his Son to bring his message to us. God created the universe by his Son, and everything will someday belong to the Son.
1.3: God's Son has all the brightness of God's own glory and is like him in every way. By his own mighty word, he holds the universe together. After the Son had washed away our sins, he sat down at the right side of the glorious God in heaven.
1.4: He had become much greater than the angels, and the name he was given is far greater than any of theirs. God's Son Is Greater than Angels
1.5: God has never said to any of the angels, "You are my Son, because today I have become your Father!" Neither has God said to any of them, "I will be his Father, and he will be my Son!"
1.6: When God brings his first-born Son into the world, he commands all of his angels to worship him.
1.7: And when God speaks about the angels, he says, "I change my angels into wind and my servants into flaming fire."
1.8: But God says about his Son, "You are God, and you will rule as King forever! Your royal power brings about justice.
1.9: You loved justice and hated evil, and so I, your God, have chosen you. I appointed you and made you happier than any of your friends."
1.10: The Scriptures also say, "In the beginning, Lord, you were the one who laid the foundation of the earth and created the heavens.
1.11: They will all disappear and wear out like clothes, but you will last forever.
1.12: You will roll them up like a robe and change them like a garment. But you are always the same, and you will live forever."
1.13: God never said to any of the angels, "Sit at my right side until I make your enemies into a footstool for you!"
1.14: Angels are merely spirits sent to serve people who are going to be saved.

2.1: We must give our full attention to what we were told, so that we won't drift away.
2.2: The message spoken by angels proved to be true, and all who disobeyed or rejected it were punished as they deserved.
2.3: So if we refuse this great way of being saved, how can we hope to escape? The Lord himself was the first to tell about it, and people who heard the message proved to us that it was true.
2.4: God himself showed that his message was true by working all kinds of powerful miracles and wonders. He also gave his Holy Spirit to anyone he chose to. The One Who Leads Us To Be Saved
2.5: We know that God did not put the future world under the power of angels.
2.6: Somewhere in the Scriptures someone says to God, "What makes you care about us humans? Why are you concerned for weaklings such as we?
2.7: You made us lower than the angels for a while. Yet you have crowned us with glory and honor.
2.8: And you have put everything under our power!" God has put everything under our power and has not left anything out of our power. But we still don't see it all under our power.
2.9: What we do see is Jesus, who for a little while was made lower than the angels. Because of God's wonderful kindness, Jesus died for everyone. And now that Jesus has suffered and died, he is crowned with glory and honor!
2.10: Everything belongs to God, and all things were created by his power. So God did the right thing when he made Jesus perfect by suffering, as Jesus led many of God's children to be saved and to share in his glory.
2.11: Jesus and the people he makes holy all belong to the same family. That is why he isn't ashamed to call them his brothers and sisters.
2.12: He even said to God, "I will tell them your name and sing your praises when they come together to worship."
2.13: He also said, "I will trust God." Then he said, "Here I am with the children God has given me."
2.14: We are people of flesh and blood. That is why Jesus became one of us. He died to destroy the devil, who had power over death.
2.15: But he also died to rescue all of us who live each day in fear of dying.
2.16: Jesus clearly did not come to help angels, but he did come to help Abraham's descendants.
2.17: He had to be one of us, so that he could serve God as our merciful and faithful high priest and sacrifice himself for the forgiveness of our sins.
2.18: And now that Jesus has suffered and was tempted, he can help anyone else who is tempted.

3.1: My friends, God has chosen you to be his holy people. So think about Jesus, the one we call our apostle and high priest!
3.2: Jesus was faithful to God, who appointed him, just as Moses was faithful in serving all of God's people.
3.3: But Jesus deserves more honor than Moses, just as the builder of a house deserves more honor than the house.
3.4: Of course, every house is built by someone, and God is really the one who built everything.
3.5: Moses was a faithful servant and told God's people what would be said in the future.
3.6: But Christ is the Son in charge of God's people. And we are those people, if we keep on being brave and don't lose hope. A Rest for God's People
3.7: It is just as the Holy Spirit says, "If you hear God's voice today,
3.8: don't be stubborn! Don't rebel like those people who were tested in the desert.
3.9: For forty years your ancestors tested God and saw the things he did.
3.10: "Then God got tired of them and said, 'You people never show good sense, and you don't understand what I want you to do.'
3.11: God became angry and told the people, 'You will never enter my place of rest!'"
3.12: My friends, watch out! Don't let evil thoughts or doubts make any of you turn from the living God.
3.13: You must encourage one another each day. And you must keep on while there is still a time that can be called "today." If you don't, then sin may fool some of you and make you stubborn.
3.14: We were sure about Christ when we first became his people. So let's hold tightly to our faith until the end.
3.15: The Scriptures say, "If you hear his voice today, don't be stubborn like those who rebelled."
3.16: Who were those people that heard God's voice and rebelled? Weren't they the same ones that came out of Egypt with Moses?
3.17: Who were the people that made God angry for forty years? Weren't they the ones that sinned and died in the desert?
3.18: And who did God say would never enter his place of rest? Weren't they the ones that disobeyed him?
3.19: We see that those people did not enter the place of rest because they did not have faith.

4.1: The promise to enter the place of rest is still good, and we must take care that none of you miss out.
4.2: We have heard the message, just as they did. But they failed to believe what they heard, and the message did not do them any good.
4.3: Only people who have faith will enter the place of rest. It is just as the Scriptures say, "God became angry and told the people, 'You will never enter my place of rest!'" God said this, even though everything has been ready from the time of creation.
4.4: In fact, somewhere the Scriptures say that by the seventh day, God had finished his work, and so he rested.
4.5: We also read that he later said, "You people will never enter my place of rest!"
4.6: This means that the promise to enter is still good, because those who first heard about it disobeyed and did not enter.
4.7: Much later God told David to make the promise again, just as I have already said, "If you hear his voice today, don't be stubborn!"
4.8: If Joshua had really given the people rest, there would not be any need for God to talk about another day of rest.
4.9: But God has promised us a Sabbath when we will rest, even though it has not yet come.
4.10: On that day God's people will rest from their work, just as God rested from his work.
4.11: We should do our best to enter that place of rest, so that none of us will disobey and miss going there, as they did.
4.12: What God has said isn't only alive and active! It is sharper than any double-edged sword. His word can cut through our spirits and souls and through our joints and marrow, until it discovers the desires and thoughts of our hearts.
4.13: Nothing is hidden from God! He sees through everything, and we will have to tell him the truth. Jesus Is the Great High Priest
4.14: We have a great high priest, who has gone into heaven, and he is Jesus the Son of God. That is why we must hold on to what we have said about him.
4.15: Jesus understands every weakness of ours, because he was tempted in every way that we are. But he did not sin!
4.16: So whenever we are in need, we should come bravely before the throne of our merciful God. There we will be treated with undeserved kindness, and we will find help.

5.1: Every high priest is appointed to help others by offering gifts and sacrifices to God because of their sins.
5.2: A high priest has weaknesses of his own, and he feels sorry for foolish and sinful people.
5.3: That is why he must offer sacrifices for his own sins and for the sins of others.
5.4: But no one can have the honor of being a high priest simply by wanting to be one. Only God can choose a priest, and God is the one who chose Aaron.
5.5: That is how it was with Christ. He became a high priest, but not just because he wanted the honor of being one. It was God who told him, "You are my Son, because today I have become your Father!"
5.6: In another place, God says, "You are a priest forever just like Melchizedek."
5.7: God had the power to save Jesus from death. And while Jesus was on earth, he begged God with loud crying and tears to save him. He truly worshiped God, and God listened to his prayers.
5.8: Jesus is God's own Son, but still he had to suffer before he could learn what it really means to obey God.
5.9: Suffering made Jesus perfect, and now he can save forever all who obey him.
5.10: This is because God chose him to be a high priest like Melchizedek. Warning against Turning Away
5.11: Much more could be said about this subject. But it is hard to explain, and all of you are slow to understand.
5.12: By now you should have been teachers, but once again you need to be taught the simplest things about what God has said. You need milk instead of solid food.
5.13: People who live on milk are like babies who don't really know what is right.
5.14: Solid food is for mature people who have been trained to know right from wrong.

6.1: We must try to become mature and start thinking about more than just the basic things we were taught about Christ. We shouldn't need to keep talking about why we ought to turn from deeds that bring death and why we ought to have faith in God.
6.2: And we shouldn't need to keep teaching about baptisms or about the laying on of hands or about people being raised from death and the future judgment.
6.3: Let's grow up, if God is willing.
6.4: But what about people who turn away after they have already seen the light and have received the gift from heaven and have shared in the Holy Spirit? What about those who turn away after they have received the good message of God and the powers of the future world? There is no way to bring them back. What they are doing is the same as nailing the Son of God to a cross and insulting him in public!
6.7: A field is useful to farmers, if there is enough rain to make good crops grow. In fact, God will bless that field.
6.8: But land that produces only thornbushes is worthless. It is likely to fall under God's curse, and in the end it will be set on fire.
6.9: My friends, we are talking this way. But we are sure that you are doing those really good things that people do when they are being saved.
6.10: God is always fair. He will remember how you helped his people in the past and how you are still helping them. You belong to God, and he won't forget the love you have shown his people.
6.11: We wish that each of you would always be eager to show how strong and lasting your hope really is.
6.12: Then you would never be lazy. You would be following the example of those who had faith and were patient until God kept his promise to them. God's Promise Is Sure
6.13: No one is greater than God. So he made a promise in his own name when he said to Abraham,
6.14: "I, the Lord, will bless you with many descendants!"
6.15: Then after Abraham had been very patient, he was given what God had promised.
6.16: When anyone wants to settle an argument, they make a vow by using the name of someone or something greater than themselves.
6.17: So when God wanted to prove for certain that his promise to his people could not be broken, he made a vow.
6.18: God cannot tell lies! And so his promises and vows are two things that can never be changed. We have run to God for safety. Now his promises should greatly encourage us to take hold of the hope that is right in front of us.
6.19: This hope is like a firm and steady anchor for our souls. In fact, hope reaches behind the curtain and into the most holy place.
6.20: Jesus has gone there ahead of us, and he is our high priest forever, just like Melchizedek.

7.1: Melchizedek was both king of Salem and priest of God Most High. He was the one who went out and gave Abraham his blessing, when Abraham returned from killing the kings.
7.2: Then Abraham gave him a tenth of everything he had. The meaning of the name Melchizedek is "King of Justice." But since Salem means "peace," he is also "King of Peace."
7.3: We are not told that he had a father or mother or ancestors or beginning or end. He is like the Son of God and will be a priest forever.
7.4: Notice how great Melchizedek is! Our famous ancestor Abraham gave him a tenth of what he had taken from his enemies.
7.5: The Law teaches that even Abraham's descendants must give a tenth of what they possess. And they are to give this to their own relatives, who are the descendants of Levi and are priests.
7.6: Although Melchizedek wasn't a descendant of Levi, Abraham gave him a tenth of what he had. Then Melchizedek blessed Abraham, who had been given God's promise.
7.7: Everyone agrees that a person who gives a blessing is greater than the one who receives the blessing.
7.8: Priests are given a tenth of what people earn. But all priests die, except Melchizedek, and the Scriptures teach that he is alive.
7.9: Levi's descendants are now the ones who receive a tenth from people. We could even say that when Abraham gave Melchizedek a tenth, Levi also gave him a tenth.
7.10: This is because Levi was born later into the family of Abraham, who gave a tenth to Melchizedek.
7.11: Even though the Law of Moses says that the priests must be descendants of Levi, those priests cannot make anyone perfect. So there needs to be a priest like Melchizedek, rather than one from the priestly family of Aaron.
7.12: And when the rules for selecting a priest are changed, the Law must also be changed.
7.13: The person we are talking about is our Lord, who came from a tribe that had never had anyone to serve as a priest at the altar.
7.14: Everyone knows he came from the tribe of Judah, and Moses never said that priests would come from that tribe.
7.15: All of this becomes clearer, when someone who is like Melchizedek is appointed to be a priest.
7.16: That person wasn't appointed because of his ancestors, but because his life can never end.
7.17: The Scriptures say about him, "You are a priest forever, just like Melchizedek."
7.18: In this way a weak and useless command was put aside,
7.19: because the Law cannot make anything perfect. At the same time, we are given a much better hope, and it can bring us close to God.
7.20: God himself made a promise when this priest was appointed. But he did not make a promise like this when the other priests were appointed. The promise he made is, "I, the Lord, promise that you will be a priest forever! And I will never change my mind!"
7.22: This means that Jesus guarantees us a better agreement with God.
7.23: There have been a lot of other priests, and all of them have died.
7.24: But Jesus will never die, and so he will be a priest forever!
7.25: He is forever able to save the people he leads to God, because he always lives to speak to God for them.
7.26: Jesus is the high priest we need. He is holy and innocent and faultless, and not at all like us sinners. Jesus is honored above all beings in heaven,
7.27: and he is better than any other high priest. Jesus doesn't need to offer sacrifices each day for his own sins and then for the sins of the people. He offered a sacrifice once for all, when he gave himself.
7.28: The Law appoints priests who have weaknesses. But God's promise, which came later than the Law, appoints his Son. And he is the perfect high priest forever.

8.1: What I mean is that we have a high priest who sits at the right side of God's great throne in heaven.
8.2: He also serves as the priest in the most holy place inside the real tent there in heaven. This tent of worship was set up by the Lord, not by humans.
8.3: Since all priests must offer gifts and sacrifices, Christ also needed to have something to offer.
8.4: If he were here on earth, he would not be a priest at all, because here the Law appoints other priests to offer sacrifices.
8.5: But the tent where they serve is just a copy and a shadow of the real one in heaven. Before Moses made the tent, he was told, "Be sure to make it exactly like the pattern you were shown on the mountain!"
8.6: Now Christ has been appointed to serve as a priest in a much better way, and he has given us much assurance of a better agreement.
8.7: If the first agreement with God had been all right, there would not have been any need for another one.
8.8: But the Lord found fault with it and said, "I tell you the time will come, when I will make a new agreement with the people of Israel and the people of Judah.
8.9: It won't be like the agreement that I made with their ancestors, when I took them by the hand and led them out of Egypt. They broke their agreement with me, and I stopped caring about them!
8.10: "But now I tell the people of Israel this is my new agreement: 'The time will come when I, the Lord, will write my laws on their minds and hearts. I will be their God, and they will be my people.
8.11: Not one of them will have to teach another to know me, their Lord.' "All of them will know me, no matter who they are.
8.12: I will treat them with kindness, even though they are wicked. I will forget their sins."
8.13: When the Lord talks about a new agreement, he means that the first one is out of date. And anything that is old and useless will soon disappear.

9.1: The first promise that was made included rules for worship and a tent for worship here on earth.
9.2: The first part of the tent was called the holy place, and a lampstand, a table, and the sacred loaves of bread were kept there.
9.3: Behind the curtain was the most holy place.
9.4: The gold altar that was used for burning incense was in this holy place. The gold-covered sacred chest was also there, and inside it were three things. First, there was a gold jar filled with manna. Then there was Aaron's walking stick that sprouted. Finally, there were the flat stones with the Ten Commandments written on them.
9.5: On top of the chest were the glorious creatures with wings opened out above the place of mercy. Now isn't the time to go into detail about these things.
9.6: But this is how everything was when the priests went each day into the first part of the tent to do their duties.
9.7: However, only the high priest could go into the second part of the tent, and he went in only once a year. Each time he carried blood to offer for his sins and for any sins that the people had committed without meaning to.
9.8: All of this is the Holy Spirit's way of saying that no one could enter the most holy place while the tent was still the place of worship.
9.9: This also has a meaning for today. It shows that we cannot make our consciences clear by offering gifts and sacrifices.
9.10: These rules are merely about such things as eating and drinking and ceremonies for washing ourselves. And rules about physical things will last only until the time comes to change them for something better.
9.11: Christ came as the high priest of the good things that are now here. He also went into a much better tent that wasn't made by humans and that doesn't belong to this world.
9.12: Then Christ went once for all into the most holy place and freed us from sin forever. He did this by offering his own blood instead of the blood of goats and bulls.
9.13: According to the Law of Moses, those people who become unclean are not fit to worship God. Yet they will be considered clean, if they are sprinkled with the blood of goats and bulls and with the ashes of a sacrificed calf.
9.14: But Christ was sinless, and he offered himself as an eternal and spiritual sacrifice to God. That's why his blood is much more powerful and makes our consciences clear. Now we can serve the living God and no longer do things that lead to death.
9.15: Christ died to rescue those who had sinned and broken the old agreement. Now he brings his chosen ones a new agreement with its guarantee of God's eternal blessings!
9.16: In fact, making an agreement of this kind is like writing a will. This is because the one who makes the will must die before it is of any use.
9.17: In other words, a will doesn't go into effect as long as the one who made it is still alive.
9.18: Blood was also used to put the first agreement into effect.
9.19: Moses told the people all that the Law said they must do. Then he used red wool and a hyssop plant to sprinkle the people and the book of the Law with the blood of bulls and goats and with water.
9.20: He told the people, "With this blood God makes his agreement with you."
9.21: Moses also sprinkled blood on the tent and on everything else that was used in worship.
9.22: The Law says that almost everything must be sprinkled with blood, and no sins can be forgiven unless blood is offered. Christ's Great Sacrifice
9.23: These things are only copies of what is in heaven, and so they had to be made holy by these ceremonies. But the real things in heaven must be made holy by something better.
9.24: This is why Christ did not go into a tent that had been made by humans and was only a copy of the real one. Instead, he went into heaven and is now there with God to help us.
9.25: Christ did not have to offer himself many times. He wasn't like a high priest who goes into the most holy place each year to offer the blood of an animal.
9.26: If he had offered himself every year, he would have suffered many times since the creation of the world. But instead, near the end of time he offered himself once and for all, so that he could be a sacrifice that does away with sin.
9.27: We die only once, and then we are judged.
9.28: So Christ died only once to take away the sins of many people. But when he comes again, it will not be to take away sin. He will come to save everyone who is waiting for him.

10.1: The Law of Moses is like a shadow of the good things to come. This shadow isn't the good things themselves, because it cannot free people from sin by the sacrifices that are offered year after year.
10.2: If there were worshipers who already have their sins washed away and their consciences made clear, there would not be any need to go on offering sacrifices.
10.3: But the blood of bulls and goats cannot take away sins. It only reminds people of their sins from one year to the next.
10.5: When Christ came into the world, he said to God, "Sacrifices and offerings are not what you want, but you have given me my body.
10.6: No, you are not pleased with animal sacrifices and offerings for sin."
10.7: Then Christ said, "And so, my God, I have come to do what you want, as the Scriptures say."
10.8: The Law teaches that offerings and sacrifices must be made because of sin. But why did Christ mention these things and say that God did not want them?
10.9: Well, it was to do away with offerings and sacrifices and to replace them. That is what he meant by saying to God, "I have come to do what you want."
10.10: So we are made holy because Christ obeyed God and offered himself once for all.
10.11: The priests do their work each day, and they keep on offering sacrifices that can never take away sins.
10.12: But Christ offered himself as a sacrifice that is good forever. Now he is sitting at God's right side,
10.13: and he will stay there until his enemies are put under his power.
10.14: By his one sacrifice he has forever set free from sin the people he brings to God.
10.15: The Holy Spirit also speaks of this by telling us that the Lord said,
10.16: "When the time comes, I will make an agreement with them. I will write my laws on their minds and hearts.
10.17: Then I will forget about their sins and no longer remember their evil deeds."
10.18: When sins are forgiven, there is no more need to offer sacrifices. Encouragement and Warning
10.19: My friends, the blood of Jesus gives us courage to enter the most holy place
10.20: by a new way that leads to life! And this way takes us through the curtain that is Christ himself.
10.21: We have a great high priest who is in charge of God's house.
10.22: So let's come near God with pure hearts and a confidence that comes from having faith. Let's keep our hearts pure, our consciences free from evil, and our bodies washed with clean water.
10.23: We must hold tightly to the hope that we say is ours. After all, we can trust the one who made the agreement with us.
10.24: We should keep on encouraging each other to be thoughtful and to do helpful things.
10.25: Some people have gotten out of the habit of meeting for worship, but we must not do that. We should keep on encouraging each other, especially since you know that the day of the Lord's coming is getting closer.
10.26: No sacrifices can be made for people who decide to sin after they find out about the truth.
10.27: They are God's enemies, and all they can look forward to is a terrible judgment and a furious fire.
10.28: If two or more witnesses accused someone of breaking the Law of Moses, that person could be put to death.
10.29: But it is much worse to dishonor God's Son and to disgrace the blood of the promise that made us holy. And it is just as bad to insult the Holy Spirit, who shows us mercy.
10.30: We know that God has said he will punish and take revenge. We also know that the Scriptures say the Lord will judge his people.
10.31: It is a terrible thing to fall into the hands of the living God!
10.32: Don't forget all the hard times you went through when you first received the light.
10.33: Sometimes you were abused and mistreated in public, and at other times you shared in the sufferings of others.
10.34: You were kind to people in jail. And you gladly let your possessions be taken away, because you knew you had something better, something that would last forever.
10.35: Keep on being brave! It will bring you great rewards.
10.36: Learn to be patient, so that you will please God and be given what he has promised.
10.37: As the Scriptures say, "God is coming soon! It won't be very long.
10.38: The people God accepts will live because of their faith. But he isn't pleased with anyone who turns back."
10.39: We are not like those people who turn back and get destroyed. We will keep on having faith until we are saved.

11.1: Faith makes us sure of what we hope for and gives us proof of what we cannot see.
11.2: It was their faith that made our ancestors pleasing to God.
11.3: Because of our faith, we know that the world was made at God's command. We also know that what can be seen was made out of what cannot be seen.
11.4: Because Abel had faith, he offered God a better sacrifice than Cain did. God was pleased with him and his gift, and even though Abel is now dead, his faith still speaks for him.
11.5: Enoch had faith and did not die. He pleased God, and God took him up to heaven. That's why his body was never found.
11.6: But without faith no one can please God. We must believe that God is real and that he rewards everyone who searches for him.
11.7: Because Noah had faith, he was warned about something that had not yet happened. He obeyed and built a boat that saved him and his family. In this way the people of the world were judged, and Noah was given the blessings that come to everyone who pleases God.
11.8: Abraham had faith and obeyed God. He was told to go to the land that God had said would be his, and he left for a country he had never seen.
11.9: Because Abraham had faith, he lived as a stranger in the promised land. He lived there in a tent, and so did Isaac and Jacob, who were later given the same promise.
11.10: Abraham did this, because he was waiting for the eternal city that God had planned and built.
11.11: Even when Sarah was too old to have children, she had faith that God would do what he had promised, and she had a son.
11.12: Her husband Abraham was almost dead, but he became the ancestor of many people. In fact, there are as many of them as there are stars in the sky or grains of sand along the beach.
11.13: Every one of those people died. But they still had faith, even though they had not received what they had been promised. They were glad just to see these things from far away, and they agreed that they were only strangers and foreigners on this earth.
11.14: When people talk this way, it is clear that they are looking for a place to call their own.
11.15: If they had been talking about the land where they had once lived, they could have gone back at any time.
11.16: But they were looking forward to a better home in heaven. That's why God wasn't ashamed for them to call him their God. He even built a city for them.
11.17: Abraham had been promised that Isaac, his only son, would continue his family. But when Abraham was tested, he had faith and was willing to sacrifice Isaac,
11.19: because he was sure that God could raise people to life. This was just like getting Isaac back from death.
11.20: Isaac had faith, and he promised blessings to Jacob and Esau.
11.21: Later, when Jacob was about to die, he leaned on his walking stick and worshiped. Then because of his faith he blessed each of Joseph's sons.
11.22: And right before Joseph died, he had faith that God would lead the people of Israel out of Egypt. So he told them to take his bones with them.
11.23: Because Moses' parents had faith, they kept him hidden until he was three months old. They saw that he was a beautiful child, and they were not afraid to disobey the king's orders.
11.24: Then after Moses grew up, his faith made him refuse to be called Pharaoh's grandson.
11.25: He chose to be mistreated with God's people instead of having the good time that sin could bring for a little while.
11.26: Moses knew that the treasures of Egypt were not as wonderful as what he would receive from suffering for the Messiah, and he looked forward to his reward.
11.27: Because of his faith, Moses left Egypt. Moses had seen the invisible God and wasn't afraid of the king's anger.
11.28: His faith also made him celebrate Passover. He sprinkled the blood of animals on the doorposts, so that the first-born sons of the people of Israel would not be killed by the destroying angel.
11.29: Because of their faith, the people walked through the Red Sea on dry land. But when the Egyptians tried to do it, they were drowned.
11.30: God's people had faith, and when they had walked around the city of Jericho for seven days, its walls fell down.
11.31: Rahab had been a prostitute, but she had faith and welcomed the spies. So she wasn't killed with the people who disobeyed.
11.32: What else can I say? There isn't enough time to tell about Gideon, Barak, Samson, Jephthah, David, Samuel, and the prophets.
11.33: Their faith helped them conquer kingdoms, and because they did right, God made promises to them. They closed the jaws of lions
11.34: and put out raging fires and escaped from the swords of their enemies. Although they were weak, they were given the strength and power to chase foreign armies away.
11.35: Some women received their loved ones back from death. Many of these people were tortured, but they refused to be released. They were sure that they would get a better reward when the dead are raised to life.
11.36: Others were made fun of and beaten with whips, and some were chained in jail.
11.37: Still others were stoned to death or sawed in two or killed with swords. Some had nothing but sheep skins or goat skins to wear. They were poor, mistreated, and tortured.
11.38: The world did not deserve these good people, who had to wander in deserts and on mountains and had to live in caves and holes in the ground.
11.39: All of them pleased God because of their faith! But still they died without being given what had been promised.
11.40: This was because God had something better in store for us. And he did not want them to reach the goal of their faith without us.

12.1: Such a large crowd of witnesses is all around us! So we must get rid of everything that slows us down, especially the sin that just won't let go. And we must be determined to run the race that is ahead of us.
12.2: We must keep our eyes on Jesus, who leads us and makes our faith complete. He endured the shame of being nailed to a cross, because he knew that later on he would be glad he did. Now he is seated at the right side of God's throne!
12.3: So keep your mind on Jesus, who put up with many insults from sinners. Then you won't get discouraged and give up.
12.4: None of you have yet been hurt in your battle against sin.
12.5: But you have forgotten that the Scriptures say to God's children, "When the Lord punishes you, don't make light of it, and when he corrects you, don't be discouraged.
12.6: The Lord corrects the people he loves and disciplines those he calls his own."
12.7: Be patient when you are being corrected! This is how God treats his children. Don't all parents correct their children?
12.8: God corrects all of his children, and if he doesn't correct you, then you don't really belong to him.
12.9: Our earthly fathers correct us, and we still respect them. Isn't it even better to be given true life by letting our spiritual Father correct us?
12.10: Our human fathers correct us for a short time, and they do it as they think best. But God corrects us for our own good, because he wants us to be holy, as he is.
12.11: It is never fun to be corrected. In fact, at the time it is always painful. But if we learn to obey by being corrected, we will do right and live at peace.
12.12: Now stand up straight! Stop your knees from shaking
12.13: and walk a straight path. Then lame people will be healed, instead of getting worse. Warning against Turning from God
12.14: Try to live at peace with everyone! Live a clean life. If you don't, you will never see the Lord.
12.15: Make sure that no one misses out on God's wonderful kindness. Don't let anyone become bitter and cause trouble for the rest of you.
12.16: Watch out for immoral and ungodly people like Esau, who sold his future blessing for only one meal.
12.17: You know how he later wanted it back. But there was nothing he could do to change things, even though he begged his father and cried.
12.18: You have not come to a place like Mount Sinai that can be seen and touched. There is no flaming fire or dark cloud or storm
12.19: or trumpet sound. The people of Israel heard a voice speak. But they begged it to stop,
12.20: because they could not obey its commands. They were even told to kill any animal that touched the mountain.
12.21: The sight was so frightening that Moses said he shook with fear.
12.22: You have now come to Mount Zion and to the heavenly Jerusalem. This is the city of the living God, where thousands and thousands of angels have come to celebrate.
12.23: Here you will find all of God's dearest children, whose names are written in heaven. And you will find God himself, who judges everyone. Here also are the spirits of those good people who have been made perfect.
12.24: And Jesus is here! He is the one who makes God's new agreement with us, and his sprinkled blood says much better things than the blood of Abel.
12.25: Make sure that you obey the one who speaks to you. The people did not escape, when they refused to obey the one who spoke to them at Mount Sinai. Do you think you can possibly escape, if you refuse to obey the one who speaks to you from heaven?
12.26: When God spoke the first time, his voice shook only the earth. This time he has promised to shake the earth once again, and heaven too.
12.27: The words "once again" mean that these created things will someday be shaken and removed. Then what cannot be shaken will last.
12.28: We should be grateful that we were given a kingdom that cannot be shaken. And in this kingdom we please God by worshiping him and by showing him great honor and respect.
12.29: Our God is like a destructive fire!

13.1: Keep being concerned about each other as the Lord's followers should.
13.2: Be sure to welcome strangers into your home. By doing this, some people have welcomed angels as guests, without even knowing it.
13.3: Remember the Lord's people who are in jail and be concerned for them. Don't forget those who are suffering, but imagine that you are there with them.
13.4: Have respect for marriage. Always be faithful to your partner, because God will punish anyone who is immoral or unfaithful in marriage.
13.5: Don't fall in love with money. Be satisfied with what you have. The Lord has promised that he will not leave us or desert us.
13.6: That should make you feel like saying, "The Lord helps me! Why should I be afraid of what people can do to me?"
13.7: Don't forget about your leaders who taught you God's message. Remember what kind of lives they lived and try to have faith like theirs.
13.8: Jesus Christ never changes! He is the same yesterday, today, and forever.
13.9: Don't be fooled by any kind of strange teachings. It is better to receive strength from God's undeserved kindness than to depend on certain foods. After all, these foods don't really help the people who eat them.
13.10: But we have an altar where even the priests who serve in the place of worship have no right to eat.
13.11: After the high priest offers the blood of animals as a sin offering, the bodies of those animals are burned outside the camp.
13.12: Jesus himself suffered outside the city gate, so that his blood would make people holy.
13.13: That's why we should go outside the camp to Jesus and share in his disgrace.
13.14: On this earth we don't have a city that lasts forever, but we are waiting for such a city.
13.15: Our sacrifice is to keep offering praise to God in the name of Jesus.
13.16: But don't forget to help others and to share your possessions with them. This too is like offering a sacrifice that pleases God.
13.17: Obey your leaders and do what they say. They are watching over you, and they must answer to God. So don't make them sad as they do their work. Make them happy. Otherwise, they won't be able to help you at all.
13.18: Pray for us. Our consciences are clear, and we always try to live right.
13.19: I especially want you to pray that I can visit you again soon. Final Prayers and Greetings
13.20: God gives peace, and he raised our Lord Jesus Christ from death. Now Jesus is like a Great Shepherd whose blood was used to make God's eternal agreement with his flock.
13.21: I pray that God will make you ready to obey him and that you will always be eager to do right. May Jesus help you do what pleases God. To Jesus Christ be glory forever and ever! Amen.
13.22: My friends, I have written only a short letter to encourage you, and I beg you to pay close attention to what I have said.
13.23: By now you surely must know that our friend Timothy is out of jail. If he gets here in time, I will bring him with me when I come to visit you.
13.24: Please give my greetings to your leaders and to the rest of the Lord's people. His followers from Italy send you their greetings.
13.25: I pray that God will be kind to all of you!

1.1: From James, a servant of God and of our Lord Jesus Christ. Greetings to the twelve tribes scattered all over the world. Faith and Wisdom
1.2: My friends, be glad, even if you have a lot of trouble.
1.3: You know that you learn to endure by having your faith tested.
1.4: But you must learn to endure everything, so that you will be completely mature and not lacking in anything.
1.5: If any of you need wisdom, you should ask God, and it will be given to you. God is generous and won't correct you for asking.
1.6: But when you ask for something, you must have faith and not doubt. Anyone who doubts is like an ocean wave tossed around in a storm.
1.7: If you are that kind of person, you can't make up your mind, and you surely can't be trusted. So don't expect the Lord to give you anything at all. Poor People and Rich People
1.9: Any of God's people who are poor should be glad that he thinks so highly of them.
1.10: But any who are rich should be glad when God makes them humble. Rich people will disappear like wild flowers
1.11: scorched by the burning heat of the sun. The flowers lose their blossoms, and their beauty is destroyed. That is how the rich will disappear, as they go about their business. Trials and Temptations
1.12: God will bless you, if you don't give up when your faith is being tested. He will reward you with a glorious life, just as he rewards everyone who loves him.
1.13: Don't blame God when you are tempted! God cannot be tempted by evil, and he doesn't use evil to tempt others.
1.14: We are tempted by our own desires that drag us off and trap us.
1.15: Our desires make us sin, and when sin is finished with us, it leaves us dead.
1.16: Don't be fooled, my dear friends.
1.17: Every good and perfect gift comes down from the Father who created all the lights in the heavens. He is always the same and never makes dark shadows by changing.
1.18: He wanted us to be his own special people, and so he sent the true message to give us new birth. Hearing and Obeying
1.19: My dear friends, you should be quick to listen and slow to speak or to get angry.
1.20: If you are angry, you cannot do any of the good things that God wants done.
1.21: You must stop doing anything immoral or evil. Instead be humble and accept the message that is planted in you to save you.
1.22: Obey God's message! Don't fool yourselves by just listening to it.
1.23: If you hear the message and don't obey it, you are like people who stare at themselves in a mirror
1.24: and forget what they look like as soon as they leave.
1.25: But you must never stop looking at the perfect law that sets you free. God will bless you in everything you do, if you listen and obey, and don't just hear and forget.
1.26: If you think you are being religious, but can't control your tongue, you are fooling yourself, and everything you do is useless.
1.27: Religion that pleases God the Father must be pure and spotless. You must help needy orphans and widows and not let this world make you evil.

2.1: My friends, if you have faith in our glorious Lord Jesus Christ, you won't treat some people better than others.
2.2: Suppose a rich person wearing fancy clothes and a gold ring comes to one of your meetings. And suppose a poor person dressed in worn-out clothes also comes.
2.3: You must not give the best seat to the one in fancy clothes and tell the one who is poor to stand at the side or sit on the floor.
2.4: That is the same as saying that some people are better than others, and you would be acting like a crooked judge.
2.5: My dear friends, pay attention. God has given a lot of faith to the poor people in this world. He has also promised them a share in his kingdom that he will give to everyone who loves him.
2.6: You mistreat the poor. But isn't it the rich who boss you around and drag you off to court?
2.7: Aren't they the ones who make fun of your Lord?
2.8: You will do all right, if you obey the most important law in the Scriptures. It is the law that commands us to love others as much as we love ourselves.
2.9: But if you treat some people better than others, you have done wrong, and the Scriptures teach that you have sinned.
2.10: If you obey every law except one, you are still guilty of breaking them all.
2.11: The same God who told us to be faithful in marriage also told us not to murder. So even if you are faithful in marriage, but murder someone, you still have broken God's Law.
2.12: Speak and act like people who will be judged by the law that sets us free.
2.13: Do this, because on the day of judgment there will be no pity for those who have not had pity on others. But even in judgment, God is merciful! Faith and Works
2.14: My friends, what good is it to say you have faith, when you don't do anything to show that you really do have faith? Can that kind of faith save you?
2.15: If you know someone who doesn't have any clothes or food,
2.16: you shouldn't just say, "I hope all goes well for you. I hope you will be warm and have plenty to eat." What good is it to say this, unless you do something to help?
2.17: Faith that doesn't lead us to do good deeds is all alone and dead!
2.18: Suppose someone disagrees and says, "It is possible to have faith without doing kind deeds." I would answer, "Prove that you have faith without doing kind deeds, and I will prove that I have faith by doing them."
2.19: You surely believe there is only one God. That's fine. Even demons believe this, and it makes them shake with fear.
2.20: Does some stupid person want proof that faith without deeds is useless?
2.21: Well, our ancestor Abraham pleased God by putting his son Isaac on the altar to sacrifice him.
2.22: Now you see how Abraham's faith and deeds worked together. He proved that his faith was real by what he did.
2.23: This is what the Scriptures mean by saying, "Abraham had faith in God, and God was pleased with him." That's how Abraham became God's friend.
2.24: You can now see that we please God by what we do and not only by what we believe.
2.25: For example, Rahab had been a prostitute. But she pleased God when she welcomed the spies and sent them home by another way.
2.26: Anyone who doesn't breathe is dead, and faith that doesn't do anything is just as dead!

3.1: My friends, we should not all try to become teachers. In fact, teachers will be judged more strictly than others.
3.2: All of us do many wrong things. But if you can control your tongue, you are mature and able to control your whole body.
3.3: By putting a bit into the mouth of a horse, we can turn the horse in different directions.
3.4: It takes strong winds to move a large sailing ship, but the captain uses only a small rudder to make it go in any direction.
3.5: Our tongues are small too, and yet they brag about big things. It takes only a spark to start a forest fire!
3.6: The tongue is like a spark. It is an evil power that dirties the rest of the body and sets a person's entire life on fire with flames that come from hell itself.
3.7: All kinds of animals, birds, reptiles, and sea creatures can be tamed and have been tamed.
3.8: But our tongues get out of control. They are restless and evil, and always spreading deadly poison.
3.9: My dear friends, with our tongues we speak both praises and curses. We praise our Lord and Father, and we curse people who were created to be like God, and this isn't right.
3.11: Can clean water and dirty water both flow from the same spring?
3.12: Can a fig tree produce olives or a grapevine produce figs? Does fresh water come from a well full of salt water? Wisdom from Above
3.13: Are any of you wise or sensible? Then show it by living right and by being humble and wise in everything you do.
3.14: But if your heart is full of bitter jealousy and selfishness, don't brag or lie to cover up the truth.
3.15: That kind of wisdom doesn't come from above. It is earthly and selfish and comes from the devil himself.
3.16: Whenever people are jealous or selfish, they cause trouble and do all sorts of cruel things.
3.17: But the wisdom that comes from above leads us to be pure, friendly, gentle, sensible, kind, helpful, genuine, and sincere.
3.18: When peacemakers plant seeds of peace, they will harvest justice.

4.1: Why do you fight and argue with each other? Isn't it because you are full of selfish desires that fight to control your body?
4.2: You want something you don't have, and you will do anything to get it. You will even kill! But you still cannot get what you want, and you won't get it by fighting and arguing. You should pray for it.
4.3: Yet even when you do pray, your prayers are not answered, because you pray just for selfish reasons.
4.4: You people aren't faithful to God! Don't you know that if you love the world, you are God's enemies? And if you decide to be a friend of the world, you make yourself an enemy of God.
4.5: Do you doubt the Scriptures that say, "God truly cares about the Spirit he has put in us"?
4.6: In fact, God treats us with even greater kindness, just as the Scriptures say, "God opposes everyone who is proud, but he is kind to everyone who is humble."
4.7: Surrender to God! Resist the devil, and he will run from you.
4.8: Come near to God, and he will come near to you. Clean up your lives, you sinners. Purify your hearts, you people who can't make up your mind.
4.9: Be sad and sorry and weep. Stop laughing and start crying. Be gloomy instead of glad.
4.10: Be humble in the Lord's presence, and he will honor you. Saying Cruel Things about Others
4.11: My friends, don't say cruel things about others! If you do, or if you condemn others, you are condemning God's Law. And if you condemn the Law, you put yourself above the Law and refuse to obey either it
4.12: or God who gave it. God is our judge, and he can save or destroy us. What right do you have to condemn anyone? Warning against Bragging
4.13: You should know better than to say, "Today or tomorrow we will go to the city. We will do business there for a year and make a lot of money!"
4.14: What do you know about tomorrow? How can you be so sure about your life? It is nothing more than mist that appears for only a little while before it disappears.
4.15: You should say, "If the Lord lets us live, we will do these things."
4.16: Yet you are stupid enough to brag, and it is wrong to be so proud.
4.17: If you don't do what you know is right, you have sinned.

5.1: You rich people should cry and weep! Terrible things are going to happen to you.
5.2: Your treasures have already rotted, and moths have eaten your clothes.
5.3: Your money has rusted, and the rust will be evidence against you, as it burns your body like fire. Yet you keep on storing up wealth in these last days.
5.4: You refused to pay the people who worked in your fields, and now their unpaid wages are shouting out against you. The Lord All-Powerful has surely heard the cries of the workers who harvested your crops.
5.5: While here on earth, you have thought only of filling your own stomachs and having a good time. But now you are like fat cattle on their way to be butchered.
5.6: You have condemned and murdered innocent people, who couldn't even fight back. Be Patient and Kind
5.7: My friends, be patient until the Lord returns. Think of farmers who wait patiently for the spring and summer rains to make their valuable crops grow.
5.8: Be patient like those farmers and don't give up. The Lord will soon be here!
5.9: Don't grumble about each other or you will be judged, and the judge is right outside the door.
5.10: My friends, follow the example of the prophets who spoke for the Lord. They were patient, even when they had to suffer.
5.11: In fact, we praise the ones who endured the most. You remember how patient Job was and how the Lord finally helped him. The Lord did this because he is so merciful and kind.
5.12: My friends, above all else, don't take an oath. You must not swear by heaven or by earth or by anything else. "Yes" or "No" is all you need to say. If you say anything more, you will be condemned.
5.13: If you are having trouble, you should pray. And if you are feeling good, you should sing praises.
5.14: If you are sick, ask the church leaders to come and pray for you. Ask them to put olive oil on you in the name of the Lord.
5.15: If you have faith when you pray for sick people, they will get well. The Lord will heal them, and if they have sinned, he will forgive them.
5.16: If you have sinned, you should tell each other what you have done. Then you can pray for one another and be healed. The prayer of an innocent person is powerful, and it can help a lot.
5.17: Elijah was just as human as we are, and for three and a half years his prayers kept the rain from falling.
5.18: But when he did pray for rain, it fell from the skies and made the crops grow.
5.19: My friends, if any followers have wandered away from the truth, you should try to lead them back.
5.20: If you turn sinners from the wrong way, you will save them from death, and many of their sins will be forgiven.

1.1: From Peter, an apostle of Jesus Christ. To God's people who are scattered like foreigners in Pontus, Galatia, Cappadocia, Asia, and Bithynia.
1.2: God the Father decided to choose you as his people, and his Spirit has made you holy. You have obeyed Jesus Christ and are sprinkled with his blood. I pray that God will be kind to you and will keep on giving you peace! A Real Reason for Hope
1.3: Praise God, the Father of our Lord Jesus Christ. God is so good, and by raising Jesus from death, he has given us new life and a hope that lives on.
1.4: God has something stored up for you in heaven, where it will never decay or be ruined or disappear.
1.5: You have faith in God, whose power will protect you until the last day. Then he will save you, just as he has always planned to do.
1.6: On that day you will be glad, even if you have to go through many hard trials for a while.
1.7: Your faith will be like gold that has been tested in a fire. And these trials will prove that your faith is worth much more than gold that can be destroyed. They will show that you will be given praise and honor and glory when Jesus Christ returns.
1.8: You have never seen Jesus, and you don't see him now. But still you love him and have faith in him, and no words can tell how glad and happy
1.9: you are to be saved. That's why you have faith.
1.10: Some prophets told how kind God would be to you, and they searched hard to find out more about the way you would be saved.
1.11: The Spirit of Christ was in them and was telling them how Christ would suffer and would then be given great honor. So they searched to find out exactly who Christ would be and when this would happen.
1.12: But they were told that they were serving you and not themselves. They preached to you by the power of the Holy Spirit, who was sent from heaven. And their message was only for you, even though angels would like to know more about it. Chosen To Live a Holy Life
1.13: Be alert and think straight. Put all your hope in how kind God will be to you when Jesus Christ appears.
1.14: Behave like obedient children. Don't let your lives be controlled by your desires, as they used to be.
1.15: Always live as God's holy people should, because God is the one who chose you, and he is holy.
1.16: That's why the Scriptures say, "I am the holy God, and you must be holy too."
1.17: You say that God is your Father, but God doesn't have favorites! He judges all people by what they do. So you must honor God while you live as strangers here on earth.
1.18: You were rescued from the useless way of life that you learned from your ancestors. But you know that you were not rescued by such things as silver or gold that don't last forever.
1.19: You were rescued by the precious blood of Christ, that spotless and innocent lamb.
1.20: Christ was chosen even before the world was created, but because of you, he did not come until these last days.
1.21: And when he did come, it was to lead you to have faith in God, who raised him from death and honored him in a glorious way. That's why you have put your faith and hope in God.
1.22: You obeyed the truth, and your souls were made pure. Now you sincerely love each other. But you must keep on loving with all your heart.
1.23: Do this because God has given you new birth by his message that lives on forever.
1.24: The Scriptures say, "Humans wither like grass, and their glory fades like wild flowers. Grass dries up, and flowers fall to the ground.
1.25: But what the Lord has said will stand forever." Our good news to you is what the Lord has said.

2.1: Stop being hateful! Quit trying to fool people, and start being sincere. Don't be jealous or say cruel things about others.
2.2: Be like newborn babies who are thirsty for the pure spiritual milk that will help you grow and be saved.
2.3: You have already found out how good the Lord really is.
2.4: Come to Jesus Christ. He is the living stone that people have rejected, but which God has chosen and highly honored.
2.5: And now you are living stones that are being used to build a spiritual house. You are also a group of holy priests, and with the help of Jesus Christ you will offer sacrifices that please God.
2.6: It is just as God says in the Scriptures, "Look! I am placing in Zion a choice and precious cornerstone. No one who has faith in that one will be disappointed."
2.7: You are followers of the Lord, and that stone is precious to you. But it isn't precious to those who refuse to follow him. They are the builders who tossed aside the stone that turned out to be the most important one of all.
2.8: They disobeyed the message and stumbled and fell over that stone, because they were doomed.
2.9: But you are God's chosen and special people. You are a group of royal priests and a holy nation. God has brought you out of darkness into his marvelous light. Now you must tell all the wonderful things that he has done. The Scriptures say,
2.10: "Once you were nobody. Now you are God's people. At one time no one had pity on you. Now God has treated you with kindness. Live as God's Servants Should
2.11: Dear friends, you are foreigners and strangers on this earth. So I beg you not to surrender to those desires that fight against you.
2.12: Always let others see you behaving properly, even though they may still accuse you of doing wrong. Then on the day of judgment, they will honor God by telling the good things they saw you do.
2.13: The Lord wants you to obey all human authorities, especially the Emperor, who rules over everyone.
2.14: You must also obey governors, because they are sent by the Emperor to punish criminals and to praise good citizens.
2.15: God wants you to silence stupid and ignorant people by doing right.
2.16: You are free, but still you are God's servants, and you must not use your freedom as an excuse for doing wrong.
2.17: Respect everyone and show special love for God's people. Honor God and respect the Emperor. The Example of Christ's Suffering
2.18: Servants, you must obey your masters and always show respect to them. Do this, not only to those who are kind and thoughtful, but also to those who are cruel.
2.19: God will bless you, even if others treat you unfairly for being loyal to him.
2.20: You don't gain anything by being punished for some wrong you have done. But God will bless you, if you have to suffer for doing something good.
2.21: After all, God chose you to suffer as you follow in the footsteps of Christ, who set an example by suffering for you.
2.22: Christ did not sin or ever tell a lie.
2.23: Although he was abused, he never tried to get even. And when he suffered, he made no threats. Instead, he had faith in God, who judges fairly.
2.24: Christ carried the burden of our sins. He was nailed to the cross, so that we would stop sinning and start living right. By his cuts and bruises you are healed.
2.25: You had wandered away like sheep. Now you have returned to the one who is your shepherd and protector.

3.1: If you are a wife, you must put your husband first. Even if he opposes our message, you will win him over by what you do. No one else will have to say anything to him,
3.2: because he will see how you honor God and live a pure life.
3.3: Don't depend on things like fancy hairdos or gold jewelry or expensive clothes to make you look beautiful.
3.4: Be beautiful in your heart by being gentle and quiet. This kind of beauty will last, and God considers it very special.
3.5: Long ago those women who worshiped God and put their hope in him made themselves beautiful by putting their husbands first.
3.6: For example, Sarah obeyed Abraham and called him her master. You are her true children, if you do right and don't let anything frighten you.
3.7: If you are a husband, you should be thoughtful of your wife. Treat her with honor, because she isn't as strong as you are, and she shares with you in the gift of life. Then nothing will stand in the way of your prayers. Suffering for Doing Right
3.8: Finally, all of you should agree and have concern and love for each other. You should also be kind and humble.
3.9: Don't be hateful and insult people just because they are hateful and insult you. Instead, treat everyone with kindness. You are God's chosen ones, and he will bless you. The Scriptures say,
3.10: "Do you really love life? Do you want to be happy? Then stop saying cruel things and quit telling lies.
3.11: Give up your evil ways and do right, as you find and follow the road that leads to peace.
3.12: The Lord watches over everyone who obeys him, and he listens to their prayers. But he opposes everyone who does evil."
3.13: Can anyone really harm you for being eager to do good deeds?
3.14: Even if you have to suffer for doing good things, God will bless you. So stop being afraid and don't worry about what people might do.
3.15: Honor Christ and let him be the Lord of your life. Always be ready to give an answer when someone asks you about your hope.
3.16: Give a kind and respectful answer and keep your conscience clear. This way you will make people ashamed for saying bad things about your good conduct as a follower of Christ.
3.17: You are better off to obey God and suffer for doing right than to suffer for doing wrong.
3.18: Christ died once for our sins. An innocent person died for those who are guilty. Christ did this to bring you to God, when his body was put to death and his spirit was made alive.
3.19: Christ then preached to the spirits that were being kept in prison.
3.20: They had disobeyed God while Noah was building the boat, but God had been patient with them. Eight people went into that boat and were brought safely through the flood.
3.21: Those flood waters were like baptism that now saves you. But baptism is more than just washing your body. It means turning to God with a clear conscience, because Jesus Christ was raised from death.
3.22: Christ is now in heaven, where he sits at the right side of God. All angels, authorities, and powers are under his control.

4.1: Christ suffered here on earth. Now you must be ready to suffer as he did, because suffering shows that you have stopped sinning.
4.2: It means you have turned from your own desires and want to obey God for the rest of your life.
4.3: You have already lived long enough like people who don't know God. You were immoral and followed your evil desires. You went around drinking and partying and carrying on. In fact, you even worshiped disgusting idols.
4.4: Now your former friends wonder why you have stopped running around with them, and they curse you for it.
4.5: But they will have to answer to God, who judges the living and the dead.
4.6: The good news has even been preached to the dead, so that after they have been judged for what they have done in this life, their spirits will live with God.
4.7: Everything will soon come to an end. So be serious and be sensible enough to pray.
4.8: Most important of all, you must sincerely love each other, because love wipes away many sins.
4.9: Welcome people into your home and don't grumble about it.
4.10: Each of you has been blessed with one of God's many wonderful gifts to be used in the service of others. So use your gift well.
4.11: If you have the gift of speaking, preach God's message. If you have the gift of helping others, do it with the strength that God supplies. Everything should be done in a way that will bring honor to God because of Jesus Christ, who is glorious and powerful forever. Amen. Suffering for Being a Christian
4.12: Dear friends, don't be surprised or shocked that you are going through testing that is like walking through fire.
4.13: Be glad for the chance to suffer as Christ suffered. It will prepare you for even greater happiness when he makes his glorious return.
4.14: Count it a blessing when you suffer for being a Christian. This shows that God's glorious Spirit is with you.
4.15: But you deserve to suffer if you are a murderer, a thief, a crook, or a busybody.
4.16: Don't be ashamed to suffer for being a Christian. Praise God that you belong to him.
4.17: God has already begun judging his own people. And if his judgment begins with us, imagine how terrible it will be for those who refuse to obey his message. The Scriptures say,
4.18: "If good people barely escape, what will happen to sinners and to others who don't respect God?"
4.19: If you suffer for obeying God, you must have complete faith in your faithful Creator and keep on doing right.

5.1: Church leaders, I am writing to encourage you. I too am a leader, as well as a witness to Christ's suffering, and I will share in his glory when it is shown to us.
5.2: Just as shepherds watch over their sheep, you must watch over everyone God has placed in your care. Do it willingly in order to please God, and not simply because you think you must. Let it be something you want to do, instead of something you do merely to make money.
5.3: Don't be bossy to those people who are in your care, but set an example for them.
5.4: Then when Christ the Chief Shepherd returns, you will be given a crown that will never lose its glory.
5.5: All of you young people should obey your elders. In fact, everyone should be humble toward everyone else. The Scriptures say, "God opposes proud people, but he helps everyone who is humble."
5.6: Be humble in the presence of God's mighty power, and he will honor you when the time comes.
5.7: God cares for you, so turn all your worries over to him.
5.8: Be on your guard and stay awake. Your enemy, the devil, is like a roaring lion, sneaking around to find someone to attack.
5.9: But you must resist the devil and stay strong in your faith. You know that all over the world the Lord's followers are suffering just as you are.
5.10: But God shows undeserved kindness to everyone. That's why he appointed Christ Jesus to choose you to share in his eternal glory. You will suffer for a while, but God will make you complete, steady, strong, and firm.
5.11: God will be in control forever! Amen. Final Greetings
5.12: Silvanus helped me write this short letter, and I consider him a faithful follower of the Lord. I wanted to encourage you and tell you how kind God really is, so that you will keep on having faith in him.
5.13: Greetings from the Lord's followers in Babylon. They are God's chosen ones. Mark, who is like a son to me, sends his greetings too.
5.14: Give each other a warm greeting. I pray that God will give peace to everyone who belongs to Christ.

1.1: From Simon Peter, a servant and an apostle of Jesus Christ. To everyone who shares with us in the privilege of believing that our God and Savior Jesus Christ will do what is just and fair.
1.2: I pray that God will be kind to you and will let you live in perfect peace! May you keep learning more and more about God and our Lord Jesus. Living as the Lord's Followers
1.3: We have everything we need to live a life that pleases God. It was all given to us by God's own power, when we learned that he had invited us to share in his wonderful goodness.
1.4: God made great and marvelous promises, so that his nature would become part of us. Then we could escape our evil desires and the corrupt influences of this world.
1.5: Do your best to improve your faith. You can do this by adding goodness, understanding,
1.6: self-control, patience, devotion to God,
1.7: concern for others, and love.
1.8: If you keep growing in this way, it will show that what you know about our Lord Jesus Christ has made your lives useful and meaningful.
1.9: But if you don't grow, you are like someone who is nearsighted or blind, and you have forgotten that your past sins are forgiven.
1.10: My friends, you must do all you can to show that God has really chosen and selected you. If you keep on doing this, you won't stumble and fall.
1.11: Then our Lord and Savior Jesus Christ will give you a glorious welcome into his kingdom that will last forever.
1.12: You are holding firmly to the truth that you were given. But I am still going to remind you of these things.
1.13: In fact, I think I should keep on reminding you until I leave this body.
1.14: And our Lord Jesus Christ has already told me that I will soon leave it behind.
1.15: That is why I am doing my best to make sure that each of you remembers all of this after I am gone. The Message about the Glory of Christ
1.16: When we told you about the power and the return of our Lord Jesus Christ, we were not telling clever stories that someone had made up. But with our own eyes we saw his true greatness.
1.17: God, our great and wonderful Father, truly honored him by saying, "This is my own dear Son, and I am pleased with him."
1.18: We were there with Jesus on the holy mountain and heard this voice speak from heaven.
1.19: All of this makes us even more certain that what the prophets said is true. So you should pay close attention to their message, as you would to a lamp shining in some dark place. You must keep on paying attention until daylight comes and the morning star rises in your hearts.
1.20: But you need to realize that no one alone can understand any of the prophecies in the Scriptures.
1.21: The prophets did not think these things up on their own, but they were guided by the Spirit of God.

2.1: Sometimes false prophets spoke to the people of Israel. False teachers will also sneak in and speak harmful lies to you. But these teachers don't really belong to the Master who paid a great price for them, and they will quickly destroy themselves.
2.2: Many people will follow their evil ways and cause others to tell lies about the true way.
2.3: They will be greedy and cheat you with smooth talk. But long ago God decided to punish them, and God doesn't sleep.
2.4: God did not have pity on the angels that sinned. He had them tied up and thrown into the dark pits of hell until the time of judgment.
2.5: And during Noah's time, God did not have pity on the ungodly people of the world. He destroyed them with a flood, though he did save eight people, including Noah, who preached the truth.
2.6: God punished the cities of Sodom and Gomorrah by burning them to ashes, and this is a warning to anyone else who wants to sin.
2.7: Lot lived right and was greatly troubled by the terrible way those wicked people were living. He was a good man, and day after day he suffered because of the evil things he saw and heard. So the Lord rescued him.
2.9: This shows that the Lord knows how to rescue godly people from their sufferings and to punish evil people while they wait for the day of judgment.
2.10: The Lord is especially hard on people who disobey him and don't think of anything except their own filthy desires. They are reckless and proud and are not afraid of cursing the glorious beings in heaven.
2.11: Although angels are more powerful than these evil beings, even the angels don't dare to accuse them to the Lord.
2.12: These people are no better than senseless animals that live by their feelings and are born to be caught and killed. They speak evil of things they don't know anything about. But their own corrupt deeds will destroy them.
2.13: They have done evil, and they will be rewarded with evil. They think it is fun to have wild parties during the day. They are immoral, and the meals they eat with you are spoiled by the shameful and selfish way they carry on.
2.14: All they think about is having sex with someone else's husband or wife. There is no end to their wicked deeds. They trick people who are easily fooled, and their minds are filled with greedy thoughts. But they are headed for trouble!
2.15: They have left the true road and have gone down the wrong path by following the example of the prophet Balaam. He was the son of Beor and loved what he got from being a crook.
2.16: But a donkey corrected him for this evil deed. It spoke to him with a human voice and made him stop his foolishness.
2.17: These people are like dried up water holes and clouds blown by a windstorm. The darkest part of hell is waiting for them.
2.18: They brag out loud about their stupid nonsense. And by being vulgar and crude, they trap people who have barely escaped from living the wrong kind of life.
2.19: They promise freedom to everyone. But they are merely slaves of filthy living, because people are slaves of whatever controls them.
2.20: When they learned about our Lord and Savior Jesus Christ, they escaped from the filthy things of this world. But they are again caught up and controlled by these filthy things, and now they are in worse shape than they were at first.
2.21: They would have been better off if they had never known about the right way. Even after they knew what was right, they turned their backs on the holy commandments that they were given.
2.22: What happened to them is just like the true saying, "A dog will come back to lick up its own vomit. A pig that has been washed will roll in the mud."

3.1: My dear friends, this is the second letter I have written to encourage you to do some honest thinking. I don't want you to forget
3.2: what God's prophets said would happen. You must never forget what the holy prophets taught in the past. And you must remember what the apostles told you our Lord and Savior has commanded us to do.
3.3: But first you must realize that in the last days some people won't think about anything except their own selfish desires. They will make fun of you
3.4: and say, "Didn't your Lord promise to come back? Yet the first leaders have already died, and the world hasn't changed a bit."
3.5: They will say this because they want to forget that long ago the heavens and the earth were made at God's command. The earth came out of water and was made from water.
3.6: Later it was destroyed by the waters of a mighty flood.
3.7: But God has commanded the present heavens and earth to remain until the day of judgment. Then they will be set on fire, and ungodly people will be destroyed.
3.8: Dear friends, don't forget that for the Lord one day is the same as a thousand years, and a thousand years is the same as one day.
3.9: The Lord isn't slow about keeping his promises, as some people think he is. In fact, God is patient, because he wants everyone to turn from sin and no one to be lost.
3.10: The day of the Lord's return will surprise us like a thief. The heavens will disappear with a loud noise, and the heat will melt the whole universe. Then the earth and everything on it will be seen for what they are.
3.11: Everything will be destroyed. So you should serve and honor God by the way you live.
3.12: You should look forward to the day when God judges everyone, and you should try to make it come soon. On that day the heavens will be destroyed by fire, and everything else will melt in the heat.
3.13: But God has promised us a new heaven and a new earth, where justice will rule. We are really looking forward to that!
3.14: My friends, while you are waiting, you should make certain that the Lord finds you pure, spotless, and living at peace.
